奉献

Dedication

感谢我的孩子 Michele 和 Joshua，尤其是我的妻子 Miriam 的帮助和鼓励。还要感谢 Krista Heinlein Byers 建议我阅读 Susan Carey 的作品，以及感谢 Albert Low 建议我思考学习。

Thanks to my children Michele and Joshua and especially to my wife Miriam for their help and encouragement. Thanks also to Krista Heinlein Byers for suggesting I read Susan Carey and to Albert Low for suggesting I think about learning.

指数

前言：聪明人还是智能机器？

Preface: Smart People or Smart Machines?

 

 

生产“智能”机器需要“聪明”的人。但“人的智能”不一定等同于“机器智能”。无人驾驶汽车的“智能”与开发汽车软件的人的“智能”相同吗？当然有区别，但这种区别是质的还是量的？如果是量的区别，即计算能力、分析和大数据的问题，那么我们终有一天会与有感知能力的机器人共享世界。然而，如果区别是质的，我相信是质的，那么人类智能与机器智能就完全不同了。两者的区别在于本书所称的“深度思考”。我认为，人类——即使是孩子——也能够进行“深度思考”，而即使是最复杂的机器也不行。

It takes “smart” people to produce “smart” machines. But “people smart” is not necessarily the same thing as “machine smart.” Is the “intelligence” of a driverless car the same as the “intelligence” of the person who created the software that drives the car? Certainly there is a difference but is this difference qualitative or quantitative? If it is quantitative, a matter of computing power, analytics, and big data, then we will one day share our world with sentient robots. However if the difference is qualitative, and I believe that it is, then human intelligence is in a different league from machine intelligence. The difference between the two lies in what this book will call “deep thinking.” It is my contention that human beings—even children—are capable of “deep thinking” and even the most complex machines are not.

深度思考是创造力和学习的核心过程。它有许多名字——突破性思维、重新构建和范式转变。深度思考的结果是，人们开始以一种与以前截然不同的方式看待事物。突破不可避免地难以实现，并且会涉及不连续性，有时被称为“顿悟时刻”。本书使用数学主题来描述深度思考是什么，以及它与逻辑、数学证明和计算机算法中常见的基于规则的思考有何不同。数学是探讨思考、学习和创造力问题的良好视角，因为 (1) 它内置于我们的核心认知系统中；(2) 它是科学和技术的语言；(3) 初等数学对大多数人来说都很容易理解。

Deep thinking is the process that is at the heart of creativity and learning. It has many names—breakthrough thinking, reframing, and paradigm change. The result of deep thinking is that one comes to see things in a manner that is radically different from the way one previously saw them. Breakthroughs are inevitably difficult to achieve and involve a discontinuity, which is sometimes called the “eureka moment.” This book uses the subject matter of mathematics to describe what deep thinking is and how it differs from the rule-based thinking that is familiar from logic, mathematical proofs, and computer algorithms. Mathematics is a good vantage point from which to approach questions of thinking, learning, and creativity because (1) it is built-in to our core cognitive systems; (2) it is the language of science and technology; and (3) elementary mathematics is readily accessible to most people.

人类思维和机器思维之间存在着差距，实际上是不可逾越的鸿沟。概念化这一差距的一种方法是思考现实与​​现实模拟之间的差异。任何模拟，无论其构思多么出色，都与其模拟的对象存在着本质区别。人类智慧和创造力是真实而直接的初级现象，而模拟则不是以同样的方式真实，它们是次级现象。模拟源于对模型之外和之前存在的真实情况进行深度思考。后续工作——计算和数据分析——是在模型内生成的。深度思考是首先创建模拟的过程。

There is a gap—an unbridgeable chasm, really—between human mind and machine mind. One way of conceptualizing this gap is to think about the difference between reality and simulations of reality. Any simulation, no matter how brilliant in conception, is qualitatively different from what it simulates. Human intelligence and creativity are primary phenomena that are real and immediate, whereas simulations are not real in the same way—they are secondary phenomena. Simulations arise from applying deep thinking to a real situation that exists outside of and prior to the model. Subsequent work—computation and the analysis of data—is generated within the model. Deep thinking is the process that creates the simulation in the first place.

例如，研究物理世界秩序的基本方法是引入“数字”。要做到这一点，必须创建一个系统，告诉我们什么是数字——例如计数数字或实数。我们可以将数字系统视为数字的模型（或模拟）。一旦建立了这样的数字概念系统，它就成为许多可能的计算和其他分析思维用途的背景。人类创造了这个系统；机器在这个系统内工作。当然，许多人类活动也在系统内进行——在计数系统中，你可以加法和乘法，（有时）你可以减法和除法。因此，机器正在扩大人类使用思维的一种方式。然而，还有其他使用思维的方式。这对每个人来说并不明显，但对于本书中提出的观点至关重要。深度思考不是分析性的。它不仅涉及概念系统的创建，还涉及学生对它的重新创建。

For example, the basic way to investigate order in the physical world is through the introduction of “number.” To do so a system must be created, which tells us what a number is—the counting numbers or the real numbers, for example. We could think of number systems as models (or simulations) of number. Such a conceptual system for number, once established, is the context for many possible computations and other uses of analytic thought. The human being produces the system; the machine works inside this system. Of course, many human activities are also carried out within the system—in the system of counting numbers you can add and multiply, and (sometimes) you can subtract and divide. Thus the machine is amplifying one way in which human beings use their minds. However there are other ways to use the mind. This is not obvious to everyone but is of crucial importance to the point of view developed in this book. Deep thinking is not analytic. It is not only involved in the creation of the conceptual system but also in the student’s re-creation of it.

“深度思考”是具体谈论机器智能与人类智能之间差距的一种方式。深度思考让大多数人想到爱因斯坦发展相对论和其他革命性的科学突破。然而，我们可以在婴儿和幼儿身上发现这种思考的本质。事实上，深度思考的一个范例是当孩子从数数的世界转向分数的世界时发生的概念重构。这两个概念系统都告诉你数字是什么，但方式却大不相同。从从成人的角度来看，从前一种系统转向后一种系统似乎自然而简单，但这实际上是一项重大的智力成就，因此也是深度思考的典范。

“Deep thinking” is a way to talk in concrete terms about the gap between machine and human intelligence. Deep thinking makes most people think of Einstein developing the Theory of Relativity and other revolutionary breakthroughs in science. Yet we can discover the essence of such thinking in infants and young children. In fact a paradigm of deep thinking is the conceptual reframing that occurs when a child moves from the world of counting numbers to the world of fractions. Both of these conceptual systems tell you what a number is but in ways that are substantially incompatible with one another. Looking at things from the perspective of adults, the movement from the former system to the latter may seem natural and simple, but it is actually a major intellectual accomplishment, and as such, a model for deep thinking.

因此，机器智能不是人类智能，机器学习不是人类学习。一方面，这种说法是直接而明显的，但另一方面，它意义深远，对技术世界和人类世界的关系具有重要意义。本书的任务是探索智能、学习和创造力及其模拟之间的差距。在这一调查过程中，我们将跨越机器智能的极限，从而为不可或缺的人类保留一席之地。

Thus machine intelligence is not human intelligence, machine learning is not human learning. On the one hand this statement is immediate and obvious but, on the other hand, it is profound and has important implications for the relationship between the world of technology and the world of human beings. The task that this book sets itself is to explore the gap between intelligence, learning, and creativity and their simulations. In the process of this investigation we will run across the limits of machine intelligence, thereby preserving a place for what is irreducibly human.

创新

Innovation

推动技术世界发展的动力是创新，但突破性的创新并非来自于对每个人都熟悉的想法进行调整。它来自深度思考，即创建一个全新的框架。每个人都知道，要想出一个绝妙的想法，就必须“跳出固有的思维框架”，但如何做到这一点呢？这是本书将要探讨的一个问题。

The motor that drives the technological world is innovation but groundbreaking innovation does not come out of tweaking ideas with which everyone is familiar. It comes out of deep thinking, that is, creating a totally new framework. Everyone knows that to come up with a brilliant idea one has to “think outside of the box” but how does one go about doing that? This is one question that the book will address.

我认为，我们的文化能否持续创新，人们能否成功适应持续变化且不断加速的世界，取决于社会能否理解机器智能与人类智能之间的差异。尽管近年来机器人技术和人工智能取得了重大进展，但情况并非如此。事实上，正是这些进步使得这样的讨论至关重要。

Our culture’s capacity to sustain innovation and people’s ability to adjust successfully to a world in which change is not only continuous but also accelerating, depends, in my view, on society’s ability to conceptualize the difference between machine and human intelligence. This is despite the major strides that have occurred in recent years in robotics and artificial intelligence. In fact it is precisely these advances that make such a discussion vitally important.

忘记这种差异，也就是忘记让我们成为人类的心灵特质，将是一场灾难。这甚至会是技术世界的灾难。毕竟，人类的创造力是下金蛋的鹅，尤其是在苹果、谷歌和微软这样的公司。

To forget the difference, that is, to forget about the very qualities of the mind that make us human, would be a disaster. It would even be a disaster for the world of technology. After all human creativity is the goose that lays the golden eggs especially at companies like Apple, Google, and Microsoft.

然而，很多事情正在把社会推向错误的方向，假装真正的创造力和机器智能之间的界限已经或将被消除。算法无法产生创造力。事实恰恰相反——创造力才是算法的源泉。这看起来像是一个先有鸡还是先有蛋的问题，但要想彻底理解，我们必须仔细区分机器智能模拟的人类能力和我称之为“深度思考”的智能和学习的其他方面，而这些方面无法通过模拟来捕捉。智能机器和大数据的发展非常令人兴奋，但也伴随着巨大的风险。正如科学技术的每一次重大发展一样，社会应该认真思考我们即将进入的世界的利弊。

Nevertheless there is a great deal that is pushing society in the wrong direction, in the direction of pretending that the line between true creativity and machine intelligence has been or will be eradicated. An algorithm cannot generate creativity. In fact the reverse is true—creativity is what produces algorithms. It can seem like a kind of chicken and egg problem but, to think it through, we must carefully distinguish between those human capabilities that machine intelligence simulates and those other aspects of intelligence and learning that I call “deep thinking” and that cannot be captured by a simulation. The movement towards intelligent machines and big data is very exciting but carries substantial risks. As with every major development in science and technology it behooves society to engage in some serious reflection about the pros and cons of the world that we are on the verge of jumping into.

每次我们在 iPhone 上向 Siri 提问或启动 Google 搜索时，我们都在与机器智能互动。我们发现这种互动越来越自然，而且往往不会考虑技术带来的负担。有人说，媒介就是信息，而媒介越来越是智能机器的世界。当 IBM 的“蓝色巨人”击败人类最好的国际象棋选手时，社会认为机器智能在某些方面优于人类智能。当时并不明显的是，我们对智能和学习的概念正在被重新定义——“计算机国际象棋”与“人类国际象棋”不是同一种游戏。而这一开创性事件只是冰山一角。如今，“大数据”和“分析”正在重新定义人类活动的几乎每一个领域。这意味着社会对心智、思维、智能、学习和创造力的工作模式正在发生根本性变化——简而言之，我们对人类意义的认识很可能正在发生变化。

Every time we ask Siri a question on our iPhone or initiate a Google search we are interacting with machine intelligence. We find such interactions more and more natural and do not often reflect on the baggage that comes along with the technology. The medium, it has been said, is the message and the medium is increasingly the world of smart machines. When I.B.M.’s “Big Blue” beat the best human chess player, society decided that in certain respects machine intelligence was superior to human intelligence. What was not obvious at the time was that our notions of intelligence and learning were being redefined—“computer chess” is not the same game as “human chess.” And this seminal event was just the tip of the iceberg. “Big data” and “analytics” are today redefining almost every area of human activity. This means that a radical change is underway in society’s working model of mind, thinking, intelligence, learning, and creativity—in short a change may well be occurring in our idea of what it means to be human.

“媒介即信息”意味着技术改变了我们对真实事物的理解，例如，当我们将思维视为计算机，将思维视为算法时。作为一个社会，我们即将被智能技术革命席卷而去，因此，我们可能很快就无法提出我在本书中提出的问题。思维是计算机、知识是数据、学习是数据分析的隐喻将定义思维、知识和学习的含义。到那时，考虑更大的问题可能为时已晚。我们都如此热爱我们的小玩意以及它们赋予我们的自由和力量，以至于我们可能忘记批判地看待他们所创造的世界和那些我们有可能失去的东西。

The medium is the message means that technology changes our conception of what is real, as, for example, when we think of the mind as a computer and thought as algorithmic. As a society we are on the verge of being swept away by the revolution of smart technology and, as a consequence, we soon may not even be able to formulate the questions that I am raising in this book. The metaphor of the mind as a computer, knowledge as data, and learning as the analysis of data will come to define what is meant by mind, knowledge, and learning. By then it may be too late to consider the larger questions. We are all so in love with our gadgets and the freedom and power that they give us that we may forget to take a critical look at the world they are creating and those things that we are in danger of losing.

章节摘要

Chapter Summaries

第一章根据当代儿童发展研究，总结了深度思考的关键特征。婴儿对数字有两个核心认知系统，几乎所有儿童都是在此基础上首先学习计数系统，然后学习分数系统。这些系统，尤其是后两个学习系统，是至关重要的例子，我在书中的各个地方都提到了它们。它们足以让我介绍深度思考的许多特征。特别是深度思考是自然的，每个人都有可能做到，但它取决于解决某种基本困难。这两个看似不一致的属性——自然性和难度——是理解深度思考的关键。

Chapter one isolates the crucial features of deep thinking based on contemporary research in child development. The infant has two core cognitive systems for number on the basis of which almost all children first learn the system of counting numbers and subsequently the system of fractions. These systems, especially the latter two learned systems, are crucial examples and I refer back to them at various places in the book. They are sufficient for me to introduce many of the features of deep thinking. In particular deep thinking is natural and potentially available to everyone yet it depends on resolving a certain fundamental kind of difficulty. These two, seemingly inconsistent properties—naturalness and difficulty—are the key to understanding deep thinking.

深度思考涉及从一个概念系统转移到另一个概念系统。从一个角度看，这两个系统互不相容；从另一个角度看，它们又具有层级关系，相互融合。

Deep thinking is involved in moving from one conceptual system to another. The two systems are incompatible from one point of view yet, in other, they have a hierarchical relationship, which integrates them with one another.

第二章关注的是作为基本认知结构的概念系统。概念系统是我们与世界互动的基础；它们定义了什么是真实的。它们是科学的范式，也是由特定新技术产生的技术概念系统。在所有这些情况下，人们关注的基本问题是一个概念系统如何发展成另一个概念系统。本章最后指出，第一章列举的深度思考的属性也适用于一般的概念变化，特别是与技术发展相关的变化。

Chapter two is concerned with conceptual systems as basic cognitive structures. Conceptual systems are basic to our interactions with the world; they define what is real for us. They are the paradigms of science and the technological conceptual systems that are generated by particular new technologies. The basic problem that is of concern in all of these situations is how one conceptual system develops into another. The chapter ends with the observation that the properties of deep thinking that were enumerated in chapter one also apply to conceptual change in general and in particular to the changes associated with developments in technology.

第三章展示了前两章的框架如何适用于科学和数学范式转变的具体情况。接下来讨论了不同的数字概念系统：整数、零、无穷大、可构造数、实数和复数系统。新颖之处在于，数字系统以一种不同寻常的方式被看待——作为概念系统，而不是作为形式结构。特别是，讨论了逻辑在数学和科学论述中的作用，并将其与深度思考中思维的使用方式进行了比较。

In chapter three the framework of the first two chapters is shown to apply to specific situations of paradigm change in science and mathematics. This is followed by a discussion of different conceptual systems for number: the integers, zero, infinity, the constructible, real, and complex number systems. The novelty is that number systems are looked at in an unusual way—as conceptual systems rather than as formal structures. In particular there is a discussion of the role of logic in mathematical and scientific discourse as compared to the way that the mind is used in instances of deep thinking.

在第四章中，我回顾了深度思考与儿童发展之间的关系，并讨论了神经科学中的一些相关工作。深度思考涉及一种使用思维的方式，这种方式被称为“灯笼意识”，比我们正常的集中意识或“手电筒意识”更为基本。甚至可以看到深度思考如何反映在大脑的生物学及其半球分化中。深度思考将涉及大脑的两个半球，并利用分析和综合思维。

In chapter four I return to the relationship between deep thinking and child development and also discuss some relevant work in neuroscience. Deep thinking involves a way of using the mind, which has been called “lantern consciousness,” and is more basic than our normal focused awareness, or “flashlight consciousness.” It is even possible to see how deep thinking is reflected in the biology of the brain and in its hemispheric differentiation. Deep thinking will be seen to involve both hemispheres of the brain and utilize both analytic and synthetic thinking.

从一个概念系统过渡到另一个概念系统需要创造性的飞跃，因此，本文为第五章的内容——数学和科学中的创造力——的讨论做好了准备。我将讨论一些理论家，他们将在头脑中毫不畏缩地持有两个相互矛盾的想法的能力分离出来，作为创造性活动的基本要素。这与前面几章中关于深度思考的内在困难的讨论有关，并引出了关于科学和数学中创造性过程的性质的一些一般性评论。

Transitioning from one conceptual system to another requires a creative leap and so the stage is set for a discussion of creativity in mathematics and science, which is the content of chapter five. I shall discuss a number of theorists who have isolated the ability to hold two contradictory ideas in the mind without flinching as the essential element in creative activity. This is related to the discussion in earlier chapters of the intrinsic difficulty associated with deep thinking and leads to some general comments about the nature of the creative process in science and mathematics.

第六章和第七章将前两章的结论应用于学习和教学。“深度学习”是一种源于深度思考的学习。它存在于概念和概念系统的学习中，但尤其存在于新概念系统的开发中。这些章节讨论了学生需要付出什么样的努力才能进行深度学习，以及如果希望产生这种学习，需要什么样的教学。

Chapters six and seven apply the conclusions of the earlier chapters to learning and teaching. “Deep learning” is the kind of learning that arises from deep thinking. It is to be found in the learning of concepts and conceptual systems but especially in the development of new conceptual systems. These chapters discusses the kind of effort on the part of the student that is required in order for deep learning to occur and the kind of teaching that is needed if one hopes to produce this kind of learning.

学习并非只是孩子们的专利。在当今技术飞速变化的世界里，人们需要“学会如何学习”并终生学习。如果一个人要适应这种变化，就需要进行彻底的重新定位，这与深度思考类似。

Learning is not just an activity reserved for children. In the present world of rapid technological change people need to “learn how to learn” and to keep learning throughout their lives. The radical reorientation that is called for if an individual is to adapt to such change is analogous to what is involved in deep thinking.

第八章将教育讨论提升到中学后阶段，并建议将“概念学习”作为我们在这一阶段教授数学的基础。一些对特定主题做出了详细的评论：实数，函数，微积分和线性代数。

Chapter eight moves the discussion of education up to the postsecondary level and suggests that “conceptual learning” become the basis of how we approach the teaching of mathematics at this level. Some detailed comments are made about particular subjects: the real numbers, functions, calculus, and linear algebra.

第九章利用已开发的框架推断数学的本质。它讨论了数学和科学中谓词演算的逻辑，并将其与书中介绍的深度思考的“规则”——创造力和发展的逻辑——进行了比较。真正的数学被视为概念数学，并讨论了其后果。

Chapter nine uses the framework that has been developed to draw inferences about the nature of mathematics. It discusses the logic of the predicate calculus in mathematics and science and compares it with the “rules” of deep thinking—the logic of creativity and development—that has been introduced in the book. Real mathematics is seen to be conceptual mathematics and the consequences of that are discussed.

最后一章回顾了深度思考的特性，并思考了它们揭示了思考和心智的本质。特别是，书中进一步讨论了深度思考是原始和自然的说法与深度思考本质上非常困难的说法之间存在的矛盾。所有科学和数学理论都受到我们通过概念系统描述世界这一事实的限制。讨论的其他主题包括 (1) 所有思想系统的局限性；(2) “引导”；(3) 智力的本质；(4) 进化作为一种​​深度思考的形式。本书最后提醒人们正确的教育方法的重要性。

The last chapter revisits the properties of deep thinking and considers what they reveal about the nature of thinking and the mind. In particular there is a further discussion of the tension that exists between the claims that deep thinking is primordial and natural and the claim that it is intrinsically very difficult. All scientific and mathematical theories are constrained by the fact that we describe the world by means of a conceptual system. Other topics that are discussed include (1) the limits to all systems of thought; (2) “bootstrapping;” (3) the nature of intelligence; and (4) evolution as a form of deep thinking. The book ends with a reminder of the importance of the correct approach to education.

第 1 章

Chapter 1

什么是深度思考？

What is Deep Thinking?

1.1介绍

1.1Introduction

本导论章节的目的是介绍“深度思考”。我无法从正式定义开始；深度思考不是通过写出正式定义并推断出必然结果来实现的。相反，我将在各种情况下探索深度思考，并通过分离出它的一些基本属性来描述它。我将从研究儿童发展方面的最新研究开始，更具体地说，是婴儿数字概念的发展。这将引导我从两个角度来研究各种数字概念系统——它们在历史上的出现方式和儿童学习它们的方式。这些资料足以让我列出一系列深度思考的一般特征。它们将给我们一个相当好的深度思考的感觉——至少足以让我们继续探索。

The objective of this introductory chapter is to introduce “deep thinking.” I cannot begin with a formal definition; deep thinking does not work by writing formal definitions and deducing inevitable consequences. I shall instead proceed by exploring deep thinking in a variety of situations and characterize it by isolating a number of its basic properties. I shall begin by looking at recent work in child development, more specifically, the development of the number concept in infants. This will lead me to examine various conceptual systems for number from two points of view—the manner that they arose historically and the way in which children learn them. These sources will be enough for me to list a series of general characteristics of deep thinking. They will give us a pretty good feeling for deep thinking—enough, at least to continue the exploration.

然而，在描述深度思考之前，让我们花点时间考虑一下更普遍的问题：“思考是什么？”思考是一种心理过程，一种使用思维的方式，它涉及将思维引向某物——通常是一系列的想法、陈述或命题。思想是思考的内容，通常通过语言媒介发生，但也可以使用非语言元素进行思考，例如符号、图像、声音甚至感觉。然而，对于我们大多数人来说，思考主要是语言的。

However before we can describe deep thinking let’s spend a moment considering the more general question, “What is thinking?” Thinking is a mental process, a way of using the mind, which involves directing it towards something—normally a sequence of ideas, statements, or propositions. Thought, which is the content of thinking, usually occurs through the medium of words but it is also possible to think using nonverbal elements such as symbols, images, sounds, or even feelings. Nevertheless for most of us thinking is predominantly verbal.

理性思维由一系列按逻辑顺序排列的命题组成，这些命题的组织方式使得每个步骤都通过逻辑推理规则从前一步开始​​。第一个陈述通常称为假设，最后称为结论。对某些人来说，理性思维是思维的最高形式，其他所有思维方式都是不充分的。

Rational thinking consists of a sequence of propositions arranged in a logical order that is organized so that each step follows from the preceding one by means of the rules of logical inference. The first statement is usually called the hypothesis and the last, the conclusion. For some people rational thinking is the highest form of thinking and all other ways of thinking are deficient.

但事实是，还有其他使用思维的方式，既不理性也不连贯。“深度思考”是我给一种非连贯思考起的名字。大多数人通常不知道这种思考的存在，也不知道自己有能力进行这种思考。非理性思考看起来是无定形和模糊的，正是因为我们习惯于将思考等同于理性。了解正在讨论的内容的一种方法是将“创造性”一词替换为“深度”，因为深度思考是思维在创造性工作中的运用方式。创造性思维不是严格意义上的理性，但也不是非理性的。理性思考和深度思考之间的关系很重要，也是本书的主题之一。现在，我只想说，理性思考的发现是一种创造性行为，最初源于深度思考。逻辑思维在我将要描述的各种过程中发挥着作用，但它的作用次于更基本的深度思考过程。

The fact remains, however, that there are other ways of using the mind, which are neither rational nor sequential. “Deep thinking” is the name that I am giving to a kind of non-sequential thinking. Most people are not normally aware of the existence of such thinking nor that they are capable of it. Non-rational thinking would appear to be amorphous and vague precisely because we are used to identifying thought with rationality. One way to get a feeling for what is being discussed would be to substitute the word “creative” for “deep” because deep thinking is the way the mind is used in creative work. Creative thinking is not strictly rational but neither is it irrational. The relationship between rational thinking and deep thinking is important and one of the themes of this book. For now let me just say that the discovery of rational thinking was a creative act that initially arose out of deep thinking. Logical thinking has its role in the various processes that I shall describe but it is a role that is secondary to the more basic process of deep thinking.

深度思考很难掌握，不是因为它很复杂，而是因为它太基础了。深度思考是心智自然运作的方式，而不是必须强迫心智去做的事情。心智的“默认状态”是活跃、动态和创造性的。它不必被“开启”。它一出现就已经开启了。通过考虑婴儿在最初尝试对世界进行概念性理解时的思维方式，我们将获得心智动态默认状态的证据。从最近关于婴儿概念系统发展的研究，我们将开始辨别出构成深度思考的一些基本成分。因此，深度思考的另一个术语可能是“发展性思考”。

Deep thinking is something that is difficult to get a handle on, not because it is complex, but, on the contrary, because it is so basic. Deep thinking is the way the mind functions naturally, not something that the mind must be coerced into doing. The “default condition” of the mind is active, dynamic, and creative. It does not have to be “turned on.” It arrives on the scene already turned on. We shall get evidence for the dynamic default condition of the mind by considering the way infants think as they make their initial attempts to get a conceptual understanding of the world. It is from recent work on the development of conceptual systems in infants that we shall begin to discern some of the essential ingredients that make up deep thinking. For this reason yet another term for deep thinking might be “developmental thinking.”

这种思维是普遍存在的——每个孩子都有这种能力。由于这种思维本质上是创造性的，而儿童概念发展的每一步都需要创造性行为，因此可以说儿童天生具有创造力。这意味着创造力的潜力也存在于所有成年人身上，至少是潜在的。它不仅仅是才华横溢的人的专利。为什么大多数成年人都失去了创造力呢？为什么我们的大脑，成年人的大脑，经常感觉迟钝和呆滞？为什么要花这么大功夫才能激发它？为什么创造力如此困难？这些都是非常好的问题，但现在我们只需观察一下：深度思考是大脑的自然状态，即使这种状态对于大多数人来说很难实现。

Such thinking is universal—every child is capable of it. Since such thinking is essentially creative and every step in the conceptual development of children requires an act of creativity, it follows that children are naturally creative. This means that the potential for creativity also exists, latently at least, in all adults. It is not just reserved for the brilliant and talented. Why do most adults lose touch with it? Why does our mind, the adult mind, so often feel torpid and dull? Why does it take so much effort to turn it on? Why is creativity so hard? These are all excellent questions but for now it is enough to make the observation that deep thinking is the natural condition of the mind even if this state is difficult for most people to actualize.

换句话说，通常的顺序被颠倒了。人们不再将创造力视为理性思维的高级形式，而是将理性思维视为捕捉和放大深度思考某些方面的方式。深度思考更为基础，因此开发真正具有创造力的人工智能系统是徒劳的。此类程序最多只能模拟创造力和深度思考。

In other words the usual order of things is reversed. Instead of viewing creativity as a higher form of rational thought, rational thought is seen as a way of capturing and amplifying certain aspects of deep thinking. Deep thought is more basic and so it is futile to develop systems of artificial intelligence that are truly creative. The most such programs can possibly do is to simulate creativity and deep thinking.

深度思考中的“深度”一词指的是基础性属性，因此我们很自然地会关注幼儿概念的发展，特别是最基本的概念之一——数字概念。

The word “deep” in deep thinking refers to the property of being fundamental so it is natural to turn to the development of concepts in young children especially one of the most elementary of all concepts—the concept of number.

1.2婴儿概念发展中的深度思考

1.2Deep Thinking in the Conceptual Development of Infants

哈佛大学心理学教授苏珊·凯里 (Susan Carey) 和她最近出版的开创性著作《概念的起源》将引导我们探索儿童发展。凯里的书围绕三个主要论点展开。第一，人类（以及非人类动物）“具有核心认知系统，核心认知是人类概念理解的发展基础。” i这种核心系统（我们生物学中固有的系统）的存在表明，婴儿的概念发展建立在早期生物学发展的基础上。似乎存在一条发展弧线，从大脑和思维结构的进化开始，然后发展为婴儿的核心概念系统，然后发展为年轻人在学校和大学学习的更复杂的概念结构。这条弧线最终导致科学和数学的创造性研究。在整个发展弧线的每个阶段，从原始到最复杂的阶段，都可以辨别出类似的认知过程的运作——深度思考。

Our guide in this foray into child development will be Susan Carey, Professor of Psychology at Harvard University and her recent seminal book, The Origin of Concepts. Carey’s book is built around three major theses. The first is that human beings (and non-human animals as well) “have systems of core cognition, and that core cognition is the developmental foundation of human conceptual understanding.”i The existence of such core systems—systems that are built-in to our biology—suggests that the conceptual development of infants builds on a foundation of an earlier biological development. There appears to be an arc of development that begins with the evolution of brain and mind structures, proceeds to the development of core conceptual systems in infants, then to the development of the more sophisticated conceptual structures that young people learn in schools and universities. This arc culminates in the creative research of science and mathematics. At every stage in this entire developmental arc, from the primitive to the most sophisticated, it is possible to discern the operation of a similar process of cognition—deep thinking.

“Carey 的第二个主要论点是，在发展过程中出现了新的表征资源——比其构建基础更具有表现力的表征系统，以及与其构建基础无法比较的表征系统。也就是说，概念发展涉及理论上重要的不连续性。” ii在这里，Carey 分离出深度思考的几个基本特征，这涉及到一个不可或缺的不连续性元素，即从一个观点跳到另一个观点。此外，新观点与旧观点无法比较。这意味着深度思考总是困难的。

“Carey’s second major thesis is that new representational resources emerge in development—representational systems with more expressive power than those they are built from, as well as representational systems that are incommensurable with those they are built from. That is, conceptual development involves theoretically important discontinuities.”ii Here Carey isolates a number of essential characteristics of deep thinking, which involves an indispensible element of discontinuity, that is, a jump from one point of view to another. Further the new point of view is incommensurable with the old. This implies that deep thinking is always difficult.

“Carey 的第三个主要论点是，科学史和科学哲学文献中描述的引导过程也是儿童时期新表征资源构建的基础。” iii这是试图解释发展和创造力的巨大难题。如果这么难，那么它是如何发生的？发展和学习是如何发生的？人类如何设法提出从根本上全新的、与过去彻底决裂的思想和理论？这些新思想和新表征从何而来？这一切都相当神秘，甚至神奇。

“Carey’s third major thesis is that the bootstrapping processes that have been described in the literature on the history and philosophy of science underlie the construction of new representational resources in childhood as well.”iii This is an attempt to explain the great conundrum of both development and creativity. If it is so difficult then how does it happen? How do development and learning come about? How do human beings manage to come up with ideas and theories that are fundamentally new and constitute a radical break with the past? Where do these new ideas and representations come from? It is all quite mysterious and even miraculous.

我发现围绕核心认知系统存在的争论很有趣，但我无意在此深入探讨。我只会接受这个论点，尽管它可能对某些人有争议。它支持我论点的主旨，但对它来说并不重要。我对本章的兴趣在于第二和第三个论点——新表征系统的不连续出现及其产生的方式。

I find the argument around the existence of systems of core cognition fascinating but it is not my intention to go into it here. I will merely accept this thesis even though it may be controversial to some. It supports the main thrust of my argument but is not crucial to it. My interest in this chapter is in the second and third theses—the discontinuous emergence of new representational systems and the way in which they come about.

有趣的是，Carey 在她的第三篇论文中使用了科学史和科学哲学文献来支持她在儿童发展方面的工作。我还打算使用这两个来源，即概念发展以及科学史中的事件，来支持我的一般论点，即学习、创造力和发展存在一个共同的根源，即我所说的深度思考。

It is interesting that Carey in her third thesis uses the literature of the history and philosophy of science to support her work in child development. I also intend to use both of these sources, conceptual development as well as episodes from the history of science, to support my general thesis that there exists a common root to learning, creativity, and development, namely what I am calling deep thinking.

1.3数字的核心认知系统

1.3 Core Cognitive Systems for Number

现在，我来谈谈 Carey 对几个核心认知系统的描述，这些系统处理所谓的“数字感iv ”。她说：“数字感是核心认知的典型例子……”并列出了两个具有数字内容的不同核心认知系统的证据。

I now turn to Carey’s description of a couple of systems of core cognition that deal with what has been called the “number senseiv.” She says, “The number sense is a paradigm example of core cognition …” and lays out the evidence for two distinct systems of core cognition with numerical content.

这些核心系统中的第一个是“数字的模拟量表示。数字用物理量表示”（例如线段的长度），“该物理量大致与被列举的个体数量成比例”。因此，数字 7 可以用长度为某个单位长度七倍的线段来表示。这个系统在我们所有人身上仍然有效。它并不精确，因为大多数人很难区分长度为十二的线段和长度为十三的线段。这个核心系统的迷人之处在于，它可以区分两个量，而不是它们的基数或它们的差异，而是它们的比率v。因此，一个六个月大的婴儿可以成功区分 24 个物体和 12 个物体（2 比 1），但不能区分 24 个物体和 16 个物体（3 比 2）。Carey 认为动物也以这种方式表示数字。她提供的数据支持“存在一个进化的古老表征系统，其中数字由与集合中物体数量成比例的模拟量编码。”对于 Carey 的论点来说，重要的是，这种“数字表征是概念性的；它们的内容超越了时空和感官词汇。” vi

The first of these core systems is the “analog magnitude representation of number. Number is represented by a physical magnitude” (say the length of a line segment) “that is roughly proportional to the number of individuals being enumerated.” Thus the number seven would be represented by a line of length that is seven times as long as some unit length. This system is still operational in all of us. It is not precise since most people would have difficulty telling the difference between a line segment of length twelve and one of length thirteen. The fascinating thing about this core system is that it can discriminate two magnitudes as a function, not of their cardinality or their difference, but of their ratiov. So a six-month old infant can discriminate successfully between 24 objects and 12 objects (2 to 1) but not between 24 and 16 (3 to 2). Carey maintains that animals also represent number in this way. She produces data that supports “the existence of an evolutionary ancient representational system in which number is encoded by an analog magnitude proportional to the number of objects in the set.” It is important to Carey’s argument that such “number representations are conceptual; their content goes beyond spatio-temporal and sensory vocabulary.”vi

然后，Carey 转向了第二个具有数字内容的核心系统：“小集合的并行个体化”。该系统并行存储（即同时存储）1、2 或 3 个对象的小集合中的对象数量。这是一种精确的表示，但它仅适用于非常小的对象集合。

Then Carey turns to a second core system with numerical content: “parallel individuation of small sets.” This system stores in parallel, that is, simultaneously, the number of objects in small collections of 1, 2, or 3 objects. This is a precise representation but it applies only to very small collections of objects.

“有大量证据表明，存在两个具有数字内容的不同核心认知系统，在其中一个系统中（平行个体化），数字仅以隐性方式表示，而在另一个系统中，数字则以与所考虑的一组项目的基数成比例的心理量级表示。” vii [这]“……提出了关于它们之间的关系。在什么意义上它们是不同的？它们是否会整合成一个表示数字的单一系统？如果是，什么时候、如何整合的？” viii

“There is massive evidence for two distinct core cognition systems with numerical content, in one of which (parallel individuation) number is represented only implicitly and in the other, number is represented by a mental magnitude that is proportional to the cardinal value of the set of items under consideration.”vii [This] “… raises several questions about the relations between them. In what senses are they distinct? Do they ever become integrated in a single system for representing number? If so, when and how?”viii

凯里强调了这两个系统之间的根本区别。这些区别包括：前一个系统的数字代表量级，是几何的、连续的和近似的，而后者代表的是众多，是离散的和精确的。为什么我们有多个核心数字系统？数字不是一个单一的概念，那么为什么我们没有一种独特的方式来表示数字，然后在我们成长和受教育的过程中发展这个基本概念呢？进化为我们提供了两个（或更多）数字系统，这一事实是发展和学习如何进行的重要标志。如果不是因为存在两个独立而重要的系统，它们对数字有不同的看法，就不会有同样的发展需要。数字概念的所有历史延伸——包括分数、负数、实数等等——都是我们核心系统中隐含的紧张关系的解决。没有这种紧张关系，很可能就不会有发展。

Carey emphasizes the radical difference between the two systems. These differences include the fact that the former system number represents magnitude and is geometric, continuous and approximate whereas the latter represents multitudeix and is discrete and precise. Why do we have more than one core system for number? Isn’t number a singular concept so why don’t we have a unique way to represent number and then develop this basic notion as we grow and are educated? The fact that evolution has provided us two (or more) systems for number is an important indication of how development and learning proceeds. There wouldn’t be the same need for development if not for the situation of having two separate and essential systems that carry different perspectives on number. All of the historical extensions of the idea of number—including the fractions, negative numbers, real numbers, and so on—are resolutions of the tension that is implicit in our core systems. Without that tension there might well have been no development.

在我的书《盲点x》中，我详细讨论了数字概念的核心矛盾，以及在数学史上，这种矛盾以多种不同的方式得到解决。例如，希腊人发现，二的根是一个精细的几何数，因为它是毕达哥拉斯定理中线段的长度，但很难将这个数字纳入众多的世界，因为它是无理数或与有理数不相容。离散和连续之间的这种不兼容性只有在实数的发明后才能得到令人满意的解决。

In my book, The Blind Spotx I discussed at length this tension that lies at the heart of the idea of number and the way in which this ambiguity has been resolved in many different ways in the history of mathematics. For example the Greeks discovered that the root of two was a fine geometric number since it arose as the length of a line segment in Pythagoras’ Theorem but that it was difficult to incorporate this number into the world of multitude since it is irrational or incommensurable with the rational numbers. This incompatibility between the discrete and the continuous is only really resolved in a satisfactory way with the invention of the real numbers.

重复一遍，婴儿核心概念系统之间的冲突为发展提供了动力，而这种发展是由某种解决方案的需求推动的。隐含的冲突通过发展一种新的概念系统——计数数字来解决。然而，这种解决并不完整或明确。这是我们现代数字概念发展的漫长旅程中的一步。在这次旅程中，我们核心系统之间的原始差异始终保持活跃，因此能够生成更复杂的决议。

To repeat, the conflict between an infant’s core conceptual systems provides the impetus for development, which is fueled by the need for some sort of resolution. The implicit conflict is resolved through the development of a new conceptual system—the counting numbers. However this resolution is not complete or definitive. It is a step on the long voyage that constitutes the development of our modern notion of number. On this voyage the primal differences between our core systems always remain active and so remain capable of generating more complex resolutions.

1.4计数数字

1.4The Counting Numbers

令人惊讶的是，仍然有这么多人相信数字源自计数——计数是原始的。我总结的发展证据告诉我们，计数数字不是“数字”的起源，而是计数数字从更原始的核心系统发展而来。尽管如此，计数数字（1、2、3 等）是每个人认知发展中的重要一步。今天，它是我们学到的第一个数字概念系统。计数系统整合了核心数字系统的主要方面，同时调和了它们之间的许多冲突。它支持新的计算，例如加法、减法、乘法和除法。这是一个复杂的系统，其进一步发展的潜力实际上是无限的。即使在今天，它也是数学研究的一个主要领域，在加密等领域有非常具体和实际的应用。

It is surprising how many people still believe that numbers derive from counting—that counting is primitive. The developmental evidence that I have been summarizing tells us that the counting numbers are not at the origin of “number” but rather that counting numbers develop from more primitive core systems. Nevertheless the counting numbers (1, 2, 3, and so on) are a vital step in every person’s cognitive development. Today, it is the first conceptual system for number that is learned. The system of counting numbers integrates major aspects of the core numerical systems while reconciling many of their conflicts. It supports new computations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. It is a sophisticated system, which is effectively infinite in terms of its potential for further development. Even today it is a major area of research in mathematics with very concrete and practical applications in areas such as encryption.

这种计数系统是许多基本概念发展的背景。这些概念包括线性顺序、基数和无穷大，仅举三个例子。然而，年幼的孩子对它非常熟悉——熟悉到足以回答“最大的数字是多少？”这个问题，用复杂的答案回答“没有最大的数字——它们永远存在。”许多初等算术都与掌握这个概念系统有关，使之成为自己的概念系统。计数数字是最基本的例子，表明人类即使在相对较小的时候，也能接触和使用极其微妙和深刻的文化系统。

This system of counting numbers is the context within which many fundamental concepts are developed. These include linear order, cardinality, and infinity, to name just three. Yet young children become quite familiar with it—familiar enough to answer the question, “What is the largest number?” with the sophisticated answer, “There is none— they go on forever.” Much of elementary arithmetic is concerned with grasping this conceptual system, making it one’s own. The counting numbers are the most elementary example of the way human beings, even at a relatively early age, can access and work with cultural systems of incredible subtlety and depth.

许多人对数字的理解从未超出这个基本系统。对他们来说，数字始终是一个计数数字。数学史上也是如此，正如我们将看到的，即使认识到两个数字之间的比率（例如 2 比 3 的比率）是（或可以用）数字表示，也是一项重大发展，将我们带入了一个新的概念系统。

Many people’s understanding of number never goes much beyond this basic system. For them a number always remains a counting number. And so it was in the history of mathematics where, as we shall see, even the recognition that the ratio between two numbers, such as the ratio of 2 to 3 is (or can be represented by) a number, is a major development that takes us into a new conceptual system.

数学家利奥波德·克罗内克（Leopold Kronecker）有句名言：“整数是上帝创造的，其他都是人造的。”然而，正整数更有可能是后天习得的。Carey 提出了一个详细而令人信服的论点，我在这里没有篇幅来重复，以说明两件事。第一，从一个概念系统到另一个概念系统的移动（这里是从核心系统到计数数字）是不连续的。第二，她提出了一种用于这种移动的机制，她称之为“奎尼安引导法”，我将在本章后面讨论。

The mathematician Leopold Kronecker famously remarked that “The integers were created by God; all else is man-made.” However it is much more likely that the positive integers are learned. Carey makes a detailed and convincing argument, that I do not have the space to replicate here, to show two things. The first is that the movement from one conceptual system to another (here from the core systems to the counting numbers) is discontinuous. The second proposes a mechanism for this movement, which she calls “Quinian bootstrapping,” and I shall discuss later on in this chapter.

正是从核心数字系统到计数数字的转变，让凯里能够分离出深度思考的关键特征。“……如果 CS 2（更发达的概念系统——这里指计数数字）在包含 CS 1中未表示的概念的意义上超越了 CS 1，那么 CS 2对儿童来说一定很难学习。”掌握一个新的概念系统所涉及的不连续学习必然是困难的。当我们更仔细地研究这种困难的性质时，我们就会发现，学习一个新的概念系统与创造的困难完全相同。事实上，学习一个新的概念系统是创造力的典型行为。连续学习，即在先前获得的概念系统的基础上获得进行计算的技术技能，并不会带来同样的困难。例如，学习乘法表，然后学习将两个三位数相乘的算法需要努力，但从生活在计数数字的概念世界中转移到分数的概念世界中，需要做另一种工作。

It is the movement from the core systems for number to the counting numbers that allows Carey to isolate crucial features of deep thinking. “… If CS2 [the more developed conceptual system—here the counting numbers] transcends CS1 in the sense of containing concepts not represented in CS1, it must be the case that CS2 is difficult for children to learn.” The discontinuous learning that is involved in the mastery of a new conceptual system is inevitably difficult. When we come to look more closely at the nature of this difficulty we shall see that learning a new conceptual system is hard in precisely the same sense that being creative is hard. In fact learning a new conceptual system is the quintessential act of creativity. Continuous learning, which means acquiring the technical skill to make computations on the basis of a previously acquired conceptual system, does not carry with it the same sort of difficulty. For example, learning the multiplication tables and then the algorithm for multiplying two three digit numbers takes work but it a different kind of work that is required to move from living in the conceptual universe of the counting numbers to that of fractions.

让我以另一个警告结束本节，警告人们将“数字”与“计数数字”混为一谈是危险的。就连凯里也在很多地方犯了这个错误。然而，它们之间存在着根本的区别——事实上是鸿沟。我们都知道计数数字是什么，但“数字”在其最普遍和最基本的意义上既不存在于形式数学结构的世界，也不存在于认知的世界。严格来说，它既不是对象也不是概念。它是现实的一个方面，必然是非正式的，因此可以通过不同的数字系统以多种方式表示。数字与其说是一个形式概念，不如说是一个原始概念，它可以产生多个概念。

Let me end this section with another cautionary note about the danger of identifying “number” with “counting number.” Even Carey slips into this mistake at various places. However there is a fundamental difference—in fact a chasm—between them. We all know what the counting numbers are but “number”, in its most general and basic sense, lives neither in the world of formal mathematical structures nor in the world of cognition. It is not, strictly speaking, either an object or a concept. It is an aspect of reality that is necessarily informal and so can be represented in multiple ways by means of different number systems. Number is not so much a formal concept as it is what could be called a proto-concept, which generates multiple concepts.

数字非常微妙——你无法将它固定下来，但你也不能说它什么都不是。可以说，数字是一种唤起世界统一性的方式，因为它表现为秩序和模式。我们可以将它与存在于我们的心理过程和自然世界中的“趋向复杂秩序”联系起来。当希腊人断言“世界就是数字”时，他们就明白了这一点；这是“上帝是数学家”这句老话的深层含义，也可能是心理分析学家卡尔荣格断言数字是一种原型的意思。数字是非正式的，但却非常重要。毫不夸张地说，它也许是我们整个科技文明中最重要的基础元素。

Number is very subtle—you can’t pin it down but you can’t say it is nothing. One might say that number is a way of evoking the unity of the world as it manifests itself as order and pattern. We might identify it with “a tendency towards a complex order” that is present both in our mental processes and in the natural world. This is something the Greeks understood when they asserted that “the world is number;” it is the deeper meaning of the old saying, “God is a mathematician” and possibly what the psychoanalyst Carl Jung meant when he asserted that number is an archetype. Number is informal yet incredibly significant. It is no exaggeration to say that it is perhaps the most important foundational element of our entire scientific and technological civilization.

1.5几何核心系统

1.5Core Systems for Geometry

Carey 的同事 Elizabeth Spelke xi和她的同事 Sang Ah Lee 和 Véronique Izard 将 Carey 在数字方面的工作扩展到了几何学。他们声称在这个领域也存在类似的情况，并假设：“与自然数一样，自然几何学建立在两个进化古老、早期发展和跨文化普遍的认知系统之上，这两个系统捕捉了有关周围世界形状的抽象信息：两个核心几何系统。 ……孩子们……构建了一个更完整、更通用的新几何表示系统。”

Carey’s colleague Elizabeth Spelkexi and her co-workers Sang Ah Lee and Véronique Izard have extended Carey’s work on number to geometry. They claim that an analogous situation occurs in this domain, and hypothesize: “Like natural number, natural geometry is founded on two evolutionarily ancient, early developing, and cross-culturally universal cognitive systems that capture abstract information about the shape of the surrounding world: two core systems of geometry. … Children … construct a new system of geometric representation that is more complete and general.”

斯佩尔克和凯里一样，提出了两个核心系统，这一点很有意思。她的工作遵循了凯里的思路，将发展更多地视为两个核心系统整合的结果。不过，现在就几何本身来讨论，我会离题太远。我在这里提到几何，是因为以这种方式人为地将“数字”和“几何”分开，会导致对两者的误解，尤其是对数字的发展。数字概念的发展不仅源于计数活动（人们可能会从这些研究人员的著作中相信这一点），也同样源于测量活动。对于希腊人来说，人们可以认为测量是更重要的来源——数字是测量数字，尤其是线段的长度。换句话说，数字起源于多个核心系统，这些系统先于计数和几何。

It is fascinating that Spelke, like Carey, posits two core systems. Her work follows Carey’s lead in viewing development more as an outcome of the integration of the two core systems. Nevertheless it would take me too far afield to discuss geometry in its own right at this time. I mention geometry here because of the danger that artificially separating “number” and “geometry” in this way will result in a misunderstanding of both, especially the development of number. The development of the concept of number does not only arise out of the activity of counting, as one might believe from reading these researchers, but also equally from the activity of measuring. For the Greeks one could argue that measuring was the more important source—numbers were measuring numbers, especially the length of line segments. In other words number has its origins in multiple core systems, which are antecedent to both counting and geometry.

数学概念的发展并不是从“数值”核心概念到计数的数字概念，而几何概念的发展则是从核心几何概念到更复杂的“欧几里得”系统。相反，相同的核心系统会产生不同的概念系统，这些系统涉及对潜在差异的不同解决方案。数字既是测量（几何）概念，也是计数对象。计数数字和测量数字都是成功解决核心系统中固有的一些但不是全部模糊性的解决方案。两者都有助于发展更复杂的数字概念。

The development of mathematical concepts does not proceed with a number concept that goes from “numerical” core concepts to counting whereas that of geometry goes from the core geometric concepts to a more sophisticated “Euclidean” system. Rather the same core systems give rise to different conceptual systems that involve different resolutions of the underlying discrepancies. Number is as much a measuring (geometric) concept as it is a counting object. Both counting numbers and measuring numbers are resolutions that succeed in resolving some but not all of the ambiguities inherent in the core systems. Both contribute to the development of more sophisticated notions of number.

1.6有理数作为概念系统

1.6The Rational Numbers as a Conceptual System

分数是计数之后学习的概念系统。数学中的数字系统基本上是可以进行算术运算的情况，即可以进行加、减、乘、除。但是，这些运算下的闭包有时是不完整的。例如，两个计数数字相加或相乘会得到另一个结果，但减或除可能会或可能不会。你不能从计数数字中的 3 中减去 8，但尝试这样做最终会导致创建新的数字系统（整数）及其相关的概念系统，正如我们将在第三章中看到的那样。

The fractions are the conceptual system that is learned after the counting numbers. Number systems in mathematics are basically situations in which you can do arithmetic, that is, you can add, subtract, multiply, and divide. However closure under these operations is sometimes incomplete. For example, adding or multiplying two counting numbers results in another one but subtracting or dividing may or may not do so. You can’t subtract 8 from 3 in the counting numbers but trying to do so will ultimately lead to the creation of a new number systems—the integers—and its associated conceptual system, as we shall see in chapter three.

在本节中，我将重点介绍除法而不是减法。你可以在计数系统中进行除法。你可以将 12 颗珠子分成 3 组，然后发现每组有 4 颗珠子。或者，你可以将饼切成 12 个规则的块，并认为 3 块的子集合与整个饼具有一定的几何关系。换句话说，分数是作为两个计数数字（这里是 3 和 12）之间的关系引入的。在这个阶段，它是一种关系，还不是一个数字。你也可以称之为计算除法运算发生在计数数字的概念系统中，因此除法运算发生在计数数字的概念系统中。你可以完美地除整数，而不需要发展分数的概念，就像我们第一次学到“三除以七二，余数为一”时一样。

In this section I shall focus not on subtraction but on division. You can divide in the system of counting numbers. You can divide 12 beads into 3 collections and see that there are 4 beads in each collection. Alternately you can cut a pie into 12 regular pieces and consider that a sub-collection of 3 pieces bears a certain geometrical relationship to the whole pie. In other words a fraction is introduced as a relationship between two counting numbers, here 3 and 12. At this stage it is a relationship and not yet a number. You could also call it a computation over the counting numbers because the operation of division is occurring within the conceptual system of the counting numbers. You can divide whole numbers perfectly well without ever developing the concept of a fraction as we all did when we first learned that “three divides into seven two times and leaves a remainder of one.”

但分数不仅仅是比率的表示系统。要理解这个额外的维度，就必须严肃地问自己：“比率为什么是数字？”不要回答：“当然是！”这没有什么显而易见的。理解比率是数字，并将这一认识与早期的计数系统相结合，是我们小时候取得的一项重大智力成就。这是迈向新数字世界——有理数的一次飞跃。

But fractions are more than a representation system for ratios. To appreciate this extra dimension it is necessary to ask oneself in all seriousness, “Why is a ratio a number at all?” Don’t answer, “Of course it is!” There is nothing obvious about it. Grasping that a ratio is a number and integrating that realization with the earlier system of counting numbers is a major intellectual accomplishment that we all made as children. It is a leap to a new world of numbers—the rational numbers.

我们可以通过伟大数学家威廉·瑟斯顿 (William Thurston) 讲述的自己童年的一个轶事来体会这种飞跃。瑟斯顿讲述了有一天他兴奋地跑到父亲面前，告诉他他刚刚意识到 134 除以 29 是一个数字，而不仅仅是长除法的问题。父亲的回答是“当然是了”。数学家可能会说“这很明显”。但事实恰恰相反。父亲是从分数的概念体系出发来讲的，在分数中这确实是很明显的。但瑟斯顿描述的是你超越计数系统并跳跃到分数的顿悟时刻。从这个角度来看，这是一个启示！这两个回答抓住了从一个概念体系跳跃到另一个概念体系所涉及的内容，并指出深度思考过程所涉及的不连续的跳跃，这让你非常兴奋，因为它让你看到了一个全新的世界。

We may appreciate this leap through an anecdote that the great mathematician, William Thurston, told of his own childhoodxii. Thurston tells of the day when he ran excitedly up to his father and told him that he had just realized that 134 divided by 29 was a number and not just a problem in long division. His father’s response was, “Of course it is.” A mathematician would probably say, “That’s obvious.” But on the contrary it is the opposite of obvious. The father was speaking from the conceptual system of the fractions in which it is indeed obvious. But Thurston was describing the moment of insight when you transcend the system of the counting numbers and make the leap to the fractions. From this point of view it is a revelation! The two responses capture what is involved in going from one conceptual system to another and point out that what is involved in the process of deep thinking includes a discontinuous leap that gets you very excited because it gives you a vision of an entirely new world.

让我们用完全不同的方式思考这个发展问题，从古希腊人的角度来看待它。对于希腊人来说，数字与其说是计数，不如说是测量数字——长度或面积。因此，问某个东西是否是数字，归根结底就是问它是否可以构造——在欧几里得几何中，这种构造只能使用直尺和圆规。

Let’s think of this developmental problem in an entirely different way and look at it from the point of view of the ancient Greeks. For the Greeks numbers were not so much counting numbers as they were measuring numbers—lengths or areas. So asking whether something is a number comes down to asking if it can be constructed—in Euclidean geometry this construction can only use a straightedge and compass.

几何问题是：给定长度为a和b 的线段，你能构造长度为ab和a/b 的线段吗？对于希腊对于几何学家来说，此构造只能使用直尺和圆规。此乘积所需的构造涉及比率和比例理论，更具体地说，相似三角形（具有相同形状且具有完全相同角度的三角形）的边是成比例的。构造背后的想法基于几何方程ab/a = b/1，其中我们将所有这些数字视为长度。画一个三角形ABC，使 AB 的长度= b且AC的长度= 1。将边AC延伸至D，使AD的长度为a 。画一条平行于CB 的线DE与延长线AB相交于E 。那么AD的长度为ab，因为三角形ABC和ADE相似。（商可以用大致相同的方式构造。）

The geometric problem is: given line segments of lengths a and b, can you construct segments of lengths ab and a/b? For the Greek geometers the construction could only use a straight-edge and compass. The required construction for the product involved the theory of ratio and proportion, more specifically, that similar triangles (triangles of the same shape and having exactly the same angles) have sides that are proportional. The idea behind the construction is based on the geometric equation, ab/a = b/1, where we think of all of these numbers as lengths. Draw a triangle ABC such that the length of AB = b and the length of AC = 1. Extend the side AC to D so that the length of AD is a. Draw a line DE parallel to CB hitting the extended line AB at E. Then the length of AD is ab because the triangles ABC and ADE are similar. (The quotient can be constructed in much the same way.)

因为这种构造是可能的，所以每个有理数都可以具体表示为长度，因此对于希腊人来说，比率从仅仅是两个长度之间的关系变成了本身就是长度。但孩子们并不是欧几里得几何的专家。他们不太清楚 5 块馅饼和 12 块馅饼之间的关系是一个与 5 和 12 同等重要的数字。事实上，乍一看，比率和计数数字是完全不同的东西。对于一个通过计数数字概念系统定义数字的孩子来说，5 比 12（甚至 3 比 12）的比率肯定不是一个数字。如果它是一个数字，那么它在计数数字中处于什么位置？它大于 1 还是小于 1？它甚至可以与 1 相比吗？这样的问题并不简单。它们很难，如果从“错误”的角度来看，甚至是“不可能”的。

Because this construction is possible every rational number can be represented concretely as a length, and so a ratio for the Greeks moved from being merely the relationship between two lengths to a length in its own right. But children are not experts in Euclidean geometry. It is not so obvious to them that the relationship between 5 pieces of a pie and the 12 pieces of the whole pie is a number that stands on the same footing as the numbers 5 and 12. In fact at first glance ratios and counting numbers are completely different things. For a child who defines number by the conceptual system of the counting numbers the ratio of 5 to 12 (or even of 3 to 12) is definitely not a number. If it is a number where does it fit into the counting numbers? Is it bigger than 1 or smaller than 1? Is it even comparable to 1? Such questions are not simple. They are hard, even “impossible” if they are looked at from the “wrong” point of view.

这些问题在什么意义上是“难”的？答案是，所讨论的两个概念系统，即计数数字和分数，是彼此不相容的。处于第一个系统的人以一种方式看待数字，而处于第二个系统的人则以完全不同的方式看待数字。正如 Carey 所说，“在有理数构建之前和之后，数字概念的外延和概念作用明显不同。”孩子对“一到二之间有多少个数字？”这个问题的回答将取决于孩子当时生活在哪个概念系统中。换句话说，每当你上升到数字概念系统的层次结构时，数字的世界就会发生变化和增长。从一个到另一个的变化是突然发生的；它具有洞察力的性质。这种不连续这一方面直接源于两个数字世界的强烈不兼容性或不可通约性。

In what sense are such questions “hard?” The answer is that the two conceptual systems in question, the counting numbers and the fractions, are incompatible with one another. A person in the first system sees number in one way whereas a person in the second sees it in a completely different way. As Carey says, “The extension and conceptual role of the conceptxiii of number are markedly different before and after the construction of the rationals.” The child’s answer to the question, “How many numbers are there between one and two?” will depend on which conceptual system the child is living in at the time. In other words the world of number changes and grows whenever you ascend the hierarchy of numerical conceptual systems. The change from one to the other comes suddenly; it has the nature of an insight. This discontinuous aspect comes directly from the strong incompatibility, or incommensurability, of the two number worlds.

当然，当你进入分数的世界时，你会发现它包含的其实是计数数字的副本，现在被视为分数n/1。从那时起，我们成功地处理了将整数n视为计数数字和（同时）分数的歧义。数学家会说，我们已经将计数数字同构地嵌入到分数中，这意味着复制过程保留了所有算术运算。数学家认为这是一个正式的过程，因此相对容易，并且并不总是记住，对于学习者来说，这涉及到概念系统的改变，而这总是很难的。

Of course when you ascend to the world of fractions you learn that it contains what is essentially a copy of the counting numbers, now considered as the fractions n/1. From then on we successfully manage the ambiguity of considering an integer n as both a counting number and (simultaneously) as a fraction. The mathematician would say that we have isomorphically embedded the counting numbers into the fractions, which means that the copying process preserves all of the operations of arithmetic. The mathematician thinks of this as a formal process and so relatively easy, and does not always bear in mind that for the learner it involves the change of conceptual systems and that is always hard.

1.7歧义

1.7Ambiguity

数字的符号表示（2作为计数数字和分数）抑制了赋予数字概念精确含义的上下文（所讨论的概念系统），这一观察表明，即使是初等数学也包含模糊性的基本元素。xiv这种模糊性不是一种错误，而是数学概念结构的一个基本组成部分。

The observation that the symbolic representation of number (2 as counting number and fraction) suppresses the context (the conceptual system in question) that gives a precise meaning to the concept of number, demonstrates that even elementary mathematics contains an essential element of ambiguity.xiv This sort of ambiguity is not an error but an essential part of the conceptual structure of mathematics.

我在最近的书中强调了一个有争议的观点，即模糊性是数学和科学的一个关键要素。xv几乎同时，数学哲学家 Emily Grosholz 独立地出版了一本关于数学和科学中“生产性模糊性”的优秀著作，也从同样的视角探讨了数学。xvi模糊性涉及一种可以用多种方式表示或理解的单一情况或想法。模糊情况是指具有多个参考框架的情况，而这些参考框架通常包含不可避免的相互不兼容性。因此，模糊情况的核心是需要解决的问题。这个问题可能微不足道，也可能意义深远。如果它很有趣；如果它的解决方案来自对情况的新思考方式，那么我们可以说模糊性是富有成效的。在换句话说，解决生产性歧义需要创造性行为。

In recent books I highlighted the controversial notion that ambiguity is a key element in mathematics and science.xv Independently but almost simultaneously the philosopher of mathematics, Emily Grosholz, published an excellent book about “productive ambiguity” in mathematics and science that approached mathematics from this same perspective.xvi Ambiguity involves a singular situation or idea that can be represented or understood in more than one way. An ambiguous situation is one that has multiple frames of reference and these frames of reference often contain a mutual incompatibility that cannot be avoided. Thus an ambiguous situation has a problem at its core that requires resolution. This problem may be trivial or it may be profound. If it is interesting at all; if its resolution comes from a new way of thinking about the situation then we could say that the ambiguity is productive. In other words the resolution of a productive ambiguity involves a creative act.

现在，这种对模糊性的描述适用于我所描述的两种情况。第一种情况涉及儿童对数字的两个核心概念系统。我已经讨论过这些系统，但要回顾一下：

Now this description of ambiguity applies to the two situations that I have been describing. The first involves a child’s two core conceptual systems for number. I have already discussed these systems but to review:

（1）两种系统都为数字和数量的原始概念赋予了操作意义。每种系统本身都是一致的。

(1)Both systems give operational meaning to the primal ideas of number and quantity. Each is consistent in its own right.

（2）它们彼此冲突，也就是说，它们之间存在不兼容的因素。

(2)They conflict with one another, that is, there is an element of incompatibility between them.

（3）对于这种极具成效的模糊性，有多个解决方案，即各种数字系统，特别是计数数和分数。

(3)There are multiple resolutions to this extremely productive ambiguity, namely, various number systems, in particular the counting numbers and the fractions.

第二个产生性歧义的例子涉及计数数字作为基本概念系统 CS 1 ，从而产生分数 CS 2。这里我们又有两种不同的方式赋予“数字”意义。这两个系统再次不一致，但这种不一致与两个核心系统的情况不同。后一种不一致可以说是水平的，而这种不一致是垂直的或分层的，因为 CS 1可以嵌入 CS 2。现在，我们可能可以将分数视为与整数不相交，因此可以将这两个系统视为处于同一水平。例如，当我们将2/3视为数字之间的关系而不是数字时，我们就是这样做的。将计数数字嵌入分数需要处理这种歧义，并且所有算术和排序运算都可以从 CS 1一致地扩展到 CS 2。也就是说，说1/2 < 2/3或' 2 + 3 ' 中的' + ' 与' 1/2 + 2/3 ' 中的 ' + '“相同”是有意义的。在这种情况下，歧义一词适用于两个不同的层面：涉及集合中的元素和操作层面以及系统本身层面。

The second example of productive ambiguity involves the counting numbers as the base conceptual system—CS1—giving rise to the fractions—CS2. Here again we have two different ways of giving meaning to “number.” Again the two systems are inconsistent but the inconsistency is different than in the case of the two core systems. The latter inconsistency is horizontal, one might say, whereas this one is vertical or hierarchical since CS1 can be embedded in CS2. Now it might be possible to consider the fractions as disjoint from the integers and so think of these two systems as lying at the same level, so to speak. This is what we do when we think of 2/3, for example, not as a number but as a relationship between numbers. Embedding the counting numbers in the fractions requires dealing with that ambiguity and also that all of the operations of arithmetic and order may be extended consistently from CS1 to CS2. That is, it makes sense to say 1/2 < 2/3 or that the ‘+’ in ‘2 + 3’ is the “same” as the ‘+’ in ‘1/2 + 2/3’. In this situation the word ambiguity applies at two different levels: at the level of the elements and operations in the sets involved and at the level of the systems themselves.

结论是，新概念系统的发展是产生性歧义情况的原型，因此，解决这种情况需要创造性行为。在学生的数学发展过程中，计数数字产生分数的情况会重复无数次。

The conclusion is that the development of a new conceptual system is the very prototype of a situation of productive ambiguity and therefore of a situation whose resolution requires an act of creativity. The situation of the counting numbers giving rise to the fractions is repeated countless times in a student’s mathematical development.

1.8引导思维

1.8Bootstrap Thinking

深度思考在从一个概念系统转变为另一个概念系统的过程中是连续的还是不连续的？学习涉及离散阶段还是许多渐进变化的结果？我听说有些计算机模型似乎支持这两种假设。xvii

Is deep thinking as it arises in the change from one conceptual system to another continuous or discontinuous? Does learning involve discrete stages or is it the result of many incremental changes? I have been told that there are computer models that seem to support both hypotheses.xvii

本书将承认连续变化和非连续变化的存在。发展、学习和科学进步中重要事件的不连续性是不能被忽视的，也不能被连续变化的增量序列所取代。为什么这一定是真的，我将在下一章讨论概念系统时解释。从一个概念系统到其后继系统的变化是彻底的，因为新旧世界观是不相容的（凯里追随科学哲学家托马斯·库恩的脚步，称这两个系统是不可通约的），这种不兼容性是概念变化不连续的原因——很难同时持有这两种观点。正是解决不兼容性的需要推动了深度思考，无论它是以发展、概念学习还是科学进步的重大突破的形式出现。

This book will recognize the existence of both continuous and discontinuous change. The discontinuity of important events in development, learning, and scientific progress cannot be discounted nor can it be replaced by an incremental sequence of continuous changes. The reason why this must be true will follow from my discussion of conceptual systems in the next chapter. The change from one conceptual system to its successor is radical because the new way and the old way of seeing the world are incompatible with one another (Carey follows the lead of the philosopher of science Thomas Kuhn, and calls the two systems incommensurable) and this incompatibility is the reason why conceptual change is discontinuous—it is very difficult to hold both views at the same time. It is the need to resolve the incompatibility that powers deep thinking whether it comes in the guise of development, conceptual learning, or major breakthroughs in the progress of science.

但这并不意味着没有持续发展的空间。事实上，学习、创造力和发展具有一定的持续性。库恩最初强调科学进步的不连续性——范式转变——但后来他改变了观点，接受了持续变化的因素。值得探索的有趣问题是解释不连续发展的机制的性质及其与持续发展的关系。

Nevertheless this does not mean that there is no room for continuous development. In fact learning, creativity, and development have a definite continuous dimension. Kuhn initially emphasized the discontinuous nature of scientific progress—paradigm change—but later on came to modify his views and accept the element of continuous change. The fascinating question to be explored is the nature of the mechanism that accounts for discontinuous development and its relationship with continuous development.

凯里将不连续变化背后的机制描述为“奎因引导”。 “靠自己的力量向上爬”是不可能的，这凸显了这种学习方式的神秘性。她说，这就像使用梯子从一个层次到达另一个层次，但当你到达更高的层次时，就把梯子扔掉。实际上，这更像是爬到梯子的最上面，然后再迈出一步。最后的“不可能”一步就是神秘的创造性飞跃。

Carey describes the mechanism behind discontinuous change as “Quinian bootstrapping.” “Pulling yourself up by your own bootstraps” is impossible and this highlights the mystery of this kind of learning. She says it is like using a ladder to get from one level to another but then throwing away the ladder when you are at the higher level. Actually it is more like climbing up to the top rung of a ladder and then taking one more step. That last “impossible” step is the mysterious creative leap.

孩子最初通过死记硬背来学习部分数字序列，后来才理解单词和序列的全部含义。在这种情况下，引导隐喻中的阶梯是背诵数字单词序列的活动。这是一种死记硬背的活动，一种即使在较原始的概念系统中也可以进行的连续活动。这解释了死记硬背的作用并说明了它的重要性。此外，它表明死记硬背和概念学习之间的对立是一种错误的对立。但是，如果孩子仍然停留在死记硬背的水平，那么学到的东西就会受到严重限制——孩子对概念的掌握不会有任何增长。学习的目标是或应该是让孩子熟练掌握新的概念系统并将新的观点与以前的观点相结合。

The child initially learns a portion of the sequence of counting numbers by rote and only later understands the full meaning of the words and the sequence. The ladder in the bootstrapping metaphor is, in this case, the activity of reciting the sequence of number words. This is a rote activity, a continuous activity that can be performed even while remaining in the more primitive conceptual system. This explains the role of rote learning and demonstrates why it is important. Moreover it shows that the opposition between rote learning and conceptual learning is a false opposition. However if the child remains at the rote level then what is learned is severely limited—there is no growth in the child’s grasp of concepts. The objective of learning is, or should be, for the child to become fluent in the new conceptual system and integrate that new perspective with her earlier ones.

很多持续性活动，包括死记硬背，都可以看作是对既定概念系统的计算。最初掌握概念系统会给个人带来一种新的力量，这种力量最初可能看起来是无限的。然而，随着对概念系统的探索不断深入，人们通常会遇到问题因素——某种阻碍。学校和社会的要求，或者个人成长的需要，使得人们很难或不可能忽视问题因素。需要以一种新的方式看待这种情况。学生被解决困难的需要所推动，并希望在父母和老师的支持和鼓励以及她自己的直觉（即建设性的整合是可能的）的推动下向前迈进。

Much of continuous activity, including rote learning, can be thought of as a computation over an established conceptual system. Initially having command of a conceptual system gives the individual a new power that initially may appear to be virtually limitless. However as the exploration of the conceptual system is extended one normally encounters problematic elements—a blockage of some sort. The demands of schooling and society, or just the need for personal growth make it difficult or impossible to ignore the problematic elements. A new way of looking at the situation is demanded. The student is pushed from behind by the need to resolve the difficulty and, hopefully, pulled forward by the support and encouragement of parents and teachers and her own intuition that a constructive integration is possible.

在决定性的时刻，一个新的概念系统诞生了，其中旧系统中的计算成为新系统的概念元素。在分数的发展中，2/3成为一个数字，而不是两个数字之间的关系。在计数数字的发展中，这是孩子开始形成概念系统的时刻，该系统扩展了核心系统和作为引导过程基础的死记硬背计算。然后，孩子不仅可以数数：“一、二、三、……七”，还可以列举一组七个弹珠或积木，并理解在两种情况下都是相同的“七”。此外，她会明白8不仅在数字序列中排在7之后，而且8 “大于”7.她还能用7减3，或用6除以2，并辨别出数字系统中的其他各种模式。

At the decisive moment a new conceptual system is born in which the computation in the earlier system becomes a conceptual element of the new one. In the development of the fractions 2/3 becomes a number instead of remaining a relationship between two numbers. In the development of the counting numbers this is the moment when the child begins to form a conceptual system that extends the core systems and the rote computations that were the basis for the bootstrapping process. Then the child can not only count: “one, two, three, …, seven” but enumerate a collection of seven marbles or blocks and understand that it is the same “seven” in both cases. Moreover she will understand that 8 not only comes after 7 in the number sequence but that 8 is “more” than 7. She can also subtract 3 from 7, or divide 6 by 2, and discern various other patterns within the system of numbers.

1.9概括

1.9Summary

深度思考涉及一个紧张与放松、专注与不专注的循环，我将在接下来的几章中讨论这些循环。但在论证的这个阶段，列出深度思考的一些显著特征可能会有所帮助，其中一些特征已被迄今为止的讨论所揭示，而另一些特征则被纳入其中，以备将来的讨论。

Deep thinking involves a cycle of tension and release, of focusing and un-focusing that I shall discuss in the next few chapters. But at this stage in the argument it may be useful to list some of the salient features of deep thinking some of which have been revealed by the discussion so far and others, which are included in anticipation of the discussion to come.

自然性。深度思考存在于幼儿的概念发展中，这一事实导致人们推测深度思考是大脑自然运作的方式。除非受到阻碍、抑制或压抑，否则无需教授或学习。深度思考通常存在于学习、概念发展和创造力中。

Naturalness. The fact that deep thinking is found in the conceptual development of young children leads to the conjecture that deep thinking is the natural way the mind works. It need not be taught or learned unless it has been blocked, inhibited, or repressed. Deep thinking is usually present in learning, conceptual development, and creativity.

困难。深度思考总是由有问题的事情引发。这个问题可能表现为模棱两可、不兼容，甚至矛盾。因此，深度思考总是困难的。

Difficulty. Deep thinking is always generated by something that is problematic. This problem may manifest itself as an ambiguity, an incompatibility, or even a contradiction. As a result deep thinking is always difficult.

这种困难的本质是本书的主题之一。然而，即使在这个初步阶段，我也注意到“自然性”和“困难”的性质似乎相互矛盾。如果深度思考是自然的，那么人们会认为它很简单，但我认为它总是很难。想想一个学走路的婴儿——走路是自然的，但学走路很难。它需要付出巨大的努力和克服许多失败的意志。所有重要的学习和创造力事件都会发现有这两个组成部分：一些天生的东西驱使人们努力，一些障碍阻碍人们最终的成功。

The nature of this difficulty is one of the themes of the book. However even at this preliminary stage I note that it would appear as though the properties of “naturalness” and “difficulty” are at odds with one another. If deep thinking were natural, then one would think that it would be simple yet I claim that it is always difficult. Think of a baby learning to walk—walking is natural and yet learning to walk is hard. It takes a great deal of effort and the will to overcome many failures. All significant episodes of learning and creativity will be found to have these two components: something innate that drives one towards making the effort and some obstacle that stands in the way of one’s eventual success.

不连续性。深度思考总是包含不连续性——要么你明白，要么你不明白。它涉及洞察力，涉及对新观点的飞跃。

Discontinuity. Deep thinking always involves an element of discontinuity—you either get it or you don’t. It involves an insight, a leap to a new point of view.

不确定性和不完整性。深度思考以未知和不确定性为基础，因此深度思考总是包括放弃已知和确定。不确定性是事物是；而确定性则只能在既定的概念体系中找到。因此，从一个概念体系转移到另一个概念体系必然需要进入不确定的领域。它不能通过逻辑论证的方式从确定性转移到确定性。

Uncertainty and Incompleteness. Deep thinking is grounded in the unknown and the uncertain and so deep thinking always includes abandoning the known and the certain. Uncertainty is the way things are; certainty, on the other hand, is only to be found within an established conceptual system. Thus moving from one conceptual system to another inevitably necessitates stepping into the realm of the uncertain. It cannot come by moving from certainty to certainty in the way of a logical argument.

深度思考产生的洞察力伴随着一种主观的确定感，但这种确定性不是绝对的或永久的。正如哥德尔教导我们的那样，所有思想体系都是不完整的，这种不完整性可以被认为是不确定性的必然残留。系统总是包含有问题的元素，通常只有在充分探索新系统的含义后才会清楚。问题通常可以用初始系统的语言来陈述，但只能通过创建新系统来解决。没有一种理论或概念系统是普遍有效的。另一方面，没有概念系统就没有知识或理解。头脑永远不会是一张白纸。

The insight that arises from deep thinking comes with a subjective feeling of certainty but this certainty is not absolute or permanent. All systems of thought are incomplete, as Gödel taught us, and this incompleteness can be thought of as an inevitable residue of uncertainty. Systems always contain problematic elements in a sense that is usually not clear until the implications of the new system are sufficiently explored. Often problems can be stated in the language of the initial system but can only be resolved by creating a new system. No theory or conceptual system is universally valid. On the other hand there is no knowledge or understanding without a conceptual system. The mind is never a blank slate.

重构、模糊性和物化。深度思考涉及重构，即以全新的方式看待给定的情况。重构总是意味着情况是模糊的——同一情况可以用多种框架来看待。此外，这两种观点最初是互不相容的。物化是一种涉及过程-对象模糊性的重构，即某一级别的过程成为更高级别系统中的对象。这也被称为“封装”、“聚集”或“块学习”。

Reframing, Ambiguity, and Reification. Deep thinking involves reframing, that is, coming to look at a given situation in an entirely new way. Reframing always implies that the situation is ambiguous—the same situation can be viewed in more than one frame. Moreover the two points of view are initially incompatible with one another. Reification is a reframing that involves a process-object ambiguity, that is, processes at one level become objects in a higher-level system. This has also been called “encapsulation,” “clumping,” or “block learning.”

层次结构和集成。深度思考涉及从一个观点 CS 1转向另一个观点 CS 2。一方面，这两个观点之间总是不兼容的。然而，这两个观点在 CS 2中是集成的。集成可以通过在 CS 2中嵌入 CS 1的同构图像来实现。因此，深度思考自然是层次化的，并且朝着复杂性增加的方向发展。

Hierarchy and Integration. Deep thinking involves proceeding from one point of view, CS1, to another CS2. On the one hand there is invariably an incompatibility between these two viewpoints. Nevertheless the two viewpoints are integrated within CS2. The integration may be accomplished by embedding an isomorphic image of CS1 within CS2. Thus deep thinking is naturally hierarchical and moves in the direction of increasing complexity.

与系统思维的关系。深度思维包括但不限于系统的思维元素：即连续的、计算的和逻辑的。在这种情况下，系统思维可以被认为是在已知和固定的环境中进行的探索。它可能会澄清该环境的某些方面，但永远不会用另一个不兼容的系统替换该环境。然而，持续思考往往是深度思考的先决条件。

Relation to Systematic Thinking. Deep thinking includes, but is not restricted to, elements of thought that are systematic: that is, continuous, computational, and logical. Systematic thought in this context can be thought of as explorations that remain within a known and fixed environment. It may clarify aspects of that environment but it will never replace that environment with another incompatible system. Nevertheless continuous thinking is often a prerequisite to deep thinking.

我Carey (2009)。

i Carey (2009).

ii同上。

ii Ibid.

iii同上。

iii Ibid.

iv Dehaene (1997)。

iv Dehaene (1997).

v在文献中这被称为韦伯定律。

v This is referred to in the literature as Weber’s Law.

vi Carey，（2009）。

vi Carey, (2009).

vii同上。

vii Ibid.

viii同上。

viii Ibid.

ix数量和众多是亚里士多德用来描述数量不同方面的术语。它们大致对应于连续性，例如测量长度或面积，而不是离散性，例如计数。

ix Magnitude and multitude were Aristotle’s terms for different aspects of quantity. They roughly correspond to the continuous, for example in measuring length or area, as opposed to the discrete as in counting.

x拜尔斯（2011）。

x Byers (2011).

xi Spelke 等人，（2010 年）。

xi Spelke et al, (2010).

xii Thurston (1990)。第 846 页。

xii Thurston (1990). p. 846.

xiii Carey（2009）。

xiii Carey (2009).

xiv有关这一点的更多内容请参见《Gray and Tall》（1994 年）。

xiv More on this in Gray and Tall (1994).

xv Byers（2007 年和 2011 年）。

xv Byers (2007 and 2011).

xvi Grosholz（2007）。

xvi Grosholz (2007).

xvii心理学家诺曼·西加洛维茨（Norman Segalowitz）在私人讨论中。

xvii Psychologist Norman Segalowitz in a private discussion.

第 2 章

Chapter 2

概念系统

Conceptual Systems

2.1介绍

2.1Introduction

第一章利用学习动态和人类概念发展来揭示深度思考的一些基本特征。这些特征是从深度思考的基本例子——儿童对计数数字和分数的构建中抽象出来的。正如我所讨论的，概念发展和学习涉及用一种理解数字的方式替代另一种理解数字的方式，即从一个数字概念系统转移到一个更复杂的系统。我们将这种发展象征性地表示为 CS 1 → CS 2，其中箭头代表深度思考的行为。深度思考涉及整数或分数等概念系统的构建、解构和重构，这是一种非常正常且看似不可避免的发展，我们常常不会停下来惊叹它是多么非凡的成就。

Chapter one used the dynamics of learning and human conceptual development to reveal some essential features of deep thinking. These features were abstracted from elementary examples of deep thinking, the child’s construction of the counting numbers and fractions. Conceptual development and learning, as I discussed them, involved the replacement of one way of understanding number by another, that is, the movement from one conceptual system for number to a more sophisticated system. We represented this development symbolically as CS1 → CS2, where the arrow stands for an act of deep thinking. The deep thinking that is involved in the construction, deconstruction, and reconstruction of conceptual systems such as the integers or the fractions is such a normal and seemingly inevitable development that we don’t often stand back and marvel at what an extraordinary accomplishment it is.

概念学习的非凡之处何在？在数字系统中，回想一下“数字”没有客观的、先验的意义可能会有所帮助。它的意义是通过被置于概念系统中而赋予的。因此，数字要么是计数数字，要么是分数。从“数字是计数数字”到“数字是分数”是一种革命性的行为，它使“理性”世界成为现实。分数似乎是凭空而来的。它当然不存在于计数数字的世界中，在计数数字的世界中，它只是一种被称为除法的计算。这种计算的具体化是典型的创造性行为，它给世界带来了一些新的和意想不到的东西。它不仅仅是以这种方式产生的单个分数，同时也是一个全新的数字世界，有它自己的属性和规律，也有它自己的问题和挑战。

What is it about conceptual learning that is so remarkable? In the case of number systems, it may help to recall that “number” has no objective, a priori meaning. It is given meaning by virtue of being placed within a conceptual system. Thus number is a counting number or it is a fraction. To go from “a number is a counting number” to “a number is a fraction” is a revolutionary act, which brings the “rational” world into existence. The fraction comes into existence seemingly out of nowhere. It certainly does not exist in the world of the counting numbers in which it is merely the computation that is called division. The reification of this computation is the quintessential creative act, which brings something new and unexpected into the world. It is not only individual fractions that come into existence in this way but also a totally new number world with its own properties and laws as well as its own problems and challenges.

为了将深度思考置于更普遍的背景下，有必要以更普遍和更全面的方式考虑概念系统的性质。这将为数学和科学的新思维方式以及从它们产生的概念系统的角度思考新技术奠定基础。

In order to place deep thinking in a more general context it will be necessary to consider the nature of conceptual systems in a more general and complete manner. This will prepare the ground for a novel way of thinking about mathematics and science as well as a way of thinking about new technologies in terms of the conceptual systems that they generate.

随着讨论的深入，有两个问题需要牢记。第一个问题涉及将技术、数学系统或科学理论视为概念系统，而不仅仅是“事物现状”的客观描述的含义。第二个问题涉及是否可以对科学、数学和技术中从一个概念系统或范式向另一个概念系统或范式的转变说些有用的话。我首先要回答第一个问题。

There are two questions to bear in mind as this discussion develops. The first concerns the implications of considering a technology, a mathematical system, or a scientific theory as a conceptual system rather than merely as an objective description of “the way things are.” The second involves whether one can say something useful about the movement from one conceptual system or paradigm to another in science, mathematics, and technology. I shall begin by taking up the first question.

2.2什么是概念系统？

2.2What is a Conceptual System?

概念系统是至关重要的认知结构。自然世界的结构看似无可争议，客观坚固，但其构造在很大程度上取决于我们概念系统的存在。我们只能通过概念窗口来体验世界

Conceptual systems are crucial cognitive structures. The structure of the natural world with its seemingly uncontestable objective solidity is a construct that depends crucially on the existence of our conceptual systems. We can only experience the world through a conceptual window

概念系统是一个综合的概念系统，支持对世界某些方面的连贯看法。概念系统是个人的；它是一种“观察方式”，即一种“认知方式”。另一方面，许多概念系统是在学校学习的，存在于社会背景或特定的科学文化中。因此，它们具有客观可验证的属性。一旦我们写下了计数数字的公理，那么费马大定理，它指出方程a n + b n = c n对于n > 2没有整数解，成为一个潜在的数学真理，可能为真也可能为假，实际上已被安德鲁·怀尔斯证明为真。有趣的是概念系统的一个显著特点是，它既有主观维度，又有客观维度。

A conceptual system is an integrated system of concepts that supports a coherent vision of some aspect of the world. A conceptual system is personal; it is a “way of seeing,” that is, a “way of knowing.” On the other hand many conceptual systems are learned in school and exist within a social context or a particular scientific culture. As such they have objective verifiable properties. Once we have written down the axioms of the counting numbers then Fermat’s Last Theorem, which states that the equation an + bn = cn has no integer solutions for n > 2, becomes a potential mathematical truth which could be true or false and was actually proved to be true by Andrew Wiles. The intriguing thing about conceptual systems is that they possess both a subjective and an objective dimension.

顺便说一句，重要的是，我以概念系统而不是单个概念作为讨论的开端，尽管更传统的阐述会从元素（概念）开始，然后系统被设想为元素的集合。关键在于，概念的意义是由它们所属的系统赋予的。概念系统至关重要，因此我将其作为切入点。

By the way, it is significant that I have begun my discussion by talking about conceptual systems and not about individual concepts even though a more conventional exposition would go from the elements—the concepts—to the system that would then be conceived as an ensemble of elements. The point is that the concepts have their meaning conferred upon them by the system of which they form a part. It is the conceptual system that is crucial and thus I have made it my point of entry.

2.3现实之窗

2.3Windows on Reality

有一个著名的心理学实验，即“大猩猩实验”。实验人员向人们展示一段视频，视频中一只大猩猩在一群正在打球的人中间走来走去。令人惊讶的是，大多数视频观众都没有看到大猩猩，也许是因为它的出现是出乎意料的，不协调的。从这个实验中可以学到的教训是，人们不只是观察客观存在的东西，而且感知是期望、文化和经验的函数。人们需要一个窗口才能感知现实，而概念系统提供了这样一个窗口。概念系统是人类用来区分可见和不可见的过滤器——图形和背景之间的区别。这种区别是感知和意识本身的基础——人们只意识到图形，而不是背景。图形和背景不是客观现象，但在我们感兴趣的情况下，它们是由操作概念系统决定的。

There is a famous psychological experiment, the “gorilla experiment,” in which people are shown a video in which a gorilla wanders through a group of people playing a ball game. Surprisingly the gorilla passes unseen by most viewers of the video perhaps because it’s presence is unexpected and incongruous. The lesson to be learned from this experiment is that people do not just observe what is objectively there but that perception is a function of expectation, culture, and experience. People need a window in order to be able to perceive reality and a conceptual system provides such a window. The conceptual system is the filter that human beings use to separate what is seen from what is not—the distinction between figure and ground. This distinction is basic to perception and to consciousness itself—people are only conscious of the figure not the ground. Figure and ground are not objective phenomena, but in the cases that interest us here, are determined by the operative conceptual system.

暂且不谈数学和科学，通常情况下，许多人认为对所有人、所有时间都一样的现实，是通过语言和概念的窗口来看待的。乍一看，这并不奇怪。大多数人会承认，我们生活在一种受语言等诸多因素影响的特定文化中。语言和文化是窗户——巴黎人和伦敦人看待世界的方式略有不同。在蒙特利尔这样的双语城市，你可以看到这一点政治和文化领域每天都在上演着各种动态。许多紧张局势的出现都是由于不同文化群体的成员用不同的文化视角来看待特定情况。

To step back from mathematics and science for a moment, it is generally the case that the reality that many believe to be the same for all people at all times is seen through the window of language and concepts. At first glance this is not really surprising. Most people would acknowledge that we live in a particular culture that is influenced by our language, among many other factors. Language and culture are windows—a Parisian and a Londoner see the world in ways that are subtly different. In a bilingual city like Montreal you can see this dynamic play out every day in the political and cultural arenas.
