Many of the tensions that arise are due to the different cultural lenses through which members of different cultural communities use to look at some particular situation.

尽管我们都接受文化在构建人们对真实事物的感知中所起的作用，但几乎每个人都相信存在着一种客观现实，它就在那里，独立于文化之外。当我们走在街上时，我们不是都看到同样的树木、汽车、人行道和房屋吗？正是这种普遍而客观的背景现实的存在，让我想请读者提出质疑。我并不是说没有任何东西是真实的——当然有！但我们只能通过中介，即概念系统的隐喻窗口，才能接触到真实。大多数人认为，他们所看到的东西与他们所看到的东西无关；他们认为，可以将他们所看到的东西的内容与他们所看到的窗口分开。这就像相信一个人的知识与一个人的“知道”不同，后者是知道这些知识的认知机制。这种信念要求科学结果必须是“客观的”——独立于观察者。如果科学结论取决于有效的科学范式（即观察科学结论的视角），那么“客观性”的本质就必须重新考虑。

Even though we might all accept the role that culture plays in constructing people’s sense of what is real, nevertheless almost everyone believes that there exists an objective reality that is out there and is independent of culture. Is it not true that when we walk down the street we all see the same trees, cars, sidewalks, and houses? It is precisely the existence of this universal and objective background reality that I am asking readers to question. I am not saying that there is nothing that is real—of course there is! But we can only get in touch with the real through an intermediary, the metaphorical window of a conceptual system. Most people believe that what they see is independent of the fact that they see it; they imagine that it is possible to separate the content of what they see from the window through which they see it. This is the same as believing that one’s knowledge is distinct from one’s “knowing,” the cognitive mechanisms through which that knowledge is known. This belief informs the requirement that a scientific result must be “objective”—independent of the observer. If the scientific conclusion depends on the operative scientific paradigm—the lens through which it is viewed—then the very nature of “objectivity” must be reconsidered.

我认为，认知和知识紧密相连，只有通过人为的方式才能将它们分开，而且代价是扭曲正在研究的系统。换句话说，没有这个窗口，我们就看不到任何东西！例如，我们倾向于认为数据是独立的，是中立和客观的，但在我看来，我们总是在特定的背景下或从特定的角度来看待数据。

I shall take the position that knowing and knowledge are intertwined so tightly that they can only be pried apart in an artificial manner and at a cost of distorting the system that is being studied. In other words, without the window we wouldn’t see much of anything! For example, we tend to think that data stands on its own, that it is neutral and objective, but in my view we always view the data, we see it within a certain context or from a particular perspective.

考虑一下火箭的轨迹。当然，轨迹并不取决于观察者是中国人还是美国人，也不取决于观察者的心情是好是坏。从这个意义上说，它是客观的。假设观察到的轨迹不依赖于测量过程或支持测量的概念系统，则是另一回事。

Consider the trajectory of a rocket. Of course the trajectory does not depend on whether the observer is Chinese or American, or on whether the observer is in a good or bad mood. It is objective in this sense. It is quite another thing to assume that the observed trajectory does not depend on the measuring process or on the system of concepts that support measurement.

要描述火箭的轨迹，我们至少需要使用时间、空间、数字、坐标系、速度和加速度的概念。你必须首先使这些概念精确且可量化，否则你就没有机会获得对火箭运动的准确描述。显然，火箭的轨迹是真实的，但我们用来描述它的概念系统又如何呢？

To describe the trajectory of the rocket we would need to use the concepts of time, space, number, coordinate system, velocity, and acceleration at the very least. You must first make these notions precise and quantifiable or else you have no chance of obtaining an accurate description of the motion of the rocket. Obviously the trajectory of the rocket is real but what about the system of concepts that we use to describe it?

时间、空间、数字等概念指的是真实、客观和永恒的事物吗？从科学史可以清楚地看出，例如，时间对不同的人有不同的含义，而且这种含义现在仍然如此。我们对时间的科学理解已经发展和变化。例如，有牛顿的时间、爱因斯坦的时间、我们生物钟的时间，以及心理学家威廉·詹姆斯所描述的心理时间感知。所有这些都指的是同一个原始“时间”吗？很可能是这样，但这并不明显，科学家和哲学家至今仍在争论这个问题。例如，在物理学这样的学科中，当我们提到时间时，我们通常会在脑海中有一个定义明确且可量化的概念。但当我们回顾历史或甚至当我们改变学科时，这种精确性就消失了。

Do the concepts of time, space, number, and so on refer to things that are real, objective, and permanent? Well it is clear from the history of science that time, for example, has meant different things to different people and continues to do so. Our scientific understanding of time has evolved and changed. There is the time of Newton, the time of Einstein, the time of our biological clocks, and our psychological perception of time as described by the psychologist William James, for example. Do all of these refer to the same primordial “time?” This may well be so but it is not at all obvious and scientists and philosophers argue about it to this day. Within a discipline like physics, for example, we usually have a well-defined and quantifiable concept in mind when we refer to time. But this precision disappears when we look back through history or even when we change disciplines.

我并不是说时间不是真实的（尽管确实有人这样说）。时间概念的所有变体显然都有一些共同点。时间有一个原始概念，所有精确的表述都可追溯到这个概念。因此，我在我的书《盲点》中将其称为原始概念。时间、空间、数字和随机性（以及许多其他概念）都是这样的原始概念。时间指的是某种真实的东西，是生命和存在的基础。这就是我们被驱使去探索和解释它的原因。时间是真实的，但无法一劳永逸地捕捉到它。我们必须逐步地用在特定情况下或多或少有效的精确定义来接近它。这样，我们就把时间变成了可以利用的精确的东西；我们将时间嵌入到概念系统中。

I am not saying that time is not real (although there are serious people who make that claim). All of the variations on the notion of time clearly have something in common. There is a primordial notion of time that all precise formulations refer back to. For this reason I called it a protoconcept in my book, The Blind Spot.i Time, space, number, and randomness (and many others) are all such primordial ideas. Time refers to something real, something that is at the foundations of life and existence. That is why we are driven to explore it and explain it. It is real but it cannot be captured once and for all. We must approach it incrementally with precise definitions that work more or less well in particular situations. In doing so we make time into something precise that can be worked with; we embed time into a conceptual system.

因此，火箭的轨迹是真实的，但要利用它，我们必须通过一个概念系统来看待它，这个概念系统虽然不是完全客观的，但也是真实的。在这方面，有趣的是，“客观”一词可以有两种不同的用法ii。第一种是“不依赖于概念系统的第一个含义是“个人观点或偏见”，而第二个含义是“独立于思想的”。概念系统在第一种意义上是客观的，但在第二种意义上则不是。后一种说法有些争议，它将为我的科学、数学和学习方法奠定基础。没有一个系统来观察，就什么也看不见。例如，你不能真正地将“学到的东西”与学习者的认知过程区分开来。你甚至不能明确地将理论内容与理解和操作理论的概念系统区分开来。

So the rocket’s trajectory is real but to work with it we must look at it through a conceptual system, which is also real even though it is not totally objective. It is interesting in this regard that the word “objective” can be used in two different waysii. The first is “not dependent on personal opinion or prejudice,” while the second is “independent of mind.” The system of concepts is objective in the first sense but not the second. The latter claim is somewhat controversial and it will set the stage for my approach to science, mathematics, and learning. Nothing can be seen without a system through which to view it. It follows, for example, that you cannot realistically separate “what” is learned from the cognitive processes of the learner. You can’t even definitively separate theoretical content from the conceptual systems by means of which the theory is understood and made operational.

没有概念系统，你就无法进行数学或科学研究，但这样的系统不是客观和永久的。它们会发生变化和发展。因此，我们不能声称我们在科学中经历和处理的现实与科学家的思想无关。我们声称数学和科学结果的客观性是相对客观性的。费马大定理相对于计数系统是正确的，而牛顿定律F = ma则取决于对力、质量和加速度的精确概念的阐述。

You cannot do mathematics or science without a conceptual system but such systems are not objective and permanent. They are subject to change and development. Therefore we cannot claim that the reality that we experience and work with in science is independent of the mind of the scientist. The objectivity that we claim for mathematical and scientific results is relative objectivity. Fermat’s Last Theorem is true relative to the system of the counting numbers and Newton’s Law, F = ma, depends on having articulated a precise notion of force, mass, and acceleration.

考虑一下这个几何定理：三角形的内角和等于两个直角。这个定理在一个系统（欧几里得几何）中是正确的，而在另一个系统（非欧几里得几何）中是错误的。欧几里得几何和非欧几里得几何不仅是不同的数学系统，而且也是不同的概念系统。从一个公理系统切换到另一个公理系统很容易——你只需修改平行公设。但概念系统并不容易改变。非欧几里得几何的出现震惊了十九世纪的数学家。接受这种新几何的合法性需要获得一种新的世界观。或者，用更戏剧性的方式来说，世界本身随着非欧几里得几何的出现而发生了变化。

Consider the geometric theorem that the interior angles of a triangle sum to two right angles. This theorem is true relative to one system (Euclidean geometry) and false in another (non-Euclidean geometry). Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometry are not only different mathematical systems but are also different conceptual systems. It is easy to change from one of these axiomatic systems to the other—you just modify the parallel postulate. But conceptual systems do not change easily. The advent of non-Euclidean geometry was shocking to the mathematicians of the nineteenth century. Accepting this new geometry as legitimate involved acquiring a new way of viewing the world. Or, to put it in a more dramatic way, the world itself changed with the advent of the non-Euclidean geometries.

2.4概念窗口是一种观点

2.4A Conceptual Window is a Point of View

让我举几个非科学的例子，也许可以澄清这个基本的观点，而且对很多人来说，这是违反直觉的——事实需要概念系统是人们适应特定情境的手段。如果一个人在树林里行走，如果没有办法适应周围环境，就很容易迷路。同样，一个人也必须有办法在心理领域（例如前面讨论过的数字世界）中适应环境。在认知情况下，迷失方向会导致连贯性和意义的丧失，因此无法理解。在某些学习环境中迷失方向的学生只能看到原始数据，她只能通过记忆来处理这些数据。顺便说一句，这意味着现代世界将世界视为数据的倾向是极其令人迷失方向的。数据本身毫无意义，也无法理解。

Let me give a couple of non-scientific examples that may serve to clarify this essential and, for many, counter-intuitive point—facts require a cognitive context if they are to be to be meaningful. One can think of it as involving an orientation. A conceptual system is the means by which one orients oneself to a particular situation. If one is walking in the woods then it is easy to become hopelessly lost if one does not have some way to orient oneself to one’s surroundings. Similarly one has to have a way to orient oneself in mental domains such as the number worlds that have been discussed. In cognitive situations disorientation involves the loss of coherence and meaning, and, as a consequence understanding is impossible. A student who is disoriented in some learning environment only sees raw data, which she can only deal with by means of memorization. As an aside this means that the tendency in the modern world to see the world as data is extremely disorienting. Data means nothing on its own and cannot be understood.

从历史上看，绘画用来引导观察者的方法之一是线性透视，这是 15 世纪由布鲁内莱斯基和莱昂·巴蒂斯塔·阿尔伯蒂等艺术家和建筑师发明的技巧，后来被伟大的列奥纳多·达·芬奇用于《三博士来朝》等画作。在这种技巧中，画中的线条会汇聚到地平线上的一个点，即消失点。这使得二维绘画看起来像三维的，因为它模拟了我们看东西的方式——平行的铁轨似乎也会汇聚到地平线上的一个点。因此，画家考虑的不是客观场景（其中的铁轨永远不会汇聚），而是观察者如何看待场景。只有当绘画的观察者（其眼睛使绘画栩栩如生）与二维画布（客观绘画）一起考虑时，绘画才有意义。然而，眼睛这一基本要素并不存在于绘画中；它只是暗示。类似地，学习不仅涉及一些客观材料，还涉及个人对材料的看法。正如每个观察者都会将自己的历史和整个存在带到他们对图片的观察中一样，我们也会将我们所有的文化和概念包袱带到学习的每一种情况中。更有争议的是，我们可以对科学和数学说同样的话。熟悉用于查看结果的认知系统是理解“客观”科学情况并使其变得有意义的关键。生活。任何曾经努力去理解枯燥抽象的科学研究论文的人都知道，除非读者熟悉其背后的概念体系，否则这篇论文仍然相对难以理解，即使如此，读者也必须付出巨大的努力，才能将其核心思想及其含义生动地呈现出来。

Historically, one of the ways that painting has used to orient the observer involves linear perspective, a technique that was invented in the fifteenth century by artists and architects like Brunelleschi and Leon Battista Alberti and later used by the great Leonardo da Vinci in paintings like Adoration of the Magi. In this technique, lines in the painting converge to a point, the vanishing point, on the horizon. This makes the two-dimensional painting appear to be three-dimensional because it simulates the way in which we see—parallel railway tracks also appear to converge to a point on the horizon. Thus the painter has in mind not the objective scene (in which the railway tracks never converge) but how the observer views the scene. The painting only makes sense when the observer of the painting, whose eye makes the painting come alive, is considered along with the two-dimensional canvas (the objective painting). Yet this essential ingredient, the eye, is not present in the painting; it is only implied. In an analogous way learning does not only involve some body of objective material but also the point of view that an individual brings to the material. Just as every observer brings their history and entire being to their viewing of the picture so we bring all of our cultural and conceptual baggage to every situation of learning. Even more controversially, we could say the same thing about science and mathematics. A familiarity with the cognitive system through which the results are being viewed is the thing that makes sense of the “objective” scientific situation and makes it come to life. Anyone who has struggled to make sense of a dry and abstract scientific research paper knows that it remains relatively inaccessible unless the reader is familiar with the conceptual system that lies behind it and, even then, makes the substantial effort that is required to bring its central ideas and their implications to life.

观察者的参与在量子力学中很常见，它被称为“波函数坍缩”。但它也出现在任何科学实验中，比如社会科学实验，其中需要考虑观察者的影响。这意味着科学实验不仅仅是可以保持距离并在远处检查的东西。除非亲眼看到，否则每种情况都是不真实的。换句话说，科学实验（或其他任何东西）的完整描述必须包括一个观点，一种观察现象的方式，这就是概念系统所提供的。包括观察者观点的需要是完全普遍的。在某些情况下，比如向月球发射火箭，我们可能会觉得观察者的影响可以忽略不计。然而，即使在这种情况下，我们的计算也受到理论视角的限制，其中包括我们用来模拟情况的数学、我们用来执行计算的算法等等。大自然仍时常给我们带来惊喜，我们才后知后觉地意识到需要拓展我们的视野。

The involvement of the observer is familiar from Quantum Mechanics where it is known as the “collapse of the wave function.” But it is also evident in any scientific experiment, like those in the social sciences, where the effect of the observer needs to be taken into account. This means that a scientific experiment is not just something that can be held at arm’s length and examined at a distance. Every situation is not real unless it is viewed. Another way to say this is that the complete description of a scientific experiment (or anything else) must include a point of view, a way of looking at the phenomenon, which is what a conceptual system provides. The need to include the viewpoint of the observer is completely general. In some situations, like sending a rocket to the moon, we may feel that the effect of the observer is negligible and can be ignored. However even in such situations our calculations are constrained by our theoretical perspective, which includes the mathematics that we use to model the situation, the algorithms that we use to perform our calculations, and so on. On a regular basis nature still manages to surprise us and we belatedly realize that we need to expand our point of view.

2.5深度思考的困难

2.5The Difficulty of Deep Thinking

记住了概念系统的讨论，现在就更容易理解我在第一章末尾提到的深度思考特征之一的困难的性质了。掌握这一困难的性质是理解概念发展的关键，而且正如我们将在后续章节中看到的那样，也是理解创造力和学习的关键。

With this discussion of conceptual systems in mind it is now easier to understand the nature of the difficulty I spoke about as one of the characteristics of deep thinking at the end of chapter one. Grasping the nature of this difficulty is the key to understanding conceptual development and, as we shall see in subsequent chapters, is also the key to understanding creativity and learning.

我上面说过，概念系统是一扇观察现实的窗户；现实并不是独立存在的，而是总是被“观察”的。然而，窗户的比喻可能会产生误导，因为它可能看起来暗示有人从窗外往外看（心灵），并且有一个被观看的外部场景（客观世界），也就是说，观看者和被观看者是情况的原始要素。相反，观看是原始的，而观看者和被观看者是此事件的次要的、主观的和客观的维度。换句话说，我们必须从概念系统开始。

I said above that a conceptual system is a window that looks out at reality; reality does not stand on its own but is always “viewed.” However the metaphor of the window can be misleading for it may seem to imply that there is someone looking out of the window (the mind) and that there is an external scene that is viewed (the objective world), that is, that the viewer and the viewed are the primordial elements of the situation. On the contrary, it is the viewing that is primordial whereas the viewer and the viewed are secondary, subjective and objective, dimensions of this event. In other words we have to start with the conceptual system.

这导致了以下难题。现实必然要通过概念系统来观察，并且与观察现实的系统密不可分。但现实在定义上是单一的——只有一个现实；不可能有两个或三个。某事要么是真实的，要么不是。认为现实是相对的，或者认为可以有两个相互竞争且不一致的现实，这种观点令人困惑，并会产生站不住脚的认知失调。

This leads to the following conundrum. Reality is necessarily viewed through a conceptual system and is inseparable from the system through which it is viewed. But reality is by definition singular—there is only one reality; there cannot be two or three. Something is either real or it is not. The notion that reality is relative or that there can be two competing and inconsistent realities is disorienting and produces untenable cognitive dissonance.

因此，对于同一种情况，存在两个相互竞争的概念系统是令人无法接受的，甚至是不可能的。在我之前关于“数字”的讨论中，我提到，对于许多成年人来说，数字仍然是计数数字。计数数字捕捉了数字的现实，而所有其他类型的数字（分数、小数、实数和复数）都不那么引人注目。这种感觉使他们不必面对存在两个相互竞争的数字操作定义且都声称具有同等的真理性的情况。然而，每当孩子们面对学习新的数字系统时，他们就会面临这种令人不安的情况。

Thus having two competing conceptual systems for the same situation is experienced as unacceptable, even impossible. In my earlier discussion of “number” I mentioned that for many adults a number remains a counting number. The counting numbers capture the reality of number for them and all of the other kinds of numbers—fractions, decimals, real and complex numbers—are less compelling. This feeling frees them from having to deal with the situation of having two competing operational definitions for number with an equal claim to truth. And yet children face such a disturbing situation whenever they are faced with learning a new number system.

存在两个相互冲突的概念系统是一种令人恼火的情况。它甚至可能让人感到威胁。然而，当人们被迫承认存在两个不同的概念系统（例如，两个数字系统）时，就会出现这种情况。从这个角度来看，概念系统竟然会为个人或整个社会而改变，这令人震惊。人们可能倾向于说概念改变是不可能的，但它确实会发生，这是一个经验事实。这就是创造力和学习的非凡之处。要改变概念系统，旧系统、旧世界必须失去其定义现实的强大力量，并被一种全新的世界观所取代。要从一个概念世界转移到另一个概念世界，我们必须我们不可避免地会面临第一世界崩溃而新世界尚未牢固建立的时刻。我们必须面对这一空白并继续前进。这就是概念变化情况下不可避免地出现的非凡困难的本质。

Having two conflicting conceptual systems is a situation that is irritating. It may even feel threatening. And yet that is the situation that arises when one is forced to admit to the existence of two different conceptual systems that cover the same ground—two systems for number, for example. From this point of view it is astounding that conceptual systems ever change for individuals or for society in general. One might be inclined to say that conceptual change is impossible and yet it is an empirical fact that it does happen. This is what is so extraordinary about creativity and learning. To change conceptual systems the old system, the old world, must lose its compelling power to define reality and be replaced by an entirely new way of seeing the world. To move from one conceptual world to another we must inevitably confront the moment when the first world breaks down and yet the new one is not firmly established. We must face this void and keep on going. This is the nature of the extraordinary difficulty that inevitably arises in situations of conceptual change.

这一讨论还解释了为何概念变化是不连续的。现实要么由 CS 1定义，要么由 CS 2定义，这个“或”是排他性的“或”，不允许两个系统同时运行的可能性。人们必然必须从 CS 1跳到CS 2。为了捕捉范式变化的不连续性，托马斯·库恩使用了格式塔图片的比喻，例如年轻女子和老太太的图片，就像我在我的书《数学家如何思考》和《盲点》中所做的那样。从视觉上讲，人们一次只能看到其中一个图像。你要么看到年轻女子，要么看到老太太，你看到的图像是对整个视野的诠释。因此，这些格式塔图片很好地捕捉到了概念变化的不连续性。

This discussion also explains why conceptual change is discontinuous. Reality is either defined by CS1 or CS2 and this “or” is the exclusive “or” which does not admit the possibility that both systems are operative at the same time. Of necessity one must jump from CS1 to CS2. In order to capture the discontinuous aspect of paradigm change Thomas Kuhn used the metaphor of the Gestalt picture, for example, the one of the young woman and the old lady, as I did in my books, How Mathematicians Think and The Blind Spot. Visually one can only see one of these images at one time. You either see the young woman or the old lady and the image you see is an interpretation of the entire visual field. Thus these Gestalt pictures capture the discontinuity of conceptual change very well.

2.6技术概念系统

2.6Technological Conceptual Systems

概念系统是思维进入我们对自然描述的手段。我们通常认为世界是由原子、分子和细胞等物质组成的，而忘记了这些不是“纯粹”的物体；它们是概念物体。因此，原子理论是一个概念系统，是一种看待世界的方式。物质的原子理论不仅是对物质客观属性的描述，而且是一种思考物质的方式，乍一看似乎很奇怪。但事实就是如此。我们体验和思考的世界必然涉及思维。

Conceptual systems are the means through which the mind enters into our description of nature. We normally think of the world as being made up of things like atoms, molecules, and cells, and forget that these are not “pure” objects; they are conceptual objects. Thus the atomic theory is a conceptual system, a way of looking at the world. It may initially seem strange to say that the atomic theory of matter not only is a description of the objective properties of matter but is also a way of thinking about matter. But that is the way it is. The world that we experience and think about necessarily involves the mind.

这似乎是一个非常抽象和哲学的观点，但在当代世界，这些问题至关重要，因为它们与我们这个时代最重要的现象——技术变革直接相关。技术就像科学理论一样，带有概念系统。技术——电话、收音机、电视、电脑、手机等——不仅仅是硬件。它们的重要性源于它们产生“技术概念系统”（TCS）。每一项重要的新技术都会带来新的 TCS，一种体验和与世界互动的新方式。在前言中，我提到了马歇尔·麦克卢汉的格言：“媒介即信息”。这里的媒介是技术，但信息是 TCS。

This may seem to be a very abstract and philosophical point but in the contemporary world such questions are vitally important because of their immediate relevance to the most important phenomenon of our time—technological change. Technologies, just like scientific theories, carry conceptual systems with them. Technologies—the telephone, radio, television, computers, cell phones, and so on—are not just pieces of hardware. Their importance stems from the fact that they generate “technological conceptual systems” (TCS). Every significant new technology ushers in a new TCS, a new way of experiencing and interacting with the world. In the preface I spoke of Marshall McLuhan’s aphorism, “the medium is the message.” The medium here is the technology but the message is the TCS.

从非常实际的意义上讲，这是每个人的生活经历的问题，随着这些新技术的出现，世界、社会和个人都在发生变化。这解释了为什么这些新技术如此令人兴奋，但也可能令人恐惧。年轻人对变化的抵抗力较低，因此他们通常是第一个接受新技术的人。他们的父母随后惊讶地发现，他们的孩子生活在一个与他们不同的世界里。

In a very real sense that is a matter of the life experience of everyone, the world changes, society changes, and individuals change with the advent of these new technologies. This explains why they are so exciting but also why they may be frightening. Young people have less resistance to change and so they are usually the first to embrace the new technology. Their parents are then shocked to discover that their kids are living in a different world than they are.

说我们生活在一个不断变化的世界几乎是陈词滥调。在过去，文化可能稳定几个世纪。主流技术文化体系的变化需要很长时间才能融入文化。然而，今天我们所有人都在一生中经历了多次技术革命。当代世界的主要挑战涉及文化、社会和个人对挑战的反应，不是一两次变化，而是加速和持续的变化。

It is practically a cliché to say that we are living in a world of continuous change. In the past cultures might be stable for centuries. A change in the dominant TCS took a very long time to be assimilated into culture. Yet today all of us have experienced multiple technological revolutions in our lifetimes. The major challenge of the contemporary world involves the reaction of cultures, societies, and individuals to the challenge, not of one or two changes, but of accelerating and continuous change.

从我之前对概念变革的讨论中，我们可以清楚地看出，我们所面临的要求有多么重大和激进。TCS 和其他概念系统一样，定义了对接受它的个人和社会来说什么是真实的。例如，电话带来了通信、商业和工业的革命，更不用说人们的隐私观念了。许多人最初抵制在家中安装电话的想法，因为他们对如此自由地与世界接触的想法感到厌恶，在他们看来，这是对隐私和家庭的不可接受的侵犯。电话彻底改变了人们之间的关系，以至于很难想象前电话的世界是什么样的。电话创造了一个与之前的世界截然不同的世界。而且这种特殊的变化只会加速。今天，即使是攀登珠穆朗玛峰的人也携带卫星电话。我们大多数人可能对没有即时通信的世界有些怀念，但可能会发现生活在这样一个世界，前电话的世界，很难，甚至可能让人焦虑。要测试是否如此，请尝试几天不接触科技产品——关闭所有电子设备并监控你的反应。你会感到与世隔绝、奇怪地感到被贬低和孤独。

The magnitude and radical nature of what is demanded of us is clear from my earlier discussion of conceptual change. A TCS, like any other conceptual system, defines what is real for the individuals and societies that embrace it. The telephone, for example, brought about a revolution in communications, commerce and industry, not to speak of people’s notion of privacy. Many people initially resisted the specter of having a telephone in their homes because they were repelled by the idea of being so freely accessible to the world, which seemed to them to be an unacceptable intrusion into privacy and the home. The telephone so completely changed people’s relationship with one another that it is difficult to imagine what the pre-telephone world was like. The telephone produced a world that was radically different from the world that preceded it. And that particular change has only accelerated. Today even people who climb Mount Everest carry satellite phones. Most of us may have some nostalgia for the world without instant communications but probably would find living in such a world, the pre-telephone world, to be difficult, maybe even anxiety provoking. To test whether this is so try taking a technology fast for a few days—turn off all your electronic gadgets and monitor your reactions. One feels cut off, oddly diminished, and alone.

如果一项新技术改变了个人对现实的感知，那么技术变革当然会令人感到压力和困难。如果从 TCS 1到 TCS 2 的单一变化都很困难，那么与当今所有发达社会对人们的要求相比就显得微不足道了——适应反复和加速的变化。概念变化本质上很难，原因我之前已经讨论过，但从一个数字系统到另一个数字系统的转变显然与通讯方式的重大变化不同，后者会改变一个人与家人、朋友和社会的关系。

If a new technology changes the individual’s sense of what is real then, of course, technological change is stressful and difficult. If a single change from TCS1 to TCS2 is difficult it pales in comparison to what is demanded of people today in all advanced societies—accommodating to repeated and accelerating change. Conceptual change is intrinsically difficult for reasons that I have discussed earlier but the change from one number system to another is clearly not in the same league as a major change in the means of communication where one’s relationship with one’s family, friends, and society is altered.

人类天性的一个基本要素是安全感的需求以及由此产生的对变化的抵制。我们将在第四章中看到，这种倾向甚至根深蒂固地植根于我们的大脑中。这意味着，一旦我们掌握了 CS，我们就有强烈的倾向继续留在那里。现在，概念系统是弹性的，并且可能是无限的，因此留在 CS 中并不意味着我们注定要不断地重复自己，陷入一种无休止的循环中。我们可以花大量的时间——可能是我们的一生——生活在一个给定的概念系统中，探索它赋予生命的宇宙，并对我们获得的知识感到满意。在这种情况下，我们可以同时感到富有成效和舒适。我们可能不知道每个问题的答案，但我们已经学会了如何寻找答案。

One basic element of human nature involves the need for security and the resulting resistance to change. As we shall see in chapter four this tendency is even hard-wired into our brains. This means that once we have grasped a CS we have a strong predilection to remain there. Now conceptual systems are elastic and potentially infinite so that staying within a CS does not mean that we are doomed to go on repeating ourselves in a kind of endless loop. We can spend a good deal of time—possibly our whole lives—living within a given conceptual system, exploring the universe that it brings to life, and feeling good about the knowledge that we have acquired. In such a situation we can feel productive and comfortable at the same time. We may not know the answer to every question but we have learned how to look for answers.

不断被迫离开我们的安全区是文明进化史上前所未有的事件。如果对安全和稳定的需求确实是人类的基本天性，那么现代技术世界要求的正是一类全新的、不同类型的人——能够接受变化的人。总有一些人似乎在变化中茁壮成长。但这样的人是少数；他们是少数不寻常的人，不知何故对变化以及随之而来的不安全感感到自在。这些人甚至拥抱变化；他们觉得变化很刺激。这让他们感觉更有活力！当我们旅行时，我们都会对此有所了解，并被新奇的景象、声音、以及我们遇到的气味。在这种时候，我们的心智不正常，也就是说，我们的意识不正常。可以说，我们生活在不同的思维中，我将在第四章讨论这种思维。

To be repeatedly forced out of our security zone is an unprecedented event in the evolution of civilizations. If the need for security and stability is indeed basic to human nature, then the modern technological world is demanding nothing less than a new and different type of human being—one who can embrace change. There have always been individuals who seem to thrive on change. But such people have been in the minority; they comprise a small number of unusual people who somehow are comfortable with change and the insecurity it brings in its wake. These people even embrace change; they find it stimulating. It makes them feel more alive! We all get some kind of inkling of this when we travel and are stimulated by the novelty of the sights, sounds, and smells that we encounter. At such times we are not in our right minds, that is, not in our habitual state of consciousness. We inhabit a different mind, so to speak, and I shall discuss this mind in chapter four.

因此，我们目前所处的境况不仅蕴含着巨大的危险和困难，也蕴含着巨大的机遇。人类不仅需要安全，还需要发展——成长和学习。毕竟，变化——称之为流动、混乱或无常——是事物的本质。人性在最基本的层面上与现实的其他部分没有什么不同，因为它在不断变化。随着语言和科学的出现，我们将变化具体化并命名。我们还通过发明“我”这个词来具体化自己。只有在人类进化的这个阶段，人们才开始将自己视为其他物体世界中固定不变的物体。他们忘记或压抑了更基本的无常。然而，现代世界威胁着要使这一策略过时。我们环顾四周，发现一切都在迅速变化，很难跟上。我们正处于这台技术跑步机上，我们跑得越快，脚下的跑步机移动得就越快。我们不断寻求新的平衡，因为过去这种平衡一直有效，但我们达到的任何平衡都会在短时间内被打破。平衡和停滞作为一种策略不再有效。

Thus the current situation that we find ourselves in carries not only great dangers and difficulties but also great opportunities. Human beings do not only need security they also need to develop—to grow and learn. After all change—call it flux, chaos, or impermanence—is the way things are. Human nature at its most basic level is no different than the rest of reality in that it is continually changing. With the advent of language and science we reified change and named it. We also reified ourselves by inventing the word “I.” It was only at this stage of human evolution that people came to see themselves as fixed, unchanging objects in a world of other objects. They forgot or repressed the more basic level of impermanence. However the modern world threatens to make that strategy obsolete. We look around us and find that everything is changing so fast that it is difficult to keep up. We are on this technological treadmill and the faster we run the faster the treadmill moves beneath our feet. We keep reaching for a new equilibrium because that is what always worked in the past but any equilibrium we reach gets disrupted within a short time. Equilibrium and stasis as a strategy will not work any more.

我们需要根本性的转变——一种新的生活方式，这种生活方式将通过接受变化作为我们的主要现实并学会驾驭这样的世界而产生。这种转变相当于接受现代科技社会的所有公民——特别是那些希望提出创新想法的人——必须习惯深度思考。这就是我之前所说的深度思考不能再被忽视或压制的意思。创造力不仅是每个人与生俱来的权利；它对每个人来说都是必需的。这是在这个与我们无休止的技术概念系统一起诞生的特殊世界中生存的唯一方式。

We need a fundamental shift—a new way of being which will arise by accepting change as our primary reality and learning to navigate that kind of world. This shift is equivalent to accepting that all citizens of a modern, technological society—especially those people who hope to come up with innovative ideas—must become comfortable with deep thinking. This is what I meant when I said earlier that deep thinking could no longer be ignored or repressed. Creativity is not only the birthright of everyone; it is also necessary for everyone. It is the only way to live in this peculiar world that has come into being alongside our endless stream of technological conceptual systems.

然而，危险在于，我们可能会集体陷入这样的思维陷阱：计算机可以为我们进行深度思考，这意味着我们可以保持安全，而不必面对所谓的“不安全的智慧”。现在，只需重申，关于深度思考和概念变革的讨论直接这些问题与现代世界最关键的问题相关。这些问题涉及思考和学习的本质，以及如何在这个（伪）智能机器的新世界中保持我们的人性。

However there is the danger that we shall collectively fall into the trap of thinking that a computer can do the deep thinking for us, which means that we can remain secure without having to confront what has been called the “wisdom of insecurity.” For now it suffices to reiterate that the discussion of deep thinking and conceptual change is directly relevant to the most vital questions that can be asked about the modern world. These involve the nature of thinking and learning and so of maintaining our humanity in this new world of (pseudo) intelligent machines.

2.7概念数学与科学

2.7Conceptual Mathematics and Science

数学最好从概念的角度来理解。数学家兼哲学家 Reuben Hersh 在最近的一篇论文中对此进行了评论，他敦促数学家和数学哲学家重新审视数学的本质。iii他首先指出了数学的现实性，他说，对于数学家来说，数学的现实性就像物理世界对于科学家一样不容置疑。然后他问道：“这个现实是什么？它是我们的内部概念，我们的心理模型，它们是具有真实属性的真实对象（原文斜体），并且彼此一致，相互契合和匹配。”换句话说，数学的现实是一种概念现实。数学是一个庞大的概念系统，数学的每个子学科，如代数、几何或分析，都构成了一个概念系统。我将在本书中详细探讨这种数学观点。这不是通常的数学观点，许多人会反对以这种方式看待数学。

Mathematics is best understood in conceptual terms. The mathematician and philosopher Reuben Hersh, a man who has urged mathematicians and philosophers of mathematics to take another look at the nature of mathematics, commented on this in a recent paper.iii He first notes the reality of mathematics, which, he says, for mathematicians is as incontestable as the physical world is for the scientist. Then he asks, “What is this reality? It is our internal concepts, our mental models, which are real objects with real properties, (italics in original) and which are congruent to each other, which fit together and match.” In other words the reality of mathematics is a conceptual reality. Mathematics is a vast conceptual system with each sub-discipline of mathematics, such as algebra, geometry, or analysis, constituting a conceptual system in its own right. This view of mathematics is one that I shall pursue in some detail in this book. It is not the usual view of mathematics and many people would take exception to looking at mathematics in this way.

谈到概念数学，就不得不提到数学现实的复杂性，它混合了主观的思维模型和坚实而客观的结构。如果我们想探究数学的深层本质，就必须接受和研究这种复杂性。

Speaking of conceptual mathematics brings to the fore the complex nature of mathematical reality with its mixture of subjective mental models and solid and objective structure. It is this complexity that we must accept and investigate if we wish to plumb the deeper nature of mathematics.

以这种方式看待数学将告诉我们概念系统是多么了不起的东西——即使概念系统像计数数字一样基本。概念系统为我们的经验世界带来了生命和连贯性。个人创造概念系统是一件了不起的事情。所有概念系统都赋予现实的一个方面意义，就计数数字而言，现实就是“数字”的世界。数字是数学和科学中最基本的概念。对于那些对数字敏感的人来说，数学、计数数字的世界是一幅美丽的景象，它在无限细微的复杂性和坚固持久的结构之间取得平衡。

Viewing mathematics in this way will teach us what an extraordinary thing a conceptual system is—even a conceptual system that is as elementary as the counting numbers. Conceptual systems bring life and coherence to the world of our experience. The creation of a conceptual system by an individual is a remarkable event. All conceptual systems give meaning to an aspect of reality and in the case of the counting numbers that reality is the world of “number.” Number is the most basic idea in mathematics and science. For those with sensitivity to mathematics, the world of the counting numbers is a vision of beauty, with its balance between infinitely nuanced intricacy and solid, enduring structure.

当概念系统（如计数数）的认知方面被忽略时，它就会变成一个枯燥抽象的系统，其本质可能看起来在于一组公理或整数序列的死记硬背。但是，当它被视为一个概念系统并从内部探索时，即使只是在有限的范围内掌握它，人们也会发现它充满了生命力。它包含无数可以提出的问题、可以进行的计算、可以辨别的规律和可以证明的定理。将计数数作为一个概念系统来讨论就是要强调系统内部的生命力。最好从内部来欣赏概念系统。

When the cognitive aspects of a conceptual system like the counting numbers is ignored, it can become a dry and abstract system whose essence may appear to lie in a set of axioms or the rote enumeration of the integer sequence. But when it is regarded as a conceptual system and explored from the inside, when it is grasped, if only to a limited extent, then one finds that it is teeming with life. It contains an unlimited number of questions that can be asked, computations that can be made, regularities that can be discerned, and theorems that can be proved. To discuss the counting numbers as a conceptual system is to highlight the life within the system. A conceptual system is best appreciated from the inside.

尽管像计数数字这样的丰富概念系统打开了一个看似无限的世界，但每个概念系统在根本上都是有限的。由于它通过（正式或非正式的）表述来明确概念和想法（如“数字”），因此不可避免地会引入某些僵化和其他有问题的元素。在计数数字的概念系统中，数字就是计数数字，因此您无法以完全令人满意的方式从三中减去五或将九除以四。每个概念系统都不可避免地存在一个问题或限制，正如我们将看到的，这可以成为开发越来越复杂的系统的动力——在我们的例子中，这将是分数或（正和负）整数。

Even though a rich conceptual system like that of the counting numbers opens up a seemingly infinite world, nevertheless every conceptual system is limited in a fundamental way. Because it makes concepts and ideas (like ‘number’) explicit by formulating them (in a formal or informal manner), certain rigidities and other problematic elements are inevitably introduced. Within the conceptual system of the counting numbers a number is a counting number so you cannot subtract five from three or divide nine by four in a way that is entirely satisfactory. Every conceptual system inevitably contains a problem or limitation and, as we shall see, this can act as the impetus for the development of increasingly more complex systems—in our example this would be the fractions or the (positive and negative) integers.

科学也由一系列概念系统或范式组成。实际上，所有科学都是一个范式系统，其特点是科学方法、逻辑连贯性和观察者的独立性。数学的概念基础比科学的概念基础更容易证明，因为在科学中，我们相信我们所研究的东西是真实的。但是，科学和数学一样，没有技术概念语言就无法发挥作用。

Science too consists of a series of conceptual systems or paradigms. Actually all of science is one paradigmatic system characterized by features such as the scientific method, logical coherence, and independence of the observer. It is easier to make the case for the conceptual foundations of mathematics than of science because in science we believe that what we are studying is real. But science, no less than mathematics, does not work without a technical conceptual language.

每一个数学和科学概念系统都可以用来进行计算iv。事实上，这是此类计算的主要目标之一系统——将研究简化为常规计算。掌握牛顿运动定律后，您就可以进行计算，从而将火箭送上月球。因此，即使系统可以有限地呈现（作为一组公理或原理），它也可以支持一组潜在的无限计算。甚至有人相信存在一种“终极”科学理论，即一个可以描述所有物理过程的有限概念系统。在这样的系统中，所有现象都将由系统元素产生的一系列计算产生。

Every mathematical and scientific conceptual system can be used to make computationsiv. In fact this is one of the main objectives of such systems—to reduce investigations to routine computations. Once you have Newton’s laws of motion you can perform the calculations that enable you to send a rocket to the moon. So even though the system can be finitely presented (as set of axioms or principles) it can support a potentially infinite set of computations. There are even people who believe in the possibility of an “ultimate” scientific theory, that is, a finite conceptual system that will describe all physical processes. In such a system all phenomena will be produced by a series of computations arising from the elements of the system.

如果没有这样的概念系统，我们就无法进行数学或科学研究，在科学中，这种概念系统更可能被称为范式。实际上，至少有两种不同的“进行”数学和科学研究的模式。第一种涉及在固定范式内工作，第二种涉及用一个范式替换另一个范式。前一种情况下的主导思维模式包括连续的分析性思维。后者涉及深度思考，但我们可以通过研究两者之间的区别来获得一些关于深度思考的信息。范式的存在对我们有什么作用？范式是一种与世界互动的方式。我们只能通过范式的镜头“看”。它带来了一种特定的世界观，但同时也限制了我们所能看到的，因为它必然排除了其他观点。它不可避免地突出了现实的某些方面，同时隐藏了其他方面。这就像透过玫瑰色的眼镜看东西。色调来自眼镜，而不是来自场景。但即使我们承认这一点并试图解释它，我们描述“客观”情况的能力仍然存在内在的局限性，客观情况是一种并不真正存在的抽象概念。现实世界与观察它的视角密切相关，最终是密不可分的。

We cannot do mathematics or science without such a conceptual system, which in science is more likely to be called a paradigm. Actually there are (at least) two distinct modes of “doing” mathematics and science. The first involves working within a fixed paradigm and the second involves replacing one paradigm by another. The dominant mode of thinking in the former situation consists of continuous, analytic thought. The latter involves deep thinking but we can get some information about deep thinking by investigating the distinction between the two. What does the existence of a paradigm do for us? A paradigm is a way of interacting with the world. We can only “see” through the lens of a paradigm. It brings a particular viewpoint of the world into existence but simultaneously limits what we can see since it necessarily excludes other viewpoints. It inevitably highlights certain aspects of reality while hiding others. It is like looking through rose-colored glasses. The hue comes from the glasses and not from the scene. But even if we acknowledge this and attempt to account for it, there remain intrinsic limitations to our ability to describe the “objective” situation, which is an abstraction that does not really exist. The real world is intimately tied to, and ultimately is inseparable from, the lens through which it is viewed.

概念系统的不可或缺性非常重要，但这一事实并不总是被人们所重视。首先，由于概念系统并不完全客观，它们所支持的科学或数学理论也不完全客观。概念系统本质上会发生变化和发展。因此，数学和科学都不是永恒不变的真理。

The indispensability of conceptual systems is of deep importance, a fact that is not always appreciated. For one thing, since conceptual systems are not totally objective neither are the scientific or mathematical theories that they support. Conceptual systems by their very nature are subject to change and development. It follows that neither mathematics nor science deals in permanent and unchanging truth.

我们不能声称我们在科学中体验和研究的现实与科学家的思想无关。我们声称数学和科学结果的客观性是相对的客观性。数学世界的无可争辩的现实包括我们的内部概念和心理模型，这些概念和心理模型是通过复杂的社会过程实现客观的。建立了这样一个系统后，就可以说某些命题相对于这个系统是真还是假。

We cannot claim that the reality that we experience and work with in science is independent of the mind of the scientist. The objectivity that we claim for mathematical and scientific results is a relative objectivity. The incontestable reality of the mathematical world consists of our internal concepts and mental models that are made objective by a complex social process. Having established such a system it becomes possible to say that certain propositions are true or false relative to this system.

所谓范式转变的深层思考是一个非常基本的过程。我们很难理解这种转变，因为我们从 CS 2（更精细的思想体系）的角度来看待它们，并错误地认为理性可以“捕捉”产生这种转变的革命性思想。这种“解释”是事后对变化的合理化。要正确思考这种概念变化，我们必须将自己置于更基本的系统中，从这个角度来看，这种变化是彻底的、不可想象的。

The deep thinking that goes by the name of paradigm change is an extremely basic process. We have difficulty understanding such changes because we look at them from the standpoint of CS2, the more refined system of thought, and erroneously imagine that reason can “capture” the revolutionary thought that produced the change. Such “explanations” are after-the-fact rationalizations of change. To think properly about such conceptual changes we must place ourselves in the more elementary system from which vantage point the change is radical and unthinkable.

2.8结论：深度思考、概念变革和技术

2.8Conclusion: Deep Thinking, Conceptual Change, and Technology

我将在本章的最后讨论与技术变革相关的深度思考的特征。至关重要的是，我们当然应该将技术变革视为概念变革——从一个概念系统到另一个概念系统的转变。与任何其他创造性努力一样，这需要深度思考。深度思考的结果不仅是一件硬件或软件，而是一种系统的世界观。同样，关键是要仔细区分过程——深度思考——和从该过程中产生的技术。记住这一点，我们可以列出深度思考的特征清单，看看它们是否适用于技术变革的例子。

I shall end this chapter by discussing the characteristics of deep thinking in relation to technological change. The crucial thing is surely that we should approach technological change as conceptual change — the movement from one conceptual system to another. Like any other creative endeavor this involves deep thinking. The result of deep thinking is not only a piece of hardware or software but a systematic way of looking at the world. Again the essential thing is to distinguish carefully between the process—deep thinking—and the technology that arises from the process. With this comment in mind we can run down the list of characteristics of deep thinking and see that they apply to examples of technological change.

深度思考是自然的，因此创新反映了人类的基本状况。现代技术工作中经常伴随的兴奋反映了创新过程触及人类精神的深刻之处。适应技术变革初期的迷茫感可以看作是一次机会，让我们突破对特定技术文化的认同，拥抱一种以持续变革为特征的新文化。奇怪的是，这意味着回归一种更基本的生存模式。

Deep thinking is natural and as a consequence innovation reflects something basic in the human condition. The excitement that often accompanies work in modern technology is a reflection that the process of innovation touches something profound in the human spirit. The sense of disorientation that characterizes the early stages of adaptation to technological change may be viewed as an opportunity to break through our identification with a particular technological culture and embrace a new kind of culture characterized by continuous change. In a strange way this would mean returning to a more basic mode of being.

技术变革是不连续的、艰难的。它是一种彻底的变革，因为它迫使人们以不同的方式对待世界，也就是说，它改变了经验世界。当我们将新技术引入学校和其他社会机构时，我们必须意识到这一点，做好准备，并以适当的方式引入它。人们正在寻找一种突然的洞察力——一种重新构建。它是突然出现的，而不是渐进的，所以引入新技术的问题与我将在后面的章节中讨论的教授和学习新概念系统的问题有很多共同之处。

Technological change is discontinuous and difficult. It is a radical change in that it forces people to deal with the world in a different way, that is, it changes the world of experience. When we introduce new technologies into schools and other social institutions we must be aware of this, prepare for it, and introduce it in an appropriate way. One is looking for a sudden insight—a reframing. It arrives suddenly and not incrementally so the problem of introducing new technology has much in common with the problem of teaching and learning new conceptual systems that I shall discuss in subsequent chapters.

不确定性指的是创新的过程。它是重新回到绘图板上，在没有任何先入之见的情况下（至少尽可能少地）仔细思考事物的不确定性。“如果我们这样想会怎么样？”是人们可能会问的一种生成性问题。

Uncertainty refers to the process of innovation. It is the uncertainty of going back to the drawing board and thinking things through with no preconceptions or, at least, as few as possible. “What if we thought about it this way?” is the kind of generative question that one might ask.

不完整性指的是最终结果永远不会完美地实现你所希望实现的目标。任何过程中总会有小问题，但更根本的是，我们必须始终牢记这项技术的优点和局限性。当人们与“智能”计算机系统互动时，这一点非常明显，但在我们开始采用无人驾驶汽车之前，这也是需要考虑的问题。

Incompleteness refers to the end result, which never accomplishes perfectly what you hoped it would accomplish. There are always glitches in any process but more fundamentally one must always bear in mind what the technology is good at and what its limitations are. This is very clear when one interacts with an “intelligent” computer system but it is also something to be considered before we all start adopting driverless automobiles.

在任何技术情况下，人类问题与将问题转化为新技术的方式之间总是存在基本的模糊性。人类的基本问题（如研究智力和思考）可以转化为人工智能问题，但代价是问题发生质变。人类问题是开放式的，除非是人类状况本身，否则没有明确的答案，但技术问题可以有许多有趣的答案，尽管是部分的。

There is always a basic ambiguity in any technological situation between the human problem and the way that problem is translated into the new technology. Basic human problems like investigating intelligence and thinking can be translated into a problem in artificial intelligence but only at the cost of making a qualitative change in the problem. The human problem is open-ended and has no definitive answer unless it is the human condition itself but the technological question can have many interesting, albeit partial, answers.

技术系统也是层级化的——它们相互依存——因此从当前情况回顾过去，变化似乎是连续的。但我们只需考虑任意数量的创新思维的例子，让我们意识到突破总是出乎意料。给人以持续发展印象的整合发生在事后。有了新技术后，我们会思考我们可以用它做的所有很酷的事情，以及我们现在用不同方式做的所有事情，我们可以用新技术做得更好。

Technological systems are also hierarchical—they build upon one another—and so change looks continuous when looking backwards from the present situation. But we have only to think of any number of instances of innovative thinking to realize that breakthroughs always come as a surprise. The integration that gives the impression of continuous development happens after the fact. After we have the new technology we think about all the cool things we can do with it and all the things that we now do in a different way that we could do better with the new technology.

系统思维发生在系统内部，因此新技术催生了新的做事方式。调整新软件以使其在新的环境中工作与最初创建软件之间存在质的差异。大多数问题解决都涉及将已知技术应用于新情况。真正创新的解决方案需要重新构建情况。公司必须问自己正在寻找什么样的问题解决方案。如果其目标是鼓励深度思考和真正的创造力，那么它需要适当地组织自己。自上而下的等级管理结构不太可能培养创造力。管理层必须愿意放弃绝对控制权，但首先必须承认系统思考和深度思考之间的差异，并决定培养后者。

Systematic thinking happens within the system so a new technology spawns new ways of doing things. There is a qualitative difference between work that is done in tweaking a new piece of software so that it works in a new environment and creating the software in the first place. Most problem solving involves applying known techniques to new situations. A truly innovative solution involves reframing the situation. A company must ask itself what kind of problem solving it is looking for. If its objective is to encourage deep thinking and true creativity then it needs to organize itself appropriately. Hierarchical, top-down management structure is not likely to foster creativity. Management must be willing to relinquish absolute control but first it must acknowledge the difference between systematic and deep thought and make a decision to foster the latter.

最后，这里存在一个悖论，这是当前情况的基本悖论。技术总是试图复制智能和深度思考的某些方面。当然，任何概念系统都是如此。尽管有些尝试非常出色，但这种尝试注定会失败。当我们对一些出色的技术创新感到惊讶时，这总是因为它以不可思议的方式复制甚至似乎超越了某些人类活动或心理过程。但封闭系统永远无法捕捉深度思考的根本开放性，原因很简单，一旦它被具体化，就会受到限制。这可以用一句格言来概括：“人工智能不是（也不可能是）智能的。”或者，“真实不是人造的，人造的不是真实的。”

Finally, there is a paradox here that is basic to what is going on. Technology is always attempting to replicate aspects of intelligence and deep thinking. Of course this could be said of any conceptual system. And this attempt is always doomed to fail in an absolute sense even though some of the attempts are extraordinary. When we are amazed by some brilliant technological innovation it is invariably because of the uncanny way it replicates and may even seem to exceed certain human activities or mental processes. But closed systems can never capture the fundamental openness of deep thinking for the simple reason that once it is reified it is constrained. This could be summarized by the aphorism “artificial intelligence is not (and cannot be) intelligent.” Or else, “The real is not artificial and the artificial is not real.”

我 Byers (2011) 第 107 页。

i Byers (2011) p. 107.

ii正如 Albert Low 向我指出的那样。

ii As has been pointed out to me by Albert Low.

iii Hersh（2014 年）。

iii Hersh (2014).

iv我将在全书中给出许多科学概念系统的具体例子——“计数数”或分数是两个最基本的概念系统。

iv I shall give many concrete examples of conceptual systems in science throughout the book—the “counting numbers” or the fractions are two of the most elementary conceptual systems.

第三章

Chapter 3

数学和科学的深度思考

Deep Thinking in Mathematics and Science

3.1介绍

3.1Introduction

第二章指出，只要一个概念系统被另一个概念系统取代，就会出现深度思考——在儿童发展、“数字”的阐述、科学和技术发展中。深度思考是数学和科学思维中不可或缺的元素，这一事实将促使人们重新审视这些学科的本质。

Chapter two made the point that deep thinking is present whenever one conceptual system is replaced by another—in child development, in the elaboration of “number,” in science, and in the development of technology. The fact that deep thinking is an irreducible element of mathematical and scientific thought will precipitate a reexamination of the nature of these disciplines.

在本章中，我将探讨 Carey 及其同事所明确阐述的数学和科学的历史发展与发展和学习之间的类比。我已经讨论了将整数和有理数等数字系统视为概念系统的含义。在本章中，我将继续讨论数学和科学史上的其他著名事件。当然，我将要讨论的数学和科学并没有什么新意，但我所采取的观点有些不同寻常。

In this chapter I consider the analogy, which is already explicit in Carey and her colleagues, between the historical development of mathematics and science, on the one hand, and development and learning, on the other. I have already discussed what it means to consider number systems such as the integers and the rational numbers as conceptual systems. In this chapter I go on to discuss other famous episodes from the history of mathematics and science. Of course there is nothing new about the mathematics and the science I shall discuss but there is something unusual in the perspective that I take.

这一观点已在第二章中概述。范式转换必然涉及不连续的跳跃。现实是独一无二的，每个范式都唤起自己的现实。这就是为什么科学范式的改变不会没有大量的冲突；这就是为什么深度思考如此困难，需要克服个人和整个文化中如此多的阻力。事实上，有人说科学家永远不会真正放弃她所受过的训练范式。发生的事情是新一代成长起来在新的范式中，老一代退休或消亡。研究人员大部分时间都在一个不变的概念系统中进行连续的计算。

This perspective was sketched out in the chapter two. Paradigm change necessarily involves a discontinuous jump. Reality is singular and each paradigm evokes its own reality. This is the reason that scientific paradigms are not changed without a great deal of conflict; the reason why deep thinking is so difficult and involves overcoming so much resistance both in the individual and in the larger culture. In fact it has been said that a scientist never really gives up the paradigm within which she has been trained. What happens is that a new generation grows up within a new paradigm and the old generation retires or dies offi. For the most part the researcher spends her time making continuous computations within an unchanging conceptual system.

概念系统不可避免地与特定的思维方式相关联。数学和科学涉及不同的思维模式，其中深度思维是最困难、最根本、最重要的。本书的一个主要主题是这些不同的思维模式及其之间的关系。我在前面的章节中讨论连续计算思维和非连续深度思维各自的作用时已经提到了这一点。在本章的最后，我们将看到，这种区别对于解决一个重要问题至关重要，即逻辑推理的正确作用，以及作为推论的计算与思维之间的关系。

A conceptual system is inevitably associated with a particular way of thinking. Mathematics and science involve different modes of thinking of which deep thinking is the most difficult, radical, and important. A major topic in this book is these different modes of thinking and the relationship between them. I have already alluded to this in the previous chapters when I discussed the respective roles of continuous, computational thinking and discontinuous, deep thinking. At the end of the chapter we shall see that this distinction is crucial for tackling an important problem, namely, the proper role of logical inference and, as a corollary, the relation between computation and thought.

逻辑演绎思维在某些情况下是合适的，但在其他情况下则不适用。人们在概念系统中使用思维的方式与从一个系统跳到另一个系统时使用思维的方式不同。前者是传统意义上的逻辑，而后者是非逻辑的。这对我们思考科学和数学的方式来说是一个巨大的改变。它使普通逻辑（我们在系统中使用的语言的一部分）变得相对，而不是超越所有系统的绝对真理。

Logical deductive thinking is appropriate in some situations but not in others. The way one uses the mind within a conceptual system is not the same as the way one uses it when one makes the leap from one system to another. The former is logical in the classical sense whereas the latter is strongly non-logical. This is a huge change for the way we think of science and mathematics. It makes ordinary logic relative—part of the language that we use within a system—not an absolute truth that stands outside all systems.

3.2日心说还是地心说？

3.2Heliocentric or Geocentric?

我首先要问的是，是地球还是太阳位于宇宙的中心，因为在这里，我所说的概念系统创造了一个世界，几乎可以从字面上理解。所有人类文化都有一种神话，描述他们在宇宙中的位置。我们将会看到，宇宙的地理中心尤其令人感兴趣，因为中心的位置为整个文化提供了方向。这里我们讨论三种可能性：（1）地心说——地球位于中心；（2）日心说——太阳位于中心；（3）没有地理中心。我们可能会问，“哪一种可能性是正确的？”但是，当我们将它们视为三个不同的概念系统时，我们应该问，“每个世界的属性、优点和缺点是什么我们并不问哪个观点正确，哪个观点错误，而是问认同某个观点意味着什么。事实上，这三个概念体系构成了现代文化发展的主要阶段。

I begin with the question of whether the earth or the sun is at the center of the cosmos because here my comment that a conceptual system creates a world can almost be taken literally. All human cultures have a mythology that describes their place within the cosmos. Of particular interest, as we shall see, is the geographical center of that cosmos, for the location of the center provides an orientation for the entire culture. Here we discuss three possibilities: (1) geocentric—the earth at the center; (2) heliocentric—the sun at the center; and (3) no geographical center. We might ask, “Which one of these possibilities is true?” But when we think of them as three different conceptual systems we should rather ask, “What are the properties, advantages, and disadvantages of each world view?” We don’t ask which is true and which is false so much as we ask about the implications of subscribing to one view or another. In fact, these three conceptual systems constitute major stages in the development of modern culture.

今天我们会说，地球和太阳都不是宇宙的中心——宇宙没有中心。从这个意义上说，地心说和日心说都是错误的。但从另一个意义上说，两者都不是错误的。当人们为某些情况建立数学模型时，通常需要建立一个坐标系，通常是相互垂直的x、y和z轴。三个轴的交点就是原点。从某种意义上说，原点的选择是任意的——任何一点都可以。你选择一个特定的原点是为了尽可能简化结果方程。从这个角度来看，选择地球还是太阳作为太阳系的中心并不重要。任何一个都会给你一个坐标系，你可以用它来描述行星的运动。这并不是说这两个系统没有区别。在地心系统中，地球是固定的，但行星的轨道相当复杂。在日心系统中，包括地球在内的所有行星都处于平等地位。它们的轨道都是椭圆形，其中一个焦点是太阳。这方便了计算，而在托勒密的旧地心系统中，计算是出了名的困难。这也使得将太阳系概念化为一个实体、将其视为一个系统变得更加容易。

Today we would say that neither the earth nor the sun is at the center of the cosmos—the cosmos has no center. In this sense both the geocentric and the heliocentric theories are false. But in another sense neither is false. When one makes a mathematical model of certain situations it is often necessary to set up a system of coordinates, normally the mutually perpendicular x-, y-, and z-axes. The intersection of the three axes is the origin. In a sense the choice of the origin is arbitrary—any point would do. You pick a particular origin so as to simplify the resulting equations as much as possible. From this point of view whether you pick the earth or the sun to be the centre of the solar system is not important. Either one will give you a coordinate system relative to which you can describe the motion of the planets. This is not to say that there is no difference between the two systems. In the geocentric system the earth is fixed but the orbits of the planets are quite complicated. In the heliocentric system all of the planets, including the earth, stand on an equal footing. Their orbits are all ellipses, one of whose foci is the sun. This facilitates computations, which are notoriously difficult in the old geocentric system of Ptolemy. It also makes it easier to conceptualize the solar system as one entity, to think of it as one system.

那么，从地心说转向日心说会失去什么呢？失去的是中世纪“人是万物的尺度”这一观念（普罗泰戈拉，公元前 480-411 年）。这是西方文化开始发生转变的开始，人类从按照上帝的形象被创造，因此处于创造的中心，转变为更加边缘的位置。地心说不仅使人类更接近宇宙的中心，而且更接近人类的日常体验。我们看到太阳从东方升起，在西方落下。这种宇宙模型与感官证据更加一致。

What, then, is lost by going from the geocentric to the heliocentric? What is lost is the medieval idea that “man is the measure of all things” (Protagoras 480–411 BCE). It is the beginning of a change in Western culture in which man moves from being created in the image of God, and so residing at the centre of creation, to a position which is further towards the periphery. The geocentric system not only situates human beings closer to the center of the universe but is also closer to everyday human experience. We see the sun rise in the east and set in the west. This model of the cosmos is then more consistent with the evidence of the senses.

你可以说，有两种可能的方式来看待我们与世界的关系。第一种是，人类是宇宙的中心，其他一切都从中获得意义和相关性。一是地球与我们的关系。二是我们是边缘的、微不足道的。从以地球为中心到以太阳为中心的运动是一种远离人类作为创造中心的运动。但这是一种中间立场，因为现代观点认为人类、地球、太阳，甚至我们所处的特定星系都没有什么特别之处。我们已经从强调人类独特性的宗教体系转向了人类没有什么特别之处的科学体系。

You could say that there are two possible ways of viewing our relationship to the world. The first is that human beings are at the center of the universe and everything else gets its meaning and relevance from its relation to us. The second is that we are peripheral and insignificant. The movement from being earth-centered to being sun-centered is a movement away from the human being as the center of creation. But it is an intermediate position because the modern view is that there is nothing special about human beings, the earth, the sun, or even the particular galaxy that we find ourselves in. We have moved from a religious system, which emphasized the uniqueness of human beings, to the scientific system where there is nothing special about mankind.

现在，很可能“中心”根本没有地理位置，但这并不意味着它不存在。“中心化”是一种非常普遍的趋势，人们可以在各种各样的情况下辨别出来。我们可以把它看作是对方向的需要，而概念系统提供的正是这种方向。这也是概念系统如此基本的另一个原因。人类对理解的需求可以从对方向的需求中看出。例如，当你不理解一个数字系统时，它似乎是由任意事实和难以理解的规则组成的，这些规则没有内在逻辑，必须死记硬背。当你理解一个数学系统时，一切都会不可避免地结合在一起——一切都非常有意义，你不记得的事实可以当场解决。现在，你对这个概念宇宙有了强烈的定位感。

Now it may well be that the “center” does not have a geographical position at all but this does not mean that it does not exist. “Centering” is a very general tendency that one can discern in a vast variety of circumstances. We can think of it as the need for an orientation, which is what a conceptual system provides. This is another reason why conceptual systems are so basic. Human beings’ need for understanding can be seen in the need to be oriented. When you do not understand a number system, for example, it seems to be made up of arbitrary facts and incomprehensible rules that have no inner logic and must be mastered by rote. When you do understand a mathematical system then it all fits together in an inevitable way—it all makes perfect sense and facts that you do not recall can be worked out on the spot. You now possess a strong sense of being well oriented within this conceptual universe.

这种对定位系统的需求是人类的基本需求。因此，所有人类社会都发展出了以自我为“中心”的方式，以及代表中心的符号。宗教哲学家米尔恰·伊利亚德 (Mircea Eliade) 颇有建树地指出了这一点ii。人类对中心的需求解释了美国总统、体育偶像和电影明星的社会和文化角色。它解释了人们对国旗或国歌等符号的依恋。对于许多人来说，对外在的、物理中心的需求已经消失，但如果这确实是一种基本需求，那么它去了哪里？现代化对中心需求做了什么？要正确回答这个问题需要的篇幅比我在这里提供的要多。我将仅限于作家艾伯特·洛的评论，他说：“在过去，人类使用了许多不同的方式来确保一个定位点或中心，……最初的焦点是在“外面”：一棵神圣的树，一根图腾柱，一面旗帜，一块岩石，一个偶像，这些在过去都曾作为一个中心，一个基本定位点，围绕这个定位点，我们就可以构建我们所知的经验和存在。如今，我们已经将中心内化，并称之为“我”。iii我们经常听到人们谈论“以中心为中心”的可取性，这无非意味着在我们自己内部找到一个中心——在我们一生中构建的自我和个性中。因此，对个人中心的需求仍然存在，但现代科学文化认为没有必要将这个中心定位在地理上。

This need for a system of orientation is a fundamental human need. As a result all human societies have developed ways of “centering” themselves and symbols that represent the center. The philosopher of religion, Mircea Eliade, points this out quite eloquentlyii. This human need for a center explains the social and cultural role of the President of the United States, of sports idols and movie stars. It explains people’s attachment to symbols like the national flag or anthem. For many people the need for an external, physical centre has dissipated but if it is indeed a basic need then where has it gone? What has modernity done with the need for a center? To answer this question properly would take more space than is available to me here. I will restrict myself to a comment by the writer Albert Low who says, “In the past human beings have used many different ways of ensuring an orientation point or center, … Originally the point of focus was “outside”: a sacred tree, a totem pole, a flag, a rock, an idol, each of these has in the past served as a center, a basic orientation point around which to structure what we know as experience and existence. Nowadays we have introjected the center and call it ‘I’.”iii We often hear talk about the desirability of “being centered,” and this can mean nothing other than finding a center within ourselves— in the self and personality that we construct over a lifetime. Thus the need for a personal center continues to exist but modern scientific culture sees no need to locate this centre geographically.

无论如何，我们可以看出，我们看待宇宙的概念体系对个人和文化有着深远的影响。地心说、日心说或无物理中心说代表了三种截然不同的生活方式。随着科学世界观的主导地位，外部中心的丧失很可能导致了现代世界普遍存在的疏离、焦虑和普遍焦虑。

Be that as it may we can see that the conceptual system through which we view the cosmos has profound implications for individuals and cultures. Geo-centered, helio-centered, or without a physical center represent three profoundly different ways of living in the world. The loss of an external center, which comes about with the dominance of the scientific worldview, may well have contributed to the alienation, anxiety, and general angst that are so common in the modern world.

3.3欧几里得几何和非欧几里得几何

3.3Euclidean and Non-Euclidean Geometry

欧几里得几何在人类文化史上具有极其重要的意义。它有时被描述为一个公理化的、演绎的系统，事实上，以这种方式组织知识体系非常重要。然而，这只是更重要和基本的一部分，即欧几里得几何是一个概念系统。我之前的评论是，概念系统创造了一个世界，这完美地说明了这一点。欧几里得几何不是空间模型——这是一种现代的看法——欧几里得几何定义了空间。它代表了我们对二维和三维空间的体验。现在这个说法并不完全正确，因为欧几里得线没有宽度，可以延伸到无穷远，所以更准确地说，欧几里得几何是我们对空间体验的理想化。几代人都相信这种理想化，相信它包含一个绝对客观的真理。事实上，这是相信数学系统准确地捕捉现实世界的起源之一，甚至相信现实本身从根本上就是数学的。从我的角度来看，这正是大型概念系统确实如此——它们定义了对于认同它们的文化而言什么是真实的。

Euclidean geometry is hugely important in the cultural history of mankind. It is sometimes presented as merely an axiomatic, deductive system and, indeed, it is of great importance that a body of knowledge could be organized in this way. However this is only part of something that is even more important and basic, namely, that Euclidean geometry is a conceptual system. My earlier comment that a conceptual system creates a world is perfectly illustrated by this. Euclidean geometry is not a model of space—that is a modern way of looking at it—Euclidean geometry defines space. It represents our experience of two and three-dimensional space. Now this statement is not precisely true because Euclidean lines have no width and are extendable to infinity so it would be more accurate to say that Euclidean geometry is an idealization of our experience of space. For generations people believed in this idealization, believed that it contained a truth that was absolute and objective. In fact this is one of the origins of the belief that mathematical systems accurately capture the real world, even that reality itself is fundamentally mathematical. From my point of view this is just what large conceptual systems do—they define what is real for the cultures that subscribe to them.

我不会重复我在其他地方写过的关于欧几里得几何和非欧几里得革命的内容。我只想快速总结一下我们可以从思想史上的这个事件中学到什么。非欧几里得几何被接受为与欧几里得几何同等合法的数学理论涉及从一个概念系统到另一个概念系统的转变。这一运动涉及两种截然不同的世界观。第一个世界 CS 1显然是欧几里得世界，但第二个世界 CS 2并非人们所期望的非欧几里得世界。相反，它是一个由欧几里得空间模型和非欧几里得空间模型组成的世界。

I shall not repeat what I have written elsewhereiv about Euclidean geometry and the non-Euclidean revolution. I shall just summarize quickly what we can learn from this episode in intellectual history. The acceptance of non-Euclidean geometries as legitimate mathematical theories on a par with Euclidean geometry involved the movement from one conceptual system to another. This movement involved two radically different ways of viewing the world. The first of these worlds, CS1, is obviously the Euclidean one but the second, CS2, is not the Non-Euclidean as one might expect. Rather it is a world consisting of both Euclidean and Non-Euclidean models for space.

从 CS 1到 CS 2 的过渡总是困难且不连续的。在这种情况下，这一过渡花费了数千年的时间，因为欧几里得世界在西方文化中根深蒂固。这一过渡的困难之处体现在这样一个事实：当时最杰出的数学家高斯预见了非欧几里得革命，但没有发表他的发现，因为他担心必然会引发争议。他是对的，结果确实存在争议，但他没有充分认识到世界已经为这种观点的转变做好了准备。

The transition from CS1 to CS2 is always difficult and discontinuous. In this case it took thousands of years to make this transition because the Euclidean world was so deeply entrenched in Western culture. The difficulty of the transition is illustrated by the fact that Gauss, the preeminent mathematician of his day, anticipated the Non-Euclidean revolution but did not publish his findings for fear of the controversy that he was sure would follow. He was right, the results were indeed controversial but he did not sufficiently appreciate how ripe the world was for this change of viewpoint.

概念系统发生重大转变，例如这种转变，总是会带来巨大的后果，而这些后果是数学家们无法预料的，​​他们以为这些转变只是在质疑某个公理的有效性，甚至只是在创造一种新的几何理论。从非常真实的意义上讲，这场革命创造了现代数学的世界——形式主义的世界。这个世界的一个重要方面，现在凸显出来了，就是数学与其逻辑结构的认同。几何学不仅不再与空间认同，而是成为空间模型，而且所有数学理论都成为物理情况的潜在模型。甚至对潜在应用的需求也减弱了，因此现在出现了为数学而数学的可能性——一种新的“纯”数学。数学的本体论地位发生了转变，现实被进一步推后。因此，真理的含义发生了根本性的变化，这一点将在下文讨论例如特鲁多的《非欧几里得革命》一书的最后一章。v

Major shifts in conceptual systems like this one always carry with them huge consequences that could not have been anticipated by the mathematicians who supposed that they were merely questioning the validity of a particular axiom or even creating a new geometrical theory. In a very real sense this revolution created the world of modern mathematics—the world of formalism. An important aspect of this world, which now came to the fore, was the identification of mathematics with its logical structure. Not only does geometry cease being identified with space and become instead a model of space but also all mathematical theories become potential models of physical situations. Even the need for potential applications gets attenuated so that now there arises the possibility of mathematics for mathematics’ sake—a new kind of “pure” mathematics. There is a shift in the ontological status of mathematics in which reality gets pushed further back. It follows that there is a radical change in the very meaning of truth, which is discussed for example in the final chapter of the book by Trudeau on The Non-Euclidean Revolution.v

这进一步证明了概念系统的发展是分层次的，正如我们在数字系统中看到的那样，而不仅仅是从一种理论转移到另一种不相关的理论。这是我的论点的重要证据，即你不能同时坚持两个这样的概念系统。正如我上面所说，在第一个系统中，空间是欧几里得的；在第二个系统中，不同的几何是空间模型，它们作为数学理论同样有效，并且可能都适用于某些空间情况。今天当我们回顾过去时，我们会认为所发生的事情只是通过调整平行公设而发明了另一个几何系统。我们常常没有意识到这种变化有多么具有革命性，因为我们是从概念系统 CS 2的角度来看待这个问题的。从 CS 1的角度来看——欧几里得世界中的欧几里得几何——任何一组公理都能产生合法数学的“相对”世界简直是不可想象的。如果不了解 CS 1和 CS 2的不兼容性，那么就会错过情况的本质。

This is more evidence that the development of conceptual systems is hierarchical, as we saw was true of number systems, and not merely the shift from one theory to another unconnected theory. This is important evidence for my thesis that you cannot simultaneously hold to two such conceptual systems. As I said above in the first system space is Euclidean; in the second different geometries are models of space that are equally valid as mathematical theories and may all have valid applications to certain spatial situations. Today when we look back we think that all that happened was the invention of another geometrical system by tweaking the parallel postulate. We often do not appreciate how revolutionary the change was because we are viewing the matter from the perspective of the conceptual system, CS2. From the perspective of CS1—Euclidean geometry in a Euclidean world—the “relative” world where any arbitrary set of axioms produces legitimate mathematics is simply inconceivable. If one does not grasp the incompatibility of CS1 and CS2 then one misses the essence of the situation.

3.4数字系统

3.4Number Systems

在第一章中，我写了关于数字的概念。我讨论了数字的两个核心系统和两个学习系统——计数数字和分数。我将计数数字和分数视为概念系统，并特别有兴趣从其中一个系统从早期系统发展而来的方式中抽象出深度思考的某些基本属性。现在，我将扩展数字概念系统的范围，看看是否可以在这些新系统中找到相同的“深度”属性。

In chapter one I wrote about the concept of number. I discussed two core systems for number and two learned systems—the counting numbers and fractions. I viewed the counting numbers and fractions as conceptual systems and was especially interested in abstracting certain basic properties of deep thinking from the way in which one of these systems developed from an earlier one. Now I shall expand the repertoire of conceptual systems for number and see if the same “deep” properties can be found in these new systems.

3.5 整数

3.5 Integers

在第一章中，我讨论了从计数到分数的过渡。分数是计数的自然发展，但数字的发展也可以朝另一个方向发展，即通过引入负整数：-1、-2、-3…… ，从计数数字到整数。（正整数和负整数）本身就形成了一个概念系统。“除法是数字吗？”这个问题让我们从计数数字转向了分数。这里类似的问题是，“减法是数字吗？”同样，这一点并不明显。例如，减去3是一个可以在计数系统中完成的计算，而不需要将-3变成一个数字。后来，当灯亮起，你看到 -3 实际上是一个数字时，你就进入了一个新的概念系统。当这种情况发生时，-3从仅仅是一个计算变成了具有模糊状态（作为过程和对象）。在这个阶段，它成为一个数学实体，可以交替地被视为计数数字的计算，或者被视为存在于另一个概念系统中的新数字，一个新的概念对象。

In the first chapter I discussed the transition from counting numbers to fractions. Fractions are a natural development of the counting numbers but the development of number can also proceed in another direction and that is from the counting numbers to the integers through the introduction of the negative integers: -1, -2, -3, … . The (positive and negative) integers form a conceptual system in their own right. “Is division a number?” was the question that got us from the counting numbers to fractions. Here the analogous question is, “Is subtraction a number?” Again this is not at all obvious. Subtracting 3, for example, is a computation that can be done within the system of counting numbers without the need of making -3 into a number in its own right. Later on, when a light goes on and you see that -3 is actually a number, you are in a new conceptual system. When this happens -3 goes from being just a computation to having an ambiguous status (as process and object). At this stage it becomes one mathematical entity which can be viewed alternatively as a computation over the counting numbers or else as a new variety of number, a new conceptual object, that lives within another conceptual system.

整数的世界与计数的世界有着本质的不同，这一点可以通过乘法过程来证明。每个人都知道2 × 3 = 6。如果问为什么，大多数人可能会指出乘法是面积或重复加法。然而，大多数孩子和许多成年人对负数的乘积有问题，例如−2 × −3 = +6。他们接受了它，但这让他们有点不舒服；他们并不真正理解它。原因是它们在一定程度上仍停留在计数数字的概念系统和在其中执行的计算中。因为负数似乎与计数数字非常相似，所以我们倾向于以旧的方式处理它们，并增加一些新的规则，例如“减乘以减等于加”，这些规则是死记硬背的。即使是数学老师也常常忘记整数对孩子来说是一个新的概念系统，从一个系统过渡到另一个系统必然很困难。记住“规则”似乎很有吸引力，因为它可以掩盖困难。它有其存在的意义，但肯定不能取代概念上的改变。最终，人们必须处理诸如负整数乘法之类的问题。

The world of integers is qualitatively different than the world of counting numbers and this can be demonstrated by considering the process of multiplication. Everyone knows that 2 × 3 = 6 . If asked why, most people would likely point to multiplication as area or as repeated addition. However, most children and many adults have a problem with the product of negative numbers, such as −2 × −3 = +6 . They accept it but it makes them a little uncomfortable; they don’t really understand it. The reason for this is that they remain to a certain extent within the conceptual system of the counting numbers and the computations that are performed within it. Because the negative numbers seem to be very similar to the counting numbers we tend to handle them in the old way, with the addition of a few new rules, such as “minus times minus equals plus,” which are learned by rote. Even mathematics teachers often forget that the integers are a new conceptual system for the child and that the transition from one system to another is necessarily hard. Memorizing “rules” seems to be attractive to the extent that it obscures the difficulty. It has its place, but certainly does not replace conceptual change. Eventually one has to deal with things like the problematic multiplication of negative integers.

另一个问题来自于计数数字嵌入整数的方式。例如，3被等同于其自身（我们可以说计数数字3等同于整数+3，这样说更清楚，但通常+号会被隐藏）。因此，当我们谈论数字3时，我们不清楚自己处于哪个系统中。符号不明确。必须推断出适当的上下文——计数数字或整数。分数具有相同的歧义性，因为即使我们可能说3等同于3/1，但实际上我们使用符号3来指代计数数字和分数。这种歧义是计算机不喜欢的，它是整数概念系统的优点而不是缺点，我们可以预料到，每当我们从 CS 1移动到 CS 2时，就会出现这种歧义。当我们从 CS 1的角度来看待问题时，问题元素也应该被视为进行必要概念飞跃的机会。如果从建设性的角度来看待（这是优秀教学的作用），它们可能是通往对数字的新更高层次理解的潜在途径。从 CS 2的角度来看，计数数字只是整数的一个特定种类。由于整数形成了一个定义明确且逻辑连贯的系统，计数数字完美地融入了这个新的层次结构。

Another problem arises from the manner in which the counting numbers are embedded into the integers. 3, for example, is identified with itself (we could make matter clearer by saying that the counting number 3 is identified with the integer +3, but normally the + sign is suppressed). As a consequence when we speak of the number 3 it is not clear what system we are in. The notation is ambiguous. The appropriate context—counting number or integer—must be inferred. Fractions have the identical ambiguity because even though we may speak of identifying 3 with 3/1, in practice we use the notation 3 to refer both to the counting number and the fraction. This ambiguity, which is something that computers do not like, is a strength and not a weakness of the conceptual system of integers and we can expect to see such ambiguities arise whenever we move from CS1 to CS2. When we look at matters from the perspective of CS1 then the problematic elements should also be regarded as an opportunity for making a necessary conceptual leap. If viewed constructively (and this is the role of good teaching) they are potential gateways to a new and higher order understanding of number. From the perspective of CS2 a counting number is just a specific variety of integer. Since the integers form a well-defined and logically coherent system, the counting numbers are perfectly integrated into this new hierarchical structure.

然而，从 CS 1的角度来看，这两个系统是不兼容的。从历史上看，这一点很容易看出。毕竟，为什么它们被称为“负”数？显然，这是因为它们本身存在问题。它们很难概念化，因为从计数数字的角度来看，-3根本不是一个数字。这对儿童来说是一个概念问题，而且永远都是一个问题。这也是数学历史发展中出现的问题。在数学教育中，有一种表达方式“认识论障碍”来描述这种在学习情境中重复历史过程的情况。在学习和历史这两种情况下出现的障碍是类似的，正是因为它们都涉及概念系统的变化。

Nevertheless from the perspective of CS1 the two systems are incompatible. This is easy to see historically. Why, after all, were they called “negative” numbers? Clearly it is because there is something problematic about them. They are hard to conceptualize, because, from the perspective of the counting numbers -3 is not a number at all. This is, and will always remain, a conceptual problem for children. It was also a problem that arose in the historical development of mathematics. In mathematics education there is the expression “epistemological obstacle” to describe this kind of situation in which the historical process is replicated within the learning situation. The obstacle that arises in these two situations—learning and historical—are analogous precisely because they both involve a change in conceptual systems.

3.6 零

3.6 Zero

整数和分数的例子似乎表明新系统 CS2一定比旧系统CS1大得多，但恰恰相反，只需添加一个新数就可以进入一个新的概念系统。恰当的例子就是在计数数字或分数中添加零。无论哪种情况，得到的系统在质量上都与旧系统不同。在计数系统中引入零作为计算很容易，比如3 − 3。我有三个苹果，你把它们全部拿走，结果就没有苹果了。这没问题。这与将零设想为与其他计数数字同等的数字的难题非常不同。将“无为有”物化是希腊人从未完成的壮举，因为他们对这个想法感到反感。希腊人不愿意以这种方式接受零，这证明当人们从一个概念体系转向另一个概念体系时，接受零是很困难的。

The examples of the integers and the fractions might seem to indicate that the new system, CS2, must be much larger than an earlier one, CS1, but, on the contrary, it is possible to enter into a new conceptual system with the addition of just one new number. The case in point is the addition of zero to the counting numbers or the fractions. The resulting system in either case is qualitatively different than the old one. It is easy to introduce zero as a computation in the system of counting numbers, say 3 − 3. I have three apples and you take them all away and, as a result, there are no apples left. No problem here. This is very different from the difficult problem of conceiving of zero as a number on a par of with the other counting numbers. The reification of “nothing as something” was a feat that the Greeks never accomplished because they were offended by the very idea. The reluctance of the Greeks to embrace zero in this way is evidence that accepting zero is difficult in the way that we have come to expect when one shifts from one conceptual system to another.

希腊人抵制这种转变，并不是因为他们愚蠢或在某些方面有缺陷，而可能是因为他们明白这将把他们带入一个不同的概念世界，他们直觉地认为这样一个世界将与他们文化中许多有价值的信条相悖。印度数学家没有这种不情愿。正如我在《数学家如何思考》中所讨论的那样，印度文化和印度教中存在概念先例，使零的概念化更容易被接受。

The Greeks resisted the shift, not because they were stupid or deficient in some way, but perhaps because they understood that this would take them into a different conceptual world and they intuited that such a world would be at odds with many of the valued tenets of their culture. The Indian mathematicians did not have this reluctance. As I discussed in How Mathematicians Think, there were conceptual antecedents in the Indian culture and the Hindu religion that made the conceptualization of zero more acceptable.

3.7无限

3.7Infinity

无限是另一个令希腊人感到困惑的概念元素。他们通过一个有趣且富有启发性的妥协解决了这个问题。他们接受了无限过程的概念，例如，当你用一系列边数越来越多的正多边形来内切和外切一个圆时，你就可以得到任意接近圆的面积。圆。你可以用这个过程来近似π的数值，这种“逐次逼近法”预示了微积分的基本思想。无限作为一个过程因此既用于数值又用于理论。另一方面，“无限作为一个对象”对希腊人来说是不可接受的，对数学家和哲学家来说也是如此，持续了两千年。

Infinity was another conceptual element that was problematic for the Greeks. They resolved the problem by a compromise that is interesting and instructive. They accepted the idea of an infinite process, as, for example, when you approximate a circle by inscribing and circumscribing it with a series of regular polygons with more and more sides. In the limit you can get as close as you wish to the area of the circle. You can use this process to approximate the numerical value of π and this “method of successive approximations” anticipates the fundamental idea of the calculus. Infinity as process was thus used in both numerical and theoretical ways. On the other hand “infinity as an object” was unacceptable to the Greeks and remained so to mathematicians and philosophers for two thousand years.

现在，我们可以用概念系统的语言来理解当时发生的事情。“无限作为过程”在 CS 1（希腊数学的概念世界）中是可以接受的，因为你可以把它看作是一种计算。当然，这是一种微妙的计算，但本质上是有限的。你可能会说你可以构造一个无限的圆的多边形近似序列，但在实践中，你不会同时考虑所有这些序列。大多数时候，你只使用一个“足够精细”的近似值。

We can now understand what was going on in terms of our language of conceptual systems. “Infinity as process” is something that is acceptable within CS1, the conceptual world of Greek mathematics, because you can think of it as a computation. It is a subtle computation, to be sure, but one which is essentially finite in nature. You may say that you can construct an infinite sequence of polygonal approximations to the circle but in practice you don’t think of all of them at the same time. You work with one “sufficiently fine” approximation most of the time.

然而“无限作为对象”必然需要转移到另一个概念系统，而这是一个巨大的飞跃，无论是希腊人还是后来的文化在很长一段时间内都无法实现。同样，这也有很好的理由。进步不仅仅是持续改进的情况。如果不把无限集合（这里是有理数）视为一个对象，你就无法真正发展实数。如果不这样做，你就永远无法发展实数系统、微积分、微分方程，因此也无法发展大部分物理和工程学。然而，实现这一飞跃意味着生活在一个陌生的新世界中，这在很多方面都是非直观的。vi这些非直观的方面在康托的作品中凸显出来，但在牛顿和莱布尼茨引入微积分后的一个世纪的早期关于无穷小量的论证中也体现出来了。

However “infinity as object” necessitates moving to another conceptual system and that is an enormous leap that neither the Greeks nor subsequent cultures were capable of making for a very long time. Again there are very good reasons for this. Progress is not merely a case of continuous improvement. You can’t really develop the real numbers without thinking of an infinite collection (here of rational numbers) as one object. And if you do not do this then you can never develop the real number system, calculus, differential equations, and therefore much of physics and engineering. However making this leap means coming to live in a strange new world, which is unintuitive in many ways.vi The unintuitive aspects come to the fore in the work of Cantor but also in the earlier arguments about infinitesimals that marked the century after the introduction of calculus by Newton and Leibniz.

实际上，用“非直觉”这个词来形容无限对象会暴露真相。它代表一个标志，告诉我们概念系统已经发生了变化，这种转变的决定性方面是人们在两个系统中的直觉不兼容。我们将在下一节中看到，从有理数发展到实数系统是一个很好的例子，说明连续的概念系统之间存在多么巨大的鸿沟。

Actually using the word “unintuitive” for infinite objects gives away the game. It represents a marker that tells us that the conceptual system has changed and the defining aspect of such a shift is that there is an incompatibility between one’s intuitions in the two systems. The development of the real number system from the rational numbers, as we shall see in the subsequent section, is a very good example about how vast a gulf may exist between successive conceptual systems.

3.8 实数

3.8 The Real Numbers

我可以将这一节命名为“无理数”，其中“无理”一词将再次凸显改变概念系统的障碍。“无理”一词传达的信息与之前使用的“否定”一词相同。

I could have titled this section “the irrational numbers” where the word irrational would again highlight the obstacle to changing conceptual systems. The word “irrational” sends the same message as the earlier use of the word “negative.”

然而，有趣的是，“实”字用于有理数和无理数的集合。当然，“实”数并不比整数或复数具有更深的现实性。如果你掌握了适当的概念系统，那么所有数字系统都是“实”的。任何概念系统的本质都是它赋予它所描述的情况现实性。给定情况的现实性取决于个人带入该情况的概念框架，这解释了为什么教师有时很难理解学生的反应。对教师而言“真实”或“显而易见”的东西对学生来说完全令人难以置信。相反，从学生的角度来看，对学生而言显而易见的东西对教师而言往往是愚蠢或无意义的。学生的概念系统不可避免地与教师的概念系统不同（否则就没有什么可学的了），但不同的概念系统彼此不兼容。一个好的老师应该对这一事实很敏感。学生并没有错或愚蠢；她生活在一个不同的数学世界中。

However it is also interesting that the word “real” is used for the collection of rational and irrational numbers. Of course the “real” numbers have no claim to a deeper reality than the integers or the complex numbers. All number systems are “real” if you have mastered the appropriate conceptual system. The essence of any conceptual system is that it confers reality on the situation that it describes.
