The reality of a given situation is a function of the conceptual framework that the individual brings to it, which explains why teachers sometimes have great difficulty understanding their students’ responses. What is “real” or “obvious” for the teacher is totally unbelievable for the student. Conversely, what is obvious for the student, from their standpoint, is often stupid or nonsensical for the teacher. The student’s conceptual system is inevitably different than that of the teacher (or there would be nothing to learn) but different conceptual systems are incompatible with one another. A good teacher should be sensitive to this fact. The student is not wrong or stupid; she is living in a different mathematical world.

无理数是毕达哥拉斯定理的结果，该定理给出了所有的平方根：的问题在于它与计数数字不相容。这意味着它不能表示为两个整数的商。因此，毕达哥拉斯学派被迫质疑他们珍视的一个信念，即所有数字都是可通约的，也就是说，数字的世界只由分数组成。这是人们对他们掌握的概念系统的感觉的正常方式，即它定义了什么是真实的。希腊人生活在一个所有数量都是可通约的世界里，也就是说，有一个共同的度量，这相当于说分数是唯一可能的数字。这种观点延伸到一种更普遍的信念，我们许多人仍然持有这种信念，即整个宇宙是“可通约的”，它都被一个理性的框架整齐地联系在一起，可以用数学来描述。这是对一个理性和谐宇宙的信仰。非理性的更大含义（毕达哥拉斯学派可能并没有忽视这一点）是，不管喜欢与否，不连续性和不相容性都是这个世界不可或缺的一部分。这个世界不能用一个单一的、理性的概念系统来描述，无论是科学的还是其他的，因为你不可避免地必须处理任何系统内不可避免地出现的问题，并产生新的系统。

The irrational numbers come into mathematics as a result of Pythagoras’ Theorem which gives you all of the square roots: The problem with is that it is incommensurable with the counting numbers. This means that it cannot be expressed as quotient of two integers. As a result of this the Pythagoreans were forced to question one of their cherished beliefs, namely that all numbers were commensurable, that is, that the universe of numbers consisted only of fractions. This is the normal way that people feel about a conceptual system that they have mastered, namely that it defines what is real. The Greeks lived for a while in a world where all quantities were commensurable, that is, have a common measure, which is equivalent to saying that fractions are the only possible numbers. This point of view was extended to a more general belief, which many of us still share, that the entirety of the universe is “commensurable,” that it is all tied together neatly by a rational framework, which can be described by mathematics. This is the belief in a rational and harmonious universe. The larger meaning of the fact that is irrational (which may not have been lost on the Pythagoreans) is that, like it or not, discontinuities and incompatibilities are an irreducible part of the world. The world cannot be described by a single, rational conceptual system, scientific or otherwise, because you inevitably must deal with the problems that inevitably develop within any system and give rise to new systems.

从现代的观点来看，即从实数概念系统的角度来看，平方根甚至还远远不能穷尽所有无理数的集合。我之前指出，中间集合，即“可构造”数字的集合，包含平方根并形成一个完美的数字系统。这基本上是希腊人定义“数字”的系统，它本身就是一个有趣的概念系统。今天我们往往不承认这个系统，因为我们相信数字起源于计数。然而，这种信念是错误的——我们讨论的两个核心系统都不涉及计数。还有其他数字来源，例如测量，这更接近希腊数学的核心。数学教育家大卫·托尔等人认为，测量也是产生数字概念的充分基础，尽管它可能产生不同类型的数字。我认为现代数字概念的根源在于计数和测量之间的紧张关系。

From the modern point of view, that is, from the point of view of the conceptual system of the real numbers, square roots do not even come close to exhausting the set of all irrational numbers. I indicated earlier that an intermediate collection, the collection of “constructible” numbers, contains the square roots and forms a perfectly good number system. This is basically the system that defined “number” for the Greeks and it is an interesting conceptual system in its own right. Today we tend not to recognize this system because of our belief that number has its origins in counting. However this belief is erroneous—neither of the core systems that we discussed involves counting. There are other sources of number such as measuring, which are closer to the heart of Greek mathematics. People, like the mathematics educator David Tall, have argued, that measuring is also a sufficient basis for producing the number concept, albeit one that may produce different kinds of numbers. I would argue that the modern concept of number has its roots in the tension between counting and measuring.

尽管这很有趣，但几何可构造数系统也有其局限性。这体现在某些困扰希腊数学家的“无法解决的问题”中，例如三等分角或化圆为方。这些问题无法在可构造数系统中得到解决。它们的解决依赖于数字概念的扩展。

As interesting as it is, the geometric system of constructible numbers has its limitations. This is seen in certain “unsolvable problems” that bedeviled the Greek mathematicians such as trisecting the angle or squaring the circle. These problems cannot be solved within the system of the constructible numbers. Their solution is dependent on an extension of the concept of number.

一个更深层次的问题与数字π 有关。π是圆周长与直径的比值。希腊人确实认为π是一个数字，而不仅仅是一个比值，阿基米德也成功找到了一些很好的有理近似值。同一类别中还有其他数字，例如“黄金分割”，显然重要但不可构造。这些不可构造的所谓超越数的本质是什么？至今它们仍有些神秘和矛盾之处，这种神秘感正是当一个人的概念系统没有完全吸收时产生的感觉。

An even deeper problem concerns the number π. It is introduced as a ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter. The Greeks did indeed think of π as a number and not just a ratio and Archimedes succeeded in finding some good rational approximations. There were other numbers in the same category such as the “golden mean” that were clearly important but not constructible. What is the nature of these non-constructible, so-called transcendental numbers? There remains something mysterious and paradoxical about them to this day and this sense of mystery is precisely the feeling that arises when one’s conceptual system is not completely assimilated.

我们看到，可构造数系统包含其自身的问题元素，所有概念系统也是如此。如何开发一个包含根和另一种不可构造数的数学和概念系统？在我们开始讨论这个问题的现代答案——实数之前，让我先指出，有许多数字系统位于分数和无限小数之间的中间领域。例如，所有形式为a和b都是分数的数字。（或者将2替换为任何其他非平方数。）

We saw that the system of constructible numbers contains its own problematic elements, as do all conceptual systems. How does one develop a mathematical and conceptual system that contains the roots and also contains this other kind of non-constructible number? Before we get into a discussion of the modern answer to this problem—the real numbers—let me just note that there are many number systems that are situated in the intermediate domain between the fractions and the infinite decimals. For example, all numbers of the form where a and b are both fractions. (Or else replace 2 with any other non-square.)

对这些各种中间数系中存在问题的元素的现代解答在于向实数的概念系统迈出巨大的一步。实际上，每个数系都有一个存在问题的元素，最终将我们推向一个新的、更复杂的系统，使我们从有理数走向可构造数。像π这样的数字将我们从可构造数带到了实数。无限小数实数系的发展是一项相对较新的成就（对于数学而言），其含义仍不清楚。毫无疑问，它的发展是一项重大的智力胜利。分数、根和所有其他无理数，包括π和黄金分割都可以用十进制形式表示。也就是说，我提到的所有数字系统都可以嵌入到这个新系统中，因此，它们的不兼容性得到了调和。与其他数学突破一样，这个系统构成了新数学真正爆发的框架，尤其是微积分和所有依赖它的科学理论。我将在第八章中更详细地讨论实数系统的优点和缺点。

The modern answer to the problematic elements of these various intermediate numbers system consists in making the huge leap to the conceptual system of the real numbers. Actually each number system has a problematic element, which eventually pushes us into a new and more complex system, got us from the rationals to the constructible numbers. Numbers like π get us from the constructible numbers to the real numbers. The development of the real number system of infinite decimals is a relatively recent accomplishment (for mathematics) whose implications still remain unclear. Undoubtedly its development was a major intellectual triumph. The fractions, the roots and all the other irrationals including π and the golden mean can all be represented in decimal form. That is, all of the numerical systems that I have mentioned can be embedded in this new system and, as a result, their incompatibilities are reconciled. Like other mathematical breakthroughs this system formed the framework for a veritable explosion of new mathematics, especially the calculus and all of the scientific theories that depend on it. I shall return to a more detailed discussion of the strengths and weaknesses of the real number system in chapter eight.

3.9虚数和复数

3.9Imaginary and Complex Numbers

“虚数”和“复数”这两个词再次表明，在概念系统中做出重大改变是多么困难——我们已经在负数、分数、零和无理数方面遇到了这种困难。“虚数”这个词告诉我们，从扎根于实数系统的人的角度来看，这些数字是不真实的。我记得在学生时代就有这种感觉，但今天我却记不起是什么让这些数字看起来如此虚幻。这可能与大多数人认为“数字”意味着数轴上的一个点有关。我们并没有完全理解实数概念系统的含义，而是理解了一条直线的简单几何模型，其中每个数字都占据一个精确的位置。从这个角度来看，平方为-1的数字i不是数字，因为它不能位于那条线上。我提到这一点是因为它会让大多数读者对扎根于 CS 1（实数）并朝着有望成为 CS 2（复数）的方向前进的含义有一个具体的感受。我们可能不记得曾将2/3想象成一个数字，但我们大多数人都能记得曾将i想象成一个数字。

The words “imaginary” and “complex” again demonstrate how difficult it is to make a major change in conceptual systems—a difficulty that we already encountered with negative numbers, fractions, zero, and irrational numbers. The word “imaginary” tells us that these numbers are unreal from the perspective of someone grounded in the real number system. I can remember having that feeling as a student and yet today I cannot recall what it was that made these numbers so seemingly illusory. It may have something to do with the fact that for most people “number” means a point on the number line. We don’t carry around the full implications of the conceptual system of the real numbers so much as we carry around the simple geometric model of a line with each number occupying a precise location. From that point of view the number i whose square is -1 is not a number since it can’t be located on that line. I mention this because it will give most readers a concrete feeling of what it means to be grounded in CS1 (the real numbers) and to be looking in the direction of what will hopefully become CS2 (the complex numbers). We may not remember having trouble thinking of 2/3 as a number but most of us can remember having trouble thinking of i as a number.

作为实数上的计算，i不是什么大问题。我们看一下方程x 2 +1 = 0，并学会利用求二次方程根的公式来求解它，或者更直接地，将该方程视为普通的代数方程，以与求解x 2 − 4 = 0 相同的方式得到当我们使用平方根符号写出它时，它甚至“看起来”像一个数字。所以在某些方面它看起来像一个数字——它是一个方程的解，并且有一个涉及平方根的符号。另一方面，它不可能是一个数字，因为它在数轴上没有位置，而且我们“知道”所有的平方必然是非负的。因此这种情况是模棱两可的，解决这种模棱两可的问题需要构建一个扩展的数字概念——形式为a+bi 的二维数字， 其中a和b是实数，i 2 =-1。

As a computation over the real numbers, i is no great problem. We look at the equation x2 +1 = 0 and learn to solve it by means of the formula that gives you the roots of quadratics or, more directly, by treating this equation as an ordinary algebraic equation, arriving at in the same way as we would solve x2 − 4 = 0 to get When we write it out using the square root sign it even “looks” like a number. So in some ways it seems like a number—it is the solution of an equation and it has a notation involving square roots. On the other hand it can’t be a number because it has no place on the number line and we “know” that all squares are necessarily non-negative. Thus the situation is ambiguous and the resolution of this ambiguity involves the construction of an extended concept of number—two-dimensional numbers of the form a+bi, where a and b are real numbers and i2=-1.

我们如何证明这些新对象是数字？所有复数都有a+bi 的形式，而且你可以用它们进行算术运算，也就是说，你可以对它们进行加、减、乘、除，保持相同的形式。例如，1/(1+i) = (1-i) / 2。通过将实数3等同于复数3+0i ，可以将实数嵌入更大的复数系统中。（就像我们通过将3等同于3/1 ，将计数数字嵌入分数中一样。）

How do we justify calling these new objects numbers? All complex numbers have the form a+bi and it turns out that you can do arithmetic with them, that is, you can add, subtract, multiply and divide them and keep the same form. For example, 1/(1+i) = (1-i)/2. It is possible to embed the real numbers in the larger system of complex numbers by identifying the real number 3, for example, with the complex number 3+0i. (Just like we embedded the counting numbers in the fractions by identifying 3 with 3/1 .)

但这些性质还不足以证明将复数称为一个新的概念系统。新系统还必须解决旧系统中的一些问题。必须解决的问题涉及代数方程，如x 2 +1 = 0，我们可以在旧系统中表述但无法求解。在新系统中，我们不仅可以求解这个方程，还可以求解任何具有实系数的（代数）方程。更妙的是，复数系统具有称为代数完备性的美妙性质，即，任何可以在复数系统中写下的（代数）方程也具有（正确数量的）复数解。例如，方程x 3 +1 = 0 有三个解。通过这种方式以及许多其他方式，复数开辟了一个新的数学世界，它不仅本身具有重要的性质和应用，而且还向您揭示了在“现实”世界中模糊但在“复杂”世界中变得非常清晰的数学对象的性质。一个重要的例子涉及三角函数和指数函数——sin(x)、cos(x)和exp(x)。作为实函数，它们似乎毫无关联，但作为复函数，它们却密切相关，e ix = cos( x ) = i sin( x )，因此可以说，它们是看待同一事物的两种不同方式。vii

But these properties are not enough to justify calling the complex numbers a new conceptual system. The new system must also resolve some problem in the old. The problem that must be resolved involves algebraic equations like x2 +1 = 0 that we can state in the old system but not solve there. In the new system not only can we solve this equation but also any (algebraic) equation with real coefficients. Even better the system of complex numbers has the beautiful property that is called algebraic completeness, namely, that any (algebraic) equation that you can write down in the system of complex number also has (the right number of) complex number solutions. For example, the equation x3 +1 = 0 has the three solutions In this and many other ways the complex numbers open up a new mathematical universe which not only has important properties and applications in itself but also reveals to you properties of mathematical objects that are obscure in the “real” world but become abundantly clear in the “complex” world. One important example involves the trigonometric and exponential functions—sin(x), cos(x), and exp(x). As real functions they seem to be unrelated but as complex functions they are seen to be so closely related, eix = cos(x) = isin(x), that one could really say that they are two different ways of looking at the same thing.vii

3.10抽象数学结构

3.10Abstract Mathematical Structures

讨论过的许多数字系统都是抽象结构的例子。有理数、实数和复数系统是所谓的（数学）域的例子。域是一种抽象结构，人们可以在其中进行广义形式的算术。换句话说，我们抽象了数字的基本计算属性，即它们可以加、减、乘、除，并考虑了这些属性的最普遍情况操作是可能的。实际上，最简单的此类系统仅由两个元素0和1组成，它们以正常方式相加和相乘，但在此系统中1+1=0。这是二进制或模 2算术系统。

Many of the number systems that have been discussed are examples of abstract structures. The rational, real, and complex number systems are examples of what is called a (mathematical) field. A field is an abstract structure in which one can do a generalized form of arithmetic. In other words we have abstracted the essential computational properties of numbers, namely, that they can be added, subtracted, multiplied, and divided, and considered the most general situation in which these operations are possible. Actually the simplest such system consists of just two elements 0 and 1 which are added and multiplied in the normal way except that in this system 1+1=0. This is the system of binary, or mod 2, arithmetic.

场论与环论和群论一样，是数学的一个分支学科，很多数学家将其职业生涯都用于研究此类代数结构的性质。如今，介绍这些结构的方式通常是列出一系列公理。这包括闭包性质（通过添加和乘以系统元素可使您留在系统中）、单位的存在（类似于数字1）和另一个元素（类似于0）。我不会写下完整的公理列表，因为我对作为抽象结构的场更感兴趣，而对作为概念系统的场更感兴趣。我之前描述过数值概念数系统有一个层次结构，还有一个新的概念系统抽象了它们的最重要性质，称为场。

Field theory, like ring theory and group theory, is a sub-discipline of mathematics and there are mathematicians who spend their professional careers investigating the properties of these kind of algebraic structures. The way these structures are normally introduced today consists of listing a sequence of axioms. This would include the property of closure whereby adding and multiplying elements of the system keeps you in the system, the existence of a unit, which would be the analog of the number 1, and another element, which would be the analog of 0. I will not write down the complete list of axioms because I am not interested in a field as an abstract structure so much as I am interested in a field as a conceptual system. There is a hierarchy of numerical conceptual number systems that I have described earlier and there is then a new conceptual system that abstracts their most important properties and is called a field.

要想在数学领域的理论中成功运作，就必须上升到这个新的概念层面。与大多数数学家认为是具体环境的实际数字系统相比，在这个层面上工作被认为是在抽象环境中工作。从概念系统的角度来看，抽象和具体的区别是什么？你掌握的概念系统的元素感觉是“具体的”；当你还没有完全掌握时，它可能感觉是抽象的。实际上，没有一个思想体系是真正具体的；它们都是抽象的。思考从一个概念系统到另一个概念系统更有用。

To successfully operate within the theory of mathematical fields one must rise up to this new conceptual level. Working at this level is thought of as working in an abstract setting as compared to working with an actual number system that most mathematicians would consider as being a concrete setting. What would be the distinction between abstract and concrete from the point of view of conceptual systems? The elements of a conceptual system that you have mastered feel “concrete;” when you are not quite there it may feel abstract. Actually no system of thought is really concrete; they are all abstract. It is more useful to think about going from one conceptual system to another.

当然，场论中的每个命题都“包含”一系列命题——每个特定领域都有一个命题。这些（旧）概念系统中的每一个都是新系统的一个实例，有些人在抽象情况下通过简单地将每个命题转化为一个或多个“通用”示例来操作。然而，也有其他人开发了一种在抽象系统本身中操作的方法。他们现在对数学领域有了“感觉”，并成功地在这个新的概念系统中站稳了脚跟。然而，他们与“代表”抽象理论的“通用”例子保持密切联系。

Of course every proposition in field theory “contains” a whole series of propositions—one for every particular field. Each one of these (old) conceptual systems is one instance of the new system and some people operate in the abstract situation by simply translating every proposition into one or more “generic” examples. However there are others who develop a way of operating in the abstract system itself. They now have a “feel” for mathematical fields and have successfully established themselves within this new conceptual system. Nevertheless they maintain close touch with the “generic” examples that “represent” the abstract theory.

每个抽象的数学系统都带有这样的概念维度。你可以说数学理论带有这两个视角：客观的“数学”视角和概念视角。通常只有第一个视角被认为是实际数学，但我更愿意认为每个数学情况都有这两个视角。如果一个人对学习感兴趣，那么必须时刻记住，我们面对的不仅仅是一个客观的、抽象的世界，而且还是一个具有不可简化的主观方面的概念世界。形式世界只有当它具有这样的认知维度时才会活跃起来。只有这样，它才配得上被称为真正的数学。当一个人向数学家提到一个抽象的想法时，它会唤起整个概念和想法的集合，数学教育家 Tall 和 Vinner viii称之为“概念形象”，即“与概念相关的整个认知结构，包括所有心理图像和相关属性和过程。”

Every abstract mathematical system comes with such a conceptual dimension. You could say that a mathematical theory comes with these two perspectives: the objective “mathematical” perspective and the conceptual perspective. Only the first is normally considered actual mathematics but I prefer to think that every mathematical situation has these two perspectives. If one is interested in learning then it is essential to remember at all times that we are not merely dealing with an objective, abstract world but also with a conceptual world that has irreducible subjective aspects. The formal world only comes alive when it has such a cognitive dimension. It is only then that it deserves to be called real mathematics. When one mentions an abstract idea to a mathematician it evokes an entire constellation of concepts and ideas, what the mathematics educators Tall and Vinnerviii have called a “concept image,” the “total cognitive structure that is associated with the concept, which includes all the mental pictures and associated properties and processes.”

3.11数字概念系统中的离散和连续

3.11The Discrete and the Continuous in Conceptual Systems for Number

连续和离散概念的核心地位，以及它们之间的紧张关系，在数学和所有文化中都能找到。发展心理学家的工作已经表明了为什么会这样。它起源于第一章讨论过的两个核心数字系统。 “模拟量表示”系统是连续和近似的，而“小集合的平行个体化”是离散和精确的。这两个系统并不能无缝地结合在一起。它们之间存在不兼容性，而看待数字概念历史的一种方式是，它由一系列对这种模糊和有问题的情况的解决方案组成。我们有两个处理数字的认知系统。在没有另一个系统的情况下，每个系统都可以以某种方式扩展以保留其基本特征，这也许会导致两个不同的数字概念，但这不是发展的方式。新系统的产生是为了解决原有系统之间的一些差异。

The centrality of the notions of the continuous and the discrete, as well as the tension between them, can be found throughout mathematics and in all cultures. The work of developmental psychologists has indicated why this should be so. It has its origins in the two core systems for number that were discussed in chapter one. The “analog magnitude representation” system is continuous and approximate whereas the “parallel individuation of small sets” is discrete and exact. These two systems do not fit together seamlessly. There is an incompatibility there and one way to view the history of the number concept is that it consists of a series of resolutions of this ambiguous and problematic situation. We have two cognitive systems for processing number. In the absence of the other each might be extended in such a way as to preserve its essential features leading, perhaps, to two distinct number concepts but this is not the way that development happens. New systems are produced in order to resolve some of the discrepancies between the original systems.

正如我们在第一章中看到的那样，计数数字，即学习到的第一个系统，不仅包含比并行个体化处理的数字更大的数字，而且还具有模拟量级系统所缺乏的精度。

As we saw in chapter one the counting numbers, the first system that is learned, not only contains numbers that are larger than the ones processed in parallel individuation but also is capable of the precision that is lacking in the analog magnitude system.

计数系统的诞生虽然令人难以置信，但这并不是终点。原因在于离散和连续之间的矛盾没有明确的解决办法。我们看到，计数数字的计算会导致无法在该系统内解决的问题，并需要创建新的数字系统，这些系统更加完整，并在一定程度上调和了我们核心概念系统中的原始二分法。尽管如此，即使我们开发的系统越来越复杂，试图创建一个全面的数字系统，从而确定数字的含义，核心系统仍然留在我们的大脑中，因此，连续和离散感觉就像不同的——甚至是相反的——想法。我们生活在以下情况下：数字是一个单一的概念——即使我们不能确切地说它是什么——但它以两种模式呈现给我们。正是这种模棱两可的情况在过去产生了新的数学系统，并将继续在未来这样做。

The accomplishment of producing the system of counting numbers, as incredible as it is, is not the end of the line. The reason for this is that the tension between the discrete and the continuous has no definitive resolution. We saw how computations over the counting numbers lead to problems that cannot be resolved in that system and necessitate the creation of new number systems which are more complete and go part of the way towards reconciling the primal dichotomy contained in our core conceptual systems. Nevertheless, even if the systems we develop are increasingly sophisticated attempts to create one comprehensive number system, and to thereby pin down a meaning for number, the core systems remain in our brain and, as a result, the continuous and the discrete feel like different—even opposite—ideas. We live with the following situation: number is a singular idea—even if we can’t quite say what it is—yet it is presented to us in two modes. It is this ambiguous situation that generated new mathematical systems in the past and will continue to do so in the future.

我们的核心系统之间的紧张关系没有明确的解决办法，原因很可能是核心系统本身的进化方式能够内化自然界的不同特征。这与我们的生物体有生物钟一样，生物钟内化了对我们在地球上生存至关重要的二十四小时昼夜节律。几乎所有文化都发现并赞扬数字，它捕捉了世界的一些基本方面。你可以称其为秩序、结构、模式或规律性。数字代表了世界的可理解性，没有它，像我们这样的智能通才物种就不可能生存。我们拥有代表世界这一方面的机制并不奇怪。有趣的是，我们有不止一个这样的系统。

The reason that there is no definitive resolution to the tension between our core systems may well be because the core systems themselves evolved in such a way as to internalize distinct features of the natural world. This would happen in the same way that our organism has biological clocks that have internalized the twenty-four hour, circadian, rhythm that is so important to our survival on earth. Number, as almost all cultures have discovered and celebrated, captures some essential aspect of the world. You can call this aspect order, structure, pattern, or regularity. Number represents the intelligibility of the world without which the very survival of an intelligent generalist species like our own would be impossible. It is not surprising that we possess mechanisms for representing this aspect of the world. What is interesting is that we have more than one such system.

对数字使用多种表示形式有什么好处？也许原因在于自然界，也许自然界本身就有不止一种方式来获取那些被纳入数字范畴的世界特征？这些特征是什么？在我看来，它们正是离散的和连续的。亚里士多德认为，数量有两种，他称之为量级（连续的）和众多（离散的）。我们可以将这种二分法看作是将数字引入现实世界的两种基本方式——计数和测量活动。但这些活动不仅仅发生在我们的头脑中——计数和测量源于自然界的特征。正如我之前所说，世界是有序的，而这种秩序的一个主要方面是数量——“多少？”或“多少？”这些问题的答案。

What is to be gained by having multiple representations for number? Perhaps the reason for them is to be found in nature, perhaps nature itself has more than one way of accessing those features of the world that are subsumed under the rubric of number? What would these features be? In my opinion they are precisely the discrete and the continuous. Quantity, as Aristotle understood, comes in two varieties that he called magnitude, the continuous, and multitude, the discrete. We can think of this dichotomy as representing two elementary ways of introducing number into the real world—the activities of counting and measuring. But these activities do not merely go on in our heads—counting and measuring arise from features of the natural world. As I said earlier the world is ordered and a prime aspect of that order is quantity—the answer to the questions, “How much?’ or “How many?”

我们的大脑已经发展出可以复制自然界这种模糊特征的系统。自然界特征与我们大脑结构之间的这种相似性在很大程度上解释了数学的核心谜团，即自然科学中所谓的“不合理的有效性”。数学之所以有效，是因为它的起源在于心理结构，这种心理结构的发展方式可以代表人类所居住环境的关键特征。

Our brains have developed systems that replicated this ambiguous feature of the natural world. This parallel between features of the natural world and structures of our brain would go a long way towards explaining the central mystery of mathematics, namely, what has been called its “unreasonable effectiveness” in the natural sciences. Mathematics works because its origins lie in mental structures that evolved in such a way as to represent crucial features of the environment that human beings inhabit.

有趣的是，现代数学（无论是纯数学还是应用数学）仍然没有调和离散和连续之间的差异。即使实数和复数等数字系统可以声称包含连续和离散特征，但仍然可以将数学的子学科分为主要为离散的和连续的。微积分、微分方程、微分几何和拓扑是连续的，而数论、代数和组合学是离散的。钟摆来回摆动，看哪种趋势占主导地位。在牛顿和经典力学时代，连续似乎抓住了宇宙的基本方面，而今天，主要由于量子力学和数字计算机的成功，人们倾向于认为离散更为基本。然而，即使是主要为离散的学科也使用连续技术，反之亦然。两者之间的紧张关系仍然是数学的一个不变特征它丰富了数学这门学科，并确保数学不断发展壮大。

It is interesting that modern mathematics, pure and applied, still has not reconciled the differences between the discrete and the continuous. Even if number systems such as the real and complex numbers can claim to contain both continuous and discrete features, nevertheless it is still possible to divide the sub-disciplines of mathematics into those that are primarily discrete and those that are continuous. Calculus, differential equations, differential geometry and topology are continuous whereas number theory, algebra, and combinatorics are discrete. The pendulum swings back and forth as to which tendency is the dominant. In the days of Newton and classical mechanics the continuous seemed to capture the basic aspects of the universe whereas today, primarily due to the successes of quantum mechanics and the digital computer, there is a tendency to think of the discrete as more fundamental. However even subjects that are primarily discrete use continuous techniques and vice versa. The tension between the two remains a constant feature of mathematics. It enriches the subject and ensures that mathematics will continue to grow and develop.

3.12深度思考的“逻辑”

3.12The “Logic” of Deep Thinking

根据我们扩展的数学和科学概念系统系列示例，我现在将讨论在开发和学习此类系统的过程中产生的深度思考与支配给定系统或范式中大部分工作的系统性、逻辑性思考有何不同。

In the light of our expanded series of examples of mathematical and scientific conceptual systems, I move on now to a discussion of the manner in which the deep thinking that arises in the development and learning of such systems differs from the systematic, logical thinking that governs much of the work within a given system or paradigm.

对数学中一个猜想或问题的研究，通常按以下顺序进行：

Research on a conjecture or a problem in mathematics often proceeds in the following order:

推测。你根据经验和直觉得出一个猜想。你根据部分证据猜测这个猜想大体上是正确的（或者猜测它是错误的）。

Conjecture.You somehow come up with a conjecture on the basis of experience and intuition. You guess that the conjecture is generally true (or else guess that it is false) on the basis of partial evidence.

主意。您会了解为什么它是正确的以及如何整理证明（或者如何构建反例）。

Idea.You get an idea of why it is true and how a proof might be put together (or an idea about how a counter-example might be constructed).

逻辑推导。您尝试将其写下来，即使用形式逻辑和非形式逻辑的组合从普遍接受为真实的结果中推导出结果。

Logical Derivation. You attempt to write it up, that is, to derive the result from results that are generally accepted as true using a combination of formal and informal logic.

困難。最初的尝试失败了，因为之前没有考虑到一些问题。在这个阶段，可能会出现新的例子，这些例子要么强化了最初的直觉（这是真的），要么将命题改变为相反的命题（这是假的）。

Difficulties.This initial attempt fails because of problems that were not thought of previously. At this stage new examples may appear that either reinforce the original intuition (it’s true) or changes the proposition to its opposite (it’s false).

改变猜想。在此阶段，可以通过修改前提、结论或两者来改变猜想或命题。然后可以重复上述步骤。

Change the Conjecture.At this stage one may change the conjecture or proposition by modifying the premises, conclusion, or both. Then the cycle of steps may be repeated.

这个过程一直持续到原始问题得到解决或出现某种“有趣”的命题或例子。它总是在第 3 步结束，即证明或验证反例。

This process continues until the original problem is solved or some sort of “interesting” proposition or example emerges. It always terminates at step 3, the proof or verified counter-example.

这个过程似乎根本不需要深度思考，但事实上，它是必不可少的。这个过程离不开第 1 步和第 2 步，即提出猜想和证明的想法。深度思考往往在完成的证明中是看不见的，这似乎从头到尾遵循线性的演绎顺序。尽管如此，即使结果得到证明并得到充分证实，深入思考仍然必不可少。数学家记住的不是证明本身，而是证明背后的想法。

It may appear that deep thinking is not involved in this process at all but, in fact, it is essential. The process cannot begin without steps 1 and 2, that is, coming up with the conjecture and the idea for the proof. Deep thinking is often invisible in the completed proof, which appears to follow a linear, deductive sequence from beginning to end. Nevertheless deep thinking remains essential even when the result is proved and well established. The mathematician does not remember the proof so much as the idea behind the proof.

尽管数学和科学发现的过程包括洞察力和逻辑推导之间的交替，但后者似乎拥有最终决定权。因此，许多人得出结论，形式逻辑是数学中运用思维的唯一方式，而在实践中，重要的是获得想法，即看待问题的有效方式。数学不仅仅是逻辑的；它的本质是深度思考！

Even though the process of mathematical and scientific discovery consists of an alternation between insight and logical derivation, the latter seemingly has the last word. Thus many people have concluded that formal logic is the only way of using the mind that matters in mathematics whereas, in practice, what matters is getting the idea, the productive way of looking at the problem. Mathematics is not (merely) logical; its essence is deep thinking!

演绎逻辑是古希腊人发明的，已成为所有数学和科学的基础。但逻辑本身是一种语言和概念系统，有其优点和缺点。其中一个缺点是，它往往会掩盖深度思考在科学中的作用。深度思考涉及将思维从其限制中解放出来——超越当前范式并重新构建情况。另一方面，形式逻辑涉及施加一系列约束。例如，思想世界和现实世界本身是大量非线性和多维的，但逻辑话语的世界是线性的。演绎逻辑引导人们思考起点（假设）和终点（结论）。在极端情况下，这意味着一方面找到最基本和最小的一组公理，另一方面找到万物的最终演绎理论。深度思考没有单一的起点，当然也没有明确的终点。这是一个纯粹的过程——一段旅程，沿途有多个站点，人们可以坐下来欣赏风景，然后再次开始创作任务。

Deductive logic was invented by the Ancient Greeks and has become the foundation of all of mathematics and science. But logic is a language and a conceptual system in its own right with its own strengths and weaknesses. One of these weaknesses is that it tends to obscure the role of deep thinking in science. Deep thinking involves freeing the mind from its constraints—seeing beyond the current paradigm and reframing the situation. Formal logic, on the other hand, involves imposing a series of constraints. For example, the world of ideas and reality itself are massively non-linear and multi-dimensional but the world of logical discourse is linear. Deductive logic leads one to think about beginnings (hypotheses) and ends (conclusions). At its extreme this means finding the most elementary and minimal set of axioms on the one hand and a final deductive theory of everything, on the other. Deep thinking has no single location where it begins and it certainly does not have a definitive end. It is pure process—a journey with multiple stops along the way where one may sit and enjoy the view before taking up the creative task once more.

因此，确定深度思考与形式化、演绎性思考之间关系的性质，即形式逻辑与创造过程之间的关系，非常重要。这在我们这个时代尤为重要，因为计算机程序是逻辑过程的一个例子，因此在建立深度思考与形式思维之间的关系时，我们要解决计算的内在限制。显然，今天有许多聪明人认为计算没有限制；至少在理论上，没有什么是计算思维无法做到这一点。这种观点只是一厢情愿。计算有其内在的局限性，我们必须意识到这一点。

It is therefore important to establish the nature of the relationship between deep thinking and formal, deductive thinking, that is, between formal logic and the creative process. This is particularly important in our time because a computer program is an example of a logical process and so in establishing the relationship between deep thinking and formal thought we are addressing the intrinsic limits of computation. It is evident that there are today many intelligent people who believe that computation has no limits; that there is, in theory at least, nothing that computational thought is not capable of. This view is just wishful thinking. Computation has intrinsic limitations, which it is essential to become aware of.

本书最重要的论点之一是，深度思考中思维的使用方式与成人日常思维中思维的使用方式有着根本的不同，也与科学和数学理论和论述中的分析性思维中思维的使用方式有着根本的不同。今天人们承认智力有很多种，但深度思考不仅仅是一种思维。如果思考与智力密不可分，那么深度思考就是最基本的智力。它是内在的，这解释了为什么它甚至存在于婴儿身上以及概念发展和变化的所有情况下。

One of the most important theses of this book is that in deep thinking the mind is used in a manner that is fundamentally different from the way it is used in the everyday thought of adults but also from the way the mind is used in the analytic thought of scientific and mathematical theory and discourse. It is acknowledged today that there are many different kinds of intelligenceix but deep thinking is not just one variety of thinking. If thinking is inseparable from intelligence then deep thinking is intelligence of the most basic kind. It is built-in and this explains why it is even present in infants and in all situations of conceptual development and change.

另一方面，形式逻辑，即推理或谓词演算的正常规则，在数学和科学中起着关键作用。逻辑的作用如此重要，以至于许多人会认为逻辑阐明了思维的客观规则，换句话说，没有逻辑规则就不可能正确思考，甚至​​根本无法思考。这些人会坚持认为形式逻辑就是事物的本来面目——逻辑是世界和我们生物学的内在组成部分。如果人们相信这一假设，那么我们就应该使用通常的逻辑规则作为讨论现实任何方面，特别是深度思考的框架。我在上面解释了为什么不可能这样做，尽管是粗略和不完整的。用神经科学的语言来说：大脑有两种截然不同的智力模式（我们将在第四章中看到），这些模式彼此不相称且独立——一种模式不能简化为另一种模式。逻辑和分析思维构成了其中一种模式；深度思考则完全不同，涉及这两种模式。我们将在下一章中看到，这两种模式之间的一个显著区别是，分析型思维不具备创造力。原创性的东西只有通过深入思考才能进入这个世界。

On the other hand, formal logic, the normal rules of inference or predicate calculus, plays a key role in mathematics and the sciences. The role of logic is so central that many people would take the position that logic enunciates the objective rules of thought, in other words, that it is not possible to think correctly—or even to think at all—without the rules of logic. Such people would maintain that formal logic is the way things are—that logic is built into the world and our biology. If one believes this hypothesis it would follow that we should use the usual logical rules as the framework within which to discuss any aspect of reality and, in particular, deep thinking. I explained above, albeit in a cursory and incomplete way, why it is impossible to do so. To use the language of neuroscience: the brain comes with two quite different modes of intelligence (as we shall see in chapter four) and these modes are incommensurate with one another and autonomous—one mode cannot be reduced to the other. Logic and analytic thought constitute one of these modes; deep thinking is something quite different and involves both modes. As we shall see in the next chapter one striking difference between those two modes is that the analytic mind is not capable of creativity. What is original only enters into the world by virtue of deep thinking.

问题不是试图把深度思考归结为逻辑思考，而是要解释普通逻辑思考如何从深度思考中产生，然后描述两者之间的关系。让我们请记住，形式逻辑的产生源于创造性行为——古希腊人，比如亚里士多德，发明了它。但创造性的规则——深度思考——显然在当时就已经发挥作用了。深度思考不是文化创造。深度思考就是事物的本来面目。

Instead of trying to reduce deep thinking to logical thought, the problem is to explain how ordinary logical thinking arises out of deep thinking and then to describe the relationship between the two. Let us remember that formal logic came into existence out of an act of creativity—the ancient Greeks, people like Aristotle, invented it. But the rules of creativity—deep thinking—were evidently already functioning at that time. Deep thinking is not a cultural creation. Deep thinking is the way things are.

我们太过视普通逻辑为理所当然，以至于我们甚至难以想象存在一种不以严格逻辑术语构建的推理形式——更不用说任何科学或哲学论述了。因此，问题是：如何讨论形式逻辑而不陷入使用形式逻辑来解释自身的循环？

We take ordinary logic so much for granted that we have difficulty even imagining that there could exist a form of reasoning—much less any scientific or philosophical discourse—that was not structured in strictly logical terms. Thus the problem is this: How to have a discussion about formal logic without entering into the circularity of using the vehicle of formal logic to account for itself?

接下来，我将概述一种关于逻辑的性质和作用的不同思考方式。首先必须打破广义逻辑（被理解为一种推理或使用思维的方式）与形式逻辑的同一性。形式逻辑是系统的、线性的和渐进的。它是一种组织分析思维的方式。但它肯定不是使用思维的唯一方式；它不应该被等同于广义的推理过程。思维也可以是综合的、非线性的、动态的和直观的。这种思维超越逻辑（超逻辑）这一事实并不意味着它是不合逻辑的。

In what follows I shall sketch out a different manner of thinking about the nature and role of logic. The first thing that must be done is to break the identification between generalized logic, understood as a way of reasoning or using the mind, and formal logic. Formal logic is systematic, linear, and incremental. It is a way of organizing analytic thought. But it is certainly not the only way in which the mind can be used; it should not be identified with the generalized process of reasoning. Thought can also be synthetic, non-linear, dynamic, and intuitive. The fact that such thought is beyond logic (trans-logical) does not imply that it is illogical.

我将冒着引起混淆的风险使用“深度思考的逻辑”这一短语，以强调深度思考是一种可以识别和学习（也许重新获得是更好的说法）的思维使用方式。它出现在概念发展、学习和范式转变的背景下。它也可以称为“发展逻辑”或“创造力逻辑”。

I will entertain the risk of confusion by using the phrase “the logic of deep thinking” in order to stress that deep thinking is a way of using the mind that can be identified and learned (perhaps recaptured is a better way to put it). It appears in the context of conceptual development, learning, and paradigm change. It could also be called “developmental logic” or the “logic of creativity.”

我们在前两章中的讨论暗示了形式逻辑和深度思考之间的自然区别。回想一下第二章中对概念系统的讨论。关于概念系统，人们可以提出的最深刻的问题是：“如果一个概念系统定义了什么是个人（或社会）的真实，那么人们如何摆脱当前的概念框架？如何超越 CS 1？”我们知道，创造性的出路是开发一种新的视角，一个新的概念系统，CS 2。虽然有一种显而易见的方法可以测试概念系统是否发生了变化，但测试概念系统是否发生变化的方法它到底是怎么发生的，永远是个谜。即使我们能（客观地）描述发生了什么，描述也不会与创造行为完全相同。换句话说，地图不是领土。然而，我们当然知道它确实发生了，当它发生时，我们会记住这是一个转变的时刻，那时“一切都变了”。概念变化是深度思考最重要、最根本的例子，人们可以立即看到它的性质与演绎推理完全不同。

Our discussions in the last two chapters give us a hint of the natural distinction between formal logic and deep thinking. Recall the discussion of conceptual systems in chapter two. The most profound question that one can ask about conceptual systems is, “If a conceptual system defines what is real for the individual (or for society, for that matter) how does one get out of one’s current conceptual framework; how does one transcend CS1?” We know that the creative way out is to develop a new way of seeing, a new conceptual system, CS2. Though there is an obvious way to test whether or not a conceptual system has changed, the way that it happens will always remain a bit of a mystery. Even if we could (objectively) describe what happens the description would not be identical to the creative act. In other words the map is not the territory. However we certainly do know that it does happen and when it happens we remember the occasion as a moment of transformation when “everything changed.” Conceptual change is the most significant and radical instance of deep thinking and one can see right away that its nature is completely different than that of deductive reasoning.

然而，深度思考也可以在给定的概念系统内部发生。深度思考通常是解决某些难题的手段——人们设法以新的方式看待问题及其所包含的情况。同样，概念系统所包含的基本概念也不断以新的方式被理解或应用于新情况。在每种情况下，深度思考都涉及重新构建情况，但这种重新构建可以是局部的，也可以是全局的。

However deep thinking can also occur inside of a given conceptual system. Deep thinking is often the means by which some difficult problem is resolved—one manages to look at the problem and the situation that contains it in a new way. In the same way the fundamental concepts that underlie a conceptual system are continually being understood in a new way or applied to novel situations. In each of these cases deep thinking involves reframing the situation but this reframing can be local or global.

我所讨论的过程分为两个不相干的类别，这取决于它们是否涉及对情况的根本重构。如果不涉及，那么这个过程通常受普通逻辑规则的支配，例如不矛盾原则。人们倾向于认为数学命题是对的或错的，因为他们看到整个事情发生在一个固定的概念系统中。

The processes that I have been talking about fall into two disjoint categories depending on whether or not they involve a fundamental reframing of the situation. If they do not then the process is usually governed by the rules of ordinary logic, by the principle of noncontradiction, for example. People tend to think that a proposition in mathematics is either right or wrong because they see the whole thing happening within a fixed conceptual system.

深度思考不可避免地包含非逻辑元素。当它发生在固定的概念空间中时，例如证明一个数学定理，结果必须通过逻辑推导与数学概念系统重新整合。科学的完善概念系统也遵循普通逻辑规则，这导致许多人犯了一个根本性的错误，即概念系统以逻辑方式产生，而正如我将在第五章详细讨论的那样，概念系统正是在逻辑规则失效的情况下通过深度思考产生的。

Deep thinking inevitably contains non-logical elements. When it occurs within a fixed conceptual space, such as proving a mathematical theorem, the result must later be reintegrated with the conceptual system of mathematics by means of a logical derivation. The well-established conceptual systems of science also obey the rules of ordinary logic and this leads many to make a fundamental error, namely, that the conceptual system comes into existence in a logical way, when, as I shall discuss in some detail in chapter five, the conceptual system arises through deep thinking in precisely those situations where the logical rules break down.

这种每一步都遵循普通逻辑规则的思维可能是通往深度思考的必经之路。这种思维是连续的、线性的、渐进的和/或计算性的，就像我们童年时记得的算术练习一样。当想法和程序掌握之后，加、减、乘、除就可以机械地完成，而不会产生在需要深度思考的情况下经常出现的那种紧张感。

The kind of thinking that obeys the rules of ordinary logic at every step may be an essential step on the way to deep thinking. Such thinking is continuous, linear, incremental, and/or computational as in the arithmetic exercises we remember from our childhood. When the ideas and procedures are mastered, adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing can be accomplished in a mechanical way without the kind of tension that often accompanies situations that call for deep thinking.

一个完善的范式或概念系统是令人安心的地方——当它发挥作用时。你有很强的方向感。这并不意味着你知道可能出现的每个问题的答案，但你会觉得你面临的问题都有答案，而且你对如何得到答案有很好的感觉。你很少会有完全茫然的感觉，这种感觉是当一个人的概念系统开始崩溃时产生的，要么是由于实验结果无法在概念系统中解释，要么是在教育中，因为老师给学生布置了一项任务，她知道学生当时掌握的概念和工具无法成功完成这项任务。

A well-established paradigm or conceptual system is a comfortable place to be—when it works. You have a strong sense of orientation. This does not mean that you know the answer to every question that may arise but you have the feeling that the questions you face have answers and moreover you have a good feeling about how to go about getting the answers. You rarely have the feeling of being totally at sea which is the feeling that one has when one’s conceptual system starts falling apart either as a result of experimental results that cannot be explained within the conceptual system or, in education, because a teacher has set the student a task that she knows cannot be successfully accomplished with the concepts and tools that the student has available at the time.

此处的区别涉及连续和离散之间的区别——不重新定义操作是连续的，而重新定义则是离散的。对给定概念系统执行计算是一种连续活动，例如，我们可以将5除以3，并得出答案为1，余数为2，而无需使用分数概念。

The difference here involves the distinction between the continuous and the discrete—operating without reframing is continuous; reframing is discrete. Performing computations over a given conceptual system is a continuous activity as, for example, when we can divide 5 by 3 and say that the answer is 1 with a remainder of 2 without having to use the concept of a fraction.

CS 1上的计算可能非常复杂，但它们不会改变概念系统的性质。有一个既定的概念系统，人们可以在其中执行操作。我们可能会对系统产生更强的直觉，因为我们有更多以各种方式使用它的经验。框架可能会延伸，但不会断裂。它的变化是连续的。另一方面，掌握一个新的概念系统是激进而突然的——CS 1和 CS 2是不可比拟的。

Computations over CS1 can be quite sophisticated and complicated but they do not change the nature of the conceptual system. There is an established conceptual system within which one performs the operations. We may develop a stronger intuition for the system because we have more experience of working with it in various ways. The framework may stretch but it does not break. The change in it is continuous. On the other hand grasping a new conceptual system is radical and abrupt—CS1 and CS2 are incommensurable.

连续思维遵循形式或非形式逻辑的规则。因此，我们认为一个问题不可能有两个相互矛盾的答案，也就是说，答案要么是对的，要么是错的。这只存在于一个概念系统中，而不是两个不同的概念系统之间，例如，问一个孩子这个问题，“ 1和2之间有多少个数字？”这个问题的答案取决于孩子所处的概念系统——计数数字或分数。在概念系统中，人们受制于逻辑一致性，当系统不能满足对它的某些要求时，逻辑一致性就会崩溃。

Continuous thought follows the rules of formal or informal logic. Thus we believe that a question cannot have two contradictory answers, that is, an answer is either right or wrong. That this is only so within a conceptual system and not between two different ones as is illustrated by asking a child the question, “How many numbers are there between 1 and 2?” This question has different answers depending on the conceptual system within which the child is operating—the counting numbers or the fractions. Within a conceptual system one is bound by the need for logical consistency, which is the very thing that breaks down when the system proves inadequate to some of the demands that are put upon it.

CS 1和 CS 2可能都是逻辑一致的领域，但当我们试图过早地强加一个逻辑框架来推动过渡，即学习、发展和创造力时，就会出现问题。大多数数学和科学的描述都是从给定的概念系统内部进行的描述，因此整个系统必须在逻辑上一致。即使我们讨论从一个范式 CS 1到另一个范式 CS 2 的过渡，我们也经常从更先进的 CS 2的角度进行讨论，因此采用了“内部观点”。正如我之前指出的那样，我们从形式主义的角度来描述欧几里得几何，形式主义是一个概念系统，它只是由于非欧几里得几何的出现而产生的危机。经典逻辑是概念系统内部观点的语言和结构支持。我们倾向于认为它是中立的，在这样做时，我们没有看到经典逻辑本身是一个概念系统——一种观察世界的方式。当我们采用它时，我们自然会继承它的后果。这些后果包括偏爱客观性、一致性、精确性，以及对悖论、矛盾和模糊性等问题的排斥。正如我们在第五章中看到并将再次看到的，这些因素在深度思考中起着至关重要的作用。

CS1 and CS2 may both be areas of logical consistency but problems arise when we try to prematurely force a logical framework on the transition, that is, on learning, development, and creativity. Most descriptions of mathematics and science are descriptions from within a given conceptual system and therefore the whole system must be logically consistent. Even when we discuss the transition from one paradigm, CS1, to another, CS2, we often do so from the point of view of the more advanced CS2 and so adopt a “view from within.” As I pointed out earlier we describe Euclidean geometry from the point of view of Formalism, a conceptual system that only arose as a result of the crisis associated with the advent of non-Euclidean geometries. Classical logic is the language and structural support of the view from within a conceptual system. We tend to think that it is neutral and, in doing so, we don’t see that classical logic is itself a conceptual system—a way of viewing the world. When we adopt it we naturally inherit its consequences. These consequences include a partiality for objectivity, consistency, precision and intolerance for the problematic in the form of paradox, contradiction, and ambiguity. These latter elements, as we have seen and will see again in chapter five, have an essential role in deep thinking.

3.13结论

3.13Conclusion

最后，我将回顾第一章中列出的深度思考的属性列表，并快速回顾它们如何延伸到从一个数学和科学范式到另一个数学和科学范式的转变。

In these final words I shall go back to the list of properties of deep thinking that were initially listed in chapter one and quickly review how they extend to the movement from one mathematical and scientific paradigm to another.

第一个特性我称之为“自然性”，这意味着深度思考是思维的默认设置。我们难以接受这一点的原因之一是，我们想象思维的默认状态是静止，甚至是一片空白。然而，我们今天知道这不是真的。思维天生就很活跃，我们可以通过测量大脑的活动来看到这一点的证据。如果大脑确实如果得不到足够的外界刺激，它就会自我刺激。婴儿（或者成人）睡觉时，大脑不会自行关闭，而是会进行对其健康至关重要的活动。思考和智慧是心灵自然活力和动力的表现。你不必打开它们；它们一出现就已经打开了。讽刺的是，深度思考的默认状态使得它很难定义。深度思考不是通过客观精确来运作的。它比客观性和精确性更为基础，正如我上面提到的，并将在第四章中详细讨论，客观性和精确性是通过深度思考产生的一种看待世界的方式的要素，而不是相反。

The first property I called “naturalness” which meant that deep thinking was the default setting of the mind. One of the reason we have trouble accepting this is that we imagine that the default condition of the mind is one of quiescence, perhaps even a blank slate. However we know today that this is not true. The mind is naturally active and we can see evidence of this by measuring the activity of the brain. If the brain does not get a sufficient amount of external stimulation it will stimulate itself. When a baby (or an adult, for that matter) sleeps its brain does not turn itself off but engages in activities that are vital to its well-being. Thinking and intelligence are expressions of the natural vitality and dynamism of the mind. You don’t have to turn them on; they arrive on the scene already turned on. Ironically it is the default condition of deep thinking that makes it so difficult to define. Deep thinking does not operate by way of objective precision. It is more basic than objectivity and precision which, as I mentioned above and shall go into in more detail in chapter four, are elements of a way of looking at the world that arises out of deep thinking and not vice versa.

困难和不连续性是科学和数学历史发展中范式转变的特征，在我讨论的所有例子中都存在。因此，深思熟虑往往与争议和危机有关。在数学中，范式转变中的问题元素从历史上与数字概念的发展相关的词语中显而易见：负数、无理数、虚数、复数。

Difficulty and discontinuity characterize paradigm change in the historical development of science and mathematics and are present in all of the examples I discussed. Thus deep thinking is often associated with controversy and crisis. In mathematics the problematic elements in paradigm change are obvious from the words that were historically associated with the development of the number concept: negative, irrational, imaginary, complex.

正如第一章总结部分所提到的，“自然性”和“困难性”的性质之间似乎存在矛盾。如果它是自然的，它怎么会困难呢？答案是，有某种东西阻碍了深度思考的自然运作。我们被我们看待世界的方式所吸引，换句话说，被我们运作的概念系统所吸引，并拒绝放弃它。要继续前进，我们必须打破我们对当前观点的执着。这总是困难的，甚至是痛苦的。

As was mentioned in the summary section of chapter one, there is a seeming inconsistency between the properties of “naturalness” and “difficulty.” If it is natural how can it be difficult? The answer will turn out to be that there is something that blocks the natural functioning of deep thinking. We are captivated with the way we have come to see the world, in other words, with our operative conceptual system, and refuse to give it up. To move on our fixation with our present views must be broken down. This is always difficult and even painful.

可以用一个系统的语言来表述的问题通常无法在该系统内得到解决，因为解决方案取决于新系统的开发。数学中充满了这样的例子，例如，通过考虑类似的复值函数，最容易理解实值函数的性质。随着新范式 CS 2的胜利，可能很难看出这一切为何如此喧嚣。从新的角度来看，一切都整合成一个一致而和谐的整体——我们从宏伟的新范式看世界，对其可能性感到兴奋，并充满了活力和热情。

Problems that can be stated in the language of one system often cannot be solved within that system because the solution depends upon the development of a new system. Mathematics is full of such examples such as when the properties of real-valued functions, for example, are most easily understood through considering the analogous complex-valued functions. With the victory of the new paradigm, CS2, it may be hard to see what the fuss was all about. From the new point of view everything is integrated into one consistent and harmonious whole—we look at the world from our magnificent new paradigm and are excited about its possibilities and filled with energy and enthusiasm.

不确定性和不完整性。不确定性是科学家的一种处境，他们允许自己接受与操作范式不一致或实际上与之相矛盾的假设。从心理上讲，这是一个艰难的处境。科学家是成年人，大多数人成年后的特点是内化了某种世界观。科学家往往内化了他们成长时期存在的范式。（第五章将详细介绍。）

Uncertainty and Incompleteness.Uncertainty characterizes the situation of the scientist who has allowed herself to entertain a hypothesis that is inconsistent with or actually contradicts the operational paradigm. Psychologically this is a hard place to be in. The scientist is an adult and adulthood in most people is characterized by having internalized a certain view of the world. Scientists tend to have internalized the paradigms that were in existence during their formative years. (More of this in chapter five.)

所有科学理论都是不完整和近似的。它们可能在它们描述的领域的核心部分发挥良好作用，但往往会在边界部分失效。范式通常是对现实某些方面的深刻洞察，但它们从未明确地捕捉到现实。

All scientific theories are incomplete and approximate. They may function well at the centre of the domain that they describe but tend to break down at the boundaries. Paradigms are usually deep insights into some aspect of reality but they never capture reality definitively.

重新构建。重构实际上是范式转变的同义词。它是深入思考的体现。你无法让它发生，也无法编造出一个公式、方法或程序来保证重构。在它发生之前，它似乎是不可能的；事后它似乎显而易见。

Reframing.Reframing is practically synonymous with paradigm change. It is deep thinking in action. You cannot make it happen nor can you concoct a formula, method, or procedure that will guarantee reframing. Before it happens it seems impossible; afterwards it seems obvious.

模糊性。范式转换总是伴随着模糊性。正如我在第一章中所讨论的，任何重要的概念都有多种表述，而驾驭这种情况需要很大的思维灵活性。

Ambiguity. Paradigm change always involves ambiguity. As I discussed in chapter one, any significant concept has there multiple representations and navigating such situations requires a great deal of mental flexibility.

物化。具体化是指建立层次结构的方式。某一级别的过程成为更高级别的对象。一个很好的例子涉及编程以及子程序集成到高级语言中的方式。数学中充满了这样的例子，它们既在认知层面起作用，也在形式数学层面起作用，例如，实数被定义为无限小数。

Reification.Reification refers to the manner in which hierarchies are established. Processes at one level become objects at a higher level. A good example involves programming and the way sub-routines are integrated into higher-level languages. Mathematics is replete with such examples that work both at the cognitive and also at the level of the formal mathematics where, for example, a real number is defined to be an infinite decimal.

层次结构和集成。这在数学中最为明显，但在科学中也很明显。新系统不会消灭旧系统；旧系统仍然存在，需要与新系统相结合。概念变化中有一些非常微妙的事情需要注意。一方面，新旧系统彼此不相容。另一方面，这两个系统可以整合。这意味着掌握了新思维方式的人具有灵活性，能够从两个或更多个角度看待情况不同的方式。值得注意的是，不仅概念系统是分层的，而且它们在自然世界中的客观投影（原子、分子、细胞等等）也是分层的。

Hierarchy and Integration.This is most obvious in mathematics but also evident in the sciences. The new system does not eradicate the old; the old remains around and needs to be integrated with the new. There is something very delicate going on in conceptual change that needs to be appreciated. On the one hand the new and the old are incompatible with one another. On the other the two systems can be integrated. This means that the person who has mastered the new way of thinking has the flexibility that goes with the ability to look at the situation in two or more different ways. It is important to note that not only are conceptual systems hierarchical but so are their objective projections into the natural world—atoms, molecules, cells, and so on.

系统思考。这种思维方式是特定范式含义得以解决的时期的特征。这是一个充满信心和力量的时期，以前似乎无法解决的新问题正在得到解决。人们常常觉得，只要有足够的计算能力，范式就足以解决所有问题。物理学在其历史上曾多次处于这种境地。就数字计算机的潜力而言，或者就 DNA 研究的潜力而言，生物科学也处于这种境地。

Systematic Thinking.This is the kind of thinking that characterizes the period in which the implications of a given paradigm are being worked out. It is a period of great confidence and power when new problems are being resolved that formerly appeared to be unresovable. Often there is the feeling that the paradigm is powerful enough to resolve all problems given enough computational power. Physics has found itself in that position repeatedly in its history. We are in that situation today with respect to the potential of the digital computer or in the biological sciences with respect to the potentialities of DNA research.

i这条评论通常被认为是物理学家马克斯·普朗克说的。

i This comment is usually attributed to the physicist Max Planck.

ii Eliade, (1957)。第 1 章。

ii Eliade, (1957). Chapter 1.

iii Low,（1997 年），第 101 页。

iii Low, (1997). p. 101.

iv Byers,（2007 年）。第 153-157 页。

iv Byers, (2007). pp.153-157.

v Trudeau, (1987)。第 8 章。

v Trudeau, (1987). Chapter 8.

vi在 Byers (2007) 中进行了详细讨论。

vi Discussed at some length in Byers (2007).

vii Byers, (2007 年)。第 225-231 页。

vii Byers, (2007). pp. 225-231.

viii Tall, D.和Vinner, S.(1981年)。

viii Tall, D. and Vinner, S. (1981).

ix参见 Gardner (1985) 或 Miller (1984)。

ix C.f. Gardner (1985) or Miller (1984).

第四章

Chapter 4

心智和大脑的深度思考

Deep Thinking in the Mind and the Brain

4.1介绍

4.1Introduction

读到本书的这个阶段，读者可能会反对说，尽管我的主题是深度思考，但我实际上并没有说深度思考是什么或它是如何运作的。这是真的。不幸的是，深度思考不像逻辑、演绎思维那样可以给出相对简洁的描述。事实上，深度思考的一个特点恰恰是不可能以纯粹客观的方式描述它。在接下来的两章中，我们将开始明白为什么会这样。如果我能描述一种简单的概念学习或创造力方法，那不是很好吗？我会出名并赚很多钱。不幸的是，这种方法与我反复观察到的深度思考中不可避免地存在的困难相悖。缺乏一种可以客观制定的方法是这种困难的很大一部分。

At this stage in the book the reader might object that even though my topic is deep thinking, I have not actually said what deep thinking is or how it works. This is true. Unfortunately deep thinking is not like logical, deductive thinking which can be given a relatively concise description. In fact, one of the features of deep thinking is precisely that it is impossible to describe it in a manner which is purely objective. In the next two chapters we shall begin to see why this might be so. Wouldn’t it be lovely if I could describe a simple method for conceptual learning or creativity? I would become famous and make lots of money. Unfortunately such a method would go against my repeated observations of the kind of difficulty that is inevitably present in deep thinking. The absence of a method that could be objectively formulated is a good part of that difficulty.

尽管如此，我们还是可以对深度思考过程中大脑的使用方式有所了解。在本章中，我将首先回顾另一位发展心理学家所描述的婴儿思维研究。然后，我将继续描述大脑神经科学的最新研究，以了解大脑的结构和功能如何阐明深度思考中发生的事情。

Nevertheless it is possible to get some feeling for the manner in which the mind is used in the process of deep thinking. In this chapter I shall begin by returning to work on the thinking of babies as described by another developmental psychologist. Then I shall go on to describe recent work on the neuroscience of the brain to see in what way the structure and function of the brain can shed light on what is going on in deep thinking.

在前面的章节中，我讨论了儿童基于数字的概念系统的发展以及数学和科学的发展。两者之间存在一些惊人的相似之处这些不同的发展过程，我的假设是，这些相似之处之所以存在，是因为两种情况下发生的过程都是一种创造力，而任何创造性过程总是以深度思考为核心。

In the previous chapters I have discussed the development of number-based conceptual systems in children and on the development of mathematics and science. There were some striking parallels between these different developmental processes and my hypothesis is that these parallels exist because the process that is going on in both cases is a form of creativity and that any creative process always has a core of deep thinking.

深度思考与意识有关，但这种联系非常微妙，我将在本章中讨论它。显然，深度思考涉及一个人的意识自我，但很明显，其中也有一些元素不是有意识的。雅克·阿达玛 (Jacques Hadamard)在其关于数学创造力的论文中强调了这一点，并解释了为什么洞察力在出现时常常看起来像是偶然发现的，感觉它来自自我之外的来源。

Deep thinking is connected to consciousness but the connection is quite subtle and I shall address it in this chapter. Obviously deep thinking involves one’s conscious self but it is also evident that there are elements of it that are not conscious. This is a point that is stressed by Jacques Hadamardi in his treatise on creativity in mathematics and explains why insight, when it comes, often seems like it is discovered serendipitously and feels like it comes from sources that are outside of the self.

我们通常认为，深度思考、创造力和学习都是人类大脑中独有的过程。另一方面，大脑和思维本身就是进化的产物，仔细想想，这也是一个创造性的过程。因此，大脑和意识不一定是创造力的先决条件，但可以坚持相反的命题，即大脑和意识都源于遵循与其他创造性过程相同的一般模式的过程。换句话说，大脑和思维的进化源于一种深度思考。

We normally think that deep thinking, creativity and learning, are processes that go on exclusively in the human brain. On the other hand, the brain and the mind are themselves the product of evolution, which, when you come to think of it, is also a creative process. So the brain and consciousness are not necessarily a prerequisite to creativity but it is possible to maintain the converse proposition, namely, that the brain and consciousness both arise out of a process that follows the same general pattern as other creative processes. In other words, the evolution of brain and mind arise out of a kind of deep thinking.

如果深度思考是事物的一个基本方面，那么我们期望它出现在儿童早期的发展中，事实上，我们已经发现，儿童在学习数字概念时涉及一种创造性过程。我们还期望我们的大脑结构和功能已经进化到有利于人类识别、处理和产生变化的能力。而且，深度思考确实存在于我们的思想和大脑中。

If deep thinking is such a basic aspect of things then we would expect to see it appear in the development of children at a very early age and, indeed, we have discovered that a kind of creative process is involved in children’s learning of the number concept. We would also expect that our brain structure and function have evolved in a way that facilitates human beings ability to recognize, work with, and produce change. And, indeed deep thinking is there to be seen in our minds and our brains.

我认为，深思熟虑和创造力是心灵的本质。它不仅是聪明成年人的专利；它不是人类的附属品，而是充分活着的本质。

Deep thinking and creativity are, I would argue, the essence of mind. It is not only the preserve of brilliant adults; it is not an add-on to human beings but the essential aspect of what it means to be fully alive.

4.2手电筒意识和灯笼意识

4.2Flashlight Consciousness and Lantern Consciousness

在本节中，我们将了解到深度思考与意识（我们的思想与世界互动的方式）之间的联系。这一提示将来自近期对发展心理学的更多研究。心理学研究婴儿和幼儿的思维方式。这将让我们感受到内心深处的思考是怎样的。

In this section we shall get a hint of how deep thinking is connected to consciousness—the way in which our minds interact with the world. This hint will come from additional recent research in developmental psychology on how babies and young children think. This will give us a sense of how deep thinking feels from the inside.

这种新视角将源自伯克利大学心理学教授艾莉森·戈普尼克 (Alison Gopnik) 在其著作《哲学婴儿：儿童的思想告诉我们关于真理、爱和生命意义的事情》中所描述的一些关于儿童发展的有趣研究。戈普尼克的书与深度思考的相关性始于她的导言，她在导言中描述了人类与变化之间的联系：

This new perspective will arise from some fascinating work in child development as described by Alison Gopnik, Professor of Psychology at Berkeley, in her book The Philosophical Baby: What Children’s Minds Tell Us about Truth, Love, and the Meaning of Life. The relevance of Gopnik’s book to deep thinking starts in her introduction where she describes the connection between human beings and change:

“关于人类的一个令人费解的事实是，我们改变的能力，无论是在我们自己的生活中还是在历史中，都是我们最独特和不变的东西。……神经科学家称之为可塑性——根据经验改变的能力，是从大脑、思想到社会各个层面的人性的关键……学习是这个过程的关键部分，但人类改变的能力不仅仅是学习。学习是关于世界改变我们思想的方式，但我们的思想也可以改变世界。……”

“The puzzling fact about human beings is that our capacity for change, both in our own lives and through history, is the most distinctive and unchanging thing about us. … What neuroscientists call plasticity— the ability to change in the light of experience is the key to human nature at every level from brains and minds to societies … Learning is a key part of the process, but the human capacity for change goes beyond just learning. Learning is about the way the world changes our mind, but our minds can also change the world. …”

深度思考与改变能力和学习能力密切相关。学习（“世界改变我们思维的方式”）和创造力（“我们的思维……改变世界的方式”）都涉及相同的基本机制，即深度思考。

Deep thinking is intimately connected with the ability to change and the ability to learn. Learning, “the way the world changes our mind,” and creativity, the way “our minds … change the world,” involve the same basic mechanism, namely, deep thinking.

戈普尼克这本书最著名、最吸引人的地方是她对意识的讨论。我们必须从中了解大脑在深度思考中的运作方式，而不是在正常成年人中运作的方式。

The best-known and most intriguing aspect of Gopnik’s book is her discussion of consciousness. This where we must look to get an idea about the way the mind functions in deep thinking as opposed to how it functions in the normal adult.

她说：“儿童和成人之间的所有这些差异表明，儿童的意识，即他们日常体验世界的结构，一定与我们截然不同。ii ……我们作为成年人看待世界的方式是否与我们过去和将来看待世界的方式一样？或者意识本身会改变吗？” iii

She says, “All these differences between children and adults suggest that children’s consciousness, the texture of their everyday experience of the world, must be very different from ours.ii … Is the way we see the world as adults the way we always have and always will see the world? Or could consciousness itself change?”iii

事实上，今天很明显，意识在进化——无论是从历史还是从发展的角度。然而，重要的是要记住，早期和更基本的意识形式并没有消失。它们一直存在，但这并不意味着人们意识到了它们。深度思考涉及使用这些更原始的思维方式。正如我们将在下一章中看到的那样，富有创造力的人不知何故能够获得这种意识模式。事实上，大多数人都可以接受创造性训练，而这种训练必然包括获取儿童时期特有的意识形式。

In fact it is clear today that consciousness evolves—both historically and developmentally. However it is important to remember that the earlier and more basic forms of consciousness do not disappear. They are always present but that does not mean that people are aware of them. Deep thinking involves accessing these more primitive ways of using the mind. Creative individuals, as we shall see in the next chapter, somehow have access to such modes of consciousness. In fact most people can be trained to be creative and this training will necessarily include accessing forms of consciousness that are characteristic of childhood.

Gopnik 继续说道：“至少从某些方面来看，婴儿比我们更有意识。iv ……婴儿和幼儿似乎无法像我们一样抑制干扰——他们的注意力不太集中。……因此，婴儿似乎让世界决定他们看什么，而不是决定看什么。婴儿似乎一次就能意识到更多的世界，而不是决定将注意力集中在哪里以及抑制干扰在哪里。他们不仅会获取对他们有用的特定物体的信息，还会获取有关周围所有物体的信息，尤其是当这些信息是新信息时。” v

Gopnik continues, “Babies are at least by some measures, more conscious than we are.iv… Babies and young children don’t seem to inhibit distractions as well as we do—their attention is less focused. … So rather than determining what to look at in the world, babies seem to let the world determine what they look at. And rather than deciding where to focus attention and where to inhibit distractions, babies seem to be conscious of much more of the world at once. They aren’t just picking up information about the specific objects that are useful to them—they are picking up information about all the objects around them, especially when that information is new.”v

“这种对广泛关注的能力使婴儿成为出色的学习者。……婴儿实际上比我们意识到更多、更强烈的事情，这是有道理的。成人的注意力焦点对婴儿来说更像是一盏注意力灯笼。他们不是只体验世界的某个方面，而关闭其他一切，而是似乎同时生动地体验着一切。”

“This capacity for very general attention makes babies such terrific learners. … It’s plausible that babies are actually aware of much more, much more intensely than we are. The attention spotlight in adults seems more like an attention lantern for babies. Instead of experiencing a single aspect of their world and shutting down everything else they seem to be vividly experiencing everything at once.”

“灯笼意识”和“手电筒意识”之间的区别为我们寻找深度思考的要素指明了方向。这一区别的重要性在于它将意识与学习和创造力联系起来。学习和创造力涉及以某种方式使用思维。但这种使用思维的方式不仅仅涉及我在第一章开头描述的正常的顺序、语言或符号思维。它不合逻辑，所以很多人会声称这根本不是思考。但它确实是一种心理功能模式，是我们婴儿时期很自然地就会做的事情，但成年后我们已经忘记了。因此，它是一种非常古老和基本的东西；但同时，对我们大多数人来说，它又是一种相当新的东西。婴儿不会挑选要关注什么。它会注意其感官领域内存在的事物，不会自我审查或做出判断。

The distinction between “lantern consciousness” and “flashlight consciousness,” gives direction to our search for the elements of deep thinking. The importance of this distinction is that it connects consciousness to learning and creativity. Learning and creativity involve using the mind in a certain way. But this way of using the mind does not just involve the normal sequential, verbal, or symbolic thinking that I described at the beginning of the first chapter. It is not logical and so many people would claim that it is not thinking at all. Yet it is certainly a mode of mental functioning, something that we all did quite naturally as babies but that we have forgotten as adults. It is therefore something very old and basic; yet simultaneously, it is, for most of us, something quite new. The baby is not picking and choosing what to attend to. It pays attention to what is present within its sensory field without censoring itself or making judgments.

戈普尼克将手电筒和灯笼意识与大脑过程联系起来，她继续说道：“有两种互补的大脑过程以这种方式依赖于经验。大脑在不同的神经元之间建立越来越多的联系，但它们会修剪减少较少使用的连接，只保留最有效的连接。这两个过程在整个发展过程中同时发生。两者都受到外部事件的影响。但平衡发生了变化——在生命早期，我们建立更多的连接，随着年龄的增长，我们开始修剪更多的连接。这些过程可能反映了互补的心理过程，甚至反映了我们体验的质量。在生命早期，我们对更多的可能性很敏感，而在生命后期，我们只关注那些最有可能对我们重要和相关的可能性。” vi

Gopnik connects flashlight and lantern consciousness to brain processes when she continues, “there are two complementary kinds of brain processes that depend on experience in this way. Brains make more and more connections between different neurons, but they prune the less-used connections and retain only the most-efficient ones. Both these processes take place simultaneously throughout development. Both are shaped by external events. But the balance changes—earlier in life we make more connections, and as we grow older we begin to prune more connections. These processes may reflect complementary psychological processes, and even reflect the quality of our experience. Early in life we are sensitive to more possibilities, while later in life we just focus on the possibilities that are most likely to be important and relevant to us.”vi

建立和修剪连接是存在于许多不同过程中的两极的例子。如今，技术变革迫使大多数人不断掌握新的思维方式，同时放弃已经变得低效或不合适的旧方式。如果我们认为概念系统对应于大脑中的一组回路，那么我们就可以开始看到深度思考的神经学基础。一个完善的范式或概念系统将对应于一组同样完善的大脑回路，因此很难修改。这将是我们观察到的深度思考和概念变化困难的生理相关性。个人往往会被那些通过反复使用而根深蒂固的回路所困扰。为了实现向新概念系统的飞跃，旧回路必须失去其霸权，也就是说，它们必须以某种方式崩溃。这种崩溃将由同时出现的一组相互冲突的需求引起。

Making and pruning connections are examples of the two poles that are present in many different processes. These days technological change forces most people to continually master new ways of thinking and to simultaneously abandon old ways that have become inefficient or inappropriate. If we think that a conceptual system corresponds to a set of circuits in the brain then we can begin to see the neurological basis for deep thinking. A well-established paradigm or conceptual system would correspond to a set of brain circuits that are also well established and thus difficult to modify. This would be the physiological correlate to our observation that deep thinking and conceptual change are difficult. The individual tends to get stuck with those circuits that are deeply entrenched through repeated use. In order to make the leap to a new conceptual system the old circuits must lose their hegemony, that is, they must break down in some way. This breakdown will arise from a simultaneous set of conflicting demands.

戈普尼克并不是第一个指出意识可以通过这两种不同的模式体验的人。她引用了伟大的心理学家威廉·詹姆斯的著作“他说，意识领域就像一束聚焦的光束，周围一片黑暗。”詹姆斯说，对于其他人，“我们可以假设边缘更亮，充满了类似流星雨的图像，这些图像随机地撞击它，取代了焦点思想。”

Gopnik is not the first person to draw attention to the fact that consciousness can be experienced in these two different modes. She refers to the work of the great psychologist William James when “he says [that] the field of consciousness is like a narrowly focused beam with darkness all around it.” For others, James says, “we may suppose the margin to be brighter, and to be filled with something like meteoric showers of images, which strike into it at random, displacing the focal ideas.”

戈普尼克继续指出，灯笼意识并非婴儿独有：“冥想和旅行似乎最终会导致哲学家所说的相同现象——相同类型的主观体验。……就像童年的灯笼意识一样与普通成人注意力的聚光灯意识相反。你清楚地意识到一切，但又不专注于任何一件事。这些经历也伴随着一种兴奋和一种特殊的幸福。” vii

Gopnik goes on to point out that lantern consciousness is not reserved for infants: “Meditation and travel seem to end up causing what philosophers call the same phenomenology—the same type of subjective experience. … It’s like the lantern consciousness of childhood as opposed to the spotlight consciousness of ordinary adult attention. You are vividly aware of everything without being focused on any one thing in particular. There is a kind of exaltation and a peculiar kind of happiness that goes with these experiences too.”vii

4.3观察与参与

4.3Observing and Participating

然而，灯笼意识和手电筒意识之间还有一个值得强调的区别。大卫·布鲁克斯在他最近的著作《社会动物》viii中指出了这一区别，他警告说，灯笼的比喻似乎暗示婴儿正在照亮和观察世界，特别是观察者与她所看到的东西是分开的。但事实恰恰相反，婴儿不是在观察，而是沉浸在这个世界中。她生动地参与到任何吸引她注意力的事情中。

However there is a further difference between lantern and flashlight consciousness that it is important to emphasize. This difference is pointed out by David Brooks in his recent book, The Social Animal,viii when he cautions that the lantern metaphor may seem to suggest that the infant is illuminating and observing the world and, in particular, that the observer is separate from what she sees. But, on the contrary, the infant isn’t observing but immersing herself in the world. She is vividly participating in whatever captures her attention.

当我发现“意识”这个词可能不是描述“灯笼意识”的正确词语时，我脑海中浮现的正是这种区别。通常，“意识”是及物动词——一个人意识到某事，也就是说，意识涉及二元论，一种观察。这适用于手电筒意识，但可能不适用于灯笼意识。Low ix试图通过使用“意识”一词来解决这个问题，然后将其分为他所谓的“意识”（手电筒意识）和“意识为”（灯笼意识）。

It is this distinction that I have in mind when I observe that consciousness might not be the right word for what is going on in “lantern consciousness.” Normally consciousness is used in a transitive sense—one is conscious of something, that is, consciousness involves a dualism, a kind of observation. This would apply to flashlight consciousness but perhaps not to lantern consciousness. Lowix tries to get around this problem by using the word “awareness” and then splitting it into what he calls “awareness of” (flashlight consciousness) and “awareness as” (lantern consciousness).

手电筒意识涉及假设观察者的身份——站在情况之外。如果你想分析事物，这是你唯一可以采取的立场。换句话说，分析是建立在手电筒、观察意识之上的。另一方面，灯笼意识涉及参与。因为参与不需要明确区分自我和情况，所以它是一种更亲密、更全面的意识形式。

Flashlight consciousness involves assuming the status of observer— standing outside of the situation. This is the only stance that you can take if you wish to analyze things. In other words analysis is built upon flashlight, observational consciousness. Lantern consciousness, on the other hand, involves participation. Because participation does not require a clear differentiation between the self and the situation, it is a more intimate and more holistic form of awareness.

作为成年人，我们仍然可以参与和观察。当我坐在书房里时，我可以观察房间的细节——书籍、电脑、书桌。我从外面观察。或者我可以感觉自己是房间的一部分，是某个更大事物的一部分。我从里面观察。所以我们从外面观察，从里面参与。这是一个至关重要的区别，值得一提的是，我们早年都是在灯笼、参与模式中度过的，后来才发展出成年时期特有的观察态度。接下来我将讨论的综合根源于灯笼意识，因此，它与更原始的思维方式有着密切的关系。

Participation and observation remain accessible to us as adults. When I sit in my study I can look at the details of the room—the books, the computer, the desk. I do this from the outside. Or else I can feel myself as part of the room, as part of something larger. I do this from the inside. So we observe from the outside and participate from inside. This is a vital distinction and it is well to recall that we all spent our early years in the lantern, participatory, mode and only later developed the observational stance that is so characteristic of adulthood. Synthesis, which I shall discuss next, has its roots in lantern consciousness and, for this reason, has an affinity to a more primitive way of thinking.

通常，智力与分析能力有关，因此也与闪光灯意识有关。然而，婴儿也是聪明的——事实上是极其聪明的——但她的智力显然不是闪光灯意识的智力。这里的重点是，深度思考，即创造力和概念学习中涉及的思考，也不仅仅涉及闪光灯意识和分析智力。让我们继续探索这两种使用思维方式的本质。

Normally intelligence is identified with the analytic and therefore with flashlight consciousness. However a baby is also intelligent— extremely intelligent in fact—yet her intelligence is clearly not the intelligence of flashlight consciousness. The point here is that deep thinking, the kind of thinking that is involved in creativity and conceptual learning, also involves more than flashlight consciousness and the analytic intelligence. Let’s go on to explore the nature of these two ways of using the mind.

4.4分析思维与综合思维

4.4Analytic and Synthetic Thought

如今，当学生被要求就某个主题写一篇学期论文时，他们要做的第一件事就是使用 Google 或 Wikipedia 等电子数据库收集大量信息。许多人似乎认为，为了写一篇学期论文，他们只需要收集和组织相关材料。这涉及两个步骤——研究，对他们来说，这意味着收集相关数据，以及展示，这似乎只涉及修剪和组织数据。然而，在某个时候，学生们意识到学期论文不仅仅是事实的集合；它必须说些什么。它必须围绕一个想法或论点组织起来，并且必须提出支持该论点的论点。论点对论文至关重要，它催生了论文的结构，提供了意义和连贯性。这个基本要素经常给学生带来问题。“论点从何而来？”她问道。“我如何让读者相信我的论点是有意义的？”论点的作用是统一数据。它通常可以用一两句话来表达，但它是论文的核心——没有它，你甚至不能称它为论文，而只是一连串模糊相关的想法。

These days when students are asked to write a term paper on a given topic the first thing that they do is to collect a mass of information using electronic data bases such as Google or Wikipedia. Many seem to believe that in order to write a term paper they need only collect and organize the relevant material. This involves two steps—research, which for them means collecting the relevant data, and presentation, which seems to only involve pruning and organizing the data. However, at some point students realize that a term paper is more than a collection of facts; it must say something. It must be organized around an idea or thesis and must make an argument that supports the thesis. The thesis is essential to the paper, giving birth to its structure, providing meaning and coherence. This essential ingredient is often problematic for the student. “Where does the thesis come from?” she asks. “How do I convince the reader that my thesis makes sense?” A thesis serves the purpose of unifying the data. It can usually be stated in one or two sentences yet it is the heart of the paper—without it you can’t really even call it a paper but just a meandering flow of vaguely associated thoughts.

计算机擅长生成数据，但不太擅长组织数据或确定其重要性。计算机不会告诉你一本书或一篇论文的含义，也无法揭示其核心生成思想。中心组织原则是学期论文中的创意元素。像所有创意活动一样，它的起源有点神秘。它始于一个模糊的暗示或感觉，即在你所观察的情况中，有某种系统性的东西在发生，即使在这个阶段你还不能完全明确地说明这种模式。实际上，在这个阶段，你经常会拒绝过于严格地定义这个想法。

A computer is great for generating data but not so good at organizing the data or determining its significance. A computer won’t tell you what a book or a paper means nor can it reveal its central generating idea. The central organizing principle is the creative element in the term paper. Like all creative activity its origins are a little mysterious. It begins with a vague hint or feeling that there is something systematic going on within the situation that you are looking at even if at this stage you can’t quite make that pattern explicit. Actually at this stage you often resist defining the idea too rigidly.

这个想法在写作中得到了清晰的表达，因此人们后来可以对自己说：“啊！原来这就是我想要说的。”然而，当你看到的不是随机事实，而是统一的有意义的信息时，论点就会突然出现。统一信息的论点或想法涉及综合思维。顾名思义，综合涉及将各种元素组合成一个整体。但是，综合可以从强或弱的意义上来理解。在弱意义上，整体只不过是一个包含信息位的容器。但是，我将以更强的意义使用综合：整体大于部分之和，其属性不能从部分的属性中预测出来。这样一来，单词就不仅仅是字母的集合了。水是氢和氧的合成，但其属性是“突现的”，也就是说，它们不是从这两种气体的属性中直接获得的。水是一种全新的东西！正是这样，毕达哥拉斯学派才不会仅仅将“三”视为“一加一加一”，而是将其视为一种全新的、性质完全不同的东西。格式塔心理学强调“整体”的重要性和基本性质，但由于分析思维在文化中占主导地位，我们很难理解他们的意思。综合思维以整体或统一为基础。

The idea gets articulated in the writing itself so that one can later say to oneself, “Ah! So that’s what I was trying to say.” Nevertheless the thesis arrives suddenly when, instead of random facts, you are now looking at a unified body of information that makes sense. The thesis or idea that unifies the information involves synthetic thought. Synthesis, as the name implies, involves combining various elements into a whole. However, synthesis can be understood in a strong or a weak sense. In the weak sense the whole is nothing more than a vessel that contains the bits of information. However I shall use synthesis in a stronger sense: the whole is greater than the sum of it parts and its properties cannot be anticipated from the properties of the parts. In this way words are not just collections of letters. Water is a synthesis of hydrogen and oxygen but its properties are “emergent,” that is they are not immediate from the properties of those two gases. Water is something entirely new! In just this way the Pythagoreans would not just see “three” as “one plus one plus one” but as something entirely new, something qualitatively different. Gestalt psychology emphasized the importance and elementary nature of “wholes” but we have trouble understanding what they were getting at because of the cultural dominance of analytic thinking. Synthetic thinking takes the wholes or unities as basic.

让我们回到学期论文，并指出，证明你的论点是正确的，所使用的思维方式与最初提出论点的思维方式不同。提出论点通常涉及逻辑推理——需要的是支持论点有效性的逻辑论证。逻辑论证从一组假设开始，这些假设被认为是真实的，然后通过一系列有限的可接受步骤得出结论，即论点。在最好的逻辑论证中，假设是不证自明的。在数学和许多其他领域，我们通常将这种不证自明的真理称为公理。整个过程称为分析或分析方法。它涉及将事物分解为最基本的组成部分，然后使用逻辑论证将这些思想原子构建成复杂的结构或结论。科学理论通常以这种方式组织。这是一种使用思维的强大方法，在古希腊的数学家、科学家和哲学家中占据主导地位。计算机程序具有相同的结构，只是它涉及逻辑程序而不是逻辑论证。尽管如此，形式是相同的——计算机模拟使用思维的分析方式。

Let’s go back to the term paper and point out that making a case that your thesis is correct uses a different way of thinking than the thinking that was used to produce the thesis in the first place. Making the case usually involves logical reasoning—what is required is a logical argument that will support the validity of the thesis. A logical argument starts with a set of assumptions, which are assumed to be true, and moves to a conclusion, the thesis, via a finite sequence of acceptable steps. In the best logical arguments the assumptions would be self-evidently true. In mathematics and in many other fields we usually call such self-evident truths axioms. This whole procedure is called analysis or the analytic method. It involves breaking things down to their most elementary constituents and then using logical argument to build up these atoms of thought into complex structures or conclusions. Scientific theories are often organized in this way. It is a powerful way of using the mind, which came into prominence with the mathematicians, scientists, and philosophers of Ancient Greece. A computer program has the same structure except here it involves a logical procedure not a logical argument. Nevertheless the form is the same—the computer simulates the analytic way of using the mind.

仔细区分这两种思维方式很重要，特别是要确定分析思维和综合思维在思维中的适当作用。否则，就会陷入根本性的误解。这种误解之一是相信论点是逻辑论证的结果，但事实并非如此。论点通常在论证开始之前就存在了，因为没有它，人们就不知道从哪里开始逻辑序列。在数学中，“逆向思考”很常见，也就是说，从结论开始，问自己什么需要为真才能使结论成立。必要条件是什么？

It is important to carefully distinguish between these two ways of thinking, in particular, to identify the appropriate role of the analytic and the synthetic in thought. Otherwise, one opens the door to fundamental misconceptions. One such misconception is the belief that a thesis arises as a result of a logical argument when this is not necessarily the case. The thesis usually exists before the argument has even begun since, without it, one would not know where to begin the logical sequence. In mathematics it is common to “think backwards”, that is, begin with the conclusion and ask yourself what needs to be true in order for the conclusion to hold. What is the necessary condition?

也许这种混淆是因为结论出现在论证的最后。如果一个人关注论证而不是基本思想，我们倾向于认为结论是由于论证而产生的。逻辑顺序与创造或学习顺序并不相同。在研究或学习中，以各种方式探索情况会导致人们在情况要素中辨别出规律、模式或结构，这些规律、模式或结构在一个统一的思想中显现出来。我们正在研究的情况的要素很可能不一致、模棱两可或相互矛盾。创造性思想源于这种不连贯性，而不是逻辑顺序或论证。

Perhaps this confusion arises because the conclusion appears at the very end of an argument. If one focuses on the argument and not on the underlying idea, we tend to think that the conclusion arises because of the argument. The logical sequence is not identical to the creative or the learning sequence. In research or learning, exploring the situation in various ways leads to the moment when one discerns a regularity, pattern, or structure in the elements of the situation, which is revealed in a unifying idea. The elements of the situation we are studying may well be inconsistent, ambiguous, or contradictory. The creative idea arises out of this incoherence not the logical sequence or argumentation.
