只有在论点进入意识之后，人们才开始发展正式论证的过程。正式论证存在的原因有很多——沟通、验证、澄清和将特定结果与大量理论材料相结合。然而，这不应该掩盖这样一个事实：人们经常朝一个方向思考，却朝相反的方向辩护。现在，分析性思考可能会发现论点并不完全正确，需要修改，但它不会告诉您需要进行哪些修改。这里的要点是，有两种使用心智的方式结合在一起产生学期论文或任何数学或科学结果。综合思维是这个过程的开始，分析思维在后续阶段出现。我们将在下一节中看到，这两种使用心智的方式反映在大脑的结构和功能中。大脑似乎包含两种不同体验世界的方式的潜力，它们直接对应于分析和综合。有趣的是，这两种存在方式并不能和平共处。分析者倾向于否认综合者的存在。

It is only after the thesis has come to conscious awareness that one begins the process of developing the formal argument. The formal argument is there for a number of reasons—communication, verification, clarification, and integration of the particular result with a larger body of theoretical material. However this should not obscure the fact that one often thinks in one direction and justifies in the opposite direction. Now thinking analytically may well reveal that the thesis is not quite right and needs to be modified but it will not tell you what modifications are necessary. The point here is that there are two ways of using the mind that come together to produce the term paper or any mathematical or scientific result. Synthetic thought is where the process begins and analytic thought arises at a subsequent stage. We shall see in the next section that these two ways of using the mind are mirrored in the structure and function of the brain. The brain appears to contain the potential for two distinct ways of experiencing the world, which correspond directly to the analytic and synthetic. The interesting thing is that these two ways of being in the world do not cohabitate peacefully. There is a tendency for the analytic to deny the existence of the synthetic.

分析思维从细节开始，将这些细节构建成对整个情况的更大描述，而综合思维则从大局开始。当你遇到你认识的人时，你看不到细节——胳膊和腿、鼻子和耳朵——你会看到乔治或玛丽。当你听到一首曲子时，你会认出整首曲子，而不是调或单个音符。当你阅读时，你会认出整个单词，基本上可以忽略字母的级别。这种信息的“聚集”涉及综合思维，是人类认知、数学家的思维方式和计算机编程方式的基础。每种情况下的细节都会消失在整体中。然后我们就可以解放出来，这样我们就可以只关注最高层次，因为更基本的层次的层次结构都包含在其中。然而，如果我们需要的话，细节是可以揭示的。由于我们的短期记忆一次只能容纳少量的独立命题，因此聚集机制使我们能够创建科学和数学中发现的极其详细的结构。将整个思维序列“聚集”成单元并为其命名的过程在计算机编程的例程和子程序中很常见，但它是一种非常普遍的使用思维的方式，并解释了数学家和其他人如何能够在头脑中记住极其复杂的论点。

Analytic thought begins with the details and builds these details into a larger description of the entire situation while synthetic thought begins with the big picture. When you encounter someone that you know, you don’t see the details—arms and legs, nose and ears—you see George or Mary. When you hear a tune you recognize the tune as a whole and not the key or the individual notes. When you read you recognize whole words and can basically ignore the level of letters. This kind of “clumping” of information involves synthetic thought and is the basis of human cognition, how mathematicians think, and how computers are programmed. The details in each case disappear into the whole. We then are freed up so that we can just attend to the highest level because the hierarchy of more elementary levels is enfolded within it. However the details can be revealed, if and when we need them. Since our short term memories are only capable of holding a small number of independent propositions at any one time the mechanism of clumping makes it possible for us to create the incredibly detailed structures that one finds in science and mathematics. This process of “clumping” whole sequences of thought together into units and giving them names is familiar from the routines and subroutines of computer programming but it is a quite general way of using the mind and explains how mathematicians and others are capable of holding in their minds arguments of extraordinary complexity.

综合和分析思维与手电筒和灯笼意识有何关系？显然，分析思维与手电筒意识有密切关系，而综合思维与灯笼意识有密切关系。思考既涉及分析，又涉及综合，但两者之间的关系存在着深刻而重要的问题。哪一个更为根本？它们是彼此独立的，还是其中一个可以归结为另一个？它们之间是否存在冲突？如果有，冲突如何解决？哪一个更有可能产生创造性的想法？哪一个能产生真理？

What is the relation of synthetic and analytic thought to flashlight and lantern consciousness? Clearly analytic thought has an affinity to flashlight consciousness and synthetic thought to lantern awareness. Thinking involves both the analytic and the synthetic but there are deep and important questions about the relationship between them. Which is more fundamental? Are they independent of one another or can one of them be reduced to the other? Is there a conflict between them and, if so, how is the conflict resolved? Which one is more likely to produce creative ideas? Which one produces the truth?

在我们的文化中，分析思维最受推崇，也更容易被理解。社会对这种思维寄予厚望。我们梦想着一台有感知能力的计算机——能够思考和创造——所以我们制作了关于智能机器人的电影。我们中的许多人都对人工智能软件的潜力感到非常兴奋。不幸的是，这种思维是循环的——分析思维产生了计算机，然后计算机成为分析思维的模型，并通过推理成为一般思维的模型。然而，分析思维能够“捕捉”现实的希望早在计算机出现之前就存在了。这种知识方法的早期倡导者是欧几里得，他发明了演绎法，后来，演绎法从几何学推广到其他领域。最终，它导致了对“最终”科学理论的梦想，该理论在一个庞大的演绎系统中明确地捕捉了所有的现实。

In our culture analytic thought has the best press and is more easily understood. Society has great hopes for this kind of thinking. We dream of a computer that is sentient—that thinks and creates—and so we make movies about intelligent robots. Many of us are very excited about the potential for artificial intelligence software. Unfortunately this kind of thinking is circular—analytic thought produces the computer, which then becomes a model for analytic thought and, by inference, for thought in general. However the hope that analytic thought can “capture” reality existed long before the computer came into existence. An early exponent of this kind of approach to knowledge was Euclid with his invention of the deductive method, which, at a later date, was generalized from geometry to other fields. Ultimately it led to the dream of a “final” scientific theory that definitively captures all of reality in a one massive deductive system.

这些梦想不过是相信分析思维具有无限潜力的信念——推理、一般思维的工作方式，更不用说自然世界运作的方式，都可以通过分析方法来描述。从这种观点来看，综合思维可以归结为分析思维。例如，许多人相信，有一天，我们有可能对计算机进行编程，使其具有创造力，并产生科学和数学理论，更不用说诗歌和音乐了。这是西方文明非常强大和非常古老的项目。然而，要实现它，我们必须回答以下关于写学期论文或构思一个有趣的科学实验的简单问题。论文或假设的想法从何而来？科学家如何知道在无数个假设中要测试哪一个？我们如何说一个论点比另一个论点“更好”或更重要？为什么一个特定的结果“深刻”或“优雅”甚至“美丽”？有些人认为这些问题没有答案，因为它们是“主观”的问题，但相反，意义和美的问题非常重要，尤其是在科学领域。当我们说这些问题没有答案时，我们实际上是说从纯粹的逻辑和分析的角度来看没有答案。“答案”是存在的，但来自于以不同的方式使用思维，以及对综合和分析思维的开放。

These dreams are nothing but the belief in the unlimited potential of analytic thought—that reasoning, the way the mind works in general, not to speak of the way in which the natural world functions, can be described via the analytic method. In this view of things synthetic thought can be reduced to the analytic. For example, many people believe that one day it will be possible to program a computer to be creative and produce scientific and mathematical theories not to mention poetry and music. This is a very powerful and very old project of Western civilization. However for it to be realized we would have to answer the following simple questions about writing a term paper or dreaming up an interesting scientific experiment. Where does the idea for the thesis or hypothesis come from? How does the scientist know which one of the potentially infinite number of hypotheses to test? How can we say that one argument is “better” or more significant than anther? Why is a particular result “deep” or “elegant” or even “beautiful”? Some people think that these questions have no answers because they are “subjective” but, on the contrary, questions of significance and beauty are of immense importance, especially, in science. When we say they have no answers we really mean that there are no answers from a purely logical and analytic point of view. The “answers” exist but come from using the mind differently and opening oneself up to synthetic as well as analytic thought.

这有点像学生在面对复杂而巧妙的数学论证时总会问的问题。“她（数学家）是如何想出这个证明的？”“我怎么能指望想出这样一个想法或任何想法呢？”这是学生在面对这样的论证时做出的另一个观察的变体。“我遵循它（推理），但我不理解它。”“遵循它”是一种分析思维的练习。计算机可以被编程来做到这一点，只要付出足够的努力，学生也可以被训练这样做（尽管让他们以这种方式思考变得越来越困难）。“理解它”是更微妙的东西。它意味着得到论证背后的想法，即最初产生论证的想法。这是学习的创造性核心——真正的教育就是如此。“理解”是一个不连续的创造性过程——你要么理解它，要么不理解——而且没有获得理解的算法方法。理解和提出一个想法都是创造性的过程，涉及综合和分析。

It’s a bit like the question that students invariably ask when presented with some complex and ingenious mathematical argument. “How did she (the mathematician) come up with the idea for the proof?” “How can I hope to come up with such an idea or any idea, for that matter?” This is a variant of another observation that students make when shown such an argument. “I follow it (the reasoning) but I don’t understand it.” “Following it” is an exercise in analytic thinking. Computers can be programmed to do it and with enough work students can also be trained to do so (even though it is getting increasingly difficult to get them to think in this way). “Understanding it” is something more subtle. It means getting the idea that stands behind the argument, the idea that produced the argument in the first place. This is the creative core of learning—what real education is all about. “Understanding” is a creative process that is discontinuous—you either understand it or you don’t— and there is no algorithmic way of attaining understanding. Understanding and coming up with an idea are both creative processes that involve both the synthetic and the analytic.

我们大多数人都熟悉分析思维——受教育程度越高的人就越熟悉它。综合思维更加神秘，正是因为它不是分析思维的功能，甚至不是正常成人意识的功能。它的起源比这更深、更原始。智商很低的人，所谓的白痴天才，能够拥有非凡的记忆力、数学、艺术和音乐才能，因为他们使用的心理能力与我们通常与智力联系在一起的能力不同。他们无需有意识地计算就能“知道”一个五位数是不是素数，或者111 分解成37 的三个副本，即使他们不会乘法，甚至无法想象乘法。x这是一种不同于我们与推理和分析思维联系在一起的“知道”。这是一种综合认知，而不是分析认知。阅读戈普尼克提醒我们，综合思维这种意识与我们婴儿时期的意识有着很大的相似之处，在婴儿时期，我们还没有学会分析和集中的意识，而大多数人成年后都是在这种意识中度过清醒的。

Analytic thought is familiar to most of us—the more educated you are the more familiar it is. Synthetic thought is more mysterious precisely because it is not a function of analytic thought or even of normal adult consciousness. Its origins are deeper and more primitive than that. People with very low I.Q.’s, so-called idiot savants, are capable of extraordinary feats of memory, mathematics, art, and music because they use different mental capabilities than the ones we normally associate with intelligence. They “know” without conscious calculation that a five-digit number is or is not a prime or that 111 decomposes into three copies of 37 even if they are unable to multiply or even conceive of multiplication.x This is a different kind of “knowing” than the one we associate with reasoning and analytic thought. It is a synthetic cognition rather than analytic. Reading Gopnik reminds us that synthetic thought has strong similarities to the kind of awareness we had as infants before we learned the analytic and focused consciousness within which most of us spend our waking adult lives.

4.5不对称的大脑

4.5The Asymmetrical Brain

我所讨论的心理二分法（分析与综合、观察与参与、手电筒意识与灯笼意识的对比）的重要性在神经心理学领域的最新研究中得到了强调。不同的思维方式自然与大脑结构和功能的差异相关。这并不一定意味着大脑的结构导致了这些不同的思维模式，这是看待大脑与思维之间关系的通常方式。它仅仅意味着一方面的思维和认知领域与另一方面的大脑结构和功能之间存在着系统的相关性。“同构”是这种相关性的数学术语。当然，在数学中，同构的概念具有从一个数学结构到另一个数学结构的一一映射的精确含义，它保留了结构的一些基本元素，例如当群同构保留乘法结构时，f ( a × b ) = f ( a ) × f ( b )。如果我说“心智与大脑同构”，那么我并不是在考虑这两个领域之间存在任何明确的映射，而是指出了心理过程与大脑结构和功能之间存在某些深层类比。

The significance of the pairs of mental dichotomies that I have been discussing—the analytic versus the synthetic, observing as against participating, or flashlight consciousness in comparison to lantern awareness—are highlighted by recent work in the field of neuropsychology. Different ways of using the mind naturally correlate with differences in brain structure and function. This does not necessarily mean that the structure of the brain causes these different modes of mind, which is the usual way of looking at the relationship between brain and mind. It merely means that there exists a systematic correlation between the domains of mind and cognition, on the one hand, and brain structure and function, on the other. “Isomorphism” is the mathematical word for this kind of correlation. Of course in mathematics the notion of isomorphism carries the precise meaning of a one-to-one mapping from one mathematical structure to another, which preserves some essential element of the structure such as when a group isomorphism preserves the multiplicative structure, f (a × b) = f (a) × f (b). If I say, “mind is isomorphic to brain,” I am not thinking of any explicit mapping between the two domains so much as I am pointing to certain deep analogies between mental processes and brain structure and function.

这本书从根本上是对同构过程的思考。例如，我认为发展与学习和创造是同构的。或者，正如认识论障碍的概念所强调的那样，数学学习重现了该学科历史发展中的重要事件。思考这些事情的方式是，我们对同一情况有两种不同的观点。例如，儿童发展和在学校进行的更系统的学习都有一个共同的过程。我们也可以把同构看作一个用两种不同的语言或从不同的角度描述同一情况。

This book is in a fundamental way a meditation on isomorphic processes. I suggest, for example, that development is isomorphic to learning and creating. Or, as is highlighted in the notion of epistemological obstacles, that the learning of mathematics recapitulates significant events from the historical development of the subject. The way to think about such things is that we have two different perspectives on the same situation. For example, there is a common process that underlies both child development and the more systematic learning that happens at school. We might also think about an isomorphism as a description of the same situation in two different languages or from different points of view.

微积分给出了这种双重视角的数学例子，其中微分和积分是两个视角。在这种情况下，同构是由微积分基本定理给出的，它使人们能够将语句从一种语言翻译成另一种语言。这允许你通过将它们翻译成另一个更容易解决的领域来解决一个领域的难题。这是建设性模糊性的基本价值。它允许你“重新构建”情况，这为你带来了新的力量和灵活性。

Calculus gives a mathematical example of such a dual perspective where the differential and integral calculus are the two perspectives. The isomorphism in this case is given by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, which enables one to translate statements from one language to the other. This allows you to solve difficult problems in one domain by translating them into the other where they may be easier to resolve. This is the essential value of constructive ambiguity. It allows you to “reframe” the situation and this gives you a new power and flexibility.

在本节中，我将关注两种不同的基本模糊性——一方面是大脑和思维，另一方面是左脑和右脑。我们有一个统一的大脑，大脑半球的划分很深。这为人类提供了两种思考和生存方式。大脑分叉有什么进化优势？这不仅仅是建立冗余的问题，因为这样两个半球的结构和功能就会对称，但事实并非如此。拥有这种心理二元性一定有进化优势。会是什么呢？也许大自然使得模糊大脑结构的进化成为必要或有利的。

In this section I am concerned with two different and fundamental ambiguities—brain and mind, on the one hand, and left and right hemisphere, on the other. We have one unified brain that has a deep hemispheric division. This gives human being two ways to think and to be in the world. What is the evolutionary advantage of having a bifurcated brain? It is not merely a matter of building in redundancy for then the two hemispheres would be symmetric in structure and function, which is not the case. There must be an evolutionary advantage to having this mental duality. What could it be? Perhaps nature makes the evolution of an ambiguous brain structure necessary or advantageous.

我在本书中讨论了各种模糊结构和过程。每个模糊性都由一个统一的情况组成，可以用两种相互冲突的方式来解释。我们看到了调和问题情况的需要是推动发展和学习的动力，我们将看到它是数学和科学创造力的关键要素。也许双重处理单元的存在是使人类生命成为动态、创造性和发展过程的生物动力。

I have discussed various kinds of ambiguous structures and processes in this book. Each ambiguity consists of one unified situation that can be interpreted in two, conflicting ways. We saw how the need to reconcile problematic situations was a motor that generates development and learning and we shall see that it is a key element in creativity in mathematics and science. Perhaps the existence of dual processing units is the biological motor that makes human life into the dynamic, creative, and developmental process that it is.

20 世纪 60 年代，人们对​​左右脑分裂的简单解释非常热衷。语言在左脑，几何在右脑，各种活动被描述为左脑或右脑。然而，现在看来，语言、数学、科学和创造力通常涉及两个半球。因此，今天的研究更加微妙。因为它对我的论文有如此重要的影响，我将花一点时间讨论现代研究的结果。我的主要资料来源是一个引人入胜的故事：大师和他的 《使者十一》​​的作者是伊恩·麦吉尔克里斯特，他是一位精神病学家、哲学家，也是牛津大学万灵学院的研究员。他和越来越多的人一样，从心理学和脑科学的实证结果的角度重新审视哲学中的一些传统问题。

The 1960’s saw a lot of enthusiasm for a simplistic interpretation of the left/right brain split. Language was on the left, geometry on the right and various activities were characterized as left or right brained. However it now appears that language, mathematics, science, and creativity in general involve both hemispheres. Accordingly the research today is much more subtle. Because it has such an important bearing on my thesis, I shall spend a little time discussing what modern research has to say. My primary source is a fascinating account: The Master and his Emissaryxi by Iain McGilchrist, a psychiatrist, philosopher, and Fellow of All Souls College at Oxford. He is part of a growing number of people who have revisited some of the traditional questions in philosophy from the point of view of the empirical results of psychology and brain science.

麦吉尔克里斯特的论点是：“对于我们人类来说，存在着两种根本上对立的现实，两种不同的体验模式；每一种对于形成可识别的人类世界都至关重要；而它们的差异则根源于大脑的双脑结构。”他问道：“为什么大脑会如此明显和深刻地分裂？为什么两个大脑半球是不对称的？”在寻找答案的过程中，他指出了综合和分析之间的区别，这让人想起了我之前的讨论：“关于大脑半球的一个更持久的概括是，左脑半球倾向于更多地处理孤立的信息，而右脑半球则倾向于处理作为一个整体的实体，即所谓的格式塔……两个大脑半球给我们提供了两个根本不同的‘版本’，这两个版本都具有真实性，并且都具有巨大的价值；但它们是彼此对立的，需要彼此分开——因此才有大脑的双半球结构。”

McGilchrist’s thesis is, “that for us as human beings there are two fundamentally opposed realities, two different modes of experience; that each is of ultimate importance in bringing about the recognizably human world; and that their difference is rooted in the bihemispheric structure of the brain.” “Why,” he asks, “is the brain so clearly and profoundly divided? Why, for that matter, are the two cerebral hemispheres asymmetrical?” In his search for an answer he points to the distinction between synthetic and analytic in terms that are very reminiscent of my earlier discussion: “One of the more durable generalizations about the hemispheres has been the finding that the left hemisphere tends to deal more with pieces of information in isolation, and the right hemisphere with the entity as a whole, the so-called Gestalt … there are two fundamentally different ‘versions’ delivered to us by the two hemispheres, both of which can have a ring of authenticity about them, and both of which are hugely valuable; but that they stand in opposition to one another, and need to be kept apart from one another—hence the bihemispheric structure of the brain.”

正是这种“对立”是理解大脑半球分化的关键。我们已经看到，“对立”是深度思考本身存在困难的原因，这种困难可能以模糊性、矛盾性的形式出现，也可能仅仅是不和谐或冲突。我坚持认为，与单​​纯的差异相反，对立才是关键因素，因为正是对立以及克服对立的需要，构成了我们精神生活和整个发展活力的基础。这种对立不是由于错误而产生的，而是生命的本质。“从某种意义上说，大脑是一个对立处理器系统。换句话说，它包含相互对立的元素，这些元素的相反影响使得对复杂情况做出精确响应成为可能。” xii

It is this “opposition” that is the key to understanding hemispheric differentiation. We have seen that “opposition” is the reason that deep thinking has an intrinsic difficulty, which can arise in the form of ambiguity, contradiction, or merely as dissonance or conflict. I insist that opposition, as opposed to mere difference, is the crucial factor because it is opposition, and the need to overcome it, that underlies the dynamism of our mental life and of development in general. Such opposition does not arise as a result of a mistake but is the essence of life. “The brain is, in one sense, a system of opponent processors. In other words, it contains mutually opposed elements whose contrary influence makes possible finely calibrated responses to complex situations.”xii

由于大脑两个半球的功能不同，因此有两种不同的思维方式。我们有两种相对完整的认知器官。这并不是说大脑半球是观察预先存在的世界的不同方式，而是说每个方式都是存在于世界中的独特方式。在某种程度上，每个大脑半球都带来了不同的人类体验世界。

There are two different ways of using the mind that arise out of the disparate functioning of the two cerebral hemispheres. We have two relatively complete cognitive apparatuses. It is not that the hemispheres are different modalities from which to look at a pre-existing world but that each modality is a distinct way of being in the world. In a way each hemisphere brings a different world of human experience into existence.

这两种模式之间的冲突对麦吉尔克里斯特来说至关重要。他的书旨在公开讨论这种冲突，并探讨其对西方文化（过去和现在）的影响。正是对大脑两种冲突模式的强调引起了我对他的书的兴趣，因为它似乎为我一直以来对发展和创造力的观点提供了实证支持。我声称，每个概念系统都是一个现实的窗口，两个这样的系统不可避免地会发生冲突，因为现实总是与特定的概念系统相联系。如果我们两个半球支持的两个认知系统产生了两个不同的世界，那么首先就会导致巨大的不和谐。整合和和谐即使能实现，也只能是后来的事情。我们必须以某种方式努力工作，才能产生更高层次的综合。正是这种艰难的活动让我一直与发展、学习和创造力联系在一起。

It is the conflict between these two modalities that is crucial to McGilchrist. His book is meant to bring this conflict out into the open and explore its implications for western culture, past and present. It was this stress on the brain’s two conflicting modes that aroused my interest in his book because it seemed to provide empirical support for the point of view that I have been taking about development and creativity. I claimed that every conceptual system is a window on reality and that two such systems inevitably conflict because reality is always identified with a particular conceptual system. If the two cognitive systems supported by our two hemispheres produce two different worlds then this would lead to great discord, in the first instance. Integration and harmony would only come later, if at all. We would have to work hard in one way or another to produce a higher-level synthesis. It is this kind of difficult activity that I have been associating with development, learning, and creativity.

这种观点与通常的观点截然不同，在这种观点中，我们理所当然地认为大脑半球活动的整合本身就是内在的。我们往往对这样一种观点感到厌烦：人类内心存在着冲突，而包括科学和艺术在内的许多生活和文化都是解决这种冲突的尝试。幸运或不幸的是，不可化解的冲突就是事实。

This view is very different from the normal one in which we take for granted that the integration of the activities of our cerebral hemispheres is itself built-in. We tend to be put off by the idea that human beings carry around a conflict within themselvesxiii and that much of life and culture, including science and the arts, are attempts to resolve this conflict. Fortunately or unfortunately, irreducible conflict is the way things are.

各种类型的解决方案都是可能的。xiv我的书是关于通过创造力、发展和学习而产生的建设性解决方案。其他更具破坏性的解决方案也是可能的，它们源于压抑思想的一个方面以支持另一个方面。当投射到外部世界时，它会导致所谓的“好”与“坏”或“其他”进行无休止的斗争，以取得最终胜利。这场战斗也可以被定义为“光明”对抗“黑暗”，或“纯洁”对抗“不纯洁”。以这种方式构建情况会使冲突看起来不可调和，因此往往会演变成暴力。

Various types of resolutions are possible.xiv My book is about constructive kinds of resolutions that occur through creativity, development, and learning. Other, more destructive, resolutions are also possible and arise from suppressing one aspect of mind in favor of the other. When projected out into the external world it leads to the endless struggles of the so-called “good” for a definitive victory over the “bad” or the “other.” This battle can also be framed as the “light” against the “dark”, or the “pure” against the “impure”. Framing a situation in this way makes the conflict appear to be irreconcilable and so often degenerates into violence.

这种压制的动态也可以在数学和科学中找到，但愿冲突不会导致暴力（尽管我们不要忘记伽利略和教会这样的事件）。人们在科学和数学中观察到一种强烈的倾向，即把“左半球”的观点强加为真实的（我将在下文中描述这意味着什么和暗示什么）。这包括将大脑视为一种计算机，或以严格形式化、演绎的方式看待数学。

This dynamic of suppression can also be found in mathematics and science where, hopefully, conflict does not lead to violence (although let’s not forget episodes like Galileo and the Church). What one observes in science and mathematics is a powerful tendency to impose a “left-hemisphere” view as real (and I shall describe below what this means and implies). This would include seeing the brain as a kind of computer or viewing mathematics in strictly formal, deductive terms.

本书的其他地方也提到了我们持有两种相互矛盾的观点的情况。例如，根据 Carey 的说法，数字有两个核心概念系统。为什么是两个而不是一个独特的系统？可能是因为两个半球系统对“数字”的看法不同，而且我在第一章中详细描述的数字特征与 McGilchrist 所描述的两个半球的认知特征非常吻合。这再次证明了核心系统之间的差异源于大脑的分裂，而随后的发展是由调和这些差异的需要推动的。

Situations where we have two conflicting views have come up in other places in this book. For example there are, according to Carey, two core conceptual systems for number. Why two and not just one unique system? Possibly because the two hemispheric systems look at “number” differently, and indeed, the characteristics of number that I detailed in chapter one fit nicely with the characteristic modes of cognition of the two hemispheres as McGilchrist describes them. This is another bit of evidence that the differences between the core systems arise out of the divided brain and that subsequent development is pushed along by the need to reconcile these differences.

我们将在下一章中看到，创造力领域的各种研究人员认为，创造过程中的关键步骤是同时在头脑中持有两个相互矛盾的想法。因此，创造力取决于二元性和冲突。在本节中，我们将讨论大脑如何也包含由其分叉的结构和功能引起的二元性和冲突。在我看来，这意味着大脑被设计成一个创造性发展和学习的器官。大脑不是被设计成一台照相机，拍摄现实的快照。它旨在促进创造性发展和学习，要做到这一点，你需要不同的、相互冲突的观点。

As we shall see in the next chapter various researchers in the field of creativity hold that the vital step in the creative process involves holding two contradictory ideas in the mind simultaneously. Thus creativity depends on duality and conflict. In this section we are discussing how the brain also contains duality and conflict that arises from its bifurcated structure and function. This implies to me that the brain is set up to be an organ of creative development and learning. The brain is not set up to be a camera and take snapshots of reality. It is designed to facilitate creative development and learning and to do that you require different points of view that conflict with one another.

这是大自然智慧赐予我们的工具。然而，我想把我的观点完全说清楚，并重申大脑的结构不一定“导致”分析和综合思维或我一直在讨论的任何其他二分法。我认为，导致使用思维的不同方式的相同潜在情况也反映在大脑的结构和功能专业化中。并不是“思维导致大脑”或“大脑导致思维”，而是大脑和思维都源于我在本书中记录的相同创造过程。

This is the kind of instrument with which nature in her wisdom has provided us. However I want to make my perspective perfectly clear and repeat that the structure of the brain does not necessarily “cause” analytic and synthetic thought or any of the other dichotomies that I have been discussing. I maintain that the same underlying situation that leads to different ways of using the mind is also reflected in the structure and functional specialization of the brain. It is not that “mind causes brain” or that “brain causes mind” but that both brain and mind arise out of the same creative process that I have been documenting in this book.

如果我们的大脑确实如此划分，那么这可不是什么好消息。两个部分都声称自己是“我”，但当然，“我”只有一个。有人可能会说，两个半球通过胼胝体进行交流，从而相互合作，这在一定程度上是正确的。但胼胝体的主要功能之一就是抑制交流，这也是事实！正是这种抑制使得每个半球都能产生稳定一致的世界观。这两种观点之间存在统一性，但这种统一性往往是隐性的而非显性的，也就是说，我们不一定意识到这一点。在意识层面，我们常常认同一种观点——在“现代”人中，这种观点就是左半球特有的分析性观点。另一种观点常常被压抑或否认。

If it is indeed true that our brains are divided in this way, then it is not entirely good news. Both parts have a claim to be “me” but, of course, there can only be one “me.” One might argue that the two hemispheres communicate through the corpus callosum and so cooperate with one another and this would be true to a certain extent. But it is also true that a prime function of the corpus callosum is to inhibit communication! It is this inhibition that makes it possible for each of the hemispheres to produce a stable and consistent view of the world. There is a unity underlying these two views but it is often implicit not explicit, that is, we are not necessarily conscious of it. At the conscious level we often identify with one view—in “modern” people this would be the analytic view that is characteristic of the left hemisphere. Often the other view is repressed or denied.

这种内在的分裂是人类取得最大成就的源泉，但也是人类生活如此艰难的原因。我们的本性要求解决这种二元性，我们都被驱使着朝这个方向前进。创造力是回应这一呼唤的一种方式。学习、创造力和发展不是奢侈品，而是必需品。没有创造性的解决方案，人们只能采取镇压和暴力的流产伪解决方案。但毫无疑问，无论如何，这种深刻的分裂都会产生某种解决方案。选择实际上只是在解决方案的性质是建设性的还是破坏性的之间。

This inner division is the source of humanity’s greatest triumphs but it is also why human life is so difficult. Our very nature calls out for a resolution to this duality and we are all driven in this direction. Creativity is a way of answering this call. Learning, creativity, and development are not luxuries but necessities. Without a creative resolution one is left with the abortive pseudo-resolution of repression and violence. But make no mistake about it, one way or another this deep schism will generate some sort of resolution. The choice is really only between whether the nature of that resolution will be constructive or destructive.

4.6半球的世界观

4.6The Worldview of the Hemispheres

当一群加拿大鹅在觅食时，其中一两只成年雄鹅会以直立、专注的姿势站岗，让其他鹅可以专心觅食。这是大多数动物（包括人类）能够发挥的两种注意力的一个很好的例子。这是我之前所说的专注和非专注意识的基本形式。这两种意识都是两个半球之一的特征。这两种意识都是必要和重要的。一方面，我们必须能够专注于手头的任务，忽略任何不直接相关的事情。另一方面，我们必须我们必须对危险和机遇保持警惕；我们必须对新的和意想不到的事物保持开放态度。

When a flock of Canada geese is feeding, one or two of the adult males stand guard in an upright, attentive posture which leaves the rest of the flock free to focus on feeding. This is a good example of the two types of attention that most animals including humans can bring to bear. It is a rudimentary form of what I earlier called focused and unfocused awareness. Each of these types of awareness is a characteristic of one of the two hemispheres. Both types of awareness are necessary and important. On the one hand we must be able to focus on the task at hand and ignore anything that is not immediately relevant. On the other we must be on the alert for danger and opportunity; we must be open to what is new and unexpected.

麦吉尔克里斯特说：“一般来说，左半球的注意力狭窄而集中，……右半球的注意力广泛而警觉，……”他继续说道，“人类的每个半球都以不同的方式关注世界，而且方式是一致的。右半球负责注意力的广度和灵活性，左半球则负责集中注意力。这导致了右半球看到事物的整体和背景，而左半球看到的事物脱离背景，被分解成多个部分，然后从中重建一个‘整体’：一个完全不同的东西。”这个描述应该引起我的注意，因为它让我想起了我之前对心智特征的讨论：分析和综合思维或手电筒和灯笼意识。

McGilchrist says, “In general terms, then, the left hemisphere yields narrow, focused attention, … The right hemisphere yields a broad, vigilant attention, …” and he continues, “In humans …each hemisphere attends to the world in a different way—and the ways are consistent. The right hemisphere underwrites breadth and flexibility of attention, where the left hemisphere brings to bear focused attention. This has the related consequence that the right hemisphere sees things whole, and in their context, where the left hemisphere sees things abstracted from context, and broken into parts, from which it then reconstructs a ‘whole’: something very different.” This description should ring a bell because it is reminiscent of my earlier discussion of the characteristics of mind: analytic and synthetic thought or flashlight and lantern consciousness.

他总结道：“因此，大脑必须以两种完全不同的方式关注世界，从而创造出两个不同的世界。在其中一个世界中，我们体验到活生生、复杂、具象的个体世界，它们总是独一无二的，永远处于变化之中，是一个相互依存的网络，形成和重塑整体，一个与我们息息相关的世界。在另一个世界中，我们以一种特殊的方式‘体验’我们的体验：一种‘重新呈现’的版本，包含现在静态、可分离、有界但本质上支离破碎的实体，这些实体被分组为类别，可以以此为基础进行预测。这种注意力通过将每件事置于注意力的聚光灯下，将其隔离、固定并使其明确化。这样做会使事物变得呆板、机械、毫无生气。但它也使我们第一次能够了解，从而学习和创造事物。这给了我们力量。”

He summarizes, “Hence the brain has to attend to the world in two completely different ways, and in so doing bring two different worlds into being. In the one, we experience the live, complex, embodied, world of individual, always unique beings, forever in flux, a net of interdependencies, forming and reforming wholes, a world with which we are deeply connected. In the other we ‘experience’ our experience in a special way: a ‘re-presented’ version of it, containing now static, separable, bounded, but essentially fragmented entities, grouped into classes, on which predictions can be based. This kind of attention isolates, fixes and makes each thing explicit by bringing it under the spotlight of attention. In doing so it renders things inert, mechanical, lifeless. But it also enables us for the first time to know, and consequently to learn and to make things. This gives us power.”

这种对左右半球偏好的描述对于任何数学和科学的讨论都特别重要。例如，对数学的形式主义描述会把数学简化为一种完全左半球的活动。作为数学哲学家、数学家和教育工作者，我们的工作是理解两个半球如何协作产生数学和学习。在这样做时，我们必须意识到，存在两种可能的方式来处理数学，并且存在一种它们之间的张力导致一种模式，即分析模式，否定了另一种模式，即综合模式的重要性，甚至存在。

This description of the predilections of the right and left hemispheres is especially important to any discussion of mathematics and science. For example, the formalist description of mathematics has the effect of reducing mathematics to an exclusively left hemisphere activity. Our job, as philosophers of mathematics, as mathematicians, and as educators is to comprehend how the two hemispheres collaborate to produce mathematics and learning. In doing this we must be aware that there are these two possible ways of approaching mathematics and that there is a tension between them which results in one mode, the analytic, denying the importance and even the existence of the other, synthetic mode.

这在很大程度上解释了数学史。长期以来，形式主义并没有像数学家所经历的那样描述数学，这一点已经很清楚了。数学家所做的和他所说的之间存在着巨大的差距。他所做的是创造性的工作，直觉和严谨、综合和分析都占有重要地位。他说他所做的是证明定理，xv这只不过是将数学简化为左脑的观点。现在，数学家在研究工作中可以很好地说一套做一套，但哲学家不能，老师和学生也不能。xvi

This explains a great deal about the history of mathematics. It has been clear for a long time now that formalism does not describe mathematics as the working mathematician experiences it. There is a huge gap between what a mathematician does and what he says he does. What he does is creative work in which intuition and rigor, synthesis and analysis all have an important place. What he says he does is prove theorems,xv which is nothing but a reduction of mathematics to a left hemisphere point of view. Now mathematicians can get along quite well in their research efforts with saying one thing and doing another but philosophers cannot and neither can teachers and students.xvi

4.7学习和创造力始于右半球，也终于右半球

4.7Learning and Creativity Start and End in the Right Hemisphere

右半球是学习和创造力的起点：“……几乎在所有情况下，新事物都必须首先出现在右半球，然后左半球才能注意到它……不仅是新体验，学习新信息或新技能也比左半球更能吸引右半球的注意力，即使信息是口头的。然而，一旦通过练习熟悉了技能，它们就会转移到左半球的关注点……如果右半球对“外面”存在的东西保持警惕，它就能给我们带来一些我们已知之外的东西。左半球处理已知的事物，因此优先考虑预期的事物。”

The right hemisphere is where learning and creativity begin: “…in almost every case what is new must first be present in the right hemisphere, before it can come into focus for the left…. Not just new experience, but the learning of new information or new skills also engages right-hemisphere attention more than left, even if the information is verbal in nature. However, once the skills have become familiar through practice, they shift to being the concern of the left hemisphere, … If it is the right hemisphere that is vigilant for whatever it is that exists ‘out there,’ it alone can bring us something other than what we already know. The left hemisphere deals with what it knows, and therefore prioritizes the expected.”

学习和创造力起源于右半球，因为只有右半球才能识别新颖性和格式塔（或整体）。只有在被右半球识别后，它才会移到左半球。这在很大程度上解释了概念发展和创造力，而这些概念发展和创造力原本是晦涩难懂的。一个很好的例子来自我对“数字”的讨论。在我们能够通过正式定义确定这一知识之前，我们似乎“知道”了数字，但这种初始知识往往被视为非正式或直觉的，因为仅仅涉及一种不精确的“感觉”。拒绝更非正式的概念的原因是它缺乏精确性，因此不能用于任何后续的分析过程。然而，这只是另一种说法，即概念从右侧开始，后来才移到左侧。精确性和逻辑性是左半球运作的典型方式。

Learning and creativity originate in the right hemisphere because only the right hemisphere can recognize novelty and gestalts (or wholes). It only moves to the left hemisphere subsequent to being recognized by the right. This explains a great deal about conceptual development and creativity that is otherwise opaque and mysterious. A good example comes from my discussion of “number.” We seem to “know” number before we can pin down that knowledge by means of a formal definition but that initial knowledge is often dismissed as informal or intuitive, as merely involving an imprecise “feeling.” The reason for rejecting the more informal concept is that it lacks precision and therefore cannot be used in any subsequent analytic process. However this is just another way of saying that the concept starts on the right side and only later moves to the left. Precision and logic are characteristic ways in which the left hemisphere operates.

在教科书或研究专著中，概念与其所指含义相同；更广泛的概念形象或内涵范围被忽略了。之所以如此，是因为只有在建立了精确的概念框架之后，才有可能将数学写下来并传达给他人。如果没有精确的定义，怎么能证明连续函数的定理呢？然而，即使没有著名的ε – δ定义，也不意味着我们对过程或几何曲线的连续性没有“感觉”。我们从对连续性的非常明确的直觉开始，这种直觉很可能嵌入某些核心认知系统中，就像我们有数字和几何的核心系统一样。

In a textbook or research monograph the concept is identical to its denoted meaning; the broader concept image or range of connotations is ignored. The reason for this is that the process of writing down mathematics and communicating it to others only seems to be possible after a precise conceptual framework has been laid down. How can you prove theorems about continuous functions if you don’t have a precise definition? And yet even the absence of the famous ε–δ definition does not mean that we have no “feeling” for what it means for a process or a geometric curve to be continuous. We begin with a very definite intuition for continuity, which may well be embedded in some core cognitive system just as we have core systems for number and geometry.

什么能区分“好的”定义和本质上无用的定义？著名物理学家尤金·维格纳 (Eugene Wigner )声称，数学在自然科学中如此“不合理地有效”的原因恰恰在于其定义的微妙和独创性。定义只有在捕捉到与我们对自然世界的体验相关的右半球概念的重要方面时才有价值。定义不是任意的，正如你有时从形式主义的数学解读中得出的结论。

What distinguishes a “good” definition from one that is essentially useless? The famous physicist Eugene Wignerxvii claimed that the reason that mathematics was so “unreasonably effective” in the natural sciences was precisely the subtlety and ingenuity of its definitions. A definition is only valuable to the extent that it captures significant aspects of the right-hemispheric notion that is connected to our experience of the natural world. A definition is not arbitrary, as you might sometimes conclude from a formalist reading of mathematics.

科学的许多基本概念（如数字、随机性、时间、空间、物质和能量）都无法通过正式定义明确地捕捉到。这并不意味着它们无法定义。只是说不可能有最终或最终的定义。从半球分化的角度来看，这种不完整性是有道理的。左半球无法“捕捉”右半球的观点，也无法创造自己的原始观点——它只能“重新创造”源自右半球的观点。要做到这一点，它必须首先将右半球的概念版本转化为它可以处理的术语，这包括将过程转化为精确定义的对象或将内涵意义转化为外延意义。通常有将右脑概念转化为左脑概念的方法有很多，这意味着，特别是，数字的不同定义是可能的（正如我们所见）。每个可能的定义都抓住了数字的一个或多个方面，并产生了一个数学理论和相应的概念系统。

Many of the building blocks of science—concepts like number, randomness, time, space, matter, and energy—cannot be captured definitively by a formal definition. This does not mean that they cannot be defined. Merely that no ultimate or final definition is possible. Such incompleteness makes sense from the point of view of hemispheric differentiation. The left hemisphere cannot “capture” the view from the right and cannot create its own original view—it can only “re-create” a view that originates in the right hemisphere. To do this it must begin by translating the right hemisphere’s version of the concept into terms that it can deal with and this includes making processes into precisely defined objects or connoted meanings into denoted meanings. There are often many ways of translating the right hemispheric notion into the left’s domain and this would mean, in particular, that different definitions of number are possible (as we have seen). Each possible definition captures one or more aspect or aspects of number and gives rise to a mathematical theory and corresponding conceptual system.

右脑首先认识数字，然后将其传送到左脑。右脑的版本必然是不精确的，左脑“无法知道”。同样的考虑也告诉我们形式数学和非形式数学之间的关系。如果我们将非形式和直观归类为右脑，将形式数学归类为左脑，那么我们必须对一个主题有一种非形式的感觉，然后才能以有意义的方式处理它。“正确的方式”必须先于“左方式”，否则我们就会得到一系列毫无意义的机械推导。右脑的优先性解释了为什么我们有时在通过逻辑论证证明这种感觉之前，就会对正确的方向有一种直觉。大多数数学家会说：“给我基本的想法，我会补充（逻辑的）细节。”

Number is known first by the right hemisphere and then transferred to the left. The right hemisphere’s version is inevitably imprecise and “unknowable” by the left hemisphere. The same considerations tell us something about the relationship between formal and informal mathematics. To the extent that we identify the informal and intuitive with the right hemisphere and the formal with the left, it is necessary to have an informal feeling for a subject before we can work with it in a meaningful way. The “right way” must precede the “left way” or else we are left with a series of mechanical derivations that have no significance. The priority of the right hemisphere explains why we sometimes have an intuitive sense of the correct direction to proceed before we can justify this sense though a logical argument. “Give me the basic idea,” most mathematicians would say, “and I’ll fill in the (logical) details.”

我们在数学（以及其他领域）中所做的大部分思考涉及在众所周知的范式 CS 1内执行计算，这个过程粗略地说涉及左半球。跳跃到一个新的想法或新的概念系统 CS 2，不可避免地会利用右半球识别新颖性的能力，因此创造性步骤涉及将情况返回到右半球。一般来说，我们只有通过调用两个半球功能的交替才能理解创造力和学习。如果我们试图将学习或创造力简化为独有的左半球活动，我们将不可避免地错过它的本质。如果我们的教学只是针对掌握左半球的技能，那么诸如理解之类的事情充其量只能以杂乱无章的方式发展，最坏的情况是会受到严重阻碍。

Most of the thinking we do in mathematics (and elsewhere) involves performing computations within a well-known paradigm, CS1, a process which, roughly speaking, involves the left hemisphere. The leap to a new idea or new conceptual system, CS2, inevitably utilizes the right hemisphere’s ability to recognize novelty and so the creative step involves returning the situation to the right hemisphere. In general we can only understand creativity and learning by invoking the alternation of our two hemispheric functions. If we attempt to reduce learning or creativity to an exclusively left-hemispheric activity we will inevitably miss its essence. If our teaching is only directed to the mastery of left-hemispheric skills then things like understanding will be left to develop in a haphazard way at best and at worst will be seriously impeded.

麦吉尔克里斯特将整个过程总结如下：“右脑提供给左脑的东西又被反馈回来，并被两个半球综合起来。创造力、对艺术作品的理解、宗教意识的发展都是如此。在每一个过程中，都会有一个从直觉理解到理解的过程，通过一个通过有意识的、详细的分析理解，对整体进行更加正式的丰富过程，从而对整体产生新的、增强的直觉理解，而这种理解现在已经通过所经历的过程而发生了改变。” xviii

McGilchrist summarizes the total procedure as follows: “What is offered by the right hemisphere to the left hemisphere is offered back again and taken up into a synthesis involving both hemispheres. This must be true of the processes of creativity, of the understanding of works of art, of the development of the religious sense. In each there is a progress from an intuitive apprehension of whatever it may be, via a more formal process of enrichment through conscious, detailed analytic understanding, to a new, enhanced intuitive understanding of this whole, now transformed by the process that it has undergone.”xviii

4.8左半球的合理化倾向

4.8The Left Hemisphere’s Tendency to Rationalize

我曾多次指出，深度思考——创造力和概念发展——是困难的。我们现在可以明白为什么会这样，因为困难的根源在于左半球抵制变化的倾向。换句话说，我们执着于我们熟悉的概念系统或观点。摆脱这种惰性状态需要付出非凡的努力。所需努力的性质使得创造力和概念学习变得困难。光是努力工作、气喘吁吁或花费大量时间是不够的。我记得有个学生抱怨说，他花了很多时间解决一个数学问题却一无所获，他觉得自己应该得到表扬。我让他告诉我，他花了这么多时间到底在做什么。结果发现，他工作到了某个程度，就卡住了，又回到了起点，一遍又一遍地重复这个序列。重复一些你理解的程序永远不会给你带来新的东西，但学生不知道如何摆脱自己所处的困境。

I have repeatedly noted that deep thinking—creativity and conceptual development—is hard. We are now in a position to see why this should be so for the difficulty is rooted in the left-hemisphere’s tendency to resist change. In other words we become attached to the conceptual system or point of view with which we are familiar. Breaking free from this state of inertia necessitates an extraordinary effort. The nature of the kind of effort that is required is what makes creativity and conceptual learning difficult. It is not enough to work hard, to huff and puff, or spend enormous amounts of time. I can remember a student who complained bitterly that he had spent many hours working on a mathematics problem without any success and felt that he should be given credit for the effort he had put in. I asked him to tell me what exactly he had been doing for all of those hours. It turned out that he worked up to a certain point, got stuck, returned to the beginning and repeated this sequence over and over again. Repeating some procedure that you understand will never lead you to something new but the student had no idea of how to get out of the rut in which he found himself.

很多裂脑患者的实验都表明，左脑倾向于找借口，即编造毫无事实根据的解释。我们都有过为某事无中生有地编造借口的经历，我们的孩子在被指控犯了小过错时也会这样做——比如“狗吃了我的作业”之类的借口。政客们利用这种思维能力，雇佣了一大批“公关专家”，他们随时准备为候选人立场中的每一个错误或不一致之处编造一个即时解释。这种找借口的倾向之所以如此普遍，是因为这是我们左脑的基本运作模式。显然，我们左脑倾向于编造借口，而不是为某事找借口。合理化并不局限于人类，也适用于其他灵长类动物。xix

There have been many experiments with split-brain patients that point to the left hemisphere’s propensity to rationalize, that is, to make up explanations that have no basis in reality. We all have had the experience of making up an excuse for something out of thin air and have seen this kind of thing in our children when they are accused of some minor transgression—”the dog ate my homework” kind of excuse. Politicians use this capacity of the mind when they hire an army of “spin-doctors” who are prepared to invent an instant explanation for every mistake or inconsistency in their candidate’s positions. The tendency to rationalize in this way is so prevalent because it is a basic mode of functioning for our left hemisphere. Evidently the tendency to rationalize is not restricted to human being but extends to other primates as well.xix

麦吉尔克里斯特 (McGilchrist) 用以下方式描述了大脑半球在面对问题时的差异：“解决问题时也类似。右半球会提供一系列可能的解决方案，在探索替代方案时，这些解决方案会一直有效。相比之下，左半球会选择似乎最符合其已知情况的单一解决方案，并坚持下去。VS 拉马钱德兰 (VS Ramachandran) 对失认症 (一种患有残疾的人似乎不知道自己有残疾) 的研究表明，左半球倾向于否认不符合其已经生成的事物图式的差异。相比之下，右半球则积极地关注差异，更像是一个魔鬼代言人。这两种方法都是必要的，但方向却相反。……左半球以焦点方式运作，抑制当前不相关的意义。相比之下，右半球以非焦点方式处理信息，广泛激活相关意义。”

McGilchrist describes hemispheric differences in facing a problem in the following way: “It is similar with problem solving. Here the right hemisphere presents an array of possible solutions, which remain live while alternatives are explored. The left hemisphere, by contrast, takes the single solution that seems best to fit what it already knows and latches onto it. V. S. Ramachandran’s studies of anosognosia (in which a person who suffers from a disability seems unaware of the existence of his or her disability) reveal a tendency for the left hemisphere to deny discrepancies that do not fit its already generated schema of things. The right hemisphere, by contrast, is actively watching for discrepancies, more like a devil’s advocate. These approaches are both needed, but pull in opposite directions. … The left hemisphere operates focally, suppressing meanings that are not currently relevant. By contrast, the right hemisphere processes information in a non-focal manner with widespread activation of related meanings.”

我们的大部分工作不可避免地基于一些众所周知的范式或概念系统。由于这些系统很熟悉，所以它们位于左半球。这促进了我所说的各种计算。这些计算发生在一个固定的概念宇宙中，并不断、逐步地扩展该宇宙的边界。当一个人在操作范式中遇到异常时，他会怎么做？左半球的倾向是拒绝差异。这使得 Carey 提出的关于我们如何从 CS 1过渡到 CS 2的问题变得更加重要和神秘。鉴于我所说的左半球，我们如何设法学习或创造任何新的东西？

Most of our work is inevitably based on some well-understood paradigm or conceptual system. Because it is familiar it resides in the left hemisphere. This facilitates the kinds of computations that I have spoken about. These computations occur within a fixed conceptual universe and continuously and incrementally extend the boundaries of that universe. What does one do when one encounters anomalies within the operational paradigm? Well the tendency of the left hemisphere is to reject discrepancies. This makes Carey’s question about how we ever get from CS1 to CS2 even more important and mysterious. Given what I have said about the left hemisphere how do we manage to learn or create anything new?

新的概念学习只有在个人摆脱了他们的操作性思维模式之后才能发生。这在很大程度上解释了与此类活动相关的困难的性质。当试图放弃自己的思维模式时，会引发一种几乎自相矛盾的情况，那么一个人该如何放弃呢？习惯性思维模式扎根于左半球，它不想放手。任何强迫它放手的尝试，即使是专注于放手，也只会加强左半球的控制。我们如何摆脱习惯性的暴政？左半球并放弃手电筒意识？（在第五章中，我将更详细地讨论“放弃”的悖论。）

New conceptual learning can only occur after the individual has escaped from their operative mindset. This explains in large part the nature of the difficulty that is associated with such activities. How does one go about letting go of one’s mindset when the attempt to do so precipitates a situation that is almost paradoxical? The habitual mindset is lodged in the left hemisphere, which does not want to let go. Any attempt to force it to let go, even to focus on letting go, just reinforces the control of the left hemisphere. How do we escape from the tyranny of the left hemisphere and let go of flashlight consciousness? (In chapter five I shall discuss the paradox of “letting go” in greater detail.)

这个问题的答案是，必须打破左半球对已知事物的执着倾向。要做到这一点，就要学会反其道而行之，而不是压抑问题因素。相反，正是模糊性和矛盾性及其紧张、不一致和看似不可调和的冲突，为打破对已知事物的执着提供了机会。这就是“牢记两个矛盾的想法”的目的，我们将在下一章中讨论它，将其作为“创造力之门”。只有不和谐才能打破我们当前的思维框架，打开通往新事物的大门。逻辑和其他类型的连续计算永远不会改变我们的思维定势。这是我对那些基于计算机的思维/大脑模型的看法。创造力是一个需要超越当前思维模式的过程。它不是通过更专注或扩大左半球过程控制的现象范围来实现的。

The answer to this question is that the left hemisphere’s tendency to be fixated on the known must be broken down. The way to do this is to learn to work in the opposite direction from that of repressing problematic elements of the situation. On the contrary it is the ambiguities and the contradictions with their tensions, inconsistencies, and seemingly irreconcilable conflicts that provide an opportunity to break down the fixation with the known. This is the purpose of “holding two contradictory ideas in mind” which we will discuss in the next chapter as the “doorway to creativity.” It is only dissonance that can break up our current mental framework and open the gates to something new. Logic and other kinds of continuous computations will never change our mental set. This is my problem with those models of the mind/brain that are based on the computer. Creativity is a process that entails transcending one’s current mental model. It does not happen by focusing more intensely or by extending the range of phenomena that are under the control of left hemispheric processes.

要做到这一点，你必须真诚地面对情况中的问题因素，这些因素可能是模棱两可、悖论或矛盾，或者仅仅是感觉有些事情不对劲，没有道理。也就是说，你必须全身心投入到情况的复杂之中，尽可能地抛开那些先验地告诉你什么是可能的或合理的内心恶魔。

One does this by authentically confronting the problematic elements of the situation, which may be an ambiguity, paradox, or contradiction or merely the feeling that something is wrong and does not make sense. That is, one absorbs oneself in the situation in all of its complexity setting aside as much as possible those inner demons that tell you a priori what is possible or reasonable.

在当时已经尽了自己最大的努力之后，人们必须有勇气走开，把问题放下一段时间。这可能意味着出去散步、喝咖啡，或者只是上床睡觉。你允许自己放下负担，因为你知道大脑的其他部分不会停止运作。人们的注意力从集中状态转变为一种被称为灯笼意识的无集中意识。在这种孕育状态下，右半球捕捉到的任何随机事件都可能促成创造性联想。正是右半球能够将不同类型的组合组合在一起，将表面上不属于同一类的不同体验并列在一起，最终带来了理性思维似乎偶然获得的洞察力。

Having gone as far as one can at that time one has to have the courage to walk away and put the problem down for a while. This may mean going for a walk or getting a coffee, or just going to bed. You give yourself permission to put the burden down because you know that other parts of your mind will not stop functioning. One’s attention goes from being focused to the sort of unfocused awareness that was called lantern consciousness. In that pregnant state any random event that is picked up by the right hemisphere can precipitate the creative association. It is precisely the right hemisphere’s ability to put together different kinds of combinations, to juxtapose diverse experiences that ostensibly do not belong together that ultimately brings about the insight that appears to the rational mind to arrive serendipitously.

麦吉尔克里斯特说：“也许停止‘创造某种东西’的努力——换句话说，放松——有利于创造力，因为它允许注意力的扩大……这解释了‘舌尖’现象：我们越努力，我们就越能吸引狭窄的左半球注意力，我们就越记不住单词。一旦我们停止尝试，单词就会不请自来。”

McGilchrist says, “It may be that cessation of the effort to ‘produce something’—relaxation, in other words—favors creativity because it permits broadening of attention, … This explains the ‘tip of the tongue’ phenomenon: the harder we try, the more we recruit narrow left-hemisphere attention, and the less we can remember the word. Once we stop trying, the word comes to us unbidden.”

4.9对深度思考的启示

4.9Implications for Deep Thinking

这一讨论与我对深度思考和一般思考的讨论有着直接的关系。思考有不同的形式，相应的学习也有很多种（我们将在第六章中看到）。现在我们可以看到，它们的许多显著特征都源于大脑半球之一的主导地位。创造力和概念学习并非仅仅通过重新排列预定元素就能产生。因此，计算机程序或数学证明可能是左半球运作的良好模型，但不是深度思考所需的综合心理功能的良好模型。

This discussion has immediate relevance for my discussion of deep thinking and of thinking in general. There are different forms of thinking and corresponding kinds of learning (as we shall see in chapter six). Now we can see that many of their distinguishing characteristics follow from the dominance of one of the cerebral hemispheres. Creativity and conceptual learning do not follow from merely rearranging predetermined elements. Thus a computer program or a mathematical proof may be a good model for the functioning of the left-hemisphere but not for the integrated mental functioning that is required for deep thinking.

左右二分法显然也对我们所认为的数学（和科学）的真正本质产生了影响。从左半球看数学自然会强调其公理、逻辑和形式方面。从右半球看数学是什么？这很可能就是我在书中谈到的数学方法。在这种观点中，左半球是不可或缺的贡献者，但右半球拥有第一个和最后一个发言权。

The left/right dichotomy evidently also has implications for what we consider to be the real nature of mathematics (and science). The view of mathematics from the left hemisphere would naturally emphasize its axiomatic, logical, and formal aspects. What is mathematics when viewed from the right hemisphere? It might well be the approach to mathematics that I have talking about in my books. It is a view where the left hemisphere is an indispensible contributor but where the right hemisphere has the first and the last word.

麦吉尔克里斯特说：“当然，有大量证据表明右半球对创造力很重要，鉴于右半球能够在事物之间建立更多、更广泛的联系，并能够更灵活地思考，这一点并不令人惊讶。但这只是故事的一部分。两个半球都很重要。创造力取决于事物的结合，这些事物也是分开维持的——胼胝体的精确功能，既能分离又能连接；有趣的是，胼胝体的分裂确实会削弱创造力。”

McGilchrist says, “Certainly there is plenty of evidence that the right hemisphere is important for creativity, which given its ability to make more and wider-ranging connections between things, and to think more flexibly, is hardly surprising. But this is only part of the story. Both hemispheres are importantly involved. Creativity depends on the union of things that are also maintained separately—the precise function of the corpus callosum, both to separate and connect; and interestingly division of the corpus callosum does impair creativity.”

4.10结论

4.10Conclusion

真正的科学是“深奥的科学”，真正的数学是“深奥的数学”。它们都涉及两个半球，既涉及分析思维也涉及综合思维，但主体的生命——创造和学习——存在于右半球和综合思维中。与其说当前的理论图景是“真实的”，不如说它是实践和理解的过程。当前的模型总是过时的；新理论不断诞生。

Real science is “deep science”; real mathematics is “deep mathematics.” They both involve both hemispheres, both analytic and synthetic thought but the life of the subject—creating and learning—resides in the right hemisphere and in synthetic thought. It is not the current theoretical picture that is “true” so much as it is the process of doing and understanding. The current model is always out of date; the new theory is continually being born.

不幸的是，我们把分析的观点当作唯一的现实，因此我们扭曲了我们试图描述的东西。我们迫切需要一个不变的观点；我们希望确定真相。如果我们希望发展一种数学和科学的观点，将活动——科学的“实践”——与理论内容统一起来，那么这种观点必然会涉及两个半球的观点。

Unfortunately we take the analytic view to be the only reality and so we distort what we are attempting to describe. We have a deep need for a viewpoint that does not change; we wish to pin down the truth. If we wished to develop a view of mathematics and science that unified the activity—the “doing” of science—with the theoretical content then that view would necessarily involve the perspectives of both hemispheres.

i Hadamard, (1954)。第 2 章和第3章。

i Hadamard, (1954). Chapters 2 and 3.

ii Gopnik, (2009)。第 13-14 页。

viii Brooks, (2011). p. 45–46. 本段其余部分是对 Brooks 评论的释义。

viii Brooks, (2011). p. 45–46. The rest of the paragraph is a paraphrase of Brooks’ comments.

ix Low, (2002)。第 9 章。

ix Low, (2002). Chapter 9.

x Cf Sacks (1987). 双胞胎。

x C.f. Sacks (1987). The Twins.

xi有关半球分化章节的所有引文均来自 McGilchrist (2009)，人们可以在其中找到对科学文献的更多参考。

xii Marcel Kinsbourne，由 McGilchrist 引用。

xiii宗教可能将此称为“原罪”。

xiii Religion might call this “original sin.”

xiv参见 Low (2002)。

xiv C.f. Low (2002).

xv参见 Davis 和 Hersh, (1981)。

xv C.f. Davis and Hersh, (1981).

xvi这种差异在科学中并不那么大，因为科学与理论的同一性并不像数学中那样完整。然而，同样的紧张关系仍然存在。

xvii Wigner (1960).

十八 McGilchrist，同上。

xviii McGilchrist, Op. Cit.

xix C.f. the article entitled, “Go Ahead Rationalize. Monkeys Do It Too.” New York Times, Nov. 6, 2008.

第五章

Chapter 5

深度思考与创造力

Deep Thinking and Creativity

5.1介绍

5.1Introduction

创造力不仅仅涉及创造新奇事物。它不是将相同的程序应用于一系列不同的情况而产生的。创造力涉及以完全不同的方式看待某种情况或现象——不是现象发生了变化，而是人们看待现象的方式发生了变化。太阳绕着地球转还是地球绕着太阳转？从一个视角到另一个视角涉及创造力。换句话说，创造力涉及我一直所说的深度思考。深度思考是创造过程的本质。

Creativity does not merely involve the production of novelty. It does not arise from applying the same procedure to a series of different situations. Creativity involves coming to see some situation or phenomenon in a substantially different way—it is not the phenomenon that has changed but rather the manner in which one views the phenomenon. Does the sun go around the earth or does the earth revolve around the sun? Going from one viewpoint to the other involves an act of creativity. In other words creativity involves what I have been calling deep thinking. Deep thinking is the essence of the creative process.

由于所有深度思考都具有创造性，因此对深度思考的研究必然是对创造过程的研究。有许多这样的研究。这项研究有什么不同和不寻常之处？首先，我认为创造力和智力是一种极其普遍的东西。通常，创造力被视为才华横溢、智商极高的人的专利，基于一种使用分析智力的特定方式。然而，在我看来，人类创造力是一种更为广泛和普遍的东西。这种能力可以在许多动物身上看到，例如，乌鸦和黑猩猩使用工具和解决问题的方式。更普遍地说，进化过程本身给人的印象是它具有第一章中列举的深度思考的特征。例如，进化被一系列不连续性所打断，这让人想起我们在发展、学习和进化过程中所观察到的飞跃。范式转变。宇宙学和进化论等领域的科学进步以摆脱人类特殊性而著称。我认为创造力和思维，尤其是深度思维，也是非常普遍的现象，我们错误地将其与人类身上的发生方式联系起来。

Since all deep thinking is creative, an investigation into deep thinking is necessarily an investigation into the creative process. There have been many such studies. What is different and unusual about this particular study? For one thing I regard creativity, and intelligence for that matter, as something that is extremely general. Normally creativity is looked on as something that is the preserve of talented, highly intelligent people and is based on a particular way of using analytic intelligence. However, in my view, human creativity is a variety of something that is much more widespread and general. It is a capacity that can be seen in many animals, for example, in the way that crows and chimpanzees use tools and solve problems. Even more generally, the evolutionary process itself gives one the impression of sharing the characteristics of deep thinking that were enumerated in chapter one. For example, evolution is punctuated by a series of discontinuities, which are very reminiscent of the kinds of leaps we have been looking at in development, learning, and paradigm change. The progression of science in fields like cosmology and evolutionary theory has been notable for a movement away from human exceptionality. I suggest that creativity and thought, especially deep thought, are also very generalized phenomena, which we mistakenly identify with the manner in which they occur in human beings.

我的观点与通常观点之间的差异可以通过提出以下问题来凸显：“创造行为是我们做的还是发生在我们身上的事？”根据上一章的讨论，这就像问创造力是否涉及手电筒或灯笼意识，或者它主要涉及左半球还是右半球。

The difference between my perspective and the usual one can be highlighted by asking the following question: “Is an act of creativity something that we do or something that happens to us?” In terms of the discussion in the last chapter this would be like asking whether creativity involves flashlight or lantern consciousness or whether it primarily involves the left or the right hemisphere.

数学和科学以其非凡的创造力而闻名。科学史充满了思想革命——例如爱因斯坦或牛顿的工作——这些革命使人们以全新的方式理解了自然界的某些方面。因此，在对创造力进行一些初步介绍之后，我将开始讨论科学和数学中的创造力。我的目的是表明，创造性活动的一些基本特征类似于我在前几章中分离出的深度思考的特征。

Mathematics and science are notable for their remarkable creativity. The history of science is full of intellectual revolutions—the work of Einstein or Newton, for example—where some aspect of the natural world comes to be understood in an entirely new way. Thus after some preliminary words about creativity in general I shall turn to a discussion of creativity in science and mathematics. My aim is to show that some of the essential characteristics of creative activity are analogous to the features of deep thinking that I isolated in the earlier chapters.

5.2创世神话告诉我们关于创造力的什么

5.2What Creation Myths Tell Us About Creativity

那么，创造力是什么？在我看来，没有比创造力更神秘、更重要的问题了。即使是诸如“人性的本质是什么？”“生命的起源和命运是什么？”甚至“什么是美好的生活？”等基本问题，也需要在对创造力的作用和性质进行适当评估的基础上进行思考。

What then is creativity? There is no question that is more mysterious or, in my opinion, more important. Even such basic questions as, “What is the essence of human nature?” “What is the origin and destiny of life?” and even “What is the good life?” need to be considered in the light of a proper assessment of the role and nature of creativity.

所有文化都围绕着一个故事展开，这个故事告诉人们世界是如何诞生的——一个创世神话。“起初，上帝创造天地”就是这样一个故事。“大爆炸”是另一个。不幸的是，我们可能误解了这些故事试图告诉我们什么。例如，我们可能认为它们发生在过去的某个时间，但当然，“起初”没有时间。我们所理解的时间是某种产生的东西。

All cultures organize themselves around a story, which tells them how the world came into being—a creation myth. “In the beginning God created heaven and earth” is one such story. “The Big Bang” is another. Unfortunately we may misunderstand what these stories are trying to teach us. We may think, for example, that they happened at some time in the past but, of course, “in the beginning” there was no time. Time, as we understand it, is something that came into being.

如果上帝创造了一切，那么这就是一种创造行为。如果宇宙起源于时空连续体中的一个奇点，那么大爆炸是创造力的一个无与伦比的例子，它创造了无中生有。无论如何，创造力都与我们人类对起源的理解方式密切相关。你可能会说，“起初就有创造力。”

If God created everything then this was an act of creativity. If the universe originated at a singularity in the space-time continuums then the Big Bang was an unparalleled instance of creativity in which something comes into being out of nothing. In either case creativity is intimately connected to the way we humans conceive of our origins. “In the beginning there was creativity,” you might say.

有些人认为这种创造力发生于很久以前，从那时起，宇宙就自动运转，就像一台机器，不再需要额外的创造力。但还有另一种思考方式。那就是创造是持续的——世界、星星和星系；我们自己、我们的身体和思想，都在一刻一刻地被创造，现在如此，永远如此。这种持续的创造过程是智慧的，也就是说，创造力是智慧在行动。思考这种基本的创造力，不能不唤起敬畏和惊奇的感觉。所有的创造故事——科学、宗教或文化——都以自己的方式告诉我们，创造力是原始的本质。一切都源于这种巨大的创造力之泉，我们自己的创造性努力直接来自这一源头——它们具有相同的本质。

Some people think that this kind of creativity happened a long time ago and that ever since then the universe goes on in an automatic way, like a machine, with no further need for additional acts of creativity. But there is another way to think about these things. It is that creation is ongoing—the world, the stars and the galaxies; ourselves, our bodies and our minds, are being created moment-by-moment, right now and will be forever. This ongoing process of creation is intelligent, that is creativity is intelligence in action. Contemplating this kind of fundamental creativity cannot fail to evoke feelings of awe and wonder. All creation stories—scientific, religious, or cultural—tell us in their own way that creativity is the primordial essence. Everything arises from this vast up welling of creativity and our own creative efforts come directly from that source—they have the same essence.

所有人类都具有与生俱来的创造力，就像所有儿童都具有学习能力一样。事实上，从根本上说，学习和创造力是同一现象的不同名称。当我们观察儿童玩耍时，我们意识到玩耍是内在创造力的体现，当我们允许我们的基本创造力自我表达时，我们也是最活跃的。

All human beings possess an inherent potential for creativity in just the same way as all children have the capacity to learn. Indeed learning and creativity are, in a fundamental way, different names for the same phenomenon. When we observe children at play we become aware that play is a manifestation of an inherent creativity and that we, too, are most alive when we allow our fundamental creativity to express itself.

我们常常错误地将创造力等同于单纯的新颖性，或天才作品的产生。我们忘记了创造力也可以被认为是对日常生活中平凡活动的一种取向。几乎任何活动——甚至洗碗——都可以以创造性的方式进行；走出家门就是一种启示。然而，这些普通活动必须像第一次一样进行，而不是出于习惯或应用某种公式或规则。相反，创造力意味着克服我们对公式和规则的习惯性依赖。它要求我们敞开心扉，不带任何先入之见地体验它。

We often mistakenly identify creativity with mere novelty, on the one hand, or the production of works of genius, on the other. We forget that creativity can also be thought of as an orientation towards the mundane activities of everyday life. Almost any activity—even doing the dishes—can be pursued in a creative manner; just stepping out of your front door can be a revelation. However those ordinary activities must be undertaken as though for the first time and not by habit or by applying some formula or set of rules. On the contrary creativity means overcoming our habitual reliance on formulas and sets of rules. It requires opening ourselves up to the situation and experiencing it without preconceptions.

当我们以这种方式向现实敞开心扉时，我们会发现什么？我们有时会想象世界处于某种永恒的状态。独立于我们而存在的状态，在我们走出前门时就等待着我们。我们认为它是连贯的、易于理解的，所有的点点滴滴都像一幅画、一个宏大的理论或交响乐的元素一样组合在一起。然而，可以想象，外面的东西是动态的；这幅画在不断变化；它并不总是连贯的，我们看到的图案经常会分解成不连贯和不和谐。俄罗斯作家鲍里斯·帕斯捷尔纳克在给斯蒂芬·斯彭德的一封信中对这种动态进行了更诗意的描述：“我会假装（比喻地）看到自然和宇宙本身不是一幅画在或固定在一堵不可移​​动的墙上，而是一种画在画布上的屋顶或空中的窗帘，被某种非物质的未知和不可知的风不断地拉扯、吹动和拍打。” i

When we open ourselves up to what is real in this way what will we find? We sometimes imagine that the world is in some kind of permanent state that exists independent of us and is waiting for us when we step out the front door. We think of it as coherent and easily comprehensible with all the bits and pieces fitting together like the elements of a painting, a grand theory, or symphony. However it is conceivable that what is out there is dynamic; that the painting is constantly changing; that it isn’t always coherent but that the patterns that we see regularly break down into incoherence and discord. A more poetic description of this dynamism was expressed by the Russian author Boris Pasternak in a letter to Stephen Spender: “I would pretend (metaphorically) to have seen nature and universe themselves not as a picture made or fastened on an immovable wall, but as a sort of painted canvas roof or curtain in the air, incessantly pulled and blown and flapped by a something of an immaterial unknown and unknowable wind.”i

事实上，我们所看到的连贯性是创造力的结果——当我们通过概念系统观察世界时，世界呈现在我们面前的方式。如果是这样，那么不连贯性和混乱是任何情况不可避免的一部分。不连贯性可能看起来像一个障碍，但这种不连贯性可能成为创造力和更大理解的渠道。创造力的代价将是面对混乱的障碍和我们所依赖的心理系统的崩溃所引起的恐惧和焦虑。正如我们将看到的，伟大的创造性突破源于面对和克服冲突和不连贯性。

In fact the coherence that we see is the result of an act of creativity—the way that the world appears to us when we view it though a conceptual system. If this is so, then incoherence and chaos are inevitability part of any situation. Incoherence may seem like a barrier but this incoherence may become a conduit towards creativity and greater understanding. The price of creativity would then involve facing up to the fear and anxiety that are evoked by the barriers of chaos and the breakdown of the mental systems that we have come to rely on. The grand creative breakthrough, as we shall see, arises out of confronting and passing through conflict and incoherence.

谈论面对不连贯性和突破障碍可能听起来很戏剧化，让人觉得创造力只属于英雄。相反，正如我之前所说，每次你走出家门，都有一种可能的创造性行为在等着你。当你在一个美丽的春日走出家门时，如果你能用全新的眼光看待世界，世界似乎重生了。

Talking about facing incoherence and passing through barriers may sound very dramatic, making it seem as though creativity is reserved for heroes. On the contrary as I said earlier there is a possible creative act waiting for you every time you go out your front door. As you step outside on a beautiful spring day, the world seems to be reborn if you can only manage to see it with fresh eyes.

5.3深度思考即创造力

5.3Creativity as Deep Thinking

我讨论创造力的背景是我在第一章末尾列出的深度思考的特征。创造力行为是断断续续出现的洞察力的结果。当然，洞察力必须先于一些深层次的问题；问题如此深层次，以至于解决方案似乎不可能。这就是为什么解决方案不是通过系统手段产生的，而只有在所有系统方法都无效时才会出现，也就是说，如果你想要有创造力，有时你必须准备好盲目行事。这并不容易做到。创造力需要长期生活在认知失调情况下产生的那种紧张状态中。

The context for my discussion of creativity will be the characteristics of deep thinking that I listed at the end of chapter one. An act of creativity is the result of an insight that arises discontinuously. Of course the insight must be preceded by something that is deeply problematic; it is so deeply problematic that a resolution may well seem impossible. This is why the resolution does not arise through systematic means but only occurs when all systematic approaches have been exhausted to no effect, that is, if you want to be creative you must sometimes be prepared to fly blind. This is not easy to do. Creativity involves living for protracted periods with the kind of tension that arises in situations of cognitive dissonance.

创造力需要与计算区分开来。计算思维一直被使用，直到无法再使用为止——直到它遇到障碍。它对于深刻的创造性思维的重要性在于它所揭示的异常。当然，必须有意识地接受这些异常，才能取得进一步的创造性进展。这种接受是不寻常的和困难的，我们将在本章的其余部分看到。接受异常现实的问题源于我在上一章中对半球专业化的讨论。计算是左半球的首选模式，左半球不愿意接受异常，甚至不愿意承认它们的存在。它偏爱一致性，因此它通过旧模式的视角来查看新数据，如果这不可能，它可能会完全否认不一致数据的存在。因此，只有当系统性的心理图景崩溃时，创造力才会出现，而这种崩溃才是痛苦的体验。

Creativity needs to be distinguished from computation. Computational thought is used until it cannot be used any more—until it hits a barrier. Its importance for deep, creative thought lies in the anomalies that it uncovers. Of course these anomalies must be consciously accepted before further, creative progress can be achieved. That such acceptance is unusual and difficult will be seen in the remainder of the chapter. The problem with accepting the reality of anomalies follows from my discussion of hemispheric specialization in the previous chapter. Computation is the preferred mode of the left hemisphere and the left hemisphere is reluctant to accept anomalies or even to admit their existence. Its preference is for consistency and so it views new data through the lens of old schemas or, if that is not possible, it may deny outright the existence of the inconsistent data. Therefore creativity only can occur when the systematic mental picture of the situation breaks down and it is this breakdown that is experienced as painful.

问题因素不是由于创造性个体在工作中犯的任何错误或失误造成的，而是任何概念思维体系所固有的。我们无法通过寻找当前情况下的矛盾来完成创造性工作。而是我们意识到情况的内在矛盾。我们陷入了以下困境：没有某种理论框架，我们就无法进行科学研究，但每个这样的框架都是不完整和有问题的。我们一直在寻找“真理”，即终极理论，但这样的理论并不存在，也永远不会存在。真理永远不可能完全包含在给定的理论中。

The problematic element is not due to any mistake or error in the work of the creative individual but is intrinsic to any system of conceptual thought. We do not accomplish creative work by looking for a contradiction, let us say, in the current situation. It is that we become aware of the situation’s intrinsic contradictions. We are caught in the following double bind: we cannot do science without some theoretical framework but every such framework is incomplete and problematic. We keep looking for the “truth,” the ultimate theory, but such a theory does not and will never exist. The truth can never be fully contained within a given theory.

5.4创造力即学习

5.4Creativity as Learning

本书的主题之一是最普遍意义上的学习。儿童发展可以被视为一种学习形式，数学和科学的发展也是如此。当然，在做研究时，我们的动机是了解我们正在研究的现象，也就是理解它。正如我们将在下一章中看到的那样，学习有很多种，包括死记硬背和算法学习，但最重要的一种学习，我称之为“深度学习”，涉及创造性行为。创造力是将科学研究、儿童发展和深度学习联系在一起的共同主题。事实上，创造力就是最深刻意义上的学习。

One of the main themes of this book is learning in its most general sense. Child development can be thought of as a form of learning and so can the development of mathematics and science. Certainly in doing research we are motivated by the desire to learn about the phenomena that we are studying, that is, to understand it. As we shall see in the next chapter, there are many kinds of learning, including rote learning and algorithmic learning, but that the most significant kind of learning, which I will call “deep learning” involves acts of creativity. Creativity is the common theme that ties together scientific research, child development, and deep learning. In fact creativity is learning in its most profound sense.

当我开始思考这些事情时，我惊讶地发现，学习和儿童发展有很多共同之处，都是创造性活动的形式。这让我很惊讶，因为学习似乎是自愿的，需要意识，而发展是内在的。如果在两种情况下都在进行相同的过程，那么创造力可能不是分析思维的功能。也许它涉及潜意识的过程。甚至可能正常的成人创造力只是某种更基本的东西的一个方面。也许创造性思维与爱因斯坦所说的“揭示在世界上的思维”没有什么不同。ii

When I began thinking about these things I realized to my surprise that learning and child development had a great deal in common and were both forms of creative activity. This surprised me because learning seemed to be volitional and to require consciousness whereas development was built-in. If the same process was going on in both situations then maybe creativity is not a function of the analytic mind. Maybe it involves processes that lie below consciousness. It may even be true that normal, adult creativity is merely an aspect of something that is much more basic. Perhaps the creative mind is no different than the “mind revealed in the world” as Einstein put it.ii

5.5创造力是解决问题的正确方法

5.5Creativity is the Correct Response to the Problematic

创造力就像所有深度思考一样，需要克服根本障碍，因此绝非易事。在本节中，我打算讨论如何应对这一困难，因为这是创造力的关键。是的，情况确实有些麻烦，有些与传统智慧相矛盾，有些可能令人恼火，有些会产生紧张。这很麻烦，但有创造力的人不能置之不理，不能做“正常”的事情，不能停止思考。相反，正如牛顿所说，“……通过专注和奉献。我不断把这个问题摆在我面前，直到第一道曙光一点一点地照进完整而清晰的光芒。”牛顿面前的不是一些精心构思的想法，而是一个构思不当的问题，充满矛盾和模糊性。只有让自己完全沉浸在充满问题的情况中，与问题共处很长时间，最终克服困难，光明才会出现。通往创造力的道路没有一条可以避开问题的。这是创造力的关键要素，它为接下来的一切定下了基调。

Creativity like all deep thinking involves overcoming a fundamental obstacle and so it is never easy. In this section I intend to discuss the response to that difficulty for this is the key to creativity. Yes there is something about the situation that is troublesome, that contradicts conventional wisdom, that may be irritating, and that produces tension. It is troubling yet the creative person cannot leave the situation alone, is unable to do the “normal” thing and just stop thinking about it. On the contrary, as Newton said, “… through concentration and dedication. I keep the subject constantly before me, till the first dawning opens little by little into the full and clear light.” What Newton held before him is not some well-formulated idea but a problem that is poorly formulated, full of ambiguity and contradiction. It is by allowing oneself to become totally absorbed in the situation with all of its problematic elements, living for protracted periods with the problem, and ultimately passing through the difficulty that the light finally appears. There is no path to creativity that avoids the problematic. This is a key element in creativity and it sets the tone for all that follows.

诺贝尔物理学奖得主弗兰克·威尔切克 (Frank Wilczek) 在其著作《存在之轻》中讨论了“错误的定义可以成为伟大科学工作的基础”的方式。他继续说道：“传奇的丹麦物理学家尼尔斯·玻尔区分了两种真理。普通真理是其对立面是谎言的陈述。深刻的真理是其对立面也是深刻真理的陈述。” iii从表面上看，玻尔的这句话并不合逻辑，但它本身就是一个深刻的真理，并说明了我在概念系统中适用的逻辑与从一个系统到另一个系统适用的创造性逻辑之间的区别。玻尔显然并不是想将他的评论应用于发展情况，而是应用于量子力学和（可能）所有科学。有两种可能的逻辑（或思维方式）——经典的或创造性的。两者的区别在于前者可以被视为“水平的”；前者是肤浅的，字面意思是浮于表面，与先前对情况的表述一致。后者是垂直的；它与变化有关，通常是彻底改变既定情况的根本变化。在另一本书中，我将两者之间的区别描述为“琐碎”与“深刻”，以及复杂与复杂。iv

The Nobel Prize winning physicist Frank Wilczek in his book, The Lightness of Being, discusses the manner in which “a wrong definition can be the foundation for great scientific work.” He goes on, “The legendary Danish physicist Niels Bohr distinguished two kinds of truths. An ordinary truth is a statement whose opposite is a falsehood. A profound truth is a statement whose opposite is also a profound truth.”iii On the face of it this statement by Bohr is not logical but it is, in itself a deep truth and illustrates the distinction I made between the logic that applies within a conceptual system as compared to the creative logic that applies in going from one system to another. Bohr evidently did not mean his comment to apply to developmental situations but to Quantum Mechanics and (possibly) to all of science. There are two kinds of logic (or ways of thinking) that are possible—classical or creative. The difference between the two is that the former can be considered as being “horizontal;” it is superficial in the literal sense of lying on the surface and of being consistent with earlier formulations of the situation. The latter is vertical; it is about change, often the radical change that completely reframes the given situation. In another book I characterized the difference between the two as “trivial” versus “deep,” and as complicated versus complex.iv

5.6创作逻辑：在头脑中保留矛盾的想法

5.6Creative Logic: Holding Contradictory Thoughts in the Mind

对于许多人，几乎可以肯定对于大多数科学家来说，“逻辑”意味着普通的日常逻辑——这个词只有一种正确的用法。对于这样的人来说，“创造性逻辑”只能意味着通过使用形式逻辑程序获得创造性结果。这将包括对计算机进行编程以使其自行发挥创造力的可能性。这是完全不是我想要的，事实上这与我想要的完全相反！

For many people, and almost certainly for most scientists, “logic” means ordinary, everyday logic—there is only one proper use of the word. To such people “creative logic” could only mean obtaining creative results through the use of formal logical procedures. This would include the possibility of programming a computer to be creative on its own. This is not at all what I have in mind, in fact it is the opposite of what I have in mind!

我之前使用逻辑这个词时，指的是使用思维的方式——思考的方式。换句话说，最好说逻辑思维或算法思维，而不是创造性思维或发展性思维。逻辑思维之所以“简单”，是因为它遵循客观规则：例如，如果A意味着B，B意味着C，那么A就意味着C。这就是它如此吸引人的原因。创造性思维很难，因为这些规则会被打破。

When I used the word logic earlier I was talking about ways of using the mind—ways of thinking. In other words it might be better to speak of logical or algorithmic thinking versus creative or developmental thinking. Logical thinking is “easy” in the sense that it follows objective rules: for example, if A implies B and B implies C then A implies C. This is what makes it so attractive. Creative thinking is hard because these rules break down.

作家 F. Scott Fitzgerald 写道：“一流智力的测试标准是，能够同时在脑海中保留两种对立的想法，并且仍然保持运作能力。” v在这里，我们更接近于对使用思维的不同方式进行富有成效的区分。同时在脑海中保留两种对立的想法会产生认知失调，这可能会令人不快，因为它可能会造成紧张、不适甚至焦虑。在出现不和谐的情况下，我们习惯性地会尽一切努力摆脱这种不和谐。我们通过接受一个对立的想法而拒绝另一个来做到这一点——例如，称一个为真，另一个为假。我们甚至可能通过回避整个情况来做出反应——有意识或无意识地树立起保护我们免受冲突的障碍。菲茨杰拉德认为还有另一种可能性，那就是同时在脑海中保留这两种想法，尽管这样做很困难，也很不愉快。

The writer F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, “The test of a first-rate intelligence is the ability to hold two opposing ideas in mind at the same time and still retain the ability to function.” v Here we are closer to a productive distinction between different ways of using the mind. Holding two opposing ideas in the mind at the same time produces cognitive dissonance and this may be unpleasant since it may creates tension, discomfort, or even anxiety. What we habitually do in dissonant situations is make every effort to get rid of the dissonance. We do this by accepting one of the opposing ideas while rejecting the other—by calling one true and the other false, for example. We may even react by avoiding the entire situation—consciously or unconsciously erecting barriers that protect us from the conflict. Fitzgerald is suggesting that there is another possibility and that is to hold both ideas in the mind simultaneously even though it is difficult and unpleasant to do so.

菲茨杰拉德指出了创造力的一个关键因素。创造力源于问题，源于不和谐，而逻辑矛盾就是不和谐的一种形式。在《数学家如何思考》一书中，我花了大量时间讨论其他类型的不和谐，如模糊性和悖论。无论以何种形式出现，对立的观点都会让我们感到紧张，我们渴望和谐——一个安全的环境，在那里一切都是可预测的，都在控制之中。如果我们希望敞开心扉接受创造性的反应，我们必须放弃这种安全感。人们能否接受培训来应对认知失调的情况？这是各级教育工作者面临的一个关键问题，我将在后续章节中再次讨论这个问题。

Fitzgerald has put his finger on a key element in creativity. Creativity arises from the problematic, from dissonance, and logical contradiction is one form of dissonance. In How Mathematicians Think I spent considerable time discussing other varieties of dissonance like ambiguity and paradox. In whatever form it arises opposing ideas make us nervous and we crave consonance—a safe environment where things are predictable and under control. It is precisely this safety that we must give up if we wish to open ourselves up to a creative response. Can people be trained to work with situations of cognitive dissonance? This is a key question for educators at all levels and I shall return to it in subsequent chapters.

但是，这里需要注意的是，不和谐的情况中有一个部分通常被隐藏起来。一个孩子说 1 到 2 之间没有数字，而另一个接受分数世界的孩子说有很多。这两个答案似乎相互矛盾，而且确实如此，在一个层面上。然而，在另一个层面上，两个孩子都有“数字”的直觉。他们之所以产生不同的观点，是因为他们通过不同的概念系统来看待这种直觉。他们的分歧背后有一个共同点。同样，足球比赛的冲突只有在双方就比赛规则达成一致的情况下才有可能。冲突和不和谐的出现背后必然存在一些共同点。因此，创造力大致涉及以下舞蹈：首先，以冲突的方式解释具有隐含统一性的情况。然后解决冲突并明确（重新）建立统一性。

However a caution is in order here. It is that there is a part of a dissonant situation that is habitually hidden from view. One child says that there are no numbers between 1 and 2 while another, who accepts the world of fractions, says that there are many. These two answers seem to contradict one another, and they do, on one level. However on another level both children have an intuition of “number.” Their different views arise because they view that intuition through different conceptual systems. There is a commonality behind their differences. Similarly the conflict of a football game is only possible because the two sides agree on the rules of the game. There is necessarily some commonality behind the emergence of conflict and dissonance. Thus creativity roughly involves the following dance: First, a situation with an implicit unity is interpreted in conflicting ways. Then the conflict is resolved and the unity is explicitly (re)-established.

在接下来的几节中，我将讨论许多作家和研究人员所描述的科学创造性活动的性质。正如我们将看到的，他们都同意，正如我所讨论的那样，创造力是困难的和不连续的。我们还将看到，允许自己进入不和谐的境地并长期保持这种境地是科学大跃进的关键。创造性智力，即菲茨杰拉德所说的第一流的头脑，更多地在于这个方向，而不是能够快速计算、在记忆中存储大量数据或拥有非常微妙和强大的批判能力，而这些是我们谈到智力时通常会想到的属性。创造力是对问题的反应。

In the next few sections I shall discuss the nature of creative activity in science as it is described by a number of writers and researchers. As we shall see, they all agree that creativity is difficult and discontinuous in the way that I have discussed. We shall also see that allowing oneself to enter situations of dissonance and remain there for prolonged periods is the key to the great leaps of science. Creative intelligence, what Fitzgerald calls a first-rate mind, lies more in this direction than it does in the direction of being able to make rapid calculations, store vast amounts of data in memory, or possess a very subtle and powerful critical faculty, which are the usual attributes that we think of when we speak of intelligence. Creativity is a response to the problematic.

5.7罗森伯格和“雅努斯”思想

5.7Rothenberg and “Janusian” thought

阿尔伯特·罗森伯格六世是哈佛医学院的精神病学教授，他对艺术和科学领域的创造力进行了大量研究。他也认为某种不相容性是创造过程的关键。为了描述这种不相容性，他创造了“雅努斯思维”一词，他将其定义为“同时积极构思多个对立面或对立面”。（雅努斯是罗马神话中的双面神，同时看向未来和过去。这听起来和菲茨杰拉德所说的非常相似。

Albert Rothenbergvi is a Professor of Psychiatry at Harvard Medical School who has done a great deal of research on creativity in the arts and the sciences. He, too, considers a certain kind of incompatibility as the key to the creative process. To describe this incompatibility he coined the term “Janusian thinking,” which he defines as “actively conceiving multiple opposites or antitheses simultaneously”. (Janus was the Roman god with two faces, which looked simultaneously to the future and the past.) This sounds very similar to what Fitzgerald was talking about.

罗森伯格说：“在创作过程中，人们有意而有意识地将相反或对立的思想、主张、行动或状态并列或同时共存。……矛盾的方面无法调和，而是一直处于冲突之中；对立面结合在一起，而对立面却无法解决。对立面和对立面处于紧张的并列状态；它们并肩运作，并在后期产生新的、有价值的结构。”
