Rothenberg says, “During the course of the creative process, opposite or antithetical ideas, propositions, actions, or states are intentionally and consciously conceptualized side by side or as coexisting simultaneously. … Contradictory aspects are not reconciled but remain in conflict; opposites are combined, and oppositions are not resolved. Antitheses and opposites are held in tense apposition; they operate side by side, and in later phases, generate new and valuable constructions.”

罗森伯格采访了 22 位化学、物理学、医学和生理学领域的诺贝尔奖获得者。他还对爱因斯坦、玻尔和达尔文等过去杰出科学家的自传进行了广泛的研究。在他研究的大部分工作中，他能够将雅努斯过程确定为科学发现过程中的基本要素。

Rothenberg interviewed 22 Nobel laureates in the fields of chemistry, physics, and medicine and physiology. He also did extensive research on autobiographical accounts of the work of outstanding scientists of the past such as Einstein, Bohr, and Darwin. In most of the work that he studied he was able to identify the Janusian process as the essential element in the process of scientific discovery.

篇幅有限，我无法对罗森伯格的作品进行完整的描述。但是，我将描述和评论罗森伯格眼中创造性突破发展的四个阶段。第一是创造的动机。这超越了对名声的渴望或单纯的好奇心。他研究的科学家们被驱使去创造，即使这会带来困难和痛苦。爱因斯坦说：“一想到在这里要处理两个根本不同的情况，我就难以忍受。”1949 年因介子理论获得诺贝尔物理学奖的汤川秀树说：“为了应对这个难题，我付出了漫长的痛苦。”我们已经看到，这种困难是所有深度思考的特征。

I do not have the space to give Rothenberg’s work the complete description that it merits. However I will describe and comment on the four phases in the development of a creative breakthrough as Rothenberg sees them. The first is the motivation to create. This goes beyond a hunger for fame or mere curiosity. The scientists he studied were driven to be creative even if this involved difficulty and a kind of suffering. Einstein said, “The thought that one is dealing here with two fundamentally different cases, was, for me unbearable.” And Hideki Yukawa who won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1949 for his theory of mesons, said, “By confronting this difficult problem, I committed myself to long days of suffering.” We have seen that this kind of difficulty characterizes all forms of deep thinking.

如果科学中的创造性工作如此困难，那么人们为什么要致力于此呢？想想数学家安德鲁·怀尔斯，他花了七年时间，放弃了生活中一切与攻克费马大定理无关的事情。为什么要为一个远未保证的结果做出这样的牺牲呢？当然，我们不会问为什么一个孩子会被逼着站起来走路。孩子是在回应一种无法忽视的命令。最伟大的艺术家和科学家也无法不回应创造的需要。尽管创造性活动可能很困难，但对一些人来说，选择不去做，不可想象。这意味着否认生命中最重要、最鲜活的东西。正如画家梵高谈到自己和他强烈的创作欲望时所说，“我内心有某种东西是鲜活的：那会是什么呢？” vii

If creative work in science is so fraught with difficulty, why should one commit oneself to it? Think of the mathematician Andrew Wiles who spent seven years cutting off everything in his life that was not essential to his assault on Fermat’s Last Theorem. Why make such a sacrifice for a result that is far from guaranteed? Of course we do not ask why a child is driven to stand up and walk. The child is responding to an imperative that it is powerless to ignore. The greatest artists and scientists also are powerless to fail to respond to the need to create. As difficult as creative activity may be, choosing not to do it is, for some, unthinkable. It would mean denying what is most important and alive in one’s life. As the painter Van Gogh said of himself and his powerful need to create, “Something is alive in me: what can it be!”vii

“在雅努斯过程的第二阶段，需要整合的对立元素之一或两者被关注或确定。通常，正是在这里，科学家开始脱离其他科学家的工作。”正是在这个阶段，科学家对将发展成为新理论的想法有了些许暗示，但仅仅是些暗示。汤川说：“回想起来，介子的基本概念曾多次出现在我脑海中，但它的出现就像闪电一样，只能瞬间照亮黑暗。”罗森伯格坚持认为：“这个学科组的其他科学家也同样在没有充分认识或确信的情况下经历了解决方案和发现。”

“In Phase 2 of the Janusian process, one or both of the oppositional elements to be brought together are focused on or identified. It is here that the initial breaking away from the work of other scientists usually occurs.” It is at this stage that the scientist has a hint, but only a hint, of the idea that will blossom into a new theory. Yukawa stated, “In retrospect, the basic concept of the meson came to me several times, but its appearance were [sic] like flashes of lightening that illuminated darkness only for an instant.” Rothenberg maintains that, “Other scientists in this subject group have similarly experienced solutions and discoveries without full awareness or conviction.”

“在雅努斯过程的第三阶段，成对、成组或成系列的对立面同时被组合在一起，形成一个概念，直接导致创造性的结果……第二阶段关注的元素的对立面或对立面可能在第三阶段被单独且实质性地表述出来；然后对立面或对立面同时被组合在一起。”例如，“从自由落体的观察者同时处于静止和运动状态这一表述中，爱因斯坦能够假设运动的相对性……”当然，量子力学中互补性的矛盾性质是其最引人注目的元素。玻尔写道：“这适用于每一个问题，它都是关于粒子之间或光与物质之间的相互作用，而根据自然规律，我们得到了不连续-连续或粒子-波的非理性元素。而为了构建一个完整的表述，需要不可思议的手段。”

“In Phase 3 of the Janusian process, pairs, sets, or series of opposites are simultaneously brought together in a conception that leads directly to the creative outcome. … the opposite or antithesis of an element in focus in Phase 2 may in Phase 3 be separately and substantively formulated; then opposites or antitheses are brought simultaneously together.” For example, “From the formulation that an observer in free fall is both at rest and in motion at the same time, Einstein was able to postulate the relativity of motion… .” Of course the paradoxical nature of complementarity in quantum mechanics was its most striking element. Bohr wrote, “This applies to every problem, that it is all about interaction between particles or between light and matter, and there we get at—according to nature—the irrational element of discontinuity-continuity or particle-wave. And in order to construct a complete formulation, inconceivable means are required.”

罗森伯格所举的例子都不是数学的，但我们也可以看到同样的现象。我已经讨论过数字概念是如何通过除法或减法等算术运算具体化而发展起来的。在我们的正常思维方式中，过程涉及对象的移动或修改。对象是主要的，过程是次要的。这两者本质上是相互对立的，大多数语言都通过使用名词表示对象和动词表示过程来明确这一点。将过程同时视为一个对象是困难的，最初也很奇怪。你会得到一个提示当你考虑康托关于无限性的工作时，你会发现这是多么奇怪。正如我之前所讨论的，“无限性作为过程”是可以接受的，但“无限性作为对象”则不可接受。认为像计数这样的无限过程可以被视为一个完整的对象是一种飞跃。

None of Rothenberg’s examples come from mathematics but there too we can see the same phenomenon at work. I have already discussed how the concept of number develops by reifying arithmetical operations like division or subtraction. In our normal way of thinking processes involve the movement or modification of objects. The objects are primary and the process secondary. These two are in essential opposition to one another and most languages make this explicit by using nouns for objects and verbs for processes. To think of a process as simultaneously being an object is difficult and initially strange. You get a hint of this strangeness when you consider the work of Cantor on infinity. As I discussed earlier “infinity as process” was acceptable but “infinity as object” was not. To think that an infinite process like the counting numbers could be considered one completed object is a leap.

为了说明这一跨越对于学生（以及其他许多人）来说仍然是一个难题，请考虑以下“悖论”：“走廊里有无数的学生排队等待与 X 教授交谈。中午前一分钟，前两名学生（称为 S1 和 S2）进入房间，但 S1 立刻离开。中午前半分钟，S3 和 S4 进入办公室，S2 离开。中午前三分之一分钟，S5 和 S6 进入，S3 离开。这种情况一直持续。中午有多少学生在 X 教授的办公室？”

To illustrate that this leap is still a difficulty for students (and many others) consider the following “paradox”: “There is an infinite line of students in the hallway waiting to speak to Professor X. At one minute before noon the first two students, call them S1 and S2, enter the room but S1 leaves immediately. At a half-minute before noon, S3 and S4 enter the office and S2 leaves. At one-third of a minute before noon S5 and S6 enter and S3 leaves. This continues on and on. How many students are in Professor X’s office at noon?”

作为一个过程，在每个时间间隔里办公室里的学生都会越来越多：中午前 1 分钟有 1 名学生，中午前半分钟有 2 名学生，中午前三分之一分钟有 3 名学生，依此类推。所以答案似乎是中午时办公室里会有无数个学生。但如果你考虑到中午时分所有时间间隔都已过去，并且每个人都在某个时刻离开，那么似乎房间里根本没有人了。你认为这是一个在时间中发生并因此没有尽头的过程，还是你认为这是一个完成的过程？这将决定你的答案。大多数学生属于第一类。他们无法同时在脑海中持有这两种看似矛盾的关于无限的想法。对他们来说，无限的过程必定是不完整的，因此永远不可能是一个完成的对象。

As a process there are more and more students in the office at every interval in time: 1 at 1 minute before noon, 2 at a half-minute before noon, 3 at a third of a minute before noon, and so on. So the answer would appear to be that at noon there would be an infinite number of students in the office. But if you consider that at noon all of the intervals have passed and that everyone leaves at some moment in time there would seem to be no one left in the room at all. Do you think of this as a process that happens in time and therefore is without end or do you think of it as a completed process? This will determine your answer. Most students fall into the first category. They cannot hold these two seemingly contradictory thoughts about infinity in their minds at the same time. For them an infinite process must be incomplete and so can never be a completed object.

从正常理性的角度来看，矛盾是不可接受的，必须消除。说过程是对象似乎不合理。毕竟，对象就是对象，而不是其他任何东西，过程就是过程。我们渴望一个我们能够理解的世界，在这个世界中，不同的词语指向现实的不同特征；我们期望科学和散文的语言是明确的，而诗歌的隐喻语言的本质是模糊的。这就是希腊人难以理解零和无穷的原因，也正是这一点使得零和无穷成为如此具有创造性的突破。零和无穷都设法把对立面放在一起。我讨论了《无穷》第八章中的一组对立面，但《无穷》第八章中的对立面是什么？零的概念是什么？首先，负的“零是无”可以与正的“零是一切的‘空’源”相对立。希腊人无法达到这个阶段，但印度人在表述这些对立面时没有遇到同样的问题。

From the viewpoint of normal reason contradictions are unacceptable and must be eliminated. It might well seem irrational to say that a process is an object. After all an object is an object and not anything else and a process is a process. We desire a world that is intelligible to us, in which different words point to distinct features of reality; the language of science and prose in general we expect to be unambiguous unlike the metaphoric language of poetry whose essence is ambiguity. This is behind the Greek difficulty with zero and infinity and it is precisely what makes zero and infinity such creative breakthroughs. Both zero and infinity manage to put together opposites. I have discussed one set of antitheses contained in infinityviii but what are the antitheses in the conception of zero? For one thing, it is that the negative “zero as nothing” can be set against the positive “zero as the ‘empty’ source of all”. The Greeks could not get to this stage but the Hindus did not have the same problem in formulating these opposites.

有趣的是，罗森伯格评论道：“我发现他们（他采访过的科学家）有些不愿意透露他们思维的细节，如果表面上看起来不合理的话。”所有人都有这种不情愿，而且他们受教育程度越高，似乎越难以接受非理性（非理性似乎比非理性更合适）。我们已经看到，这种不情愿源于我们更喜欢观察性手电筒意识和左半球，而不是参与性灯笼意识和右半球。这就是为什么当我们能够将自己置于成熟的理论、范式或完善的概念系统中时，我们都感到更舒服。承认非理性进入我们的生活似乎是对我们本性中某种原始元素的回归。即使是一个足够勇敢的人，深入到这些深处，并像神话中的英雄一样带着巨大的奖品回来，可能仍然不愿意谈论它，甚至可能不愿意向自己承认它。

It is interesting that Rothenberg comments that, “I found them [the scientists he interviewed] somewhat reluctant to reveal the specifics of their thinking if it seemed, on the surface, irrational.” All people share this reluctance and the more educated they are the more difficulty they seem to have with the non-rational (which seems to be a more suitable word than irrational). We have seen how this reluctance has its origins in our preference for observational flashlight consciousness and the left hemisphere over participatory lantern consciousness and the right hemisphere. This is why we are all more comfortable when we can situate ourselves within a mature theory, paradigm, or well-developed conceptual system. To admit the non-rational into our lives seems like a reversion to some primitive element in our nature. Even someone who is brave enough to descend into these depths and has returned, like the mythological hero, with a prize of great value still may be reluctant to talk about it and maybe even admit it to herself.

现在让我继续讨论罗森伯格的最后阶段，该阶段涉及完整理论、发现或实验的构建。“正是在这个构建阶段，同时对立的结构被修改，通常到了对立和明显矛盾完全消失的地步。一些理论和发现保留了某种正面或反面的性质，从而暗示了它们在雅努斯过程中的发展，但总的来说，逐步的逻辑和外部验证决定了它们的详细内容。……在这个构建阶段，数学技能、演绎和归纳逻辑以及富有创造力的科学家对特定科学领域的全面知识占主导地位。”

Now let me go on to Rothenberg’s final phase, which involves the construction of the complete theory, discovery, or experiment. “It is in this construction phase that the structure of simultaneous opposition is modified, often to a point at which antitheses and apparent contradictions disappear completely. Some of the theories and discoveries retain a somewhat obverse or inverse quality and thereby give some hint of their development within the Janusian process, but, by and large, stepwise logic and external validation dictate their elaborated content. … In this construction phase, skill in mathematics and in deductive and inductive logic, as well as the creative scientist’s comprehensive knowledge of a particular scientific field, predominate.”

逻辑在这个阶段占主导地位，因为普通逻辑代表了思维在概念系统（尤其是理论科学和严格数学系统）中的运作方式。我们使用逻辑推理规则来组织我们的想法并将其传达给他人。更重要的是，逻辑将新见解与大量科学或数学结果相结合。

Logic predominates in this phase because ordinary logic represents the way the mind functions within conceptual systems especially within the systems of theoretical science and rigorous mathematics. We use the logical rules of inference to both organize our thoughts and to communicate them to others. More importantly logic integrates the new insights with the larger body of scientific or mathematical results.

至少，将你的见解置于逻辑阐述的检验之下可能会发现论证中的漏洞。这不仅仅是一个验证阶段，也是创作过程不可或缺的一部分。正是在“写下东西”的阶段，科学家或数学家意识到了严重的失误，至少在某种程度上，这些失误需要重新开始。因此，罗森伯格模型中的四个阶段可能不止一次。在实践中，这些阶段可能会多次重复；其中，写下东西的缺陷将导致研究人员进一步思考并修改原始见解。这正是怀尔斯在费马大定理的初始证明需要大幅修改时所发生的事情。

At the very least subjecting your insights to the test of logical exposition may reveal holes in the argument. This is not just a verification phase but part and parcel of the creative process. It is in the stage of “writing things up” that the scientist or mathematician becomes aware of serious lapses that necessitate going back to the drawing board, to some extent at least. Thus the four stages in Rothenberg’s model may be gone through more than once. In practice there may be many iterations of these stages; where lacunae in writing things up will lead the researcher to think things through some more and modify the original insight. This is exactly what happened to Wiles when his initial proof of Fermat needed to be substantially revised.

最后，我们应该记住，罗森伯格或其他任何人都不会为我们提供坚不可摧的创造力规则。然而，罗森伯格的基本见解是正确的，它强调了矛盾在创造过程中的建设性作用，从而向我们表明，支配创造活动的规则不是普通逻辑的规则。

Finally it would be wise to remember that neither Rothenberg nor anyone else will give us ironclad rules for creativity. Nevertheless Rothenberg’s fundamental insight is sound and consists of emphasizing the constructive role of contradiction within the creative process and thereby showing us that the rules that govern creative activity are not the rules of ordinary logic.

5.8凯斯特勒和“双联”

5.8Koestler and “Bisociation”

亚瑟·库斯特勒的《创造行为》一书于 1964 年问世。他在序言中写道：“本书的目的……是要表明某些基本原则贯穿于整个有机层级——从受精卵到富有创造力的个体的大脑：并且与创造性原创性类似的现象可以在所有层面找到。”换句话说，库斯特勒的直觉是，创造力的原则超越了某些特殊人物的心理现象——创造力是所有有机生命的属性，尤其是贯穿于整个人类生活。因此，他选择以幽默作为本书的开篇具有启发意义，他认为幽默是创造性活动的一个典型例子——对他来说，不仅仅是编造和讲笑话，甚至“理解”一个笑话也涉及创造力的基本要素。

Arthur Koestler’s book, The Act of Creation appeared in 1964. In a preface he wrote, “The aim … is to show that certain basic principles operate throughout the whole organic hierarchy—from the fertilized egg to the fertile brain of the creative individual: and that phenomena analogous to creative originality can be found at all levels.” Koestler’s intuition, in other words, was that the principles of creativity go beyond the mental phenomena of certain exceptional people—that creativity is a property of all of organic life and, in particular, pervades all of human life. It is therefore instructive that he chose to begin his book with a discussion of humor, which he considered as a prime example of creative activity—not just making up and telling a joke but even “getting” a joke involves, for him, the essentials of creativity.

对于科斯特勒来说，重要的是“在两个自洽但通常不相容的参照框架中感知一种情况或想法。” ix他称这种思维方式为“双重联想”，“以便区分在单一“平面”上思考的常规技能与创造性行为，后者……总是在多个平面上运作。” x

For Koestler the important thing was “the perceiving of a situation or idea … in two self consistent but habitually incompatible frames of reference.”ix He called this way of thinking, “bisociation”, “ in order to make a distinction between the routine skills of thinking on a single “plane” as it were, and the creative act, which, … always operates on more than one plane.”x

一个很好的双联想例子是阿基米德的著名故事，国王要求他确定一顶王冠是否由纯金制成。显然，熔化王冠是不切实际的，因此阿基米德被需要用另一种方式找到王冠的体积而困扰了很长时间。当阿基米德踏进一个装满水的浴缸并发现水溢出时，他终于找到了答案。这是第二个层面，直接导致了那个著名的时刻，据说，他兴奋得赤身裸体地跑到街上大喊“尤里卡”。

A good example of bisociation is the famous story of Archimedes who was asked by the king to determine whether a crown was made of pure gold. Obviously it was not practical to melt down the crown so Archimedes was stymied for a long time by the need to find the volume of the crown in another way. The resolution occurred when Archimedes stepped into a full bathtub and noticed that water spilled out. This was the second plane that led directly to the famous moment when, in his excitement, he reputedly ran down the street stark naked shouting, “eureka.”

这一事件还告诉我们有关创造力的其他事情，即创造力是突然发生的，当大脑经过长时间的专注准备后，任何偶然事件都可能促成创造力。这就是偶然发现，这是创造力过程的正常特征。回想一下，概念系统定义了什么是真实的，但现实总是单一的。只有当人们意识到新事物时（第二个框架），才会出现偶然发现。这种情况发生在右半球，并且只有当左半球倾向于以特定方式看待熟悉情况的倾向被打破时才会发生。

This incident also tells us other things about the act of creativity, namely, that it is sudden and can be precipitated by any accidental occurrence when the mind has been prepared through a lengthy period of absorption. This is serendipity, which is a normal feature of the creative process. Recall that the conceptual system defines what is real but that reality is always singular. Serendipity only happens when one becomes conscious of something new (the second framework). This happens through the right hemisphere and only occurs when the tendency of the left hemisphere to become fixated on a particular way of looking at a familiar situation is broken down.

现在，科斯特勒的理论与罗森伯格的理论并不相同，后者在其著作中不遗余力地强调这一点。xi尽管如此，这两种创造力方法之间的相似之处是有益的。科斯特勒的“自洽但习惯性不相容的参考框架”对应于罗森伯格的“积极地同时构想多个对立面或对立面”。这种“不兼容性”出现在儿童的概念发展中，是科学和数学研究的一个特点。然而，在后一种情况下，它先于对问题的最初吸收，随后是最后阶段，其中新理论或观点与更大的科学或数学理论体系逻辑地结合起来。

Now Koestler’s theory is not the same as Rothenberg’s as the latter is at pains to emphasize in his writing.xi Nevertheless the parallels between these two approaches to creativity are instructive. Koestler’s “selfconsistent but habitually incompatible frames of reference” would correspond to Rothenberg’s “actively conceiving multiple opposites or antitheses simultaneously.” This “incompatibility” appeared in the conceptual development of children and was a feature of scientific and mathematical research. However in the latter situation it preceded by an initial absorption in the problem and followed by the final stage in which when the new theory or point of view is logically integrated with the larger body of scientific or mathematical theory.

这两种理论所提出的要点是：（1）创造力源于不兼容性；（2）创造力涉及一种特定的思维方式或思维方式；（3）逻辑推理的一般规则推理不成立，（4）它涉及多个不一致的观点，（5）对原始情况进行重新阐述。这两种关于创造性活动的观点与从一个概念系统转移到另一个概念系统的特征有着惊人的相似之处。

The essential points brought out by both theories are that (1) creativity comes out of an incompatibility, (2) it involves a particular way of thinking or using the mind, (3) the ordinary rules of logical inference do not hold, (4) it involves multiple, inconsistent points of view and (5) a reframing of the original situation. There are striking parallels between both of these views of creative activity and the characteristics of moving from one conceptual system to another.

5.9马丁与反对思想

5.9Martin and the Opposable Mind

创造力不仅存在于艺术和科学领域，它也是商业和工业的圣杯，尤其是近年来，年轻人可以通过发明一些技术或新的互联网应用赚取数十亿美元。我所讨论的原则应该进入商业世界，这并不奇怪。多伦多大学罗特曼管理学院院长罗杰·马丁 (Roger Martin) 撰写了一种方法，他声称通过这种方法我们所有人都可以更具创造力。在对拥有“惊人和模范成功记录”的领导者的采访和研究中，他声称发现了贯穿他们成功的一个共同主题。用他的话来说，他所研究的人“倾向于并有能力在头脑中容纳两个截然相反的想法。然后，他们不会惊慌失措或简单地满足于一个想法或另一个想法，而是能够产生一种优于任何对立想法的综合。整合思维是我用来描述这个过程的术语——或者更准确地说，这种考虑和综合的纪律——这是卓越企业及其经营者的标志。”十二

Creativity is not only present in the arts and the sciences; it is also the holy grail of business and industry especially in recent years when young people can earn billions of dollars by inventing a bit of technology or new internet application. It is not surprising that the principles that I have been discussing should find their way into the world of business. Roger Martin, the dean at the Rotman School of Management at the University of Toronto has written about a method by which he claims we all can be more creative. In his interviews and study of leaders who have “striking and exemplary success records” he claims to have uncovered a common theme that runs through their successes. The people he studied have, in his words, “the predisposition and the capacity to hold two diametrically opposing ideas in their heads. And then, without panicking or simply settling for one idea or the other, they are able to produce a synthesis that is superior to either opposing idea. Integrative thinking is my term for this process—or more precisely this discipline of consideration and synthesis—that is the hallmark of exceptional businesses and the people who run them.”xii

令人惊讶的是，我们发现马丁对创造力的讨论与我们在本章中讨论过的其他作者的讨论相似。再次提到要毫不畏缩地坚持两种矛盾或对立的想法。然后，对马丁来说，这些想法是“整合”或“综合”。第一个是第二个的先决条件——我们通常称之为创造性突破。我认为“整合”和“综合”这两个词都不太适合这种情况，我将在本章后面讨论创造性活动的第二阶段。现在让我们再次注意，创造性体验的背景是允许自己毫无抵抗地接受整个情况及其非逻辑元素。

It is quite striking that we find Martin’s discussion of creativity to be similar to the other authors that we have discussed in this chapter. Again there is mention of holding two contradictory or opposing ideas without flinching. Then, for Martin, there is the “integration” or “synthesis” of these ideas. The first would be a prerequisite to the second—what we normally call the creative breakthrough. I believe that neither the word “integration” nor “synthesis” is well suited to this situation and shall go into this second phase of the creative activity later in the chapter. For now let’s just note again that the setting for creative experience is allowing oneself to accept, without resistance, the entire situation complete with its non-logical elements.

5.10低和想法

5.10Low and the Idea

蒙特利尔作家阿尔伯特·洛在《创造意识》和最近的《我即我思》等书中，将整个宇宙视为一个基本而持续的创造过程的中心。他对创造过程的描述也分为我们之前讨论过的各个阶段，从创造的需要开始，他称之为“对统一的渴望”。对他来说，这就是生命力本身。寻找艺术家、音乐家、诗人、科学家或有工作和家庭的普通人身上最活跃的东西，就是寻找创造力。这种寻找的结果——无论是一首歌、一种新的科学理论还是一种新颖的花园布置方式——并不比过程重要：让创造的萌芽表达自己的痛苦和回报。

The Montreal author Albert Low, in books like Creating Consciousness and the more recent I Am Therefore I Think sees the entire universe as the locus of a fundamental and ongoing creative process. His description of the creative process also breaks down into the phases that we have previously discussed and begins with the need to create which he calls “the yearning for unity.” For him, this is the life force itself. The search for what is most alive in the artist, the musician, the poet, the scientist, or the ordinary person with a job and a family is the search for the creative. What comes out of this search—whether it is a song or a new scientific theory or a novel way of arranging the garden—is not as important as the process: the agony and the rewards of allowing the creative germ to express itself.

对于 Low 来说，我们一直在讨论的问题元素在于创造力的起源（同样也在于人类状况的起源）。事实上，对他来说，问题必须得到解决——要么通过创造性行为建设性地解决，要么通过不和与暴力消极地解决。这种暴力不仅需要针对他人或自然，甚至可能针对自己。这里的寓意是，创造力的驱动力实际上无法被压抑；它必须得到表达。唯一的选择是这种表达是建设性的还是破坏性的。因此，压抑创造力的决定具有深远的影响。不仅每个人都有创造潜力，而且否认这种潜力对个人的福祉有着深远的影响。

For Low the problematic element that we have been discussing lies at the origins of creativity (and equally at the origin of the human condition). In fact for him the problematic must be resolved—either constructively through an act of creativity or negatively through discord and violence. This violence need not only be directed at other people or at nature but may even be directed at oneself. The moral here is that the drive towards the creative cannot really be repressed; it must find expression. The only choice is whether that expression is to be constructive or destructive. Thus the decision to repress the creative has far-reaching implications. Not only does every person have a creative potential but denying that potential has far-reaching consequences for the individual’s wellbeing.

洛继续讨论创造力的突然性。他也强调了创造性洞察力的不连续性。但这种洞察力的本质是什么？洛谈到了“想法”。我可能没有充分说明洛所说的“想法”，这是因为，对洛来说，想法没有，也不可能被明确地表述出来。就像一个概念系统，想法不是我们看到的东西，而是我们透过它去看的东西。正因为如此，我们看不到它。用上一章的术语来说，你可以说想法主要是右半球的产物。

Low goes on to discuss the suddenness of creativity. He, too, emphasizes the discontinuity of the creative insight. But what is the nature of this insight? Low talks about “the idea.” I shall probably not do justice to what Low is referring to by “idea” and that is because, for Low, the idea is not, and cannot be, explicitly formulated. Like a conceptual system, the idea is not something that we see but something through which we see. For that very reason we cannot see it. In the terminology of the previous chapter you could say that the idea is primarily a creature of the right hemisphere.

例如，“数”是一个概念。你无法真正定义“数”，尽管你当然可以定义许多不同类型的数，如计数数、有理数、实数等等。对 Low 来说，这些都是概念——具有明确定义的事物。但所有这些类型的数都源自一个生成概念，即数。你对数可以说很多种；你“看到它就知道它”，因此说数不存在是荒谬的。但将其固定下来是有限的。“数”是动态的，因为它在数学学科内部以及每个数学学生的理解范围内都在不断变化和发展。科学和数学的所有基本概念都是 Low 意义上的概念xiii。一个非常不完整的列表包括：空间、时间、能量、随机性、连续性等等。所有这些都是对世界的科学描述的基础。没有一个可以明确地固定下来。

For example, “number” is an idea. You can’t really define “number” although, of course, you can certainly define many different varieties of number such as counting numbers, rational numbers, real numbers, and so on. These, for Low, are concepts—things that have explicit definitions. But all these varieties of number arise from one generating idea, namely, number. You can say many things about number; you “know it when you see it” so it would be ridiculous to say that number does not exist. But it is limiting to pin it down. “Number” is dynamic because it is continually changing and evolving both within mathematics as a discipline as well as within the understanding of every student of mathematics. All of the basic ideas of science and mathematics are ideas in Low’s sensexiii. A very partial list would include: space, time, energy, randomness, continuity, and so on. All are basic to a scientific description of the world. None can be pinned down definitively.

理念是“揭示现象中的关系”。洛说：“环顾你所在的房间。你看到一把椅子：那是某人的理念。”你看到的一切都是某人的理念。理念是我们为生活注入活力和连贯性的手段。它们使科学得以存在。事实上，科学本身就是一个宏伟的理念，它仍然在积极地创造着现代世界。每一个数学证明、每一个科学理论或实验都是一个中心理念的体现。理念是根本；它是一切的起点和终点。

Idea is “that which reveals relations within phenomena.” Low says, “Look around the room in which you are sitting. You see a chair: that is someone’s idea.” Everything you see is someone’s idea. Ideas are the means through which we bring energy and coherence to our lives. They bring science into existence. In fact science itself is a magnificent idea that is still actively producing the modern world. Every mathematical proof, every scientific theory or experiment is the manifestation of a central idea. The idea is what is essential; it is the alpha and the omega.

我的每一本书都是从一个想法开始的，这个想法最初在我看来是模糊的。然而，这种“感觉”，这种初步形成的想法，给了我能量和热情，让我朝着一个明确的方向前进。在这个中心思想出现之前，我已经在一片荒原中挣扎了好几个月，但后来，一句偶然的评论或我在一本书中读到的东西引发了一场真正的爆炸，我立刻知道那里有一个想法。最终写出的数百页都隐含在那个最初的时刻。在“荒原时期”，我非常感谢朋友们，他们向我保证，这也是创作过程的一部分——一个必不可少的部分。

Each of my books began with an idea, which appeared to me originally in a nebulous manner. Nevertheless this “feeling,” this tentatively formulated idea, gave me the energy and enthusiasm to get going in a definite direction. Before the appearance of this central idea I had floundered for many months in a kind of wasteland, but then a chance remark or something I read in a book set off a veritable explosion and instantly I knew that there was an idea there. All of the hundreds of pages that were eventually written were implicit in that original moment. During the “wasteland period” I owe a great deal to friends who reassured me that this, too, was all part—an essential part—of the creative process.

这个想法的诞生在伟大的法国作家马塞尔·普鲁斯特的著名故事和玛德琳蛋糕的味道中得到了最诗意的表达：“混合着面包屑的温热液体刚接触到我的口中发出一阵寒颤，我停了下来，专心致志地看着发生在我身上的不寻常的事情。一种极致的快乐侵入了我的感官，一种孤立的、超脱的、不知从何而来的快乐。突然间，人生的沧桑对我来说变得无所谓了，灾难也无所谓了，短暂也虚幻了——这种新的感觉对我产生了爱情的作用，让我充满了珍贵的精华；或者更确切地说，这种精华不是在我身上，而是在我身上……它从何而来？它意味着什么？我怎样才能抓住和理解它？……突然间，记忆显露出来。” xiv

The birth of the idea is expressed most poetically in the famous story of the great French writer Marcel Proust and the taste of the madeleine: “No sooner had the warm liquid mixed with the crumbs touched my palate than a shudder ran through me and I stopped, intent upon the extraordinary thing that was happening to me. An exquisite pleasure had invaded my senses, something isolated, detached, with no suggestion of its origin. And at once the vicissitudes of life had become indifferent to me, its disasters innocuous, its brevity illusory—this new sensation having had on me the effect which love has of filling me with a precious essence; or rather this essence was not in me it was me… Whence did it come? What did it mean? How could I seize and apprehend it? … And suddenly the memory revealed itself.”xiv

饼干的味道是引发爆炸的根源，这个想法最终发展成为《追忆似水年华》多卷本的宏伟篇章。

The taste of the cookie was the germ that led to an explosion, the idea, which opened out into the magnificent expanse of the many volumes of In Search of Lost Time.

5.11创造力没有公式

5.11There is No Formula for Creativity

总有人声称自己拥有创造的公式或技巧。有时他们靠向他人传授自己的技巧谋生，这种“老师”的市场很大，尤其是在商业领域，正如我之前所说，创新是成功的先决条件。然而，在本节中，我将说明为什么这种技巧不存在或永远不可能存在。这将教会我们一些关于创造力本质的基本知识。

There are always people who purport to have a formula or technique for creativity. Sometimes they make a living out of teaching others their technique and there is a big market for such “teachers” especially in business where, as I noted earlier, innovation is a prerequisite for success. However, in this section I shall indicate why no such technique exists or can ever exist. This will teach us something essential about the nature of creativity.

从根本上说，这个论点很简单，甚至是同义反复：创造力不可能有技巧，因为任何由技巧或公式产生的活动都不是创造性的。一个简单的原因是，算法、公式和技术都是分析性思维的例子，涉及使用左半球的过程。创造性思维，就其原创性而言，需要右半球的参与。正如我在上一章中所说，创造力始于右半球，最终回到那里。创造力是一个过程，这个过程的本质是两种不同思维模式的交替，我们将在以下章节中看到这一点。

Fundamentally the argument is simple and even tautological: there can be no technique for creativity because any activity generated by a technique or formula is not creative. A quick reason is that algorithms, formulas, and techniques are instances of analytic thinking and involve using left hemispheric processes. Creative thinking, in so far is it is original at all, necessitates the involvement of the right. As I said in the last chapter creativity begins in the right hemisphere and ultimately returns there. Creativity is a process and the essence of that process is the alternation of two different mental modes, as we shall see in the following sections.

5.12集中思考

5.12Focused Thinking

创造过程的第一阶段涉及集中思考，即闪光灯意识，在此阶段，问题被定义并分离出其基本要素。如果人们能够将众所周知的算法应用于这种情况，这可能会直接导致解决方案。在这种情况下，就没有必要再进一步了——不需要创造力。

The first stage in the creative process involves focused thinking, that is, flashlight consciousness, in which the problem is defined and its essential elements are isolated. This may lead directly to a solution if one can apply a well-known algorithm to the situation. In this case there would be no need to go further—no creativity is called for.

通常，当我们讨论科学和数学时，我们和听众的意识心理状态是这种专注的意识，正如我们在上一章中看到的，这是大脑左半球的典型运作模式。这导致了我们以分析的方式处理世界。我们成年后的大部分时间都是在这种意识中度过的。

Normally when we discuss science and mathematics our conscious mental state and that of our audience is this focused consciousness, which, as we have seen in the last chapter, is the characteristic mode of functioning of the brain’s left cerebral hemisphere. This leads to the analytic way of dealing with the world. Much of our adult lives are spent in this type of consciousness.

任何人在能够在任何领域发挥创造力之前，都必须先精通自己的手艺，而这需要大量艰苦而重复的工作——专注的工作。我们许多人都希望创造力是一种解放，这无疑是可以实现的。不幸的是，有些人希望这种解放不需要艰苦工作——这是一种恩赐。换句话说，他们希望创造力不需要我在本章前面提到的那种困难。

Before anyone can be creative in any field they must first master their craft and this involves a lot of hard and repetitious work—focused work. Many of us hope for creativity as a kind of liberation, which it undoubtedly can be. Unfortunately some people hope that the release will come without the hard work—as a kind of grace. In other words they want creativity without the kind of difficulty that I talked about earlier in the chapter.

如果你想有创造力，你就必须付出代价，而且代价很高。其中涉及的困难有不同的形式。第一个困难是全身心投入问题，熟悉提出给定问题的学科语言。我当然遇到过一些学生，他们相信创造力意味着兴奋，然后就袖手旁观，等待奇迹发生。顿悟的时刻是一种奇迹。你不能强迫它发生；你必须让它来到你身边，这意味着承认“你”无法控制。我甚至认识一些非常成功和有创造力的学者，他们经常吸食大麻。他们中的一些人声称这有助于他们的创造力，也许确实如此，我们将在下一节中看到为什么会这样。但可以肯定的是，这些人非常努力地工作——在实验室或书房里投入无数的时间，阅读、思考和关注工作的细节。没有这种最初的工作和培训，什么也不会发生。即使你有一个绝妙的想法，为了要与人沟通，你必须说他们的语言。你不能发明自己的语言，然后又疑惑为什么自己没有得到赏识。至少你必须能够解释为什么你的工作值得考虑。所有这些都需要一个人处于专注的意识状态。

If you want to be creative you have to pay the price and the price is high. The difficulties that are involved come in different forms. The first involves absorbing yourself in the problem and familiarizing yourself with the disciplinary language within which the given problem is formulated. I’ve certainly run into students who believed that creativity involved getting high and then just standing back and waiting for the miracle to happen. The moment of insight is a kind of miracle. You cannot force it to happen; you must allow it to come to you and this means acknowledging that “you” are not in control. I’ve even known some very successful and creative academics who smoke marijuana on a regular basis. Some of them claimed that it helped their creativity and perhaps it did and we’ll see in the next section why this might be so. But what is certain is that these people work very hard at what they do— putting in endless hours in the lab or study, reading, thinking, and attending to the details of their work. Without this initial work and training nothing ever happens. Even if you have a brilliant idea, in order to communicate it to people you must speak their language. You cannot invent your own language and then wonder why you are not appreciated. At the very least you must be able to explain why your work is worth considering. All of this requires one to be in a state of focused consciousness.

然而，还有第二个层次的困难，我在前面几页中讨论过——进入一个充满困惑和矛盾的境地，坚持下去，而不是试图过早地摆脱它在你内心产生的紧张，把它推向某种预定的形式。这是逻辑规则崩溃、非理性因素找到适当位置的时候。这是创造力的熔炉。在新的结构或想法出现之前，旧的结构或想法必须让位。但它们不会轻易让位。我们热爱我们的想法和概念框架，并拒绝放弃它们。我们讨厌认知失调，这就是为什么一个新想法需要这么长时间才能扎根的原因。即使有直接证据表明我们的理论和想法行不通，我们仍然坚持它们。

However there is a second level of difficulty, one that I discussed in the previous pages—entering into a situation that is replete with confusion and contradiction and sticking with it without attempting to prematurely escape from the tension it generates within you by pushing it into some predetermined form. This is the time when logical rules break down and non-rational factors find their proper place. This time is the crucible of creativity. Before new structures or ideas can come into being the old ones must give way. But they do not give way easily. We love our ideas and conceptual frameworks and resist letting them go. We hate cognitive dissonance and that is why a new idea takes so long to take hold. We hold on to our theories and ideas even in the face of direct evidence that they do not work.

想想 2011 年诺贝尔化学奖得主丹尼尔·谢赫特曼的励志故事。他在电子显微镜下看到了一个具有五点对称性的物体，但理论认为这种对称性的晶体不可能存在。然而，面对几乎普遍的怀疑，谢赫特曼坚持认为他所看到的是真实的。他的研究领导将他踢出了团队，声称谢赫特曼所看到的不可能存在，因为教科书上说这是不可能的。伟大的科学家莱纳斯·鲍林在谈到谢赫特曼时说：“没有准晶体，只有准科学家。”我们都渴望得到同行的赞扬和认可。面对这样的反对和嘲笑，大多数人都会开始怀疑自己。谢赫特曼是一位知识英雄，因为他知道自己看到了一些重要的东西，并且拥有内在的资源来追求自己的愿景，无论发生什么。所有这些羞辱和嘲笑都表明了我们所有人，无论个人还是集体，都坚守着自己的想法，并且不愿看到它们受到挑战，更不用说改变。

Think of the instructive story of the winner of the 2011 Nobel Prize for Chemistry, Daniel Shechtman. He saw an object with five-point symmetry in his electron microscope but theory said that crystals with such symmetry could not exist. However Shechtman tenaciously held on to his belief that what he saw was real in the face of almost universal skepticism. His research leader kicked him off his team claiming that what Shechtman saw could not exist because the textbooks said it was impossible. The great scientist Linus Pauling, referring to Shechtman, said that, “There are no quasi-crystals only quasi-scientists.” We all desire the praise and approval of our peers. Most people would begin to doubt themselves in the face of such disapproval and ridicule. Shechtman is an intellectual hero because he knew that he had seen something significant and had the inner resources to pursue his vision come what may. All of this humiliation and ridicule indicates the tenacity with which we all, individually and collectively, hold on to our ideas and how reluctant we are to see them challenged much less changed.

如果想出现新的、有意义的东西，就必须打破这种惯性。这种惯性源于固守固定的概念体系，以及习惯性的思维方式。思考——逻辑分析和集中意识。正是情况中的问题因素会打破我们习惯性思维过程的惯性。这就是为什么不可能将纯逻辑运用到新想法中，最终也是为什么算法和机器无法发挥创造力。必须存在问题，并且必须真实地体验它产生的不适和紧张。必须准备好在创造力的熔炉上牺牲自己所有珍视的先入之见，这包括构建内心世界的逻辑思维过程。

This inertia has to be broken down if something new and significant is going to have a chance of emerging. This inertia results from inhabiting a fixed conceptual system together with its habitual way of thinking—logical analysis and focused awareness. It is precisely the problematic elements of the situation that will break the inertia of our habitual thought processes. This is why it is not possible to leverage pure logic into a new idea and ultimately why algorithms and machines are incapable of creativity. There must be a problem and one must authentically live out the discomfort and tension that it produces. One must be prepared to sacrifice all of one’s cherished preconceptions on the crucible of creativity and this includes the logical thought processes through which one structures one’s inner world.

5.13放手

5.13Letting Go

然而仅仅生活在紧张和不连贯中是不够的。创造性想法诞生于对问题整体的强烈吸收。一个人工作再工作，但最终你会休息一下——去度假、看书、散步，或者只是和你的配偶和孩子聊天。阿基米德洗了个澡，庞加莱去了一趟短途旅行，就在那时，那个决定性的想法迸发出来。为什么是在那时，而不是在他们如此努力工作的时候？简单的答案是，在那一刻他们允许自己放松，但更深层次的答案是“放松”意味着改变你的意识模式。xv这意味着从左半球移动到右半球，或者从专注的意识移动到更基本的东西，即戈普尼克的“灯笼意识”，也就是说，从专注的意识到一种不专注和警觉的意识。

However just living in tension and incoherence is not enough. The creative idea is born out of intense absorption in the totality of the problematic situation. One works and works but eventually you take a break—go on vacation, read a book, take a walk, or just chat with your spouse and children. Archimedes took a bath; Poincaré went on a short trip; and it was then that the fateful idea burst forth. Why then and not when they were working so hard? The simple answer is that at that moment they allowed themselves to relax but the deeper answer is that “relaxing” means changing your mode of awareness.xv This means moving from the left hemisphere to the right or from focused consciousness to something more elementary, namely, Gopnik’s “lantern consciousness,” that is, from focused consciousness to an awareness that is unfocused and alert.

正如我在上一章中讨论的那样，创造力需要位于不同半球的心理过程之间的协作。它涉及左脑和右脑的交替，以及手电筒和灯笼意识的交替。

As I discussed in the last chapter, creativity requires the collaboration between mental processes that are housed in different hemispheres. It involves an alternation of left and right and so of flashlight and lantern consciousness.

创造力需要巧妙地运用意识。专注需要努力和意图，我们都知道这意味着什么，因为专注的意识是我们正常的意识状态——你在阅读这些文字时所处的状态。不专注很难用语言描述，因为当你说话或阅读时，你是专注的；我能想到的最接近的就是重复这句话“放松”保持警惕”或“顺其自然”。想象一下，一只猫在墙洞里等待老鼠的出现——完全放松但又完全警惕——只要老鼠露出一根胡须，一切就都结束了。

Creativity involves a subtle use of awareness. Focusing takes an effort and an intention and we all have a feeling for what this means because focused awareness is our normal state of consciousness—the state that you are in when reading these words. Un-focusing is difficult to describe in words because when you are speaking or reading you are focused; the closest I can come is repeating the phrase “relaxed alertness” or “letting things be.” Think of a cat waiting for the appearance of a mouse from a hole in the wall—totally relaxed but totally alert—let the mouse show even a whisker and it’s all over.

对一个尽职尽责的人来说，顺其自然往往是最难做到的事情。它需要一种谦逊，一种放弃控制的意愿。还记得那个学生吗？他觉得自己应该得到奖励，因为他花了时间解决问题。他不知道什么时候该停下来，即使他大部分时间都在原地踏步。我们中有多少人有过同样的经历！你什么时候对自己说：“我现在已经取得了我所能取得的所有进步。我要睡觉了，明天早上再继续。”如果你能放手去干，换个方式，你会发现，当你早上坐在书桌前时，你的脑海里已经有了一些一夜之间清晰起来的东西，你会想到一种解决问题的新方法。对于大多数人来说，睡觉是改变意识状态最简单的方法。

Letting things be is often the most difficult thing for a conscientious person to do. It requires a kind of humility, a willingness to give up control. Remember the student who felt that he should be rewarded for the time that he had devoted to solving a problem. He didn’t know when to quit even if he was essentially spinning his wheels most of the time. How many of us have had the same experience! When do you say to yourself, “I’ve made all the progress I am capable of at this time. I’m going to bed and will pick this up in the morning.” If you can let things go and change gears you may find that when you sit down at your desk in the morning something has clarified itself in your mind overnight and a new approach to the problem occurs to you. Going to sleep is the easiest way for most people to alter their state of consciousness.

当我开始写书时，这是我学到的最重要的一课。这个过程包括交替进行普通的、专注的工作，而这往往会导致一个暂时看似无法克服的障碍。下一步只需要站起来换个方式，放手，第二天再回来。令我惊讶和惊讶的是，我经常发现问题已经解决了，我所需要做的就是把事情写下来。解决方案感觉很神奇，因为它似乎是凭空而来的，“凭空”意味着它不是来自分析、专注的头脑。

When I began to write books this is one of the most important lessons that I learned. The process involved alternate periods of ordinary, focused work leading, often, to an obstacle which, for the moment, seemed insurmountable. The next step involved just getting up and changing gears, letting go, and coming back the next day. To my amazement and surprise I often found that the problem had resolved itself and all I needed to do was to write things down. The resolution felt miraculous because it seemed to come from nowhere and “nowhere” means that it did not arise from the analytic, focused mind.

创造过程是一种动态情况，涉及集中注意力和放松，控制阶段与放弃控制阶段交替，从问题和不连贯中诞生连贯性。它需要在专注和不专注的意识之间建立一种工作关系。创造力的先决条件是打破我们困于当前思维模式的倾向，尤其是我们对分析性、左脑观察情况的固执。

The creative process is this dynamic situation that involves concentration and relaxation, periods of being in control alternating with periods of relinquishing control, the birth of coherence out of the problematic and the incoherent. It requires establishing a working relationship between focused and unfocused awareness. A prerequisite for creativity involves breaking our tendency to stay trapped within our present mental paradigm, our fixation, in particular, with the analytic, left-brained, way of viewing the situation.

5.14放手是不可能的

5.14Letting Go Is Impossible

但也许我过于简单了。也许我推荐自己的技巧——专注然后放手——似乎与我所说的没有创造力公式的说法相矛盾。事情并没有那么简单，原因在于“放手”这个神秘的表达。决定放手是不可能的。 “放手”的禁令，就像“随心所欲”的禁令一样，在某种程度上是自相矛盾的，让我想起了“说谎者悖论”——“这句话是错误的”。如果你因为决定放手而放手，那么你根本就不会放手。放手的反面是遵循一些规则或公式，如果你可以决定放手，你就会这样做。

But perhaps I am being simplistic. Perhaps I seem to be contradicting what I said about there being no formula for creativity by recommending my own technique—focus and then let go. Things are not so simple and the reason for this lies in the enigmatic expression “letting go.” It is impossible to decide to let go. The injunction “let go,” like the injunction “be spontaneous,” is paradoxical in a way that reminds me of the “liar’s paradox”—“this sentence is false.” If you let go because of a decision to let go then you would not be letting go at all. The opposite of letting go is following some rule or formula, which is what you would be doing if you could decide to let go.

放手不是你能强迫自己做的事情。试试看吧！但这并不意味着放手是不可能的。事实上，如果你试着放手，认真思考你在做什么，你很可能会得出这是不可能的结论。另一方面，不可否认的事实是，有时确实会发生这种情况——人们总是设法放手。这就像自愿和非自愿神经系统（躯体和自主神经）之间的区别。有些身体功能可以控制，有些通常不能控制。我们生活中的很多部分，例如治愈伤口，都可以合理地说：“我无法让它发生，但它确实会发生。”

Letting go is not something that you can force yourself to do. Try it and see! However this does not mean that it is impossible to let go. Actually, if you try to let go and really think about what you are doing, you may well conclude that it is impossible. On the other hand there is the undeniable fact that it sometimes happens—people manage to let go all the time. It’s like the difference between the voluntary and involuntary nervous systems (somatic and autonomic). There are bodily functions that can be controlled and those that normally cannot. There are huge parts of our life, such as healing a wound for example, for which is it reasonable to say, “I can’t make it happen, but it certainly does happen.”

创造力就是这样一种自相矛盾的活动。如果你能强迫自己发挥创造力，如果我能为你提供一个保证产生创造性结果的公式，那么创造力将是专注意识和分析思维的结果。掌控一切、遵循某种算法或明确定义的程序需要从外部审视我们所做的事情，但矛盾的是，它总是需要从一个明确定义的系统内部审视事物。从这个角度来看，放手似乎是不可能的。没有人在正常的意识模式中放手过。

Creativity is this kind of paradoxical activity. If you could force yourself to be creative, if I could provide you will a formula guaranteed to produce creative results, then creativity would be the outcome of focused consciousness and the analytic mind. Being in control, following some algorithm or well-defined procedure involves looking at what we are doing from the outside yet, paradoxically, it always involves looking at things from within a well-defined system. It is from this point of view that letting go seems to be impossible. No one ever let go when they were in their normal mode of consciousness.

然而，正如我上面所说，创造力需要放手，而放手需要从专注的意识转变为不专注的意识。实际上你你不能自愿决定进行这种转变，原因和你不能决定放手完全相同。无重点的意识就是放手。正如我们在第四章中看到的，它是人类的基本意识，也是婴儿的自然心理状态。创造力的很大一部分困难都归结为如何从一种意识形式转变为另一种意识形式的问题。意识或觉知有两种基本类型——离散情况——这解释了为什么创造力是突然的和不连续的。在创造过程的某个时刻，你会放手，每个有创造力的人都会以自己的方式对待放手。让我再说一遍，放手不是你做的事情，甚至不是你决定要做的事情。它是自然发生的事情。它发生在你身上，而不是你由你决定。它无法被编程，因为它不遵循这些规则。在它发生之前，如果你从正常的角度观察情况，解决问题似乎是不可能的。但事后它就会显得显而易见和不可避免。

However, as I said above, creativity involves letting go and letting go involves changing from focused to unfocused awareness. Actually you cannot voluntarily decide to make this switch for exactly the same reason that you cannot decide to let go. Unfocused awareness is letting go. It is human beings’ bedrock consciousness and the natural mind state of infants as we saw in chapter four. So much of the difficulty of creativity reduces to the question of how to move from one form of awareness to another. There are two basic kinds of consciousness or awareness—a discrete situation—this explains why creativity is sudden and discontinuous. At some point in the creative process you let go and every creative person will approach letting go in his or her own way. Let me just say again that letting go is not something you do or even decide to do. It is something that happens. It happens to you not by you. It cannot be programmed because it is does not obey these kinds of rules. Before it happens and you are observing the situation from the normal point of view, a resolution to the problem may well seem to be impossible. Afterwards it feels obvious and inevitable.

5.15结论

5.15Conclusion

不可避免的是，我们大多数情况下都是从我们习惯的思维框架（比如范式或概念系统）中进入的。然后我们遇到了一些障碍，一些在系统中毫无意义的东西。我们专注于这种有问题的情况的能力打破了我们的思维定势，但并没有用任何东西来取代它。在这个阶段，我们已经准备好出现创造性的想法，任何事情都可以引发它。无论关键因素是什么，很明显它必须来自我们当前系统之外。我们可以把这个关键事件看作是更大的世界对我们当前思维方式的有限世界的冲击。这就是为什么它似乎来自外部，并且是偶然出现的。有趣的是，进化论也将随机性视为诱发因素。如果学习也是一种创造性活动，那么它就解释了游戏和探索的重要性，这似乎比正式的、结构化的活动更适合产生新的视角。

It is inevitable that we enter most situations from within our habitual mental framework, something like a paradigm or conceptual system. Then we meet some blockage, something that just makes no sense within the system. Our ability to stay absorbed in this problematic situation breaks down our mental set but does not replace it with anything. At this stage we are ripe for the creative idea to appear and anything can set it off. Whatever the crucial element turns out to be it is evident that it must come from outside of our present system. We can think of this crucial event as the larger world impinging on the limited world of our current way of thinking. That is why it seems to come from the outside and to arise accidently. It is interesting that the theory of evolution also posits randomness as the precipitating factor. If learning is also a creative activity it explains the importance of play and exploration, which seem more suited to the production of new ways of seeing than formal, structured activities.

以这种方式看待创造力会产生什么后果？特别是，我断言不存在创造力的后果是什么？创造力的可能算法、规则或技巧是什么？人工智能界无法接受的一个后果是，没有人会编写程序让计算机自主创造，即独立于人类干预。你也许可以通过人工智能的一个新想法成功地模拟创造力，而这个想法本身可能来自计算机科学家的创造性行为。这种突破可能很有用，并具有各种理论和经济后果。然而，创造力的模拟和真实事物之间仍然存在着无法逾越的鸿沟。这种区别是程序和程序员之间的区别，是乡村风光的照片和在美丽的夏日里在乡村度过的体验之间的区别。

What are the consequences of looking at creativity in this way? What, in particular, are the consequences of my assertion that there is no possible algorithm, rule, or technique for creativity? One consequence, which would be unacceptable to the artificial intelligence community, is that no one will ever program a computer to be creative on its own, that is, independent of human intervention. You might succeed in simulating creativity through a new idea in artificial intelligence which would itself arise out of a creative act on the part of a computer scientist. This kind of breakthrough might be useful and have all kinds of theoretical and economic consequences. Nevertheless there remains an unbridgeable gap between a simulation of creativity and the real thing. The distinction is the difference between the program and the programmer, between a picture of a country scene and the experience of being out in the country on a beautiful summer’s day.

如果创造力不能通过公式或技术产生，那么它就一定是心灵的自由创造——真正原创，没有直接与之前联系起来的线索。这不仅告诉我们关于创造力的一些深刻的东西，而且还给了我们心灵、生命和自然界的一个基本特征。生命的进化和宇宙的进化是由奇妙的创造事件组成的，这些事件是无法预先预测的。相对论从何而来？从无生命到有生命的过渡？贝多芬的《第九交响曲》？面对这些令人难以置信的创造力飞跃，认为它们可能来自算法或计算机程序的想法似乎完全是愚蠢的。我们不禁受到启发和安慰，因为创造所有这些奇迹的相同创意源泉对我们所有人都是可用的。

If creativity cannot be produced by formula or technique then it must be a free creation of the mind—truly original with no direct line that connects it to what came before. This not only tells us something profound about creativity but also gives us an essential characteristic of mind, of life, and of the natural world. The evolution of life and the evolution of the cosmos consist of episodes of marvelous creativity that could not have been predicted a priori. Where did the Theory of Relativity come from? The transition from the inanimate to the animate? Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony? In the face of these incredible leaps of creativity the idea that they could come out of an algorithm or a computer program seems downright silly. We cannot help but be inspired and reassured by the idea that the very same creative sources that produced all of these marvels are accessible to us all.

i引用自《日瓦戈医生》的序言（2011 年）。

i Quoted in the introduction to Doctor Zhivago, (2011).

ii爱因斯坦，（1930 年）。

ii Einstein, (1930).

iii Wilczek，第 11 页。

iii Wilczek, p. 11.

iv Byers，（2007 年）。

iv Byers, (2007).

诉F·斯科特·菲茨杰拉德，（1945 年）。

v F. Scott Fitzgerald, (1945).

vi本节所有引文均引自 Rothenberg (1996)。

vi All of the quotations in this section are taken from Rothenberg (1996).

vii 如 Low, (2002) 第 134 页所引。

vii As quoted in Low, (2002) p.134.

viii 关于这一点的更完整描述可以在 Byers (2007) 中找到。

viii A more complete description of this point will be found in Byers (2007).

ix Koestler, (1964)，第 35 页。

ix Koestler, (1964). p. 35.

x同上，第 35-36 页。

x ibid. p. 35–36.

xi Rothenberg，（1996 年）。第 221 页。

xi Rothenberg, (1996). p. 221.

xii Martin, (2009)，第 6、7 页。

xii Martin, (2009). p. 6,7.

xiii 在《盲点》中，我将它们称为原始概念，以试图找出可以明确表达和不可以明确表达的细微差别。

xiii In The Blind Spot I called them proto-concepts in an attempt to get at the subtle difference between what can and cannot be made explicit.

xiv Proust（2003）。第 1 卷，《追忆似水年华》。

xiv Proust (2003). Vol. 1, Swann’s Way.

xv在本章的其余部分，我有时会使用 Low 的术语“意识”而不是“意识”，原因我之前提到过——意识是及物动词，即对某物的意识，而所谓的灯笼意识是不及物动词。它是参与性的，而不是观察性的。

xv In the rest of the chapter I will sometimes use Low’s terminology of awareness instead of consciousness for the reason that I mentioned earlier—consciousness is used in a transitive form, consciousness of something, and so-called lantern consciousness is intransitive. It is participatory rather than observational.

第六章

Chapter 6

深度学习

Deep Learning

6.1介绍

6.1Introduction

计算机、互联网和电子媒体正在极大地改变人们的工作、娱乐和交流方式。而我们最清楚的改变只是冰山一角。更深层次上正在发生更重要的改变。现代技术实际上正在深刻改变人们的思维方式，并因此改变人们的学习方式。思考和学习的本质正在经历根本而迅速的变化，其影响极其深远。许多人，特别是年轻人，使用思维的方式与过去有质的不同。换句话说，思考和推理的过程，以及人类意识本身，正在迅速而剧烈地改变。

Computers, the internet, and electronic media are making enormous changes in the way people work, play, and communicate. And the changes that we are most aware of are only the tip of the iceberg. There are more important changes that are happening at a deeper level. Modern technology is actually making profound changes in the way people think and, as a consequence, in the way people learn. The nature of thinking and learning are undergoing basic and rapid change with implications that are extremely far-reaching. Many people, especially young people, are using their minds in a way that differs qualitatively from how the mind was used in the past. In other words the process of thinking and reasoning, and with it human consciousness itself, is changing rapidly and dramatically.

这种根本性的变革影响着每一个人，但在有孩子的每个家庭、任何教室或大学演讲厅中，这种变革最为明显。学习的环境已经发生了变化，但社会和教育机构却难以跟上。由于技术变革如此迅速，社会没有时间关注这些变革对教育的影响。教育过程应如何改变以应对持续和加速变化的氛围？正规教育机构会继续存在吗？如果会，它们在这个正在形成的新世界中应该扮演什么角色？教育的适当目标是什么？学习在当今社会意味着什么？

This radical and fundamental change affects everyone but is most clearly evident in every home where there are children and in any classroom or university lecture hall. The environment in which learning happens has been changing for some time now but social and educational institutions have had trouble keeping up. Because technological change arises so rapidly society does not have the time to focus on the implications of these changes for education. How should the process of education be changed to respond to an atmosphere of continuous and accelerating change? Will formal educational institutions continue to exist, and if so, what should their role be in this new world that is coming into being? What are the appropriate goals of education? What does learning mean in today’s society?

学习离不开本书前面讨论过的不同思维方式。每一种思维方式都对应着一种学习——系统的逻辑思维与基于规则的学习、事实的学习和算法程序相关。深度思考与另一种学习方式相关，我将其称为深度学习。深度学习是最重要的学习方式。它应该是各级教育的目标，但我们的教育机构大多不知道它的存在，或者选择忽视它。本章将讨论有关深度学习的一些基本问题：它是什么？可以教吗？应该教吗？它在信息技术世界中扮演什么角色？

Learning cannot be separated from the different ways of thinking that were discussed earlier in the book. To each form of thinking there corresponds a kind of learning—systematic, logical thinking is associated with rule-based learning, the learning of facts and algorithmic procedures. Deep thinking is associated with a different form of learning, which I shall call deep learning. Deep learning is the most important kind of learning. It should be the goal of education at all levels but our educational institutions are, for the most part, either unaware of its existence or else choose to ignore it. This chapter will address certain basic questions about deep learning: What is it? Can it be taught? Should it be taught? What is its role in the world of information technology?

6.2学习

6.2Learning

在本章中，我将重点讨论学习，从某种意义上说，学习是我在前几章中讨论的所有过程的共同因素。我的观点是，学习是一种极其普遍和基本的活动。在某种程度上，它是人类的典型活动——文明得以发展和维持，个人被训练以扮演其在社会中被赋予的角色。然而，学习并不局限于人类。人类的学习与其他动物的学习有着相同的根源，而且学习可能比这更为普遍。我从人类概念发展的工作中得出了深度学习的概念，但也许所有的发展，例如整个进化过程，都是一种学习，一种深度学习。如果是这样，我相信是这样，那么学习过程就是所有生命和所有发展的核心方面。如果忽视深度学习的核心地位而误解学习的真正本质，那将是一个严重的错误。学习是世界运作的方式，也是我们人类工作的自然方式。它是心智运作的基本模式。

In this chapter I shall focus on learning, which is, in a sense, the factor that all of the processes that I discussed in previous chapters have in common. My perspective is that learning is an extremely general and basic activity. In a way it is the quintessential human activity—the means through which civilization is developed and sustained and individuals are trained to play their assigned roles in society. However learning is not restricted to human beings. Human learning springs from the same sources as the learning that occurs in other animals and learning may well be even more general than that. I derived the notion of deep learning from work in human conceptual development but perhaps all development, the entire evolutionary process, for example, is a kind of learning, a kind of deep learning. If this is so, and I believe it is, then the process of learning is a central aspect of all life and all development. It would be a grave error to misunderstand the true nature of learning by ignoring the centrality of deep learning. Learning is the way the world works and it is the natural way that we human beings work. It is the basic mode of functioning of mind.

孩子们总是花很多时间学习，但今天，即使是成年人也被迫花费大量时间和精力学习和适应不断变化的技术环境。因此，学习已经成为一项终身活动。我们被迫面对一个基本事实过去人们更容易忽视的一点是，生命本身就是一个不断学习的过程。生命意味着学习和成长。它没有最终的平衡，也没有静止的平台。生命在学习、适应和进化。所有这些活动的根源是什么？学习到底是什么？

Children have always spent much of their time learning but today even adults are forced to spend a great deal of time and energy learning and adapting to a shifting technological environment. Thus learning has become a life-long activity. We are being forced to face a basic truth that, in the past, it was easier to ignore, namely, that life is itself a process of continuous learning. Life means learning and growing. It has no final equilibrium, no plateau of rest. Life learns, adapts, and evolves. What is it that underlies all of these activities? What is learning, really?

6.3学习与信息技术

6.3Learning and Information Technology

信息技术对学习和教育产生了多方面的影响——不仅影响了学习的内容和学习的传递系统，而且至关重要的是，它影响了我们对学习的理解。这种新媒介带有一些通常不明确的重大假设。最重要的假设是，教育的关键要素是信息。从这个角度来看，世界是由数据组成的——比特、字节、兆字节、千兆字节和太字节的数据。可以立即在线访问的大量数据非常令人兴奋，最初似乎很有力量。有些项目旨在使所有数据都可以在线访问。人们会想到尝试扫描过去和现在的所有书籍，将它们转换为数字格式，然后将它们放入一个庞大的数据库中。想象一下能够下载任何小说或研究专著、任何电影、电视节目或音乐作品，这非常令人兴奋。人们有时会觉得一切都触手可及——整个世界都触手可及。

Information technology has had an impact on learning and education in many ways—not only on what is learned and on the delivery system for learning but, crucially, on our idea of what learning is all about. This new medium carries with it major assumptions that are usually not made explicit. The most important assumption is that the key element in education is information. The world, in this view, is made up of data— bits, bytes, megabytes, gigabytes, and terabytes of data. The vast amount of data that is instantly accessible online is very exciting and initially appears to be empowering. There are projects that aim to make all data accessible on line. One thinks of the attempts to scan all books, past and present, convert them into a digital format, and put them into one mammoth database. It is very exciting to imagine being able to download any novel or research monograph, any movie, television program, or piece of music. One sometimes gets the feeling that everything is available—that the whole world is at your fingertips.

如果有什么问题的话，那就是信息太多了。我们正淹没在信息中，所以没有一条信息显得很重要。它的重要性在信息泛滥的普遍肤浅趋势中消失了。在教育层面，这种情况导致人们专注于操纵数据——如何访问数据、利用数据以及如何“挖掘”数据中的宝贵信息。当然，不仅是教育，社会的许多其他领域，从国家安全到广告，都专注于创建庞大的数据库，这些数据库既有好的一面，也有坏的一面。社会面临的关键问题不是来自数据，而是来自对信息的痴迷所隐藏的东西。例如，是什么赋予了数据意义？是什么把它转化为知识？数据可以被理解吗？或者说，信息和理解之间的关系是什么？

If anything there is too much information. We are drowning in information so no single piece of information seems very important. Its significance is lost in the general tendency towards superficiality, which comes along with the glut of information. At the level of education this situation leads to a focus on manipulating data—how to access it, work with it, and “mine” it for nuggets of value. Of course it is not only education, but many other parts of society, from national security to advertising, that focus on creating enormous databases with their potential for good and for bad. The crucial questions that society faces come not from the data but on what is hidden because of the obsession with information. For example, what is it that gives data significance? What transforms it into knowledge? Can data be understood or, rather, what is the relationship between information and understanding?

重要的是不要过分强调信息的重要性。人们可能会过分强调信息的概念，例如声称宇宙可以归结为信息。最好采取一种更平衡的方法，并看到专注于信息会有所收获，但也会有所损失。在接下来的讨论中，我们将阐明收获和损失，但目前我只想指出，数据处于阶梯的最底层，而阶梯的上层包括知识、理解和创造力。如果停留在阶梯的最底层，我们可能会忽略更高的层次，或者错误地认为更高的层次可以通过某种算法程序从信息中生成。更糟糕的是，我们可能会与知识、学习、理解和创造力等新兴属性失去联系，甚至忘记这些事物的真正含义。数据的获取和处理并不是学习，除非从最基本的意义上来说。

It is important not to get carried away with the importance of information. One can claim too much for the concept of information such as the claim that the universe can be reduced to information. It is best to assume a more balanced approach and see that something is gained but something else is lost by the focus on information. Both the gain and the loss will be clarified in the discussion that follows but for the moment let me merely point out that data is at the bottom rung of a ladder whose higher rungs include knowledge, understanding, and creativity. By remaining on the lowest rung of this ladder, we may ignore the higher levels or make the erroneous assumption that the higher levels can be generated from information via some kind of algorithmic procedure. Even worse is the very real possibility that we may lose touch with emergent properties like knowledge, learning, understanding, and creativity—even forget what these things really mean. The acquisition and manipulation of data is not learning except in its most rudimentary sense.

如果我们不仔细思考，思考就会变成筛选数据以寻找模式的过程，学习就会变成掌握一套搜索技巧。信息不是知识，更不是理解。处理数据不需要深入思考，也就是我在本书中一直谈论的那种思考。这不是我在本章中要讨论的那种学习。

If we are not careful thinking will become the process of sifting through data for patterns and learning will become mastering a set of search techniques. Information is not knowledge, much less understanding. Manipulating data does not require deep thinking, the kind of thinking that I have been talking about in this book. It is not the kind of learning that I shall discuss in this chapter.

然而，我们面临的主要危险是，我们将开始把数据库当成现实，把模拟和真实的东西混为一谈。危险在于，我们将允许计算设备在现实和我们之间形成另一道屏障。例如，理解是人与主体之间的关系。它既不是完全客观的，也不是完全主观的。信息技术往往会模糊这种关系。它让你觉得软件可以替你思考。它站在个人和她个人的理解之间。在这方面，信息技术加剧了逻辑演绎思维中已经隐含的错误——演绎替你做了工作的感觉。因此，学生可能会觉得记住一个定理的证明意味着他们理解了这个定理，但事实往往并非如此。当我们让计算机决定什么时，在特定情况下什么是重要的，或者什么是美丽的，就此而言，我们犯了将意义和美客观化的错误。

However the main danger that we are facing is that we will begin to take the database for reality and confuse simulation with the real thing. The danger is that we will allow the computing device to form another barrier between reality and ourselves. Understanding, for example, is a relationship between the person and the subject. It is neither totally objective nor is it totally subjective. Information technology tends to obscure the relationship. It gives you the feeling that the software can do the thinking for you. It stands between an individual and her personal understanding. In this regard information technology compounds an error that is already implicit in logical deductive thinking—the feeling that deduction does the work for you. Thus a student may feel that memorizing a proof of a theorem means that they understand the theorem when this is often not the case. When we let computers determine what is significant in a given situation, or what is beautiful, for that matter, we make the mistake of objectifying significance and beauty.

最大的危险是，我们将失去与深度思考的联系，而深度思考是我们头脑中与生俱来的创造源泉，我们满足于对深度思考的简单模拟。这并不是说思维模型有什么不好，但将模型与真实事物混淆将是一个巨大的悲剧。人类不是机器，头脑也不是计算机——计算机源于一系列的创造行为，而不是相反。

The biggest danger is that we shall lose contact with deep thinking, the innate creative source of our minds, and settle for a mere simulation of deep thinking. It is not that there is anything objectionable about models of thinking but it would be a great tragedy to confuse the model with the real thing. Human beings are not machines and the mind is not a computer—the computer arose out of a series of acts of creativity and not vice-versa.

6.4人工智能内部和外部的深度学习

6.4Deep Learning Inside and Outside of AI

整个人工智能 (AI) 领域很好地说明了现实与现实模拟之间的差异。更具体地说，人工智能领域最近发展了一种程序，有趣的是，它也被称为“深度学习”，引起了极大的兴奋。其目标是教会计算机“学习”，这是朝着生产“智能机器”的最终目标迈出的一步。毫无疑问，人工智能的深度学习标志着人工智能领域的重大进步。它表明，在分离具有药用潜力的化合物或从照片、声音或其他来源识别个体等目标方面已经取得了一些进展。这些都是微妙的问题，但毫无疑问，它们正在得到解决。这是否意味着计算机程序具有创造或学习的能力？这取决于你对学习的定义。但如果它是学习，那么它就是一种非常基本的学习，而不是我使用“深度学习”一词的意义。计算机程序不可避免地是连续的和算法的。另一方面，深度学习涉及重新构建情况，并且不可避免地是不连续的。

The difference between reality and the simulation of reality is well illustrated by the whole field of Artificial Intelligence (AI). More particularly there is a recent development within AI of a procedure that is, interestingly enough, also called “deep learning” and has generated much excitement. The objective is to teach computers to “learn” as a step towards the ultimate goal of producing “intelligent machines.” Undoubtedly AI’s deep learning marks a substantial advance in the field of artificial intelligence. It shows that some progress has been made towards such goals as the isolation of compounds with medicinal potential or the identification of individuals from photographs, voices, or other sources. These are subtle kinds of problems but no doubt they are well on the way to being solved. Does this mean that the computer program has the capacity to be creative or to learn? Well that depends on what you mean by learning. But if it is learning then it is learning in a very rudimentary sense and not at all the sense in which I used the phrase “deep learning.” Computer programs are inevitably continuous and algorithmic. Deep learning, on the other hand, involves a reframing of the situation and is inevitably discontinuous.

事物本身与事物的模拟之间的区别虽然微妙，但却至关重要。因此，理性的发明是最高层次上的创造性突破，但坚持逻辑推理是创造性的，则是一个深刻的错误。然而，人们一次又一次地看到这种用模拟——理性思维——取代思想的趋势在思想史上，这种替代再次出现了。这种替代是人类对安全的需求战胜了对创造力的需求。它用分析取代了合成，用手电筒意识取代了灯笼意识。这是我在其他书中讨论过的有关数学历史发展的动态。最终，它涉及安全地生活在一个连续过程的世界中，在这个世界中，永远不会发生任何根本性的新事物，而不是生活在一个不断创造的发展和变化的世界中。创造力涉及与未知事物的相遇以及这种相遇所带来的所有困难。编写计算机程序的初衷是希望能够避免此类遭遇——不是对于开发人员，而是为了最终产品的用户。

The difference between the thing in itself and a simulation of the thing is subtle but essential. Thus the invention of reason is a creative breakthrough on the highest level but maintaining that logical inference is creative is a profound error. Nevertheless one sees this tendency to substitute the simulation—rational thought—for the mind over and over again in the history of thought. Such a substitution is a victory for the human need for security over the need for creativity. It replaces the synthetic by the analytic; lantern consciousness by flashlight consciousness. It is a dynamic that I have discussed in other books with respect to the historical development of mathematics. Ultimately it involves living safely in a world of continuous processes where nothing that is radically new ever happens as opposed to living in the ever-creative world of development and change. Creativity involves an encounter with the unknown and all of the difficulty that such an encounter entails. Computer programs are written in the hope that such encounters can be avoided—not for the person who develops the program, but for the users of the end product.

在科学和数学中，这种趋向于连续性和算法化的趋势无法盛行——即使计算机已成为科学家和数学家必不可少的工具和辅助工具，你也无法想象计算机会取得这些学科历史上的突破。科学不断提出无法理解的难题和无法在操作范式范围内解决的问题。在这种情况下，人们不得不回到最初的原则，重新思考问题。人工智能和信息技术的问题在于，它们承诺的方法将导致一种解决所有问题的方法——一种适用于所有情况的自生技术，无需新的人类见解和创造力飞跃。

In science and mathematics this tendency towards the continuous and the algorithmic cannot prevail—you cannot imagine computers making the breakthroughs that characterize the history of these subjects even if computers have become essential tools and aids to scientists and mathematicians. Science continually throws up conundrums that cannot be understood and problems that cannot be resolved within the boundaries of the operational paradigm. In such situations one is forced to go back to first principles and think things through again. The problem with artificial intelligence and information technology is that they promise a methodology that would lead to a way of solving all problems—a self-generating technology that would apply to all situations without the need for new human insights and leaps of creativity.

人类心灵的本质特征是动态和变化。从这个意义上说，计算机没有心灵。那些梦想计算机乌托邦的作家所希望的是人类心灵的停滞状态。这种永久停滞的状态是一种死亡——最深刻的人性的死亡。那些希望如此的人是在自欺欺人。

The essential characteristics of the minds of human beings are dynamism and change. The computer has no mind in this sense. What those writers who dream of a computerized utopia hope for is a situation of stasis for the human mind. Such a state of permanent stasis is a kind of death—the death of what is most deeply human. Those who wish for it are fooling themselves.

6.5发展与学习

6.5Development and Learning

前面章节中提出的每一个关于发展和创造力的问题都引出了关于学习的类似问题。一个人如何学习一个新的概念系统？这个新系统如何从一个难以理解的、根深蒂固的旧系统中产生？深度学习，即从一个概念系统或思维方式向另一个概念系统或思维方式的转变，是连续发生的，还是分阶段进行的？如果是后者，那么涉及的机制是什么？如果它同时涉及连续和离散机制，那么大脑和思维在非连续学习中的运用方式是否与连续学习中相同？还是说非连续学习需要一种不同的思维运用方式？解决这些问题将迫使我们面对一些关于教学和学习的基本问题。

Every question about development and creativity that was raised in earlier chapters gives rise to an analogous question about learning. How does a person learn a new conceptual system? How does that new system manage to arise from a well-established older system from which the new system is incomprehensible? Does deep learning, the movement from one conceptual system or way of thinking to another, happen in a continuous way or does it proceed in discrete stages? If it is the latter then what are the mechanisms involved? If it involves both continuous and discrete mechanisms then is the way the brain and mind are employed in discontinuous learning identical to the way it is used in the continuous case; or is it the case that discontinuous learning requires a different way of using the mind? Grappling with these concerns will force us to confront some essential questions about teaching and learning.

深度学习是创造性学习，也就是说，概念学习背后的机制与任何重大创造性行为的机制类似。学习、发展和创造力之间的密切相似性应该迫使我们重新评估各级教育中的许多态度和实践。人们通常认为不能指望学生有创造力，创造力只有经过多年艰苦的准备才有可能。然而，如果这种准备（我们通常认为教育就是这种准备）包括培养语言的流利程度和复杂概念系统的概念，那么这种准备已经涉及了重大的创造性活动。创造力是人类各级学习的本质，从子宫中已经开始的学习到科学工作中涉及的自然世界秘密的学习。

Deep learning is creative learning, that is, the mechanisms behind conceptual learning are analogous to those involved in any significant creative act. The close parallels between learning, development, and creativity should force us to reevaluate many of our attitudes and practices in education at all levels. Most often it is felt that one cannot expect creativity from students, that creativity is only possible after many years of arduous preparation of one sort or another. However if that preparation, which is often what we mean when we think of education, includes developing fluency with the language and the concepts of a complex conceptual system then the preparation already involves significant creative activity. Creativity is the essence of human learning at all levels from the learning that is already going on in the womb to learning about the secrets of the natural world that is involved in scientific work.

深度学习是最重要的学习类型，它涉及获得概念系统的操作知识或从一个概念系统转到另一个概念系统。这种学习会伴随你一生，不会很快忘记，有助于加深一个人的理解。这种学习为个人开辟了新的视野，可能成为进一步探索和创新的基础。

Deep learning, the kind of learning involved in obtaining an operational knowledge of a conceptual system or of going from one conceptual system to another, is the most important kind of learning. It is learning that sticks with you and is not quickly forgotten, that facilitates the growth of one’s understanding. It is the learning that opens up new vistas for the individual that may be the basis for further exploration and originality.

6.6数据和知识

6.6Data and Knowledge

学习是一个动态事件，因此认为学习主要是获取事实的观点从根本上就是错误的——获取和处理数据充其量只是学习的先决条件。真正的学习涉及获取知识和理解。这些不同层次的学习有什么特点：数据、知识、理解和创造力？

Learning is a dynamic event and so the belief that learning is primarily about the acquisition of facts is fundamentally flawed—the acquisition and manipulation of data is at best a prerequisite to learning. Real learning involves acquiring knowledge and understanding. What are the characteristics of these distinct levels of learning: data, knowledge, understanding, and creativity?

数据常常与知识相混淆，因此，这两个词经常互换使用。然而，两者之间存在着一个对我的目的和教育至关重要的区别。数据似乎是纯粹客观的——人们常说，事实就是事实，只有现实主义者才能接受它们。数据库的全部价值在于它所包含的信息对每个人都是相同的。数据似乎是客观的，也就是说，它似乎与任何可能与之交互的智能生物无关。对于知识来说，情况就不那么真实了，至少在我使用这个术语的时候是这样，知识必须是人类而不是计算机可知的。大多数人认为知识是独立的，因为对“已知事物”的关注往往会掩盖知识的认知维度。知识必须是已知的；它需要一个实际或潜在的“知者”。

Data is often confused with knowledge and, as a result, the words are often used interchangeably. There is, however, a difference between the two that is vital for my purposes and for education. Data appears to be purely objective—facts are facts, one often says, and the realist can only accept them. The whole value of a database is that the information it contains is the same for everyone. Data seems to be objective, that is, it appears to be independent of any intelligent being who might interact with it. This is less true for knowledge, at least as I shall use the term, which must be knowable not by a computer but by a human being. Most people think of knowledge as standing on its own because the focus on “what is known” tends to obscure the cognitive dimension of knowledge. Knowledge must be known; it requires an actual or potential “knower.”

事实列表不是知识，因为知识还必须涉及单个事实之间的模式或关系。模式并不像事实那样以客观的方式存在。关系和模式必须被辨别，也就是说，它们具有认知维度。北斗七星是星星的图案，但星星和北斗七星是有区别的。星星一直都在那里，但必须有人看到北斗七星。另一个例子涉及填写序列中的下一个数字的问题：1、3、5、7、9、……？答案当然是任何数字都可以是下一个。序列可以继续11、13、15、…… 或2、4、6、8、…… 甚至0、0、0、0、…… 。你的答案将揭示你感知到的模式。模式是个人的。然而，在某些情况下可能存在社会共识，因此大多数人会看到相同的模式。

A list of facts is not knowledge since knowledge must also involve patterns or relationships between individual facts. Patterns do not exist in the same objective way as facts. Relationships and patterns must be discerned, that is, they have a cognitive dimension. The Big Dipper is a pattern of stars but there is a difference between the stars and the Big Dipper. The stars are there all the time but someone must see the Big Dipper. Another example involves the problem of filling in the next numbers in the sequence: 1,3,5,7,9,…? The solution is, of course, that any number can be the next one. The sequence could continue 11, 13, 15, … or 2, 4, 6, 8, … or even 0,0,0,0,… . Your answer will reveal what pattern you perceive. Patterns are personal. Nevertheless in certain situations there may be a social consensus and so most people will see the same pattern.

知识和信息之间的区别的一个有趣例子来自老《星际迷航》系列中的智能机器人“数据”。智能机器人已经出现在一系列电影中，电视节目，我担心这些角色更多地反映了人类的希望和恐惧，而不是对未来的任何现实预测。“Data”不断面对他不太理解的人类处境，通常涉及情感或直觉等非语言的人类能力。“Data”可以获取大量信息，但他不断被提醒缺少了一些东西——他不是人类。

An amusing example of the difference between knowledge and information comes from the intelligent robot “Data” on the old Star Trek series. Intelligent robots have been featured in a series of movies and television programs and I fear these characters say more about human hopes and fears than any realistic prediction of the future. “Data” was continually faced with human situations that he didn’t quite understand, often involving non-verbal human capacities such as emotion or intuition. “Data” had access to a vast amount of information but he was continually reminded that something was missing—that he was not human.

这些对智能计算机的描述往往过于浪漫和误导，但它们确实指出了围绕人工智能展开的讨论的一个基本要素。特别是，它们指出了数据和知识之间的区别。机器生活在一个数据世界中；但知识的存在需要人类的存在。数学可以看作是一种信息——例如，所有已知定理的列表。然而，数学实际上是一个知识体系。“做”数学和学习数学涉及获取知识。

These representations of intelligent computers are often romanticized and misleading but they do put their finger on an essential ingredient for the discussions that take place around artificial intelligence. In particular they bring out the distinction between data and knowledge. Machines live in a universe of data; but the existence of knowledge necessitates a human presence. Mathematics can be looked on as information—a list of every known theorem, for example. However mathematics is really a body of knowledge. “Doing” mathematics and learning mathematics involves acquiring knowledge.

认知与知觉类似。知觉行为“我看到了树”伴随着所见之物“树”和先知“我”。知觉“我看到了树”是主要的，它将“树”和“我”这两个极点连接起来。抽象地讨论树会掩盖“先知”这个人类的观察维度，但这个维度是存在的，尽管只是隐含的。同样，我们可能会说“二加二等于四”，但我们应该说“我知道二加二等于四”。认知行为是将“知者”与“知识”联系起来的主要事件。

Cognition is in this way analogous to perception. An act of perception, “I see the tree,” comes with what is seen, “the tree,” and with a seer, “I.” The perception “I see the tree” is primary and it connects the two poles of “tree” and “I.” Discussing the tree in the abstract obscures the “seer,” the human dimension of seeing but that dimension is present if only implicitly. Similarly we might say, “two plus two equals four” but we should say, “I know that two plus two equals four.” An act of cognition is the primary event that connects the “knower” with “knowledge.”

数据和知识的区别在于“知者”被认可的程度。数据给人的感觉是完全客观的，这实际上意味着人为因素或多或少被忽略了。知识似乎也是客观的——我们认为数学或量子力学是客观的知识体系，却忘记了人类创造了它们，它们的存在只取决于它们对不同群体的兴趣和价值。因此，在知识的情况下，知者并不像在数据的情况下那样隐蔽。然而，现代世界有一种将所有知识简化为数据的趋势，这是通过完全压制“知者”来实现的。

Data and knowledge differ to the extent to which the “knower” is acknowledged. Data feels totally objective, which actually means that the human dimension is more or less ignored. Knowledge also seems objective—we think of mathematics or quantum mechanics as objective bodies of knowledge and forget that human beings created them, and that they continue to exist only to the extent that they are of interest and value to various groups of people. Thus the knower is not as well hidden in the case of knowledge as it is in the case of data. Nevertheless there is a tendency in the modern world to reduce all knowledge to data and this is done by completely suppressing the “knower.”

现代教育的一项任务是通过鼓励概念发展来区分数据和知识，只有概念发展才能赋予信息意义。知识不同于原始数据，因为它是概念性的——概念具有认知维度。正式定义不是知识。概念必须是可知的，知识是由概念组合成概念系统而形成的。概念不是事实；它不是一成不变的。

One task of modern education is to make the crucial distinction between data and knowledge by encouraging conceptual development, which alone can give significance to information. Knowledge differs from raw data because it is conceptual—concepts have a cognitive dimension. A formal definition is not knowledge. Concepts must be knowable and knowledge is built out of concepts grouped together into conceptual systems. A concept is not a fact; it is not cut and dried.

因此，知识处于比数据或事实更高的层次，“更高”一词表明对认知维度的认可程度。乘法表的事实并不会自动赋予乘法（概念）知识。这些“事实”不会告诉您乘法可以用面积或重复加法来表示。它们不一定会揭示乘法的数学性质，如交换律（“ a ”乘以“ b ”等于“ b ”乘以“ a ”）。乘法知识意味着能够使用乘法并能够辨别其某些规律。

Thus knowledge lives at a higher level than data or facts where the word “higher” indicates the extent to which the cognitive dimension is acknowledged. The facts of the multiplication table do not automatically confer knowledge of (the concept of) multiplication. The “facts” won’t tell you that multiplication can be represented by area or by repeated addition. They won’t necessarily reveal the mathematical properties of multiplication such as commutativity (‘a’ times ‘b’ equals ‘b’ times ‘a’). Knowledge of multiplication carries some implication of being able to work with multiplication and being able to discern some of its regularities.

数据和知识之间的区别与 DNA 研究有关，这是一个很好的例子。对 DNA 进行测序需要将其简化为数据。这是一项重要的成就，但只是初步成就。确实，这可以让人们解决一些重要的问题。然而，听到一些基于这项研究的过分主张是令人发笑的。事实上，我们才刚刚开始一个庞大的项目，因为真正的工作是破译冗长的 DNA 序列。换句话说，这涉及将 DNA 数据转化为实际知识。这就是突破出现的地方。数据是初步工作。

A good case in which the distinction between data and knowledge is relevant involves DNA research. Sequencing DNA involves reducing it to data. This is an important accomplishment but only a preliminary one. It is true that this enables one to solve some important problems. However it is amusing to hear some of the excessive claims that are made on the basis of this research. In fact we are only at the beginning of an enormous project for the real work involves deciphering the lengthy DNA sequence. In other words this involves converting the DNA data into actual knowledge. This is where the breakthroughs will arise. The data is preliminary work.

6.7理解

6.7Understanding

知识要有用，就必须被理解。知识主要是社会性的，而理解则是个人性的——它与特定的个人息息相关。脱离理解者来谈论理解是没有意义的。人们可以谈论“理解倍增”，但一个人的理解可能与另一个人的不同。他人的理解。不存在适用于所有人的正确“理解”模板。知识只有在被理解时才会变得鲜活。

For knowledge to be useful it must be understood. Whereas knowledge is primarily social, understanding is individual—it is tied to a particular individual. It makes no sense to talk about understanding independent of the person who understands. One can talk about “understanding multiplication” but one person’s understanding may well differ from another’s. There is no template for proper “understanding” that is the same for all people at all times. Knowledge only comes alive when it is understood.

我甚至有过这样的经历：我看了一篇多年前自己写的研究论文，却无法理解它。为了理解它，我必须付出相当大的努力，再次沉浸在论文所涉及的概念和思想中。换句话说，理解并不是某种一成不变的现象。理解是一种认知现象；它是一种对事物的洞察。你不能像对待客观现象那样指着它说：“这就是理解。”理解可以增长或减少。以一些复杂的数学概念为例，比如随机性或连续性。在某一时刻，你可能会说：“我理解随机性。”但后来你可能会转过身说：“你知道我以前从未真正理解过随机性。现在我理解得更清楚了。”此外，理解像随机性这样复杂的东西，或者就此而言，学习和思考是一个永无止境的过程。你总是可以从不同的角度更好地理解它。总是可以根据新证据重新思考你的理解。用我之前使用的语言来说，总是可以重新构建一个人的理解。

I have even had the experience of looking at a research paper, that I myself had written many years ago, and not understanding it. In order to understand it I would have had to put in the considerable effort of immersing myself again in the concepts and ideas that the paper dealt with. In other words understanding is not some phenomenon that never changes. Understanding is a cognitive phenomenon; it is a kind of insight into things. You cannot point to it as you would to some objective phenomenon and say, “this is understanding.” Understanding can grow or diminish. Take some complicated mathematical concept like randomness or continuity.
