At one point you may say, “I understand randomness.” But at a later date you may turn around and say, “You know I never really understood randomness before. Now I understand it much better.” Furthermore understanding something complex like randomness, or learning and thinking for that matter, is a process with no end. You can always understand it better or from a different angle. It is always possible to rethink your understanding in the light of new evidence. In the language I used earlier, it is always possible to reframe one’s understanding.

我们在教育中寻求的，大多是几乎每个人都能达到的最低限度的理解水平。即便如此，教师们也常常忘记，理解是因人而异的——不同的人可以以不同的方式合理地思考乘法。你无法进入别人的头脑并验证他们的理解，你也不能将自己的理解强加给别人。这就是为什么教学如此困难，好老师如此稀少。我稍后会就此展开更多讨论，但现在只需说学习就是获得理解。

What we look for in education is mostly a minimal level of understanding that almost everyone can attain. Even so teachers often forget that understanding is individual—different people can legitimately think about multiplication in different ways. You cannot get into someone else’s head and verify their understanding and you cannot impose your understanding on other people. This is why teaching is so hard and good teachers are rare. I shall have much more to say about this later but for now it will suffice to say that learning is about gaining understanding.

由于理解总是概念性的，因此谈论理解数据是没有意义的。只有理解知识才有可能，而你通过把知识变成你自己的来做到这一点。此外，理解（本书将使用这个术语）通常需要的不仅仅是对单个概念的了解。它需要看到同一概念的不同实例之间的关系，或者不同的概念。理解乘法包括很多方面，包括熟悉其各种表示形式及其与加法和除法的关系。它涉及通过各种概念系统（计数数字、分数、实数或复数）来查看乘法。

Since understanding is always conceptual it makes no sense to speak of understanding data. It is only possible to understand knowledge and you do this by making the knowledge your own. Moreover understanding, as the term will be used in this book, usually requires more than knowledge of individual concepts. It requires seeing the relationship between different instances of the same concept or between different concepts. Understanding multiplication includes many things including a familiarity with its various representations and its relationship with addition and division. It involves viewing multiplication through various conceptual systems—the counting numbers, the fractions, the real or complex numbers.

事实和概念只有在通过概念系统的视角来观察时才会获得真正的意义和重要性。然而，概念世界并不是永恒的，相反，它会不断修订，甚至发生根本性的变化。它甚至不是真正客观的，因为它会因人而异；它也不是纯粹主观的，因为它具有社会共识的属性。学习和理解意味着进入这种共识并发展自己独特的观点。

Facts and concepts only acquire real meaning and significance when viewed through the lens of a conceptual system. However the conceptual universe is not permanent but, on the contrary, is subject to continual revision and even to radical change. It is not even really objective since it varies with the individual; nor is it merely subjective since it has properties for which there is a social consensus. Learning and understanding means entering into this consensus and developing one’s own unique take on it.

然而，许多人坚持认为教育就是获得客观和永恒的知识。事实是，即使数据看起来是客观和永久的，它本身也是没有意义的。一旦人进入视野，当你讨论概念和概念系统时，你就会有客观和主观的维度，这些维度需要考虑在内。

Nevertheless many persist in thinking that education involves acquiring objective and timeless knowledge. The fact of the matter is that data on its own is meaningless even if it seems to be objective and permanent. As soon as the human being enters the picture, and that happens when you discuss concepts and conceptual systems, you have objective and subjective dimensions, which need to be taken into account.

事实不能独立于知识和理解而存在，因为如果没有概念基础，人们根本不知道要考虑哪些数据。选择的行为本身就意味着一些知识。可以说，数据、知识和理解是描述同一情况的不同方式，具体取决于所隐含的人为参与类型——“数据”意味着不强调人为因素，而“理解”则强调人为因素。当然，学习层次的顶端是创造性活动，为了保持一致，创造性活动存在于所有其他层次，但不幸的是，它经常被忽视。教育的所有错误都与忽视这一层次有关，当人们将学习和教学视为单纯的信息传递时，就会发生这种情况。

Facts do not exist independently of knowledge and understanding for without some conceptual basis one would not know what data to even consider. The very act of choosing implies some knowledge. One could say that data, knowledge, and understanding are different ways of describing the same situation depending on the type of human involvement implied—”data” means a de-emphasis on the human dimension whereas “understanding” highlights it. Of course the top of the hierarchy of learning is creative activity, which, to be consistent, is present at all the other levels but, unfortunately, is often ignored. All of the errors of education involve ignoring this hierarchy, which happens when one views learning and teaching as the mere transfer of information.

我将把事实、概念和概念系统视为学习过程中不可避免出现的暂时平衡（阶段）。我们倾向于关注这些平衡，并想象它们是永久的，而不是关注它们产生、分解和消亡的方式。并从一个转变为另一个。如果你想看到学习的实际行动，那就看看小孩子、艺术家和科学家。看看进化的过程。到处你都会看到同样的动态在发挥作用；到处你都会看到学习。

I shall look at facts, concepts, and conceptual systems as temporary equilibriums—stages—that inevitably arise within the learning process. We tend to focus on these equilibriums and to imagine that they are permanent instead of focusing on the way that they arise, break down, and morph from one into another. If you want to see learning in action then look at young children, artists and scientists. Look at the process of evolution. Everywhere you will see the same dynamic playing itself out; everywhere you will see learning.

6.8变革的现实

6.8The Reality of Change

变化是真实的，不变是幻觉。古典科学关注的是处于平衡状态的系统，而现代科学也关注可能远离平衡的状态。平衡状态会让你觉得事物是不变的，但这始终只是暂时的情况。平衡会崩塌，当平衡崩塌时，当系统远离平衡时，系统的动态性就会最为明显。在这种情况下，人们正在直接研究变化。

Change is real; the unchanging is an illusion. Classical science focused on systems that were in equilibrium whereas modern science also looks at states that may be far from equilibrium. Equilibrium situations can give you the feeling that things are unchanging but this is always only a temporary condition. Equilibriums beak down and when they do, when the system is far from equilibrium, then the dynamism of the system is most visible. In such situations one is studying change directly.

当然，进化论是一种变化理论，其寓意是生命与变化密不可分。然而，进化论的观点不仅适用于生命系统，也适用于其他领域——从行星、恒星和星系的物理宇宙到我们大脑中的回路，这些回路与心理和认知状态的发展同步发展。进化论研究的是控制变化的规则，任何关于学习的讨论也应该如此。

The theory of evolution is, of course, a theory of change and its moral is that life and change are inseparable. However the evolutionary point of view does not only apply to living systems but also to other domains—from the physical universe of planets, stars, and galaxies to the circuits in our brain, which evolve in tandem with the development of psychological and cognitive states. Evolution studies the rules that govern change and so should any discussion of learning.

古典科学经常忽视变化的原因可能是，与人类寿命相比，某些变化实在是太缓慢了。不久前，人们的生活与他们的父母和祖父母的生活几乎完全相同——可见的变化主要是自然循环。这就是人类社会难以应对全球变暖等环境变化的原因——遗传只能让我们应对在短时间内发生的紧急情况，而无法应对需要几十年或更长时间才能解决的发展。另一方面，当代社会的特点是变化速度加快；变化主要由技术进步引发。

The reason that change has often been ignored in classical science might have been that certain changes are positively glacial in comparison with the human life span. At one time, not so long ago, people’s lives were pretty much identical to that of their parents and grandparents—the changes that were visible were mostly the cycles of nature. This is the reason that it is so difficult for human societies to deal with environmental changes like global warming—heredity has only equipped us to deal with emergencies that take place over brief intervals of time but not with developments that take decades or longer to unravel. On the other hand contemporary society is characterized by the accelerating rate of change; changes that are primarily initiated by advances in technology.

很容易指出快速变化对个人和社会的负面影响，许多评论家也这样做过。你无处可躲避一天 24 小时在智能手机上跟踪你的工作。它会让你的生活压力很大。没有远离社会、广告甚至朋友的绿洲——没有和平、安宁或孤独。毫无疑问，今天的人们必须学会抽出一些时间和地点，让他们可以摆脱世界的需求，转向内心，让自己恢复活力和集中精力。

It is easy to point to the negative effects of rapid change on individuals and society and many commentators have done so. There is nowhere to hide from a job that follows you twenty-four hours a day on your smart phone. It can make life very stressful. There is no oasis from society, advertising, and even friends—no peace, tranquility, or solitude. Surely it is important that people today learn to carve out some time and place where they can shut out the demands of the world and turn inward to refresh and center themselves.

然而，变革的要求可以用另一种更积极的方式来表达。变革之所以困难，正是因为它是如此真实，因此我们创造停滞假象的企图失败了。在我们一生的很长一段时间里，我们可以保持一种幻觉，即我们在身体上和心理上都没有改变。然而，有一天，我们醒来发现，十年、二十年、三十年甚至更久过去了，我们已不再是原来的我们。挑战在于学会适应变化的现实，尽可能完整地活在当下。今天，更难保持我们和世界不变的幻觉——我们亲眼看到变化，阅读有关它的文章，听聪明的观察家讨论它——但我们对此却无能为力。教育系统和整个社会面临的挑战是从制度和社会上适应无处不在的变化，而不是像过去那样适应某些特定的变化，而是适应不断变化的现实。

Nevertheless the demands of change can be framed in another, more positive manner. Change is difficult precisely because it is so real and thus defeats our attempts to create an illusion of stasis. For long stretches of our lives we can maintain the illusion that we have not changed either physically or psychologically. Yet one day we wake up to the fact that ten, twenty, thirty, or more years have slipped by and we are not the person that we were. The challenge is to learn to live with the reality of change and to live every moment as completely as we can. Today it is more difficult to maintain the illusion that we, and the world, are unchanging—we see change with our own eyes, read about it, and listen to intelligent observers discuss it—yet we do little about it. The challenge for the educational system and for society as a whole is to adapt institutionally and socially to the omnipresence of change, not to some particular change, as was the case in the past, but to the reality of continual change.

6.9学习是对变化的积极回应

6.9Learning is a Positive Response to Change

学习是对变化的积极回应，人们公开欢迎变化进入自己的生活。我们当中没有人是应对变化的专家。在这方面，我们都有一些东西要学习，教育鸿沟的双方，教师和学生，都可能有所贡献。一个六岁孩子的学习态度很可能是所谓的专家可以效仿的。

Learning is a positive response to change in which one openly invites change into one’s life. None of us are experts at facing change. We all have something to learn in this regard and both sides of the educational divide, teachers and students, may well have something to contribute. It may well be that a six-year old child has an attitude towards learning that the so-called experts could do well to emulate.

现代教育的功能应该是让学生在这个不断变化的世界中茁壮成长。我们的认知结构总是在追赶世界。就在我们以为我们已经掌握了看待事物的“正确方式”而可以放松的时候，我们发现事情已经发生了变化，“正确方式”已经成为“老路”。然后我们必须掌握新概念和新概念系统，更不用说放弃我们现在已经过时的旧方法。这是现代教育的挑战。每件事、每个人都在不断变化，教育必须成为进入这个世界的入口。我们如何学会平衡我们对稳定和安全的需求与我们生活在变化的世界的需求，这个世界既有压力，也有兴奋和刺激？

The function of modern education should be to prepare students to prosper in this world of continual change. Our cognitive structures are always playing catch-up with the world. Just when we thought that we could relax because we have acquired the “right way” to look at things, we find that things have changed and the “right way” has become the “old way.” We then have to master new concepts and new conceptual systems, not to speak of giving up our old ways, which have now become obsolete. This is the challenge of modern education. Everything and everyone is changing all the time and education must become an entry into this world. How do we learn to balance our need for stability and security with our need to live in the world of change, which is stressful but also exciting and stimulating?

6.10学习即信息传递

6.10Learning as the Transfer of Information

让我再回头来进一步思考学习和信息传递之间的关系。什么是学习？当我在字典里查找“学习”这个词时，我首先找到的是“知识或技能的获得”，而“知识”的定义是“对信息或事实的认识”。这显然不是我谈论学习或知识的方式。对我来说，知识是概念性的。只有忽略概念维度，学习才会成为信息的获得。

Let me return to a further consideration of the relationship between learning and the transfer of information. What is learning? When I look up “learning” in the dictionary the first thing I find is “the acquisition of knowledge or skill” where “knowledge,” is then defined to be “the awareness of information or facts.” This is clearly not the way in which I have been talking about either learning or knowledge. For me knowledge is conceptual. It is only by ignoring the conceptual dimension that learning becomes the acquisition of information.

试图将教育定义为单纯的信息传递，这是现代社会的一大趋势。从这个角度来看，教师、书本或计算机程序拥有信息，并将其传递到学生的头脑中。这种学习方法在实践中行不通，因为它在很多方面都是错误的。它可能指的是计算机系统的数据采集，但不是指人类的学习。人类的大脑甚至很难记住随机的事实。为了记住一些非常复杂的东西——比如数学论证——必须理解它。它必须有意义，而这种意义是由一套思想体系来承载的。学习包括掌握思想，而思想不是事实，而是关系。

This attempt to frame education as the mere transfer of information is a powerful tendency in the modern world. From this viewpoint, the teacher, book, or computer program has the information and transfers it into the head of the student. This approach towards learning does not work in practice because it is wrong in many different ways. It may refer to the data acquisition of computer systems but not to human learning. The human mind has a lot of trouble with even remembering random facts. In order to remember something that is at all complex—like a mathematical argument—it must be understood. It must have meaning and that meaning is carried by a system of ideas. Learning involves mastering ideas and ideas are not facts, they are relationships.

我们的时代经常被称为“信息时代”，因此我们很自然地将信息等同于知识，并将这些知识视为事实、思想或原则。我们关注的是要学习的材料，而不是我们赋予材料意义的概念系统。我们认为信息是中性的，独立存在，教育任务主要涉及掌握大量信息。关键在于我们强调“我们学到什么”，而轻视“学习过程”，即教育的认知维度。由于这种错误的方法，学习很容易沦为死记硬背，这种学习虽然有其存在的意义，但与本书所讨论的创造性学习相去甚远。

Our age has often been called the “information age” and so it is natural that we identify information with knowledge and think of this knowledge as facts, ideas, or principles. We focus on the material to be learned and not on the conceptual system by means of which we give meaning to the material. We believe that information is neutral and stands on its own and that the educational task primarily involves mastering large amounts of information. The point is that we emphasize “what we learn” and de-emphasize “the learning process,” the cognitive dimension of education. As a result of this mistaken approach learning can easily be reduced to rote learning, a kind of learning that has its place but is far from the creative learning that this book is about.

将学习视为数据获取是现代教育的主流。教育机构被比作工厂，负责加工原材料（事实），并将原材料转化为成品（受过教育的人了解相关事实及其常规用途）。这种观点基于工业革命时期兴起的一种看待世界的方式，但如今已经过时，不适合我们生活的时代。

Thinking of learning as data acquisition is the direction in which much of modern education is oriented. Educational institutions have been compared to factories that process raw materials—facts—and convert the raw materials into a finished product—the educated person who knows the relevant facts and their conventional uses. It is based on a way of looking at the world that arose with the industrial revolution but is today outmoded and inappropriate to the age in which we live.

这种错误的方向是我们的教育机构未能完成其主要使命的主要原因，即培养能够批判性地评估和适应现代世界快速变化的公众。教育是或应该是为现实世界做准备，而获取很快就会过时的知识并不是所需的培训。我们的教育体系是从另一个时代延续下来的。当我们考虑修复它时，我们会倾向于通过互联网或其他类型的计算机辅助教育来传递信息。这看起来是一种新方法，但实际上是一种披着新技术外衣的非常古老的方法。我们仍然处于旧的概念体系中，而我们需要的是一个适合我们时代的新体系。但在考虑新方法之前，我们必须首先确定旧体系存在的问题。

This erroneous orientation is the main reason why our educational institutions have failed for the most part in what should be their main mission—producing a public that can critically evaluate, and adapt to, the rapid changes that characterize the modern world. Education is, or should be, a preparation for the real world and the acquisition of knowledge that will soon be obsolete is not the training that is needed. We have an educational system that is a carry-over from another time. When we think of fixing it we gravitate towards things like information delivery over the internet or other kinds of computer assisted education. This looks like it is a new approach but it is really a very old approach dressed up in new technological clothes. We are still in the old conceptual system when what we need is a new one that is appropriate to our time. But we first have to identify the problems with the old before there is space for a consideration of the new.

6.11学习就是获得技能

6.11Learning as the Acquisition of Skills

有时，学习的讨论会超出知识的积累，而涉及到技能的获得。教育当然涉及学习技能：如何写文章、编写计算机程序或区分函数。即使是语言和算术等基本技能的学习也比单纯的信息传递处于更高的水平，因为它是开放的，包含创造力的元素。一个学习了语言可以组织他们从未听过的句子。已经学会数数的孩子可以回答诸如“最大的数字是什么？”这样的问题，或者他们可以做出这样的观察：“如果 2 加 3 等于 5，那么 20 加 30 一定等于 50。”表达一个新句子或识别出一个新的算术规律，这些洞察力表明孩子已经掌握了一定的语言知识或数数系统。在语言和算术中，“事实”都被对概念模式的洞察力所取代——孩子学会识别这些模式，然后在新的情境中适当地应用它们。孩子对语言和算术的掌握具有一定的创造性。

Sometimes the discussion of learning expands beyond the accumulation of facts to the acquisition of skills. Education certainly involves learning skills: how to write an essay, program a computer, or differentiate a function. The learning of even basic skills like language and arithmetic is at a higher level than mere transfer of information because it is open- ended and contains an element of creativity. A child who learns a language can formulate sentences that they have never heard before. Children who have learned the counting numbers can answer questions like, “Is there a largest number?” Or they can make observations like “if 2 plus 3 equals 5 then 20 plus 30 must equal 50.” Expressing a new sentence or recognizing a new arithmetical regularity are insights that demonstrate that the child has acquired a certain knowledge of language or of the system of counting numbers. In both language and arithmetic, “facts” are replaced by insights into conceptual patterns—which a child learns to recognize and then apply appropriately in new situations. There is something creative in a child’s mastery of language and arithmetic.

最简单、最常见的技能涉及规则的系统应用——算法学习。通常的加法或乘法算法就是很好的例子，但算法学习不仅限于数学。然而数学就是一个很好的例子。曾经，学生的教育很大一部分用于掌握标准算法，但今天，计算设备已经使这些算法基本过时了（无论好坏）。当我谈到学习一项技能时，我通常想到的是算法。例如，学习写一篇文章涉及可以通过这种方式学习的各种技能：拼写、语法、标点符号、句子和段落结构等技能。当然，写一篇好文章超越了所有这些特定的技能。它是一种真正的艺术形式，因此有很多方面是无法通过算法学习的。因此，写作不仅涉及学习技能，还涉及另一个维度——创造力。

The simplest and most frequently learned skills involve the systematic application of rules—algorithmic learning. The usual addition or multiplication algorithms are good examples but algorithmic learning is not limited to mathematics. Yet mathematics is a good example. At one time a good part of a student’s education was spent mastering standard algorithms but today this has mostly been rendered obsolete (for good and for bad) by computing devices. When I talk of learning a skill I am usually thinking of something that is algorithmic. Learning to write an essay, for example, involves various skills that can be learned in this way: skills such as spelling, grammar, punctuation, sentence and paragraph structure, and so on. Of course writing a good essay goes beyond all of these particular skills. It’s really an art form and so has many aspects that cannot be learned algorithmically. Thus writing involves learning skills but also involves another dimension—the creative.

6.12学习概念和概念系统

6.12Learning Concepts and Conceptual Systems

我认为，数据和技能的获取不是真正的教育，而是真正的教育的开始。真正的教育涉及知识和理解的获取，这两者都包含创造力的重要元素。关键步骤涉及概念的形成。在数学和物理学中，人们需要掌握质量、速度、无理数或随机性等概念。掌握一个概念需要创造性的工作。仅仅记住一个正式的定义是不够的。你必须知道这个定义的含义，这意味着对这个概念有“感觉”。你必须体验过这个概念的许多具体例子，然后才能理解这些例子的共同点。最后，你必须能够恰当地运用这个概念，即使是在新的情况下。

I think of the acquisition of data and skills, not as real education but as the mere beginning of real education. Real education involves the acquisition of knowledge and understanding, which both include an important element of creativity. A crucial step involves concept formation. In mathematics and physics one needs to grasp concepts such as mass, velocity, irrational number, or randomness. Mastering a concept requires creative work. It is not enough to memorize a formal definition. You have to know what the definition means and this implies having a “feeling” for the concept. You have to have experienced lots of concrete examples of the concept and then make the leap to what these examples all have in common. And finally you have to be able to apply the concept appropriately, even in situations that are new.

正如我们所见，即使是初等算术也涉及数字和算术运算等概念。即使是这些基本概念也非常微妙，因为它们既涉及信息又涉及程序。掌握这些概念需要死记硬背和算法学习，以及其他一些东西 - 创造性的X因素。你可以称之为概念学习或概念理解。它涉及深度思考，因此它是在克服某些障碍后突然出现的。它通常涉及忘记已被证明无法满足手头任务要求的先前概念。新概念通常带有多种表示形式。理解，即数学教育家安娜·谢尔宾斯卡在她优秀的著作《数学中的理解》中所说的“良好的理解” ，涉及将这些不同的表示形式视为一个统一思想的不同观点。

As we have seen even elementary arithmetic involves concepts like number and the arithmetical operations. Even these elementary concepts are very subtle as they involve both information and procedures. Grasping these concepts involves rote and algorithmic learning as well as something else—a creative X-factor. You can call it conceptual learning or conceptual understanding. It involves deep thinking and so it arrives suddenly as a result of overcoming some obstacle. It often involves the unlearning of an earlier concept that has proved to be inadequate to the task at hand. The new concept typically comes with multiple representations. Understanding, what the mathematics educator Anna Sierpinska calls “good understanding” in her excellent book Understanding in Mathematics, involves seeing these different representations as different views of a unitary idea.

然而，单个概念是不够的。它们必须整合成一个概念系统。一方面，概念系统比单个概念处于更高的层次；另一方面，单个概念通过概念系统获得意义。因此，将单个概念孤立地看待是错误的。

Nevertheless, individual concepts are not enough. They must be integrated into a conceptual system. In one way the conceptual system is at a higher level than individual concepts; although, in another, individual concepts get their meaning through conceptual systems. Thus it is a mistake to think of individual concepts in isolation from one another.

6.13重构：学习作为概念系统的转变

6.13Reframing: Learning as the Change of Conceptual System

最后，也是至关重要的一点，教育涉及用一个概念系统取代另一个概念系统。这最后一步是教育的关键，也是最困难的方面，但这是现代世界要求我们所有人定期做的事情。这一步可以称为“学习如何学习”。学习不仅仅是获取知识、技能、概念，甚至概念系统。它还涉及从一种思考情况的方式转变为另一种更复杂的思考方式。后一步涉及获得一些东西（新系统），但同时也要削减其他东西（在旧系统不适用的情况下完全依赖旧系统）。通常，学习只从“获得一些东西”的角度来考虑，但它也涉及“失去一些东西”。成长涉及放弃已经过时的东西，这可能是痛苦和困难的。正是在这个阶段，教育任务的全部复杂性才得以揭示。正是在这里，我们对创造力的讨论，包括其所有的微妙和复杂性，都是有意义的。当我使用“深度学习”这个表达时，我脑海中想到的主要活动就是这个。

Finally, and crucially, education involves replacing one conceptual system by another. This last step is the key, and most difficult, aspect of education but this is what the modern world calls on us all to do on a regular basis. This is the step that could be called “learning how to learn.” Learning is not just about acquiring knowledge, skill, concepts, or even conceptual systems. It is also about moving from one way of thinking about a situation to another, more complex, way of thinking. This latter step involves acquiring something—the new system—but also pruning away something else—the total reliance on the old system in situations in which it is inadequate. Normally learning is only considered from the point of view of “gaining something” but it also involves “losing something.” Growing involves letting go of what has been outgrown and this can be painful and difficult. It is at this stage that the full complexity of the educational task is revealed. It is here that our discussion of creativity, in all of its subtlety and complexity, is relevant. This is the primary activity that I have in mind when I use the expression “deep learning.”

6.14学习和创造力的范围

6.14The Spectrum of Learning and Creativity

总而言之，我们已经看到，我们不可能精确地描述学习，因为学习有许多不同的形式：信息传递、算法学习、概念形成、概念系统的发展，以及最终重新构建或改变一个人的操作概念系统。我们真的应该谈谈“学习的光谱”，因为我列举的这些学习的不同方面都有一个方向。光谱朝着越来越复杂的学习方向发展。当我们从第一步到最后一步时，我们看到创造力的增加。事实上，在我们的光谱上增加最后一步可能是合理的，那就是我们通常认为的创造性工作——开发新的科学理论、艺术作品或技术创新。通常，创造力只与最后一步有关，与生产新的、从未见过的东西有关。从这个角度看，我们忘记了创造过程本身并不新鲜，而且一直存在。当我们把学习看作一个光谱时，我们也会以同样的方式看待创造力。当所有学习都被视为包含创造力元素时，它就不能不改变我们对教育的看法。

To sum up, we have seen that it is not possible to characterize learning with precision because learning comes in many different modalities: the transfer of information, algorithmic learning, concept formation, the development of conceptual systems, and, finally, reframing or changing one’s operational conceptual system. We should really talk about the “spectrum of learning” because these different aspects of learning that I have enumerated come with a direction. The spectrum moves in the direction of increasingly complex learning. As we move from the first to the last we see an increase in creativity. In fact it might be reasonable to add on one final step to our spectrum and that would be what we normally consider to be creative work—the development of new scientific theories, works of art, or technological innovations. Normally creativity is only associated with the final step, with the production of something that is new and has never been seen before. Looked on in that way we forget that the creative process itself is not new and has always been around. When we come to see learning as a spectrum we will also see creativity in the same way. When all learning is seen to contain elements of creativity then it cannot help but transform our view of what education should be.

6.15会心

6.15Knowing

每一个成功的学习情况都涉及了解，但“了解”这个词很容易被误解。有时我们知道一些东西，例如一个事实、一个程序或一个概念，但前提是了解一个概念并不等同于了解一个事实。掌握一个概念系统也涉及一种了解的形式，但这与其说是对某事的了解，不如说是“通过某事了解”。这就是我通过使用概念系统作为窗口的比喻来表达的观点。

Every successful learning situation involves knowing but the word knowing can easily be misunderstood. Sometimes we know something for example, a fact or a procedure or maybe a concept with the proviso that knowing a concept is not the same thing as knowing a fact. Mastering a conceptual system also involves a form of knowing but this is not so much a knowing of something as of “knowing through something.” This was the point that I was making through the use of the metaphor of a conceptual system as a window.

有趣的是，如果我们能够将认知的对象与认知的感觉本身（及物动词和不及物动词的认知意义）分开，我们会发现在所有这些情况下我们所感受到的“认知”是相同的。学习的结果就是认知，但是我们倾向于关注其他东西——与我们知道的东西相比，我们知道什么。这是因为人们将学习比作一个工业过程。当你制造小部件时，你会担心小部件的种类、质量等等。这个过程只是为了生产小部件——它是次要的。但学习不是一个工业过程，而且这个工业比喻是不恰当的。学习如何学习和学习的乐趣来自于进入认知领域。它总是与创造性行为联系在一起。它本身就是回报，也是学习感觉如此良好的原因。当人们过去在学校学习欧几里得几何时，只要他们看到推论的解决方案，就会有这种感觉。当你用一种依赖于算法（例如，区分一个函数或将两个五位数相乘）的解决方案来代替这类问题时，你不会得到这种释放。没有“啊哈！”的时刻。什么也没学到。

It is interesting that if we could divorce the object of knowing from the feeling of knowing itself—the transitive versus the intransitive senses of knowing—we would find that it is the same “knowing” that we feel in all of these situations. The result of learning is knowing but we tend to focus on something else—what we know as compared with that we know. This comes from thinking of learning as analogous to an industrial process. When you make widgets you worry about the kinds of widgets, their quality, and so on. The process is just there to produce widgets—it is secondary. But learning is not an industrial process and the industrial metaphor is a bad one. Learning how to learn, and the joy of learning, comes from accessing the domain of knowing. It is invariably associated with acts of creativity. It is its own reward and is the reason that learning feels so good. When people used to do Euclidean geometry in school they would get that feeling whenever they saw into the resolution of a deduction. When you replace this kind of problem by one whose solution depends on an algorithm—differentiating a function, for example, or multiplying two five digit numbers, you don’t get this release. There is no “aha!” moment. Nothing has been learned.

6.16教育问题

6.16The Problem with Education

我们的教育系统陷入混乱，因为它们被设定为做错误的工作。我们没有正确定义教育的任务，因此我们不可能成功。在很大程度上，我们放弃了教育的真正任务——深度学习和深度学习者的发展。许多教师可能听说过教育是一个创造性的过程，他们甚至可能相信它存在于他们的心中，但很少有人在课堂或大学讲堂里以这种方式对待它。造成这种情况的原因有很多。在大多数情况下，他们不知道如何去做，因为他们自己没有受过这样的教育。

Our educational systems are in disarray because they have been set up to do the wrong job. We have not defined the task of education properly and, as a result, we cannot possibly succeed. For the most part we have given up on the real task of education—on deep learning and the development of deep learners. Many teachers may have heard that education is a creative process, they may even believe that it is in their hearts, but few approach it in that way in the classroom or university lecture hall. There are many reasons for this. For the most part they would not know how to do so because they have not have been educated in that way themselves.

即使对于那些了解学习的创造性源泉或在生活的其他领域富有创造力的教师来说，以这种方式教学实在太难了。困难的原因显而易见——班级规模大、纪律问题、学生准备不足和积极性低，以及电子产品、互联网和媒体的干扰。然而，培养深度学习很难的更深层次原因是，​​创造性学习涉及到我认为是深度思考特征之一的那种困难。学习的难度在性质上类似于创作一件伟大的艺术作品或一种新的科学理论的难度。我们如何将我们的教育体系导向这个方向？这是关键问题。

Even for those teachers who are in touch with the creative sources of learning or who are creative in other areas of their lives find that it is just too hard to teach in this way. It is hard for the obvious reasons—large class sizes, problems of discipline, lack of preparation and motivation on the part of the students, and the distractions of electronic gadgets, the internet, and the media. However the deeper reason why nurturing deep learning is hard to do is that creative learning involves the kind of difficulty I identified as one of the characteristics of deep thinking. The difficulty of learning is qualitatively similar to the difficulty of producing a great work of art or a new scientific theory. How do we orient our educational system in this direction? This is the key question.

在大学里，创造性活动与研究有关。人们认为，学生在本科和研究生生涯的大部分时间里都把创造力束之高阁。在某个时刻，我们要求学生发生神奇的蜕变。他们曾经只是信息的收集者，但现在被期望成为创造性的研究者——思考的不是掌握旧知识，而是创造新知识。然后，当变化来得缓慢或根本没有时，学生会感到惊讶，他们的导师会感到失望。如果以我在本文中建议的方式对待教育，那么本科教育、研究生教育、博士后培训和成熟研究活动之间的差距将被视为理想情况下的连续体——同样的创造性活动，同样的基本过程，只是在不同环境中以不同的自主性进行。

At the university creative activity is identified with doing research. It is assumed that students put their creativity on the shelf through their undergraduate and a good deal of their graduate career. At a certain moment we demand a magical metamorphosis in students. They were merely amassers of information but are now expected to be creative researchers—to think, not in terms of mastering the old, but of producing the new. Then the students are surprised and their advisors are disappointed when the change comes slowly or not at all. If education were approached in the manner that I suggest in these pages then the gaps between undergraduate education, graduate education, post-doctoral training, and full-fledged research activity would be seen as the continuum that it ideally should be—the same creative activity, the same basic process, just pursued in different environments with different degrees of autonomy.

让我们从神经科学的角度来考虑一下教育的本质——从 CS 1到 CS 2 的转变。那么概念系统将对应于大脑中的一个或一组电路。一个被理解和反复使用的概念系统对应于根深蒂固的电路。从一个概念系统转变为另一个概念系统的问题将涉及建立新的大脑回路。由于大脑遵循“用进废退”的规律，我们可以看到，在相当长的一段时间内，人们会倾向于使用旧的、已建立的回路。我们如何建立新的回路？新回路和旧回路之间有什么联系？我们如何阻止自己继续优先使用旧回路而不是新回路？这些都不是简单的问题，但无论是隐性还是显性，教育都要求对这些问题给出可操作的答案。

Let us consider the essence of education—the movement from CS1 to CS2—from the point of view of neuroscience, for a moment. Then a conceptual system would correspond to a circuit or set of circuits in the brain. A conceptual system that is understood and used repeatedly corresponds to circuits that are well entrenched. The problem of changing from one conceptual system to another would involve establishing new brain circuits. Since the brain obeys the law of “use it or lose it” we can see that for a considerable time there will be a tendency to use the old, well-established, circuitry. How do we set up the new circuits? What is the connection between the new circuits and the old? How do we keep ourselves from continuing to use the old in preference to the new? These are not easy questions but implicitly or explicitly education demands operational answers to them.

实现这种根本性的心理和行为改变是困难且有压力的，因此学生需要帮助和支持。他或她不能指望从不知道教育需要这样的人那里得到这种支持。也许老师已经多年没有用新的方式思考数学了；也许她已经完全失去了创造性甚至有趣的数学方法。也许它只是变成了“东西”，即信息，需要从课本中“下载”给学生。如果是这样，老师就不可能理解学生所处的境况，更不用说提供她所需要的指导和支持了。

Accomplishing this kind of fundamental mental and behavioral change is difficult and stressful and so the student needs help and support. He or she cannot hope to get that kind of support from someone who is unaware that this is what education requires. Maybe it is years since the teacher has thought about mathematics in a new way; maybe she has totally lost touch with a creative or even a playful approach to mathematics. Maybe it has just become “stuff,” that is, information, to be “downloaded” from the text to the student. If so it will be impossible for the teacher to comprehend the situation in which the student finds herself much less to provide the guidance and support that she needs.

可悲的事实是，我们常常不努力去教育学生，而愿意接受一种复制的教育。这对教师、学生和整个社会来说都是一个巨大的悲剧。社会需要能够思考和创新的人。学生和教师都是人，都有创造性表达的基本需求。学校、学院和大学是学习如何挖掘内在创造力资源的理想场所。事实很快就会被遗忘；算法会让位于改进的计算机程序；但学习如何以创造性的方式学习和对待生活是一种无价的天赋，可以从一种情况转移到另一种情况。以这种方式教学可以改变老师；以这种方式学习可以改变学生。在事实被遗忘很久之后，这些变化仍将保持活力。

The sad truth is that we often don’t try very hard to educate students and are willing to accept a facsimile of education. This is a great tragedy—for the teacher, the student, and society as a whole. Society needs people who can think and innovate. Both students and teachers are human beings with their own basic needs for creative expression. Schools, colleges, and universities are ideal places in which to learn how to tap into one’s inner creative resources. The facts will be quickly forgotten; algorithms will give way to improved computer programs; but learning how to learn and to approach life in a creative manner is a priceless gift that is transferable from one situation to another. Teaching in this way changes the teacher; learning in this way changes the student. Long after the facts are all forgotten, these changes will remain alive and well.

6.17没有障碍就没有学习

6.17There is No Learning without Obstacles

学习不是凭空而来的；它是解决问题和克服障碍的结果。当我们把教育看作是获得知识的过程时，信息和技术的结合就像我们从花园里摘花一样——可能需要一点时间和精力，但没有什么能阻碍你。当一个学生试图理解数学中的某个主题时，情况就不一样了。她可以花费数小时的时间而不一定取得任何进展。创造性活动的标志之一是，它没有任何成功的保证，因为它是基于遇到和克服各种障碍。让我重复一下我之前说过的话，即所有的学习，无论是发展、学校学习还是科学研究，都是一个不连续的过程，它始于遇到阻碍未来进步的障碍，直到克服它。障碍的存在是教育的一个基本特征，但经常被忽视。如果你不把教育看作是对问题的回应，你就无法理智地思考教育。这就是信息理论方法的错误之处——因为它从错误的方向开始，所以它永远不会有任何有趣的结果。

Learning does not just happen; it is the result of solving problems and overcoming obstacles. When we think about education as the acquisition of information and technique it is as though we were picking flowers from our garden—it may take a little time and energy but there is nothing that obstructs you. It’s not the same when a student tries to understand some topic in mathematics. She can spend hours of her time without necessarily making any progress. One of the hallmarks of creative activity is that it is undertaken without any guarantee of success because it is based on encountering and overcoming obstacles of various sorts. Let me repeat what I said earlier, namely, that all learning, whether as development, school learning, or scientific research, is a discontinuous process, which starts with encountering an obstacle that blocks future progress until such time as it is overcome. The existence of obstacles is an essential feature of education, which is often ignored. You can’t think sensibly about education without seeing it as a response to the problematic. That is what’s wrong with the information theoretical approach—because it starts out in the wrong direction it will never get anywhere interesting.

教育不是像谷歌搜索算法那样收集和整理信息的过程！教育——深度学习——是一场探索未知的冒险。面对一个对你来说毫无意义的新情况需要勇气，然而这正是我们经常要求学生做的。相比之下，我们成年人往往会尽力避免这种具有挑战性的情况，因为它们会让我们感到不舒服。我们常常把好生活和舒适的生活等同起来。当你面对一些你不理解的事情时，很明显你无法控制局面。然后，人们很容易屈服于似乎能保证成功的方法，比如算法。不幸的是，这相当于用已知的东西、用久经考验的东西取代未知的东西。这就像试图用逻辑来推导出一个新想法——这不是它的工作方式。伟大的数学家安德鲁·怀尔斯被问到：“当你撞上一堵砖墙时，你会怎么做？”他简单地回答道：“我会出去散步。我会在湖边散步。散步有很好的效果，因为你处于放松状态，但同时你让潜意识对你起作用。”这更像是你如何打开一个空间，让新的想法有空间涌现。它澄清了教育和创造力的必要元素——障碍，吸收和放松——但是，如果不面对问题的挑战，整个过程就无法开始。

Education is not a process of gathering and sorting information like a Google search algorithm! Education—deep learning—is an adventure into the unknown. It takes courage to face a situation that is new and makes no sense to you and yet that is what we regularly ask students to do. In comparison we adults often do our best to avoid situations that are challenging in this way because they make us uncomfortable. Often we equate the good life with the comfortable life. When you face something that you don’t understand it is evident that you are not in control of the situation. It is then tempting to succumb to methods such as algorithms that appear to guarantee success. Unfortunately this amounts to replacing the unknown by the known, by the tried and true. It is like trying to use logic to deduce a new idea—that is just not the way it works. The great mathematician Andrew Wiles was asked, “What do you do when you hit a brick wall?” He answered simply, “I would go out for a walk. I’d walk down by the lake. Walking has a good effect in that you are in a state of relaxation, but at the same time you’re allowing the subconscious to work on you.” This is more like how you open up a space so that there is room for a new idea to come bubbling up. It clarifies the necessary elements of both education and creativity—obstacles, absorption, and relaxation—but the whole process cannot even get started if one does not face up to the challenge of the problematic.

是否有可能学会处理问题并学会享受它们？小时候我们都热衷于学习，经常面对各种障碍。我们不怕冒险。我们大多数人长大后都发生了什么？

Is it possible to learn to work with problematic situations, to learn to enjoy them? As young children we were all avid learners and faced up to all kinds of obstacles on a regular basis. We were not afraid to take a chance. What happened to most of us as we grew up?

6.18学习是令人羞辱的

6.18Learning is Humiliating

一个小故事可以说明这个问题。我打算在一门跨学科文科课程的课堂上讨论创造力。在上一节课中，我布置了一篇论文，要求学生阅读并评论。在下一节课中，一些学生明确地告诉我，他们发现这篇论文很难理解。现在，数学专业的学生经常会遇到一些他们最初觉得难以理解的新想法。这些学生不习惯这种情况，也不喜欢这种情况。他们中的许多人来上课时都很生气——对我和文章的作者。他们说：“我不明白他在说什么。他当然可以用更简单的方式来写。他为什么要用这么大的词？”他们反应的激烈程度与这种情况的利害关系不成比例。我认为这暗示着发生了一些更普遍、更重要的事情。

A short anecdote will illustrate the problem. I was intending to discuss creativity in a class that I was teaching to some students in an interdisciplinary Liberal Arts course. In the previous class I had assigned an essay that the students were supposed to read and comment on. In the next class I was informed in no uncertain terms by some of the students that they had found this particular essay very difficult to understand. Now mathematics students regularly encounter new ideas that they initially find difficult to understand. These students were not used to being in such a situation and didn’t like it at all. Many of them came to class angry—at me and at the writer of the article. They said things like, “I don’t understand what he is saying. Surely he could have written it in a simpler way. Why does he have to use such big words?” The virulence of their reaction was not proportional to what was at stake in this situation. I took it as a hint that something more general and important was going on.

他们不只是不理解这篇文章，还觉得这种情况让他们感到羞辱。羞辱这个词很强烈，但对某些人来说，不理解就是一种羞辱吗？也许有些学生觉得学习的情况很丢脸。这可能是因为他们过去有过不好的经历，老师或同学嘲笑他们，或者因为他们自己对自己的能力有怀疑。但还有另一个可能的原因。学习不可避免地始于承认自己的无知，即使这只是对自己承认，这会让你感到脆弱。正是这种脆弱，以及在学习环境中无法保护自己免受这种脆弱，这可能会让人感到羞辱。我们一生中的大部分时间都在通过表现得聪明、好斗、风趣或可爱来保护自己免受脆弱感。所有这些反应都使我们看不到学习障碍，更不用说克服它了。

It was not merely that they did not understand this particular essay but that they felt humiliated by the situation. Humiliation is a strong word but could it be that, for some people, incomprehension is experienced as humiliation? Perhaps some students experience learning situations as humiliating. This may be because they have had a bad experience in the past where a teacher or fellow student held them up to ridicule or because they themselves have doubts about their own capacities. But there is also another possible reason. Learning inevitably begins by admitting your own ignorance, even if this is only to yourself, and this makes you feel vulnerable. It is this vulnerability, and the impossibility of protecting oneself from it within the learning situation, that can be experienced as humiliation. We spend a good deal of our lives protecting ourselves from feelings of vulnerability by being clever or aggressive or funny or cute. All of these responses keep us from even seeing the learning obstacle much less overcoming it.

如果这是真的，那么教育者就陷入了两难境地。如果你认真教学，让学生面对在实际学习中始终存在的障碍，那么你就冒着羞辱他们的风险。如果你允许学生假装没有障碍或可以避免障碍，那么你就不是真正的教学。羞辱的威胁在任何学习情况下都存在——当学生试图避免与老师目光接触时，你可以从他们的脸上看到这一点。问题是我们该怎么做？我稍后会再谈到这个问题。

If this is true then the educator is in a double bind. If you teach conscientiously and so expose students to the obstacles that are always present in real learning then you run the risk of humiliating them. If you allow the students to pretend that there are no obstacles or that they can be avoided then you are not really teaching. The threat of humiliation is never far from any learning situation—you can see it in the faces of the students as they attempt to avoid eye contact with the teacher. The question is what do we do about it? I’ll come back to this later on.

我问这些学生：“这肯定不是你第一次遇到第一次阅读时不理解的内容吧？在这种情况下，你的策略是什么？当你发现自己不理解这篇文章时，你会怎么做？”房间里一片令人不安的沉默，我好几分钟都没有打断。似乎没有人有策略。一个学生终于有气无力地说：“再读一遍？”他们大多似乎觉得介绍困难的材料违反了游戏规则，老师的工作就是帮他们消化材料。从这个角度看，学习是一种被动活动，就像看电视节目，老师只是娱乐节目。你可以从电视节目中获取信息，但你不会从中学到任何重要的东西，因为你没有受到改变和成长的挑战。这些学生所接受的教育大多避开了障碍——我所提倡的教育却朝着相反的方向发展。

I asked these particular students, “Surely this is not the first time that you have encountered something that you did not understand at first reading? What is your strategy in such situations? What did you do when you found that you did not understand this essay?” There was an uncomfortable silence in the room, which I did not interrupt for many minutes. No one, it seemed, had a strategy. One student finally said rather weakly, “Read it again?” Mostly they seemed to feel that introducing difficult material was breaking some rule of the game, that it was the teacher’s job to digest the material for them. Learning in this view is a passive activity like watching a TV program with the teacher as entertainer. You can get information out of a TV program but you don’t learn anything important from it because you are not challenged to change and grow. The education that these students had undergone had mostly avoided obstacles— the kind of education that I am advocating goes in the opposite direction.

6.19不理解

6.19Not Understanding

这里有一个恰如其分的观察，我几乎不好意思提出，因为它太陈腐和明显了。那就是你必须“不理解”才能希望理解。如果你永远不能接受处于“不理解”的境地，那么你永远也不会理解。让我们思考一下“不理解”。因为“不理解”的表述是负面的，所以我们认为它只是一种缺失，一个需要我们去填补的洞。不理解会让我们感到不舒服，我们认为最好的办法是尽快摆脱这种不舒服。我们不会关注“不理解”的感觉。它本身就是一种有效的感觉，任何学习经验都源于此。“不理解”不一定是痛苦或困难的。将它阻挡在意识之外才会引发困难，因为它会让你陷入困境——你不想承认它，因为它会让你感到不足和失控，但如果你想在学习新想法方面取得任何进展，你就必须承认它。

There is an observation that is a propos here that I am almost embarrassed to make because it is so trite and obvious. It is that you have to “not understand” before you can hope to understand. If you can never accept being in the position of “not understanding” then you will never understand. Let’s think about “not understanding” for a moment. Because it is phrased negatively we think of “not understanding” merely as a lack, a hole that we are called upon to fill up. Not understanding makes us uncomfortable and we think that the way to go is to get rid of the discomfort as quickly as possible. We don’t focus on what it feels like to “not understand.” It is a valid sensation in its own right, which is where any learning experience originates. “Not understanding” is not necessarily painful or difficult. It is blocking it out of your consciousness that provokes difficulty because it puts you in a double bind—you don’t want to own up to it because it makes you feel inadequate and out of control but you have to admit it if you are to make any headway in learning the new idea.

实际上，“不明白”可能是一种最强烈和最令人愉悦的体验。假设你在漫长的夏日结束时欣赏美丽的日落，并被它所唤起的敬畏之情所淹没。一切都感觉很完美，但如果你试图分析和理解这种完美，它就会消失。这种感觉的本质正是“不理解”——在这种情况下，开放本身就足够了。在那一刻，一切都很好。最好的学习要求我们以这种方式敞开心扉。

Actually “not getting it” can be a most powerful and pleasurable experience. Suppose you are looking at a beautiful sunset at the end of a long summer’s day and you are swept up in the sense of awe that it evokes. Everything feels perfect but if you try to analyze and understand that perfection it just falls away. The essence of this feeling is precisely “not understanding”—an openness that in this case is sufficient in itself. Everything, in that moment, is all right. At its best learning asks us to open up in this way.

当我们面对新的学习环境时，我们必须首先接受自己的现状，不加评判，我们目前的现状是我们没有理解。不理解并不意味着你很笨或在某些方面有所欠缺。这只是过程的一部分。

When we expose ourselves to a new learning situation we must begin by accepting where we are without judgment and where we are is that we don’t get it. Not understanding does not mean that you are stupid or lacking in some way. It is just part of the process.

实际上，不理解是相当微妙的。仔细检查，就会发现它会随着时间而变化，在某个时刻，从对这种模糊定义的情况的专注中，会闪现出一些系统性正在发生的东西，即使那一刻你还不能清楚地表达那是什么。理解是突然发生的，但洞察力之前有初步的暗示。要将这些初步暗示付诸实践，需要耐心和信心。然而，如果个人不愿意或无法面对不理解的情况，整个过程就会中止。这是学习任何新事物的主要障碍。

Actually not understanding is quite subtle. Examined carefully, one finds that it changes over time and, at a certain point, from within one’s absorption with this vaguely defined situation, there arises the first glimmering that something systematic is going on even if, at that moment, you can’t yet articulate what that something is. Understanding happens suddenly but the insight is preceded by preliminary hints. Patience and confidence is required to bring these initial hints to fruition. However the entire process is aborted if the individual is unwilling or unable to face the situation of not understanding. This is the primary obstacle to learning anything new.

6.20认识论障碍

6.20Epistemological Obstacles

每种学习情况都有一系列可能遇到的障碍，教育研究领域有大量文献对学习某一概念或概念系统时遇到的障碍进行了分类。将障碍视为机遇，让我想到了法国物理学家和科学哲学家加斯通·巴什拉提出的“认识论障碍”这一观点。安娜·谢尔宾斯卡在其著作中写道：“他（巴什拉）发现，如果要发展一个新概念，就必须克服某些‘认识论’障碍。这些‘认识论障碍’是基于一些无意识的、文化习得的思维模式和对数学本质及数字、空间、原因、机会、无限等基本范畴的毫无疑问的信念的理解方式，这些方式与现代理论相比虽然不够充分，但标志着这一概念在历史上的发展。例如，学生不理解“ .999...= 1 ”，因为他们不理解完全无穷大的概念，而他们只是在重复整个数学界历史上面临的困难。”

Every learning situation has a whole collection of possible obstacles and there is a vast literature in educational research cataloging the obstacles that are associated with learning a given concept or conceptual system. Thinking about obstacles as opportunities brings me to the idea, introduced by the French physicist and philosopher of science, Gaston Bachelard, of “epistemological obstacles.”i In her book Anna Sierpinska writes, “He (Bachelard) found that students’ thinking appeared to suffer from certain ‘epistemological’ obstacles that had to be overcome if a new concept was to be developed. These ‘epistemological obstacles’ [were] ways of understanding based on some unconscious, culturally acquired schemes of thought and unquestioned beliefs about the nature of mathematics and fundamental categories such as number, space, cause, chance, infinity [that were] inadequate with respect to modern day theory [but] marked the development of the concept in history. For example students do not understand “.999… = 1” because they do not grasp the concept of completed infinity and, in that, they are merely repeating the difficulties that historically faced the mathematical community as a whole.”

这种将障碍视为认识论的概念是一种强有力的见解，Sierpinska 报告说，它引发了大量数学教育研究，人们在各种学习情况下寻找关键的认识论障碍。这个概念对我的论文很重要，原因有二。首先，它强调了概念发展与遇到和克服障碍有关的观点。其次，它强调了个人学习与科学和数学的历史进步之间的相似性，这为我关于发展、创造力和学习的所有领域都存在相似性的广义假设提供了证据。我的论文的方向也与巴什拉与他那个时代的新实证主义者的论点相似。学习不是算法；思维也不是算法。还有其他事情在发生，这是至关重要的，但非常微妙和神秘。数学教育家杜宾斯基和列文声称，“似乎一个人永远无法直接接触认知过程……但充其量只能接触到个人可以表达或理解的东西在顿悟的时刻展现出来。那一刻发生的事情似乎既难以接近又至关重要。” ii

This notion of obstacles as epistemological was a powerful insight and Sierpinska reports that it generated a great deal of research in mathematics education where one searched for key epistemological obstacles in various learning situations. The notion is important to my thesis for two reasons. First of all it underlines the view that conceptual development is concerned with meeting and overcoming obstacles. Second, it highlights the parallels between individual learning and the historical progress of science and mathematics, which provides evidence that supports my generalized hypothesis about the existence of parallels within all areas of development, creativity, and learning. The orientation of my thesis also parallels Bachelard’s argument with the neo-positivists of his time. Learning is not algorithmic; mind is not algorithmic. There is something else going on, something that is essential, but is very subtle and mysterious. The mathematics educators Dubinsky and Levin claim, “It would seem that one never has direct access to cognitive processes…but, at best, only to what an individual can articulate or demonstrate at the moment of insight itself. Precisely what occurs at that moment seems as inaccessible as it is essential.”ii

顿悟时刻是人们掌握概念或从一个概念系统到另一个概念系统进行创造性飞跃的时刻。它是深度学习的基本要素，与谢尔宾斯卡的“良好理解”概念有很多共同之处。它存在于每一个创造性行为中。它是让教育变得生动的因素。它对我们来说似乎很神秘，原因很明显，它无法被确定或推理出来。它超越了我们的分析智能——它是一个右脑现象，而不是左脑现象。

The moment of insight is the moment in which one grasps the concept or makes the creative leap from one conceptual system to another. It is the essential ingredient in deep learning, something that has a good deal in common with Sierpinska’s notion of “good understanding.” It is present in every act of creativity. It is the factor that brings education to life. It seems mysterious to us for the obvious reason that it cannot be pinned down or reasoned out. It transcends our analytic intelligence—it is a right not a left hemispheric phenomenon.

我们甚至没有意识到顿悟的那一刻，但正如杜宾斯基和莱文发现的那样，我们只能在事后意识到它。你可能会得出结论，顿悟是困难而复杂的，但恰恰相反，它是如此自然，甚至连婴儿都能做到。我们很难理解创造力，因为我们变得太复杂了。

We are not even conscious of the moment of insight but, as Dubinsky and Levin discovered, we can only be conscious of it after the fact. You might conclude that insight is difficult and complicated but, on the contrary, it is so natural that even a baby can do it. We have difficulty understanding creativity because we have become too complicated.

6.21持续学习

6.21Unstoppable Learning

Sujata Mitra 是纽卡斯尔大学的教育技术教授。他进行了一项有趣的实验，该实验向我们揭示了学习的本质。iii Mitra 在印度农村的各个贫民窟和小村庄的墙上放置了计算机。然后他离开现场，使用远程桌面监控发生的事情。这些计算机很快引起了该地区儿童的注意。不幸的是，孩子们无法轻松使用计算机，因为没有操作说明或教师，而且计算机使用的是英语，而英语是孩子们不熟悉的语言。他们必须自学英语才能使用这些机器。

Sujata Mitra is a Professor of Educational Technology at the University of Newcastle. He performed a fascinating experiment, which tells us a lot about the nature of learning.iii Mitra placed computers in a wall in various slums and small villages in rural India. Then he left the scene and monitored what happened using a remote desktop. These computers quickly attracted the attention of the children of the area. Unfortunately the children couldn’t easily use the computers because there were no operating instructions or teachers, and anyhow the computers used English, which was a language that the children were not familiar with. They would have to teach themselves English in order to use the machines.

他们做到了！他们不仅学会了所需的英语，还学会了必备的计算机知识技能。这太出乎意料、太了不起了，米特拉相信他发现了一些具有重大意义的普遍原则。“也许，”他建议，“学习可以自然发生。”“学习是教育自组织的产物。让它发生吧。”教师的作用是将其置于动作，他在这个案例中就是把这些电脑放在显眼的地方。其余的事情都由孩子们做。

And they did! Not only did they learn the English that they needed but also the computer literacy skills that were necessary. This is was so unexpected, so extraordinary, that Mitra believes that he has uncovered some universal principle of great significance. “Maybe,” he suggests, “learning can happen on its own.” “Learning is a product of educational self-organization. Let it happen.” The role of the teacher is to set it in motion, which he did in this case by planting those computers in a conspicuous place. The children did the rest.

在我讨论深度思考的基本属性时，我曾多次提到学习是不可阻挡的，是大脑自然运转的方式。我们再来考虑一下婴儿的成长过程。如我之前所说，孩子并没有决定要不要学习，成长就是学习。每个孩子的成长阶段都包含着一个紧张的学习过程。孩子在早年会做出哪些惊人的发现：他们学会辨别单个物体，学习顺序和数字，学习语言，学习走路，创造自我。这些成就中的每一项都是非凡的。我们将它们视为理所当然，以至于不会停下来思考它们有多么非凡。它们与我们最伟大的艺术家和科学家所取得的伟大创造性飞跃处于同一水平。然而，我们都能做到——我们都学会了走路和说话。所以我们都是非凡的——每个孩子都是这种创造潜力的继承者。

This idea that learning is unstoppable, the natural way that the mind functions, has come up repeatedly in my discussion of the basic properties of deep thinking in various contexts. Consider, again, the development of an infant. As I said earlier, the child does not decide to learn; development is learning. Every child’s formative years consists of an intense process of learning. What amazing discoveries children make in those early years: they learn to discern individual objects; they learn order and number; they learn language, they learn to walk; they create a self. Each one of these accomplishments is extraordinary. We take them so much for granted that we don’t stop to consider how extraordinary they are. They are at the same level as the great creative leaps taken by our very greatest artists and scientists. Yet we all manage them—we all learn to walk and to talk. So we are all extraordinary—every child is the heir to this creative potential.

婴儿最引人注目的地方在于，他们基本上是学习型的小生命——不断参与当下发生的事情，不断试图勾勒出他们与周围环境的关系。他们是年轻的科学家，系统地探索着他们的世界，这个世界同时也是由他们创造的。太多人认为孩子在某些方面存在缺陷，我们作为成年人的工作就是让他们和我们一模一样。但孩子，尤其是婴儿，拥有成年人并不总是欣赏的智慧。他们可以教给我们的东西和我们可以教给他们的东西一样多。

What is so striking about infants is that they are basically little learning beings—continuously participating in what is happening at the moment, continuously attempting to map out their relationship with their immediate surroundings. They are young scientists systematically exploring their world, a world that is simultaneously being created by them. Too many people believe that children are deficient in some way and that our job as adults is to make them exactly like us. But children, especially infants, possess an intelligence that adults don’t always appreciate. They have as much to teach us as we have to teach them.

但学习并非只适用于婴儿。科学研究​​背后的基本驱动力是需要理解，而理解是通过发展适当的概念结构来实现的；换句话说，研究就是学习正确的思考世界的方式。因此，科学的发展与儿童的发展之间存在着天然的相似性，尽管这乍一看似乎很了不起。此外，人们发现，同一种发展学习是所有生命的本质。毕竟，如果进化不是适应、成长和发展的历史，那么进化又是什么呢？如果不是学习，那么适应又意味着什么呢？因此，学习是生活的中心，因此，我们从一开始就适应学习。这是我们生物学最基本的层面。DNA 本身就是一种学习和持续变化的机制。

But learning is not just for infants. The basic drive behind scientific research is the need to understand which is actualized through the development of appropriate conceptual structures; in other words, research is learning the right way to think about the world. Thus there is a natural parallel between the development of science and the development of children as remarkable as that initially seems. Moreover one finds the same kind of developmental learning is the essence of all life. After all what is evolution if it is not a history of adaptation, growth and development and what does adaptation mean if not learning? Thus learning is central to life, and, as a result we are attuned to learning at the most basic levels of our biology. DNA is itself a mechanism for learning and continual change.

再往另一个更基础、对某些人来说可能有点牵强的层面看，现代物理学和宇宙学向我们揭示的物理宇宙的演化本身可以看作是一种学习形式。这将使我们以一种不同的方式思考宇宙历史。电子和质子学会了如何结合成氢原子的单一结构。氢和氧学会了如何结合在一起形成水。某些蛋白质学会了如何结合形成细胞。宇宙的历史就是这种飞跃的历史，这一点毋庸置疑。大多数人不会在这种情况下使用“学习”这个词，但思考所有这些截然不同的情况（我将它们统称为“学习”以强调）之间的类比，将使我们洞悉一般情况（即学习是什么）和具体情况（如儿童发展、进化或科学史）。

Moving to another level, which is more basic and may seem a little far-fetched to some, the evolution of the physical universe as revealed to us in modern physics and cosmology can itself be seen as a form of learning. This will give us a different way of thinking about cosmic history. Electrons and protons learned how to combine into the singular structure of a hydrogen atom. Hydrogen and oxygen learned how to get together to make water. Certain proteins learned how to combine to form cells. That the history of the cosmos is a history of such leaps is not in question. Most people would not use the word learning in this context but thinking about the analogies between all of these radically different situations (which I emphasize by calling them all “learning”) will give us insights into both the general situation—what learning is— and specific situations like child development, evolution, or the history of science.

学习是所有生命和宇宙本身的基础。有人可能会说，“学习就是存在”。学习、成长、进化就是活着——这是生命的本质特征。生命是千变万化的结果。生命是不断变化的，从一开始，从大爆炸和时间、空间、能量和物质的创造开始，它就一直在变化。我们所知道和经历的一切都存在了。在这个持续的创造过程中，我们学到了教训，结构也获得了一定的稳定性。我们可以从物理学和宇宙学到生物学和心理学等所有科学中辨别出学习的机制。

Learning is basic to all life and to the cosmos itself. One might say, “Learning is being.” To learn, to grow, to evolve is to be alive—it is the essential characteristic of life. Life is the flowering of a thousand possibilities. It is constant change and has been so from the very beginning, from the big bang and the creation of time, space, energy, and matter. Everything that we know and experience came into existence. In the course of this ongoing creativity lessons were learned and structures attained some stability. We can discern the mechanisms of learning in all the sciences from physics and cosmology to biology and psychology.

通常，我们认为学习是意识的结果——我们认为它是思想和经验的结果。然而，本书所描述的学习比这更基本。事实上，我们真的应该扭转局面。意识本身是学习的，是在进化过程中的某个特定阶段历史性地产生的。很难想象没有语言的思考，即使这种语言不是由文字组成，而是音乐或数学。然而，文字、音符和数字都是在历史的某个时刻创造出来的，可能基于我们与生俱来的一些先天认知结构。换句话说，这些文字无法被书写；这些想法无法被表达；如果不是因为一个可以追溯到时间起源的学习过程。

Normally we think of learning as an outcome of consciousness—we think of it as an outcome of thought and experience. However learning, the way it is described in this book, is more basic than that. In fact we really should turn things around. Consciousness itself is learned and arose historically at a definite stage in the ongoing process of evolution. It is hard to imagine thinking without language even if this language is not made up of words but is musical or mathematical. However words, notes, and numbers were all created at a given moment of history possibly based on some innate cognitive structures that we are born with. In other words these words could not be written; these ideas could not be expressed; if it were not for a learning process that stretches back to the beginnings of time.

尽管如此，每个世代的每个人仍然在学习和完善词语和数字。它们需要变成“我的词语”或“我的数字”。它们将永远保留这两个维度——个人维度和社会维度。社会维度往往显得客观，因此人们认为学习意味着掌握社会共识，这往往感觉像是一种客观现实。他们没有意识到，有必要了解词语的含义，甚至更好地了解词语背后的含义。意义总是包含主观因素。学习跨越客观和主观；它涉及对象和过程。

Nevertheless words and numbers are still learned and refined by each individual in every generation. They need to be turned into “my words” or “my numbers.” They will always retain those two dimensions—call them the personal and the social. The social dimension often appears to be objective and so people think that learning means grasping the social consensus, which often feels like an objective reality. They don’t realize that it is necessary to get the meaning of the words or, even better, the meaning behind the words. Meaning always includes a subjective element. Learning spans the objective and the subjective; it involves objects and processes.

6.22什么是教学？

6.22What is Teaching?

一个立即浮现出来的问题是：“如果学习是普遍的，那么老师在哪里或是什么？”我的答案与米特拉在前面提到的实验中获得的答案相同。没有必要有老师，至少不是通常意义上的老师，我们认为老师就是把知识塞进空脑袋里的人。老师实际上是必不可少的，我将在第七章中讨论这一点。但老师的角色需要重新审视。

One question that arises immediately is this, “If learning is universal then where or what is the teacher?” My answer is the same as the one Mitra obtained in the experiment mentioned earlier. There is no need for a teacher, at least not in the usual sense of the word, where we think of someone stuffing knowledge into empty heads. The teacher is actually essential, as I shall discuss in chapter seven. But the role of the teacher needs to be reexamined.

同样，也不需要存在或力量超越自然来推动进化过程或任何其他学习情况。创造力是自然界的固有属性，也是人类的固有属性。我们必须重新思考创造力与分析智能之间的关系。创造力才是最重要的，它更普遍、更根本。

Similarly there is no need for a being or force that stands outside of nature and drives the evolutionary process or any other learning situation. Creativity is built-in to the natural world as it is to human beings. We must rethink the relationship between creativity and the analytic intelligence. It is creativity that comes first, that is more general and more fundamental.

我们没有必要将学习限制在老师和学生之间传递信息这一简单概念上。我们必须重新定义“教学”和“老师”的含义。就像孩子学走路一样，我们都被超出我们意识控制的力量驱使着去学习。如果说有什么是“老师”，那就是这种学习的动力。为了更生动地说明这一点，我们可以说，我们基本上都是这种学习动力的表现——它是我们构成中最基本的元素。那些在这条道路上帮助我们、帮助我们释放学习天赋的人，我们称他们为老师。这是一个微妙而有益的角色，并不局限于教室或大学演讲厅。我从仔细观察婴儿以及与儿童和学生的互动中学到了一些非常深刻的教训。只要你准备好了并且愿意接受，任何人都可以成为你的老师。

There is no need to restrict what we mean by learning to the mere transfer of information from teacher to student. We have to redefine what we mean by “teaching” and “teacher.” Like the child learning to walk we are all driven to learn by forces beyond our conscious control. If anything is the “teacher” it is this drive to learn. To make this even more dramatic we could say that we are all basically an expression of this drive to learn—that it is the most basic element in our make-up. Those who aid us on this path, those who help us to liberate our natural propensity to learn, we call our teachers. This is a subtle and rewarding role and it is not restricted to the classroom or the university lecture hall. I have learned some very profound lessons from carefully observing babies and interacting with children and students. When you are ready and receptive anyone can become your teacher.

我之前说过，学习和创造力之间几乎没有什么区别，所以如果我们都有学习的动力，那么我们基本上都是有创造力的。创造性学习与其说是我们做的事情，不如说是通过我们自己发生的事情——一种对超越我们个人的更大事物的开放。当然，我们不能只是坐着等待创造力的到来。我们必须积极地参与我们周围的世界。学习和创造力是我们与生命本身的动态力量统一的表现。

I said earlier that there is little difference between learning and creativity and so if we are all driven to learn then we are all basically creative. Creative learning is not so much something that we do as it is something that happens through us—an opening up to something larger than our individual selves. Of course we can’t just sit around waiting for creativity to strike. We must actively engage with the world around us. Learning and creativity are an expression of our unity with the dynamic forces of life itself.

学习是自然而不可避免的。实际上，没有停滞，也没有处于永久平衡状态的时间。我们要么在成长和学习，要么处于衰退和衰败的状态。学习以自然的方式在我们内部和外部展开。我们确实可以阻碍它或试图强迫它朝着某个预先设定的方向发展，但这会扭曲这个过程。学习在我们内心自然展开，但这并不意味着它不需要任何努力。相反，学习需要付出巨大的努力，但正如我们在讨论创造力时所看到的那样，这是一种非常微妙的努力。

Learning is natural and inevitable. There is really no stasis, no time when we are in a state of permanent equilibrium. Either we are growing and learning, or we are in a state of decline and decay. Learning unfolds within and outside of us in a natural way. It is true that we can impede it or try to force it into some preconceived direction but this distorts the process. Learning unfolds naturally within us yet this does not mean that it does not take any effort. On the contrary learning takes great effort but, as we saw in our discussion of creativity, it is a very subtle kind of effort.

当你在学习某样东西但还不知道它时，你瞄准的状态是未知的和难以想象的。当孩子学习数数时，他们可能从看芝麻街开始，死记硬背“数数”：一、二、三、四等等；先到十，然后到二十。他们记住了列表，但他们仍然不知道它的意义——他们不知道如何数数。然而，重复数数、玩各种数字游戏和观看成人进行各种计数活动，会将所有孩子带到他们创建一个内部系统（计数的概念系统）的阶段，并突然进入一个全新的计数、加、减、乘整数的世界。他们已经掌握了现代文化的一个基本方面；他们赋予了“数字”意义，可以说是定义了它。当这一令人难以置信的飞跃发生时你知道，十颗花生中的花生数量与十颗弹珠中的弹珠数量相同。你可以回答“最大的数字是多少？”这个问题：“没有；它们会一直存在下去。”

When you are learning something but don’t yet know it, the state that you are aiming at is unknown and unimaginable. When learning to count the child may begin by watching Sesame Street and repeating by rote the “counting numbers”: one, two, three, four, and so on; first up to ten and later up to twenty. They memorize the list but they still don’t know it’s significance—they don’t know how to count. Yet repeating the counting numbers, playing various number games, and watching adults perform various counting activities bring all children to the stage when they create an internal system—the conceptual system of counting—and abruptly enter into an entirely new world of counting, adding, subtracting, and multiplying of whole numbers. They have acquired an essential aspect of modern culture; they have given meaning to “number,” defined it, you might say. When this incredible leap occurs you know that there are the same number of peanuts in a collection of ten peanuts as there are marbles in a collection of ten marbles. You can respond to the question, “What is the largest number?” by saying, “There is none; they go on forever.”

将学习视为一个事件是本文所阐述观点的关键，因为正如爱因斯坦在相对论中教导我们的那样，世界的元素就是事件。世界的特点是变化和过程。与物体不同，事件是发生的，也就是说，它们是动态的，因此事件世界适合描述本身就是动态的现实。看看孩子、艺术家和科学家，看看生命和宇宙本身的进化。到处你都会看到同样的事情在发生，到处你都会看到学习的活力。

Thinking about learning as an event is key to the view that is developed in these pages because, as Einstein taught us in the Theory of Relativity, the elements of the world are events. The world is characterized by change, by process. Events, unlike objects, happen, that is, they are dynamic so a world of events is suited to a description of a reality that is itself dynamic. Look at children, artists and scientists, and at the evolution of life and of the universe itself. Everywhere you will see the same thing going on, everywhere you will see the dynamism of learning.

当一个孩子迈出我们平淡地称之为学习数数的重大一步时，其基本过程与第一个水生生物适应陆地生活的过程相同。同样，一个孩子说出第一个词时，也重演了最初发现语言的过程。这都是学习，无论何时发生，都包含着奇迹的元素。每次发生这种情况时，都会有一种认知的震惊，一种回家的感觉，一种获得新的稳定，一种免受无常威胁的保护绿洲。

When a child makes the great leap that we prosaically call learning the counting numbers, the same fundamental process is at play as when the first aquatic life adapted to life on dry land. Similarly a child who utters her first word has recapitulated the initial discovery of language. It is all learning and whenever it happens it contains elements of the miraculous. Every time that happens there is a shock of recognition, a feeling of coming home, of attaining a new stability, an oasis of protection from the threat of impermanence.

i谢尔宾斯卡 (1994) p. 133–135。

i Sierpinska (1994) p. 133–135.

ii Sierpinska (1994) 第 120 页。

ii Sierpinska (1994) p. 120.

iii米特拉的演讲荣获 2013 年 TED 奖，您可以在 YouTube 上观看该演讲：

iii Mitra won the 2013 TED prize for the talk that can be seen on YouTube at:

www.youtube.com/watch?v=HE5GX3U3BYQ

www.youtube.com/watch?v=HE5GX3U3BYQ

第七章

Chapter 7

良好的教学

Good Teaching

7.1介绍

7.1Introduction

如果不讨论教学，几乎不可能谈论学习，因此我将在本章中专门讨论教学。什么是好的教学？好的教学涉及实现深度学习。这种教学本身就是一种创造性活动。为了培养深度学习，教师必须了解他人和自己的学习过程的动态。每门学科、每节课和每个学生对这样的教师来说都是一个挑战，这个挑战需要创造性的解决方案。学生对学科的每一个洞察都伴随着教师对学生理解的洞察。

It is scarcely possible to talk about learning without also discussing teaching and so I shall devote this chapter to a discussion of teaching. What is good teaching? Good teaching involves enabling deep learning. This kind of teaching is a creative activity in its own right. In order to nurture deep learning the teacher must be aware of the dynamics of the learning process in others and in themselves. Every subject, every class, and every student is a challenge for such a teacher, a challenge that calls for a creative resolution. Every insight into the subject on the part of the student is accompanied by an insight into the student’s understanding on the part of the teacher.

我们在第六章中发现，学习是不可阻挡的，是自然的，而教学是次要的。学习的需要和学习的冲动是普遍存在的。没有这种驱动力，生命就无法生存，宇宙也不会像现在这样充满活力。没有同样的普遍教学倾向。然而，教学的愿望，甚至教学的需要，可能非常强烈——想想父母教孩子走路或说话。

We discovered in chapter six that learning is unstoppable, that it is natural, and that teaching is secondary. The need to learn, and the compulsion to do so, is universal. Without this drive life would not survive and the universe would not be the dynamic environment that it is. There is not the same universal tendency to teach. Nevertheless the desire to teach, even the need to teach, can be extremely powerful—think of parents teaching their children to walk or to talk.

没有人可以代替别人学习。你不可能神奇地把理解传授给别人。正如我反复强调的那样，学习本质上是困难的。学生必须自己面对困难，不能把它委托给别人，即使是世界上最好、最鼓舞人心的老师也不能。在老师这边，他们必须明白自己的正确角色，显然不能代替学生学习，也不能神奇地消除学习的所有障碍。相反，它应该支持和帮助学生。鼓励学生完成艰难的学习任务；帮助他们面对必须面对的事情；将整个经历视为一次令人振奋的旅程而不是负担；向学生坦诚承认每个人——甚至是老师——在自己的学习经历中都会遇到挫折和障碍。

No one can learn for someone else. You cannot magically impart understanding to another. Learning, as I have repeatedly stressed, is intrinsically difficult. The student must face that difficulty on his or her own and cannot delegate it to anyone else not even to the best and most inspiring teacher in the world. On their side the teacher must understand their proper role, which evidently cannot be to learn for the student or to magically remove all impediments to learning. Rather it is to support and encourage the student in the difficult task of learning; to help them face what must be faced; to frame the whole experience so that it is seen as an exhilarating journey rather than a burden; to admit openly to the students that everyone—even a teacher—experiences setbacks and barriers in his own learning experiences.

柏拉图对苏格拉底教学法的描述为我们提供了一个很好的教学模式。它包括提出问题并引出答案。当然，任何老问题都行不通。问题必须针对学生、主题和情况量身定制。要以这种方式工作，需要对当前情况做出创造性和自发的反应。在最佳和最聪明的情况下，在正确的时间提出正确的问题会激发教师试图提出的洞察力。苏格拉底一直认为他的角色是助产士。他只是帮助学生有意识地意识到她一直隐含地知道的事情。无论这种预知是否真实，它都准确地表明了创造过程的主观感受，并承认学习不是信息的传递，而是洞察力的创造性过程。它把老师和学生各自的角色放在正确的角度。

A good model for teaching was given to us by Plato’s account of the Socratic method. It consists of asking questions and eliciting a response. Of course not any old question will do. Questions must be tailored to the student, the subject, and the situation. To work in this way involves a creative and spontaneous response to the immediate situation. At its best and most brilliant the right question at the right time evokes the insight that the teacher is trying to bring forth. Socrates always maintained that his role was that of a midwife. He was just helping the student to become consciously aware of something that she knew implicitly all the time. Whether this foreknowledge is real or not, it accurately suggests the subjective feeling of the creative process and it acknowledges that learning is not the transfer of information but a creative process of insight. It puts the respective roles of the teacher and student into the correct perspective.

也许将教学视为学习的另一种形式是最好的方式——老师也通过学生的学习而学习。回想一下我在第五章中讨论过的不同类型的学习。如果我把教学也加到列表中，可能会更完整。数学和其他学科的教师常常报告说，教授某一学科的知识将他们的理解提高到了一个新的水平。我记得在加州大学伯克利分校担任助教时教一门分析课，突然意识到我现在理解了连续性的概念和相关定理，而我以前的理解则变得琐碎而肤浅。学习一门新学科的好方法是教该学科的课程。

Perhaps the best way to think about teaching is as another form of learning—the teacher also learns something through the learning of the student. Recall the different kinds of learning that I discussed in chapter five. It might have been more complete if I had added teaching to the list. It is common for teachers of mathematics and other disciplines to report that teaching a subject raised their understanding to a new level. I remember teaching an analysis class as a teaching assistant at the University of California at Berkeley and suddenly realizing that I now understood the concept of continuity and the theorems associated with it in a way that made my previous understanding trivial and superficial. A great way to learn a new subject is to teach a course in the subject.

当然，教学也可以被视为一种学习形式。好的老师必须能够把自己置于学生的立场上。用我使用的词汇来说，他或她必须能够通过学生的操作概念系统来看待情况。也许这与同理心或镜像神经元有关，但这绝对是一种不太常见的技能。原因是原因在于，一名优秀的教师必须能够在一个模糊的环境中发挥作用，一方面她自己的理解，另一方面她的学生的理解也各不相同。这并非易事。更常见的情况是，教师认为自己看待事物的方式是“正确的方式”，或“唯一的方式”，因此完全无法想象别人会以不同的方式看待事物。结果，学生会觉得自己能力不足或愚蠢，这只会阻碍他或她的进步。

Of course there are other ways in which teaching can be considered a form of learning. Good teachers must be able to project themselves into the position of the student. In the vocabulary that I have been using, he or she must be able to see the situation through the operative conceptual system of the student. Maybe this has to do with empathy or mirror neurons but it is definitely a skill that is not very common. The reason for this is that a good teacher must be able to function in an ambiguous situation which contains her own understanding on the one hand and the varied understandings of her students, on the other. This is not an easy thing to do. Much more common is for the teacher to feel that her way of looking at things is the “right way,” or the “only way,” and therefore to be totally unable to imagine how anyone could see things differently. As a result the student is made to feel inadequate or stupid which only impedes his or her progress.

7.2有了互联网为什么还需要老师？

7.2Why Have Teachers When You Have the Internet?

如今，有人会问为什么还需要老师。他们说，没有老师，学习也可以进行。如果教育仅仅涉及信息传递，那么通过电子方式进行不是更有效率吗？比如，在微积分教学方面，我们为什么不把最好的微积分老师的讲座制作成视频，并通过互联网让每个人都能观看呢？许多大学已经将许多课程放在了网上。还有许多有趣的计算机课程，这些课程不仅向学生介绍必修材料，还指导他们完成这些材料，并迫使他们在进入新阶段之前展示对初步阶段的掌握。这些课程的优势远远超出了传统课堂所能提供的优势。例如，教学可以更加个性化。它可以针对具有不同优势和背景的学生量身定制，而传统的讲座课程往往是千篇一律的。学生们通常喜欢计算机化教育，因为它让他们可以自由安排自己的时间表，按照自己的节奏前进。对于面临日益繁重的财政限制的机构来说，计算机化教育可能感觉是天赐的解决方案。

There are people today who ask why teachers are even necessary. They say that learning can happen without teachers. If education merely involves the transfer of information, then wouldn’t it be more efficient to do this electronically? When it comes to the teaching of calculus, say, why don’t we just make a video of the lectures of the best calculus teacher and make it available to everyone over the internet? Many universities are already making many of their courses available online. There are also many interesting computer based courses that not only expose the students to the required material but also guide them through this material and force them to demonstrate a mastery of preliminary stages before they are allowed to proceed to the new step. Such courses have strengths that go beyond what the traditional classroom can offer. For example instruction can be more individualized. It can be tailored to students with different strengths and backgrounds as opposed to traditional lecture courses that tend to be one-size-fits-all affairs. Students often enjoy computerized education because it gives them the freedom to set their own schedule and advance at their own pace. For institutions facing increasingly onerous financial constraints computerizing education may feel like a solution made in heaven.

管理人员和政客们常常认为，计算机化教育意味着以更合理的价格提供更好的教育。教育系统将来会朝着这个方向大步迈进吗？成千上万的教育工作者会因此失业吗？有强大的力量在推动社会朝着这个方向发展。因此，教师和整个社会可能被迫面对以下问题本书中讨论的正是这一问题。教育的目标和目的是什么？什么是学习？教师的角色是什么？教师的存在对学习有何贡献？

Administrators and politicians often think that computerized education means better education at a more reasonable price. Will the education system move in this direction in a major way in the future? Will ten of thousands of educators lose their jobs in the process? There are powerful forces pushing society in this direction. As a consequence, teachers and society in general may be forced to confront the questions that I am discussing in this book. What is the goal and purpose of education? What is learning? What is the role of the teacher and what does her physical presence contribute to learning?

如果不同时考虑教学的性质和价值，我们就永远无法就计算机辅助教育的适当作用进行深思熟虑的讨论。我说我对“深度学习”感兴趣，因此我也必须明确我所说的“良好教学”是什么意思。如果我们所说的教育指的是信息的传递，如果我们指的是死记硬背或掌握标准算法，那么技术似乎是可行的方法。要理解由人类授课的价值，我们必须将教师视为“深度学习”的促进者。当教师开始将他们的主要任务视为促进学生的创造性发展时，他们在教育过程中的重要作用就会变得清晰。如果他们仅仅将自己视为信息传递的促进者，那么更有效地完成工作的机器总有一天会取代他们。当然，好老师仍然可以适当地使用技术。问题在于，拥有人类教师的定期和直接干预的价值，而不是让他们去开发软件或在线回复学生。

We will never be able to have a thoughtful discussion about the appropriate role of computer-aided education without a simultaneous consideration of the nature and value of teaching. I said that I was interested in “deep learning” and it follows that I must also specify what I mean by “good teaching.” If by education we are referring to the transfer of information, if we mean rote learning or the mastery of standard algorithms, then it seems possible that technology is the way to go. To appreciate the value of having a human being teaching a class we must look on the teacher as a facilitator of “deep learning.” When teachers begin to see their main task as fostering the creative development of their students then their vital role in the educational process will become clear. If they see themselves merely as the facilitators of information transfer then machines that do the job more efficiently will someday replace them. Of course good teachers can still make appropriate use of technology. The question at issue is really the value of having the regular and proximate intervention of human teachers as opposed to relegating them to creating software or responding to students online.

良好的教学包括培养深度学习。它本身就是一种非常有创意的活动，它涉及到我讨论过的学习变化的助产士：掌握概念和概念系统，尤其是从一个概念系统过渡到另一个概念系统。有一件事是显而易见的。你不能教你自己没有掌握的东西。你不能教你自己只掌握了一点的概念。我们只需要考虑一下在决定性的小学阶段经常被认为是数学教学的东西。有太多的人在这个阶段教授数学，几乎没有或根本没有受过学科训练，他们自己患有“数学焦虑”，并坦率地承认，“我从来就不擅长数学”。这些人并不真正理解他们在教什么，也不理解为什么这很重要。因此，经常传递给学生的​​是模糊或混乱的数学思想，焦虑的气氛一直存在，从老师到学生，让数学看起来令人不快，甚至令人生畏。因此，数学让许多聪明的孩子（甚至成年人）感到害怕。

Good teaching consists of nurturing deep learning. It is very much a creative activity in its own right, one that involves being a midwife to the kinds of learning changes that I have discussed: mastering concepts and conceptual systems, and especially, transitioning from one conceptual system to another. One thing is immediately clear. You cannot teach what you yourself have not mastered. You cannot teach concepts that you yourself only grasp weakly. One need only consider what too often passes for the teaching of mathematics at the decisive elementary school level. There are too many people who teach mathematics at this level with little or no disciplinary training, who themselves suffer from “mathematics anxiety” and freely admit, “I was never very good at mathematics.” These people don’t really understand what they are teaching or why it is important. As a consequence what often gets transmitted to students are vague or confused mathematical ideas with an ever present aura of anxiety, projected from teacher to student, that makes the subject seem unpleasant and even threatening. As a consequence mathematics is scary to many intelligent children (and adults, for that matter).

如果教师对学科概念的掌握不够，他们就必须依靠死记硬背。我记得几年前，我孩子的一位小学老师告诉我，她是如何用维恩图来解释集合的性质的。通常使用的图表包含三个重叠的圆圈，每个圆圈代表不同的集合或集合。我问她，当只有两个集合时，她用什么图。她大吃一惊，坚持认为必须有三个圆圈，而不是两个或四个。显然，她记住了一些处理维恩图的“规则”。作为概念辅助手段引入课程的东西已经退化为另一个需要死记硬背的任意事实。这是数学和科学教学的典型情况，其结果是学生学习困难，这是普遍承认的。这并不是说这门学科本身很难；而是教师没有接受过适当的教育，因此他们反过来让学生失望。只有通过更好的教学和教师培训才能解决这些问题。所需的教师培训应以“深度学习的良好教学”为目标。它将强调教师及其学生的概念发展和概念变革。

If teachers have little conceptual grasp of the subject they must rely on rote. I can remember years ago one of my children’s elementary school teachers telling me how she was using Venn diagrams to explain the properties of sets. Usually the diagram that is used contains three overlapping circles, each representing a different set or collection. I asked what diagram she used when there were only two sets. She was taken aback and maintained that there had to be exactly three circles—not two or four. Clearly what had happened was that she had memorized some “rules” for handling Venn diagrams. What had been introduced into the curriculum as a conceptual aid had degenerated into another arbitrary fact to be learned by rote. This is typical of what happens with the teaching of mathematics and science and the result is the difficulties in student learning that are generally acknowledged to exist. It is not that the subject is intrinsically so difficult; it is that the teachers have not been educated properly and therefore they in their turn fail their students. The solution to these problems will only come with better teaching and teacher training. The kind of teacher training that is required would aim at “good teaching for deep learning.” It would emphasize conceptual development and conceptual change for both teachers and their students.

数学的奇妙之处在于，我们经常会遇到非常聪明、对数学充满好奇的孩子。他们能够提出好问题；这些问题具有实质性的数学内容，因此必然是微妙而困难的。为什么 −2 × −3 = +6？为什么不能对负数开平方？表达式1/3 = .333…中的点是什么意思？为什么 π 是一个数字？什么是机会？这些开创性的问题之一是本书中反复出现的问题：“什么是数字？”所有这些问题都很精彩，但没有一个有简单、现成的答案。每一个问题都邀请人们更深入地探索数学，但除非老师认可这些问题，否则这些问题不会有任何进展，而如果老师自己从未考虑过这些问题，她就无法认可这些问题。

One wonderful thing about mathematics is that it is common to encounter children who are very bright and curious about mathematics. They are capable of asking good questions; questions that have substantive mathematical content and so are necessarily subtle and difficult. Why is −2 × −3 = +6? Why can’t you take the square root of a negative number? What do the dots mean in the expression 1/3 = .333…? Why is π a number? What is chance? One of these seminal questions is the one that has been coming up repeatedly in this book, “What is a number?” All of these questions are wonderful but none of them have easy, pat answers. Each one is an invitation to explore mathematics more deeply but they cannot lead anywhere unless the teacher validates them and the teacher cannot validate them if she has never considered such questions herself.

数学是可以谈论的、有趣的东西，数学中存在一些容易陈述但无人知晓答案的问题，这种想法对于大多数课堂来说都是陌生的。通常，以时间紧迫或将问题推迟到以后再问（不幸的是，这种情况几乎从未发生过）来结束这些问题更为容易。然后，学生们了解到，提出“好”问题（即开放式和概念性的问题）不受欢迎，他们通常会以结束这些问题作为回应。当这种情况发生时，真是令人难过。许多聪明的孩子就这样迷失在科学中。

The very idea that mathematics is something that you can talk about, something that is actually interesting, that there are easy-to-state problems in mathematics that no one knows the answer to, is alien to most classrooms. It is often easier to close down such questions by pleading time constraints or by putting off the question to some later time (which, unfortunately, almost never comes). Students then learn that asking “good” questions, that is questions that are open-ended and are conceptual, is not appreciated and they often respond by closing down. It is terribly sad when this happens. Many bright kids are lost to science in this way.

7.3教学理念

7.3Teaching Concepts
