让我们回到一个反复出现的观点，即创造性学习总是具有挑战性的，并考虑教师在这一背景下的作用。现在没有人可以强迫别人学习，也没有人可以为别人学习——每个人都必须为自己学习。认知变化发生在我们自己的头脑和大脑中——目前还没有人能进入我们的大脑并对我们的大脑回路进行必要的改变。因此，学习必须是主动的；没有被动学习这回事。这对教师的角色有何影响？人们可能会简单地得出结论，如果学生只能为自己学习，就不需要老师了，但这种回答是不幸的、过于简单和误导的。良好的学习既困难又个人化，这一事实使得优秀的老师变得更加重要。任务越困难，越需要有一位向导——一位过去走过相同道路、记得问题和潜在陷阱的人，他可以说：“我明白你的意思，但你为什么不试着用以下的方式思考呢？”好老师不能代替学生学习，但她可以在遇到困难时激励和鼓励他们。

Let’s go back to a point that has been coming up over and over again, namely, that creative learning is always challenging, and consider the role of the teacher in this context. Now no one can make a person learn and no one can learn for someone else—everyone has to learn for himself or herself. Cognitive changes happen in our own mind and brain—no one as yet can step into our brains and make the requisite changes to our brain circuits. As a consequence, learning must be active; there is no such thing as passive learning. What are the implications for the role of the teacher? One might simply conclude that if the student can only learn for herself, there is no need for the teacher but this response would be unfortunate, simplistic, and misleading. The fact that good learning is difficult and personal makes the good teacher all the more important. The more difficult the task the more important it is to have a guide—someone who has covered the same terrain in the past and remembers the problems and potential pitfalls, who can say, “I see where you are coming from but why don’t you try to think of it in the following way?” The good teacher cannot learn for her students but she can inspire them and encourage them when things get tough.

学习没有捷径。你如何从将数字视为计数数字转变为将数字视为分数？你如何实现这一飞跃？你如何帮助别人实现这一飞跃？说“这很明显。”或“这很显然”之类的话肯定没有帮助。逻辑的。”整个问题在于它对学生来说不明显或不合逻辑。一般来说，理解不仅仅取决于分析智力；你无法通过推理实现概念的改变。现在的情况是，学生过去有一种对数字很有帮助的思维方式。然后，她面临着一种新的情况，这种思维方式不起作用，她面临着挑战，需要获得一种全新的思考数字世界的方式。提出挑战的是老师，要求学生学会以不同的方式思考。这个过程从老师开始，老师通过提出学生在现有数学发展水平上无法满足的要求来为学习做好准备。

There is no royal road to learning. How do you go from thinking of a number as a counting number to thinking of a number as a fraction? How do you make that leap? How do you help someone else make that leap? It certainly does not help to say things like, “It’s obvious.” or “It’s logical.” The whole problem is that it is not obvious or logical to the student. In general understanding does not only depend on the analytic intelligence; you cannot reason your way to conceptual change. The situation that presents itself is that the student has a way of thinking about numbers that has served her well in the past. Then she is presented with a new situation in which this way of thinking does not work and is challenged to acquire a totally new way of thinking about the world of numbers. It is the teacher who presents the challenge, who demands that the student learn to think differently. The process begins with the teacher who sets the stage for learning by making a demand that the student cannot meet at their present level of mathematical development.

我之前提到过，我们错误地认为教育只关乎获得，而我们忘记了，教育同样会让我们失去这种认识：我们目前的概念系统是思考情况的唯一方式。放弃来之不易的思维方式是很难的。教师最初的作用是破坏学生认知平衡的消极作用。数学教育家大卫·托尔和埃迪·格雷有一个很好的例子，说明学生不愿意放弃熟悉和舒适的观点会带来哪些困难。这个学生非常擅长加法。她为这项技能感到自豪，并因此得到了丰厚的回报。当乘法以重复加法的形式引入时，她（相当合理地）通过将每个乘法问题转化为加法问题来乘法。后来，当面对更复杂的乘法问题时，这种方法首先变得繁重，最终完全崩溃。这里的问题不是孩子笨——而是她对加法产生了不恰当的依赖。老师需要帮助她认识到，她以前的思维方式并不适合新的乘法环境，并温和地帮助她学会以新的方式看待事物——你不必回到加法来解决每个乘法问题。

I mentioned earlier our erroneous sense that education is exclusively about gaining and that we forget that it is equally about losing our sense that our current conceptual system is the only way to think about the situation. It’s hard to give up your hard-won ways of thinking. The initial role of the teacher is the negative one of breaking down the student’s cognitive equilibrium. The mathematics educators David Tall and Eddie Grayi have a great example of the difficulties that arise out a student’s unwillingness to let go of a familiar and comfortable point of view. This particular student was really good at adding. She was proud of this skill and had been well rewarded for it. When multiplication was introduced as repeated addition she (quite reasonably) multiplied by translating every multiplication problem into a problem in addition. Later, when faced with more complicated problems in multiplication, this approach first became onerous and eventually broke down completely. The problem here was not that the child was stupid—it was that she had become inappropriately attached to addition. The teacher needed to help her see that her old way of thinking was not suitable to the new environment of multiplication and gently help her to learn to see things in a new way—you don’t have to go back to addition to solve every multiplication problem.

通过意识到对学生提出的隐性要求，教师能够理解其中一些学生将经历的困难。“最好的”学生不一定是那些最容易和最有效地掌握新程序的学生。最好的学生可能会在新概念方面遇到严重困难，因为她最清楚这些问题和潜在的陷阱。毕竟，为什么2/3是一个数字？为什么−2 × −3 = +6？这些都是数学上有趣的问题。只有非常聪明的孩子才会被这里的难题困扰。

By becoming aware of the demands that are implicitly being made of the student, the teacher is in a position to appreciate the struggles that some of them will experience. The “best” students are not necessarily those that grasp the new procedures most readily and efficiently. The best student may well have serious trouble with the new concept because she sees the problems and potential pitfalls most clearly. After all why is 2/3 a number? Why is −2 × −3 = +6? These are mathematically interesting questions. It takes a really bright child to be troubled by the difficulty here.

只有当我们考虑自己对问题情况的反应时，我们才会理解老师的作用。假设我必须在家里做一些小而陌生的维修——这是我不太擅长的事情。我试着做，但不可避免地会出现一些我没有预见到的事情。如果我不能马上解决问题，我常常会很烦躁——只是不知道如何做对让我很烦恼，为了打破紧张，我可能会做一些冲动的事情，让事情变得更糟。我之前说过，进入一个新的学习环境会让人感到羞辱。恼怒、羞辱和紧张都是发现自己处于这样的学习环境中的正常反应，在这种环境中，你被迫承认，即使只是对自己，某种不足之处。学习，在最重要的方面，涉及一种认知失调，几乎是一种双重束缚。“一个数字是（只能是）一个计数数字，但老师说2/3是一个数字。怎么会这样？”

We will only appreciate the role of the teacher if we consider our own response to problematic situations. Suppose I have to do some small but unfamiliar repair around the house—something I am not so good at. I try it but inevitably something comes up that I had not foreseen. If I cannot solve the problem right away I often become irritated—just not knowing how to do it right bugs me and, to break the tension, I may do something impulsive and make things worse. I spoke earlier about how it can feel humiliating to be placed in a new learning environment. Irritation, humiliation, and tension are all normal responses to finding oneself in the kind of learning environment where you are forced to admit, if only to yourself, a certain inadequacy. Learning, at its most significant, involves a kind of cognitive dissonance, almost a double bind. “A number is (can only be) a counting number but the teacher talks as though 2/3 is a number. How can this be?”

教师的首要任务是打破学生现有概念体系的僵化，从而为新概念腾出空间。教师必须对自己所做的事情负起责任，以便能够预测和正确评估学生在被推入此类情况时正常的反应。谁来教学生如何应对出现的压力？良好的教学需要大量的压力管理。必须达到微妙的平衡。压力太小，每个人都会昏昏欲睡；压力太大，学生就会停止学习。因为每个人都有自己最佳的压力水平，所以好老师在管理课堂方面必须是大师级的。教师的困难在于，学生和所有人一样，通常不适应压力，因此，不挑战学生的老师可能比挑战学生的老师更受欢迎，至少在最初是这样。

The teacher’s first role is to shake up the rigidity of the student’s present conceptual system and in this way make room for the new. She must take conscious responsibility for what she is doing so as to be able to anticipate and correctly evaluate the kind of reactions that are normal when one is pushed into such situations. Who teaches students how to deal with the stress that arises? Good teaching involves a great deal of stress management. It is necessary to strike a delicate balance. Too little stress and everyone goes to sleep; too much stress and the students will stop engaging with the material. Because every individual has his own optimal level of stress, the good teacher has to be a kind of virtuoso in his management of the class. The teacher’s difficulty is compounded by the fact that students, like all people, are usually uncomfortable with stress, and so the teacher who does not challenge the students may be more popular, at least initially, than the one who does.

面对一些自己不理解的新概念时，往往会伴随着自我怀疑和其他负面情绪，“也许我不够聪明，无法理解这一点。我从来就不擅长数学。”谁能帮助学生理解这些所谓的负面反应是一种学习过程中正常且不可避免的一部分？谁告诉学生，这样的反应其实是“好的”，因为它们表明学生真正投入到学习的挑战中，不这样投入就不可能有“好的学习”？谁帮助他们培养“抗压能力”，这种能力比智商更能决定谁能成为一个好的学习者和一个有创造力的人？

Confronting some new concept that one does not understand is often accompanied by self-doubt and other negative feelings, “Maybe I’m not smart enough to get this. I was never very good at mathematics.” Who helps students understand that these so-called negative reactions are a normal and inevitable part of the learning process? Who tells the students that such reactions are actually “good” because they indicate an authentic engagement with the challenge of learning and that no “good learning” can ever occur without engaging in this way? Who helps them develop the “stress tolerance” that, more than I.Q., will go a long way towards determining who will become a good learner and a creative person?

只有好老师才能做到这一点。这样的老师可以帮助学生建设性地调整自己的反应，或者重新调整自己的消极反应。请记住，同样的紧张既可以是一种需要逃避的不愉快压力，也可以是一种需要享受的令人振奋的兴奋——我们学会以这样或那样的方式体验紧张。一个好老师，他记得遇到这种情况是什么感觉（希望现在还在遇到），可以帮助学生积极、建设性地看待这些情况，并学会享受它们。这是机器永远做不到的——看着学生的脸，同情他们正在经历的事情。

Only the good teacher can do so. Such teachers can help a student to frame his reactions constructively or to reframe his negative reactions. Remember that the very same tension can be experienced either as an unpleasant stress to escape from or as an exhilarating excitement to enjoy—we learn to experience tension in one way or the other. A good teacher, who remembers what it is like to encounter such situations (and hopefully is still encountering them), can help students to see these situations positively and constructively and learn to enjoy them. This is something that a machine will never do—look into the faces of students and empathize with what they are going through.

另一方面，还有可怜的老师，对他们来说，整个科目都是“显而易见”和“客观”的，只能以一种方式理解——他们的方式。可怜的老师不知道或无法理解学生正在经历的事情。在好的教学中，学生的认知困难与老师真诚地面对如何教学的问题的认知困难相匹配。好的教学是一种持续不断的创造性活动——每个班级都是不同的；每个学生都是独一无二的，代表着他或她自己的挑战。这从来都不是一个简单的对错、聪明或愚蠢的问题。所有学生都有潜力，都有自己独特的数学内化方式。我们如何接触他们并帮助他们改变他们的内部结构？

On the other hand there is the poor teacher for whom the entire subject is “obvious” and “objective” and can only be understood in one way—their way. The poor teacher is unaware of or unsympathetic to what the student is experiencing. In good teaching the cognitive difficulties of the students is matched by the cognitive difficulties of the teacher authentically confronting the problem of how to teach. Good teaching is an ongoing and unending creative activity—each class is different; each student is unique and represents his or her own challenge. It is never a simple question of right or wrong, intelligent or stupid. All students have potential and their own unique internalization of mathematics. How do we reach them and help them to modify their internal structures?

7.4教授层次概念系统

7.4Teaching Hierarchical Conceptual Systems

我一直把数学看作一系列概念系统。我将在第九章中进一步讨论以这种方式看待数学的后果，但很明显，你不能把学习和教授数学而不关注概念。我们已经看到，孤立地研究这些系统是不够的，我们还必须研究各种概念系统之间的关系，特别是更高级的系统 CS 2是如何从更基本的系统 CS 1发展而来的。我们在这方面的原型是计数数字和分数或分数和实数。CS 1和 CS 2以层次关系联系在一起，在教授这种转变时出现的复杂性是本节的主题。

I’ve been looking at mathematics as a series of conceptual systems. I’ll say more about the consequences of looking at mathematics in this way in chapter nine but it is clear that you cannot think about learning and teaching mathematics without focusing on the conceptual. We have seen that it is not enough to study such systems in isolation from one another but we must also look at the relationship between various conceptual systems, especially how a more advanced system, CS2, develops out of the more basic system, CS1. Our prototype is this regard was the counting numbers and the fractions or the fractions and the real numbers. CS1 and CS2 are tied together in a hierarchical relationship and the complexities that arise in the teaching of such transitions are the subject of this section.

当我讨论 CS2 教学和学习的固有困难时，我指的是两个概念系统之间的不兼容性。由于教师坚定地以 CS2 为基础，这种不兼容性对她来说往往是看不见的。然而，如果不了解学生所经历的困难的性质——这些困难是基于通过 CS 1的视角来看待数学世界的这一部分，而 CS 1 的观点虽然不同，但就其本身而言相对一致和完整——就不可能有好的教学。

When I discussed the difficulties inherent in teaching and learning CS2 I was referring to an incompatibility between two conceptual systems. Because the teacher is firmly based in CS2 this incompatibility is often invisible to her. Yet without an appreciation of the nature of the difficulties that the student experiences—that they are based on seeing this piece of the mathematical world through the lens of CS1, a point of view which is different but nevertheless is relatively consistent and complete in its own terms—there can be no good teaching.

但是 CS 1和 CS 2并不是完全相互隔离的。就数学内容而言，CS 2可以从 CS 1正式推导出来。例如，给定计数数 CS 1，则可以将分数视为计数数的有序对(n,m)，其中(n,m)等价于(p,q)当且仅当nq=mp。从这些方面来看，分数将是有序对的等价类。（一半的等价类不仅包括(1,2)，还包括(2,4)、(3,6)、(4,8)等等。）然后我们可以定义对的加法和乘法，使得得到的系统基本与分数相同。当然，这是一个正式的、合乎逻辑的推导过程。即使你遵循逻辑，也不意味着你有“分数”的概念知识。但这种程序在数学中很正常。同样地，我们可以从 CS 1的分数开始，将实数定义为分数的（收敛）无限序列。

However CS1 and CS2 are not totally isolated from one another. In terms of mathematical content CS2 can be derived formally from CS1. For example, given the counting numbers as CS1 then the fractions can be considered as ordered pairs, (n,m), of counting numbers where (n,m) is equivalent to (p,q) if and only if nq=mp. In these terms a fraction would be an equivalence class of ordered pairs. (The equivalence class for one half would include not only (1,2) but also (2,4), (3,6), (4,8), and so on.) Then we can define addition and multiplication of pairs so that the resulting system is basically identical to the fractions. Of course this is a formal and logical derivation. Even if you follow the logic this does not mean that you have a conceptual knowledge of “fraction.” But this kind of procedure is normal in mathematics. In the same way we can start with the fractions as CS1 and define a real number as a (converging) infinite sequence of fractions.

然而，我们感兴趣的不是从一个系统到另一个系统的形式化推导，而是它们作为概念系统的关系。我讨论过的许多概念系统都回答了“什么是数字？”这个问题。因此，CS 1所涵盖的领域与 CS 2的领域重叠。CS 2包含本身就是 CS 1的同构表示，其中“同构”一词的使用方式受到数学术语的启发，但并不完全相同。当涉及到概念系统时，即使学生掌握了 CS 2，CS 1也不会被根除，而是继续运作。如果我们熟悉正负整数系统，我们有时仍会将 2 × 3 视为一个面积或重复加法。在我之前提到的.999... = 1 这个例子中，问题之一是无限小数触发了实数的概念系统，而“ 1 ”触发了计数数字。要比较它们，必须看到它们都存在于同一个概念宇宙中。在更基本的层面上，我在第一章中指出，我们的核心数学系统会在我们的一生中持续影响我们。

However we are not interested in the formal derivation of one system from another so much as we are interested in their relationship as conceptual systems. Many of the conceptual systems that I have discussed answer the question, “What is a number?” Therefore the terrain that CS1 covers overlaps with that of CS2. CS2 contains within itself an isomorphic representation of CS1 where the word “isomorphic” is being used in a way that is inspired by the mathematical term but not identical to it. When it comes to conceptual systems even when a student masters CS2, CS1 is not eradicated but continues to operate. If we are familiar with the system of positive and negative integers we still, on occasion, think about 2 × 3 as an area or as repeated addition. In the example, .999… = 1, that I spoke of earlier one of the problems is that the infinite decimal triggers the conceptual system of the real numbers while the ‘1’ triggers the counting numbers. To compare them it is necessary to see that they both can be seen to exist within the same conceptual universe. At a more basic level I noted in chapter one that our core mathematical systems continue to influence us throughout our lives.

数学如此复杂的原因之一是，同一个数学对象（比如整数2）可以被认为属于多个概念系统：计数数、整数、分数、实数、复数等等。我们有一系列概念系统 CS 1、CS 2、CS 3、CS 4等，其中 CS 1中的每个对象也存在于 CS 2、CS 3和 CS 4中。此外，早期系统与后期系统共存，因此即使我们表面上在 CS 4中操作，也可以自由地参考 CS 1级别的表示。换句话说，每个数学对象都有多种表示形式 - 这是数学的基本模糊性。孤立地讨论对象是不够的；必须在适当的数学背景中或同时在各种背景中考虑它们。这就是为什么数学课程不可避免地是分层次的 - 你不断地从“更高”的角度回头重新考虑旧思想。

One of the reasons mathematics is so complex is that the same mathematical object—the integer 2, say—can be thought of as belonging to multiple conceptual systems: counting numbers, integers, fractions, real numbers, complex numbers, and so on. We have a sequence of conceptual systems CS1, CS2, CS3, CS4, and so on where every object in CS1 also lives in CS2, CS3 and CS4. Furthermore the earlier systems coexist with the latter ones so that we are free to refer back to representations at the CS1 level even when we are ostensibly operating within CS4. Another way of saying this is that every mathematical object has multiple representations—this is the basic ambiguity of mathematics. It is not sufficient to discuss objects in isolation; one must consider them within an appropriate mathematical context or rather within various contexts at the same time. This is why mathematics courses are inevitably hierarchical—you keep going back and reconsidering old ideas from a “higher” point of view.

建立层次结构的一种方法是通过抽象过程，在这个过程中，一个或多个“具体”情况 CS 1的属性被概括以产生一个新的观点 CS 2（正如我在第三章中讨论的那样）。例如，分数或实数等数字系统被概括为“数学领域”。或者人们关注实数之间的距离，然后将实数概括为“度量空间”，这些空间配备了广义的距离概念。当人们以这种方式从具体的基础系统转移到更一般的抽象系统时，旧系统 CS 1常常被看作是广义结构 CS 2的一个“例子” 。但从认知上讲，它根本不是这样运作的，因为旧系统在新情况下仍能正常运转。实际上，新旧系统是紧密相连的，人们不断地在两者之间来回切换。如果人们试图理解抽象的 CS 2 中的某些东西（比如一个域或一个度量空间），或者试图确定 CS 2中的某个假设是否有效，人们会回过头来在 CS2 概括的各种 CS 1系统中进行检查。CS2 的强大之处在于它是一个融合了一系列 CS 1子系统的系统。

One way that hierarchical structures are established is through the process of abstraction in which properties of one or more ‘concrete’ situations, CS1, are generalized to produce a new point of view, CS2, (as I discussed in chapter three). For example number systems like the fractions or the real numbers are generalized to “mathematical fields.” Or one focuses on the distance between real numbers and then generalizes the real numbers to “metric spaces,” which are spaces equipped with a generalized idea of distance. When one moves from a concrete base system to a more general abstract system in this way, the old system, CS1, is often thought of as a mere “example” of the generalized structure CS2. But cognitively it does not work that way at all because the old system keeps functioning within the new situation. In practice the new and the old are tied together and one keeps going backwards and forwards between the two. If one tries to understand something within a abstract CS2 (like a field or a metric space) or attempts to determine whether some hypothesis in CS2 is valid one goes back and checks it out in the various CS1 systems which CS2 generalizes. The power of CS2 is that it is one system that incorporates a whole series of CS1 subsystems.

在这一阶段，我们发现了教学和学习如此复杂的另一个原因。从某种角度来看，CS 1和 CS 2是互不兼容的。CS 1的孩子会给你一个与 CS 2孩子不同的答案（而且两个答案都是“正确的”）。但是，这种不兼容性并不存在于同一水平面上，就像你用两种不同的语言描述某事一样。这些系统是分层的，也就是说，CS 1可以在 CS 2中表示。构建 CS 2包括创建与 CS 1 的兼容性。此外，可以说，CS 1的视图即使在 CS 2中也能继续发挥作用。如果有人让你在脑海中将两个数字相乘，你就会回到旧的计数概念世界，就像你向月球发射火箭时使用牛顿力学而不是相对论一样。旧系统仍然存在，可以在适当的情况下使用。不同的表示形式也可用，但不再是问题；例如，.999... = 1。

At this stage we have uncovered another reason why teaching and learning are so complex. From one point of view CS1 and CS2 are incompatible with one another. A child in CS1 will give you a different answer to a question than a child who is in CS2 (and both answers will be “right”). However the incompatibility does not lie in the same horizontal plane as would be the case if you were describing something in two different languages. The systems are hierarchical, that is, CS1 can be represented within CS2. Constructing CS2 includes creating a compatibility with CS1. Moreover the view from CS1, so to speak, keeps on functioning even within CS2. If someone asks you to multiply two numbers in your head you go back to the old conceptual universe of the counting numbers in just the same way that you use Newtonian mechanics and not the theory of relativity if you are sending a rocket to the moon. The old systems stick around and are available for use in the appropriate situation. The different representations are also available but cease being a problem; .999… = 1, for example.

教授这样的层次系统有何意义？首先，教师必须认识到：（1）CS 1和 CS 2在逻辑上兼容，因为 CS 1的同构图像可以嵌入到 CS 2中（计数数字“ n ”是整数“+ n ”）；但是（2）CS 1和 CS 2在概念上不兼容，因为2乘以3 '是'一个面积，而-2 乘以-3不是，也就是说，整数乘法在概念上与计数数字乘法不同。

What are the implications for teaching such hierarchical systems? In the first place the teacher must appreciate that: (1) CS1 and CS2 are logically compatible because an isomorphic image of CS1 can be embedded in CS2 (the counting number ‘n’ is the integer ‘+n’) but (2) CS1 and CS2 are conceptually incompatible because 2 times 3 ‘is’ an area whereas −2 times −3 is not, that is, multiplication of integers is a different conceptually than multiplication of counting numbers.

这种不兼容性会长期困扰学生。你永远无法摆脱学生的旧思维方式。教师不仅要介绍新概念，还要整合我们必须将新的与旧的结合起来。否则，这两个系统将彼此独立地运作，结果将会导致不必要的认知冲突。我们常常忽略整合的过程，而从头开始教授每个新课程或概念。这是形式主义数学哲学的后果之一。它认为你总是可以从一组公理，也就是从零开始，来发展一门数学学科。从认知上来说，这是不可能的；没有零阶段。教学需要意识到每个学生都必须掌握的概念基础。在任何情况下，老师都必须花时间去调查学生对数字、函数、连续性等的含义。这很难做到。仅仅给学生讲课是不够的——你必须问他们怎么想，并试图辨别他们理解了什么。我们并不是像很多人认为的那样，教授客观材料；我们更多的是在帮助学生发展适当的概念系统。

This incompatibility remains with the student for a long time. You can never dispense with the student’s old way of thinking. The teacher must aim not only at introducing the new concept but also at integrating the new with the old. Otherwise the two systems will operate independently of one another and the result will be unnecessary cognitive conflict. All too often the process of integration is omitted and the teaching of each new course or concept starts from scratch. This is one of the consequences of the formalist philosophy of mathematics. It is the idea that you can always develop a mathematical subject from a set of axioms, from zero so to speak. Cognitively this is never possible; there is no zero stage. Teaching involves remaining aware of the conceptual foundations that every student must inevitably bring to the table. In every situation the teacher must take the time to investigate what the student means by number, by function, by continuity, as so forth. This is hard to do. It is not enough to lecture at your students—you must ask them what they think and attempt to discern what they understand. We are not teaching objective material, as so many believe; so much as we are helping students to develop appropriate conceptual systems.

7.5连续或不连续教学

7.5Continuous or Discontinuous Teaching

在讨论学习时，我强调概念学习包含连续和不连续的元素。死记硬背和突然顿悟都有可能。连续元素涉及掌握给定概念系统中的计算——你理解计数和小整数的加法，然后学习加法算法。这样的计算增加了人们对相关概念系统的熟悉度和直觉。经典逻辑规则适用，特别是，这是强调精确性的环境。正是在这个层面上，事情要么正确，要么错误。系统性错误很重要，因为它们意味着学生的内部概念系统与社区所认同的概念系统不太相符。

In my discussion of learning, I emphasized that conceptual learning contains both continuous and discontinuous elements. There is room both for rote learning and sudden bursts of insight. The continuous element involves mastering computations within a given conceptual system—you understand the counting numbers and the addition of small integers and then you learn the algorithm for addition. Such computations increase one’s familiarity with, and intuition for, the conceptual system in question. The rules of classical logic apply and, in particular, this is the context within which one emphasizes precision. It is at this level that things are either right or wrong. Systematic errors are important because they imply that the student’s internal conceptual system is not a good fit for the one to which the community subscribes.

不连续元素涉及从一个系统转到另一个系统。经典逻辑的规则不适用，也就是说，你希望学生发现问题；你预计会出现矛盾甚至悖论。这种情况总是模棱两可的，因为对同一数学领域有两种不一致的观点。

The discontinuous element involves going from one system to another. The rules of classic logic do not apply, that is, you expect the student to find things problematic; you anticipate contradiction and even paradox. Such situations are always ambiguous because there are two inconsistent views of the same mathematical terrain floating around.

这两种截然不同的学习必然需要不同的教学方式。我在本章中讨论的大部分教学都涉及不连续的情况。另一方面，课堂和演讲厅中发生的大部分事情都涉及连续的教学和学习。小学、中学和本科等各个级别的数学教学大部分都属于这种类型。其他学科的学生的数学教学也是如此——心理学学生的统计学、未来工程师的微分方程、经济学和商学学生的微积分。不幸的是，它还包括数学专业的大多数数学教学。

These two very different kinds of learning inevitably require different kinds of teaching. Most of the teaching that I have been discussing in this chapter involves situations of discontinuity. On the other hand most of what goes on in the classroom and lecture hall involves continuous teaching and learning. Most of the teaching of mathematics at all levels—elementary, secondary, and undergraduate—is of this type. So is the teaching of mathematics to students in other disciplines—statistics to students in psychology, differential equations to future engineers, calculus to students in economics and commerce. Unfortunately it also includes most teaching of mathematics to mathematics majors.

正是在这里，我们看到了错误地概念化学习和教学任务的后果。从我们作为“专家”的角度来看，我们拥有自己认为的“正确”或“客观”的思维方式，我们忘记了学习是一个不断用 CS 2替换 CS 1的过程。优秀的教师必须始终保持警惕，意识到学习的动态性质——预测它、期待它并鼓励它。如果忽视了这一点，那么人们不妨放弃，承认没有真正的教育在进行。

It is here that we see the consequences of incorrectly conceptualizing the tasks of learning and teaching. From our perspective as “experts,” endowed with what we think of as the “correct” or “objective” way of thinking about the subject, we forget that learning is a process of repeatedly replacing CS1 by CS2. The good teacher must constantly remain vigilantly aware of the dynamic nature of learning—anticipate it, expect it, and encourage it. If it is ignored then one might as well throw in the towel and admit that there is no real education going on.

7.6镜像神经元：作为社会活动的教学和学习

7.6Mirror Neurons: Teaching and Learning as Social Activities

现代神经科学最有趣的发现之一是镜像神经元——我们大脑中的回路反映了他人大脑中的回路。我们似乎以一种非常亲密和直接的方式与他人联系在一起。我们自然而然地感受到他人的感受，思考他人的想法。这涉及到他人与自己之间的一种共鸣。镜像神经元现象是人类是社会动物这一事实的生物学关联。许多人推测，大脑的进化是社会互动复杂性的结果。这解释了人类意识核心的基本二元性。我们既是强烈的个体——独立于他人之外——但同时，我们又深深地融入了多个社会群体——从家庭到国家再到整个全球社会。从这个角度来看学习和教学是最好的视角。它既是个人的——发生在你头脑中的事情——也是社会的——只有在社会和文化背景下才有意义。好的教学和学习必须兼顾这两个视角

One of the most intriguing discoveries in modern neuroscience has been mirror neurons—circuits in our brains that reflect the circuits in the brains of others. We seem to be connected to other people in a very intimate and direct way. We naturally feel what others feel and think what they think. A kind of resonance between others and ourselves is involved. The phenomenon of mirror neurons is the biological correlate of the fact that human beings are social animals. There is much speculation that large brains evolved as a result of the complexities of social interaction. This accounts for a basic duality that is at the heart of human consciousness. We are simultaneously intensely individualistic— separate and distinct from others—but, at the same time, we are deeply enmeshed in multiple social groups—from families to nations to the entire global society. Learning and teaching are best viewed from this perspective. It is both individual—something that happens to you in your head—and social—something that only has meaning in a social and cultural context. Good teaching and learning must address both of these perspectives

学习的社会维度的一个结果是，人类教师的存在至关重要。在很大程度上，我们都是通过模仿来学习的。我们理解事物的方式与父母、老师或教授理解事物的方式相同。大多数人的教学方式与被教的方式相同，这是一句老生常谈。如果老师能力不足，这可能是个坏消息，但另一方面，这也可能是个好消息。我们与老师的互动越多，我们就越了解她的思维过程、直觉和概念系统，因此我们对她理解的内容、方式和想法就越开放。学生不仅仅是内化老师提供的信息，还直接受到老师肢体语言、她对课程的热情和热爱等因素的影响。老师不能假装。非语言暗示与明确表达的内容同样重要；她不说的话与她说的话同样重要。如果她感到恐惧或焦虑，那么她就会传达这种恐惧或焦虑。如果她的理解很肤浅，那么她传达的就是肤浅。如果她对这个主题有很深的理解，那么她就会传达出她的自信和快乐。

One consequence of the social dimension of learning is that the presence of a human teacher is essential. To a considerable extent we all learn through imitation. We understand things in the way our parents, teachers or professors understand them. It is a cliché to say that most people teach in the same way that they have been taught. This can be bad news if the teacher is inadequate but, on the other hand, it can be very good news indeed. The more we interact with our teacher the more we are privy to her thought processes, intuition, and conceptual systems and so the more open we will be to what she understands, how and what she thinks. The student is not merely internalizing the information that the teacher provides but is being directly affected by such things as the teacher’s body language, her enthusiasm for and love of her subject. The teacher cannot fake it. Nonverbal cues count as much as what is made explicit; what she doesn’t say is as important as what she does say. If she is fearful or anxious then she communicates this fear or anxiety. If her understanding is superficial then superficiality is communicated. If she has a deep understanding of the subject then she will communicate her confidence and enjoyment.

成为一名好老师需要勇气和开放性。当你站在教室前面时，你无处可藏——你的为人、你的知识对每个人来说都是显而易见的，尤其是你自己。老师是否有信心承认自己的无知和错误，并回答问题：“我不知道答案，但我会考虑一下，下次再回答你。”教师是一种在工作满意度方面回报丰厚的职业，但也需要满足很多要求。如果学习环境要求学生允许自己表现出脆弱性，以便向新方法和新观点敞开心扉，那么它也要求老师表现出同样的开放性和脆弱性。总是会有人想躲在权威或学科的正式方面后面，换句话说，就是封闭自己。总是会有人想在智力上偷懒——一节又一节地埋头学习同样的内容年复一年——却忽视了这个班级的学生群体的特殊需求。每节课和每个学生都是不同的挑战。世界上最有意义的事情就是看到学生眼中闪烁着光芒，听到他们说：“啊，是的。我明白了！”归根结底，老师和学生处于同一个人类层面。学生不断学习如何学习，老师不断学习如何教学，这两者都归结为同一个创造性过程。

To be a good teacher requires courage and openness. There is nowhere to hide when you stand in front of a class—what you are and what you know are visible to everyone, especially yourself. Does the teacher have the confidence to admit ignorance and fallibility and answer a question by, “I don’t know the answer to that but I’ll think about it and get back to you next time.” Teaching is a profession with great rewards in terms of job satisfaction but there are major demands to be met. If the learning situation requires the students to allow themselves to be vulnerable in order to open themselves up to new approaches and perspectives then it also makes the same demand for openness and vulnerability on the part of the teacher. There will always be the temptation to hide behind authority or the formal aspects of the subject, in other words, to close down. There will always be the temptation to be intellectually lazy—to plod through the same material class after class and year after year—and ignore the particular needs of the group of students in this particular class. Every class and every student is a different challenge. The most rewarding thing in the world is to see the light go on in the eyes of the student and hear them say, “Ah, yes. I get it!” Ultimately teacher and student are on the same human level. The student is continually learning how to learn and the teacher is constantly learning how to teach, both of which come down to the same creative process.

当我听到人们把对教育未来的希望寄托在智能手机或平板电脑的教育应用上时，我忍俊不禁。我也发现自己对技术创新着迷，但我们不要让最新科技产品的新颖性蒙蔽了我们的双眼，让我们看不到真正重要的东西。没有这些设备，你也可以获得出色的教学，而拥有世界上最好的设备，教学质量也会很差。事实上，正如最近对多任务虚幻本质的研究表明的那样，技术往往既是一种辅助，也是一种干扰。我们作为一个社会的迫切需要是“深度学习”，而要实现这一目标，我们需要“深度教学”。

I laugh when I hear people placing their hopes for the future of education on educational apps for the smart phone or tablet computer. I, too, find myself captivated by technological innovation but let us not allow the novelty of the latest technological gadget to blind us to what is essential. You can have great teaching without gadgets and poor teaching with the best equipment in the world. In fact technology is often as much a distraction as it is an aid, as the recent research into the illusory nature of multi-tasking makes clear. Our vital need as a society is for “deep learning” and to get there we need “deep teaching.”

好老师是稀缺资源，极其稀缺。这样的人与优秀的科学家和艺术家一样重要——他们本身就是科学家和艺术家。我们如何才能吸引合适的人才从事教学工作？我们如何才能培训他们，让他们明白什么是利害攸关的？我们如何才能支持他们创造性地教学，创造和维持真正学习所必需的非常棘手和微妙的课堂氛围？我们能否给予这个职业应有的尊重，并使其恢复到社会的中心地位？在一个表面上崇尚创新的社会中，让我们记住，一个名副其实的教育体系应该从小学开始，在各个阶段培养创造力。创造性学习将被视为现代世界中必须进行的终身活动。让我们永远不要忘记，未来的社会是由今天的教师一个接一个地创造的。

A good teacher is a rare commodity, extremely rare. Such people are as important as good scientists and good artists—they are scientists and artists in their own right. How can we attract the right kind of people into teaching? How can we train them so that they understand what is at stake? How can we support their efforts to teach creatively, to create and maintain that very tricky and subtle classroom atmosphere that is required for real learning to go on? Can we accord this profession the respect that it deserves and restore it to a central position in society? In a society that ostensibly worships innovation let us remember that an educational system that is worthy of its name would foster creativity at every level from elementary school on up. Creative learning would then be seen as the lifetime activity that it must be in the modern world. Let us never forget that the society of the future is being created student-by-student by the teachers of today.

i Gray 和 Tall, (1994)。

i Gray and Tall, (1994).

第八章

Chapter 8

本科数学

Undergraduate Mathematics

8.1介绍

8.1Introduction

在本章中，我将重点讨论数学教育中的一些具体情况，重点是概念发展。我选择的主题处于中级水平——不是太初级以至于人们可能难以理解为什么有人可能不理解；也不是太高级以至于许多人无法理解。这些例子中的每一个都是一个重要的话题，值得进行比我所能容纳的更长的讨论。它们都代表了数学史和学生数学发展的关键点。

In this chapter I turn to some specific situations in mathematics education with an emphasis on conceptual development. The topics I have chosen are at an intermediate level—not so elementary that one might have trouble comprehending how anyone might not understand it; not so advanced as to be inaccessible to many. Each of these examples is a weighty topic in its own right and deserves a much lengthier discussion than I have the space for. They each represent pivotal points both in the history of mathematics and in the mathematical development of students.

第一个主题是实数，是第三章开始的讨论的延续。这是一门深奥难懂的学科，大多数学生，甚至是相当高级的学生，以及许多教师都对其了解甚少。这是一门非常重要的学科，因为它是几乎所有数学及其应用的基础。然后，我将讨论另一门必修学科微积分的教学，以及线性代数的教学，线性代数是现代世界应用密度最高的数学领域。我将从教学的角度，从数学和概念两个方面讨论它们。我之所以选择这些特定的学科，不仅因为它们在数学和历史方面很有趣，而且还因为它们能让我展示我们一直在讨论的创造力和发展原则如何在实际教学情境中发挥作用。

The first topic is the real numbers and is a continuation of the discussion begun in chapter three. It is a deep and difficult subject, which is generally poorly understood by most students—even fairly advanced students—and also by many teachers. It is a subject of great importance since it underpins almost all of mathematics and its applications. I shall then discuss the teaching of calculus, which is another essential subject, and linear algebra, which is the area of mathematics that finds the greatest density of applications in the modern world. I shall discuss them all from the perspective of teaching and learning, in both their mathematical and conceptual dimensions. I chose these particular subjects both because of their interest, mathematically and historically, but also because they will enable me to show how the principles of creativity and development that we have been discussing play themselves out in actual pedagogical situations.

8.2无理数和实数

8.2Irrational and Real Numbers

什么是无理数？如何向学生正确介绍无理数？这些问题的答案将告诉我们概念发展过程的微妙之处。

What is an irrational number? What is the proper way to introduce them to students? The answer to these questions will tell us a great deal about the subtleties of the process of conceptual development.

在数学中，引入一个新概念通常始于定义，然后是例子，然后是定义的逻辑后果——定义对象的属性以及与其他数学对象或过程的联系。按照这个顺序，数学对象（在我们的例子中是无理数）被仔细而精确地定义，因为我们认为这个概念等同于它的定义。不幸的是，概念的发展，特别是像实数或无理数这样微妙的概念，并不是严格合乎逻辑的，因此，教学和学习不应该遵循这种模式。奇怪的是，你必须在确切了解数学概念是什么之前，引入数学概念并使用它们。正如我在第一章中提到的，你必须自力更生地进入一个新概念，而自力更生并不是一个纯粹的逻辑过程。

The introduction of a new concept in mathematics conventionally begins with a definition, which is followed by examples, and then the logical consequences of the definition—properties of the defined object and connections with other mathematical objects or processes. In this sequence the mathematical object, which in our case is an irrational number, is carefully and precisely defined because we regard the concept as identical with its definition. Unfortunately conceptual development, especially of something as subtle as the real or the irrational numbers, is not strictly logical and, as a consequence, teaching and learning should not follow this model. Strangely enough you must introduce mathematical concepts and work with them before you know exactly what they are. As I mentioned in chapter one you have to bootstrap your way into a new concept and bootstrapping is not a purely logical procedure.

我们的普通逻辑在单一概念系统中运行得最自然。有时定义在概念系统中也能很好地运行。例如，当你将乘法定义为重复加法时。首先，这只是加法的扩展。即使你并不真正理解乘法，你也可以通过将每个关于乘法的语句翻译回关于加法的语句来处理它。然而，在无理数的情况下，我们对旧系统中的东西不感兴趣，相反，我们感兴趣的是引入一个全新的概念以及赋予它意义的概念系统。我们的问题是如何从 CS 1（学生的旧系统）转移到 CS 2。要做到这一点，你必须以不同的方式来处理这种情况。旧的方式（通过精确的定义）行不通，我们将通过考虑各种可能的定义的不足之处来看到这一点。

Our ordinary logic works most naturally within a single conceptual system. Sometimes a definition also works well within a conceptual system. For example, when you define multiplication as repeated addition. To begin with this is just an extension of addition. Even if you don’t really understand multiplication you can work with it by translating every statement about multiplication back into a statement about addition. However in the case of irrational numbers we are not interested in something that lives within an older system but, on the contrary, we are interested in introducing a totally new concept together with the conceptual system that gives it meaning. Our problem is how to move from CS1, the student’s old system, to CS2. To do this you have to approach the situation in a different way. The old way—through a precise definition—will not work, as we shall see by considering the inadequacies of various possible definitions.

8.2.1无理数的可能定义

8.2.1Possible Definition of Irrational Numbers

以下是引入无理数的三种可能方法：

Here are three possible ways of introducing the irrational numbers:

1.不能写成m/n 的数字，其中m且n 为整数且n≠0。

1.A number that cannot be written as m/n, where m and n are integers and n≠0.

2.数字不循环的无限小数。

2.An infinite decimal whose digits are non-repeating.

3.数轴上的一点。

3.A point on the number line.

这些定义有什么问题？让我们逐一分析。第一个定义是负面表述的。它告诉你无理数不是什么，而不是它是什么。如果学生的概念系统是分数（她认为每个数字都是分数），那么无理数对她来说就不存在，定义也是空洞的。有人可能会反对说这是希腊人的做法，但这并不准确，只要仔细观察希腊人的做法，我们就会明白。希腊人生活在一个可构造的几何数的世界中，因此无理数通过毕达哥拉斯定理以长度的形式存在。正是在这种情况下，他们才表明二的平方根不是有理数。

What is wrong with these definitions? Let’s take them one at a time. The first one is phrased negatively. It tells you what an irrational is not, not what it is. If the student’s conceptual system is the fractions (she thinks that every number is a fraction) then irrational numbers do not exist for her and the definition is vacuous. One might object that this is how the Greeks did it but this is not accurate, as we shall see by looking carefully at what the Greeks were doing. The Greeks lived in a universe of constructible, geometric numbers and so irrational numbers existed as lengths via Pythagoras’ Theorem. It was only in this context that they showed that the square root of two was not rational.

我们的学生从与希腊人不同的概念系统开始学习，这个系统更基于计数而不是测量。无论如何，我们试图开发的概念系统是实数，它比希腊人的可构造数字要微妙得多。对于希腊人来说，定义 1 是合理的，但对于现代教育所考虑的任务来说，它严重不足。这告诉我们，将无理数的概念置于整个概念系统（实数）的背景下至关重要。任何定义在概念系统之外都是没有意义的。

Our students start off in a different conceptual system than the Greeks, one that is more based on counting than measuring. Anyhow the conceptual system that we are attempting to develop is the real numbers, which is much subtler than the Greeks’ constructible numbers. For the Greeks definition 1 was reasonable but for the task that modern education has in mind it is seriously inadequate. This tells us that it is vital to place the concept, irrational number, in the context of the conceptual system as a whole, the real numbers. No definition is meaningful outside of a conceptual system.

所有数字系统的扩展都基于同一个问题：“什么是数字？”这个问题在不同情况下被反复提出。新数字作为旧系统内计算的结果出现，然后在新系统构建时作为新数字活跃起来。例如，我们在比率和分数中看到了这个过程。你可以将平方根引入为长度，但不能引入一般无理数数字。要使定义 1 有意义，您必须已经有一个大于有理数的数字系统。构建这个更大的系统正是手头的概念任务。存在似乎是一个非常抽象和哲学的问题，但它是潜在的教学问题——这个问题背后的问题，“什么是数字？”

All extensions of number systems are based on the same question, “What is a number?” which is asked over and over again in different contexts. The new numbers appear as a result of computations within the old system and then come alive as new numbers when the new system is constructed. We saw this process with ratios and fractions for example. You can introduce the square roots as lengths but not general irrational numbers. For definition 1 to make sense you must already have a number system larger than the rational numbers. The construction of that larger system is precisely the conceptual task at hand. Existence may seem like a very abstract and philosophical question but it is the underlying pedagogical problem—the problem that lies behind the question, “What is a number?”

第二个定义解决了存在性问题，实际上告诉了你什么是无理数，即某种无限小数。但是，除非你知道什么是无限小数，否则它毫无意义。你可以尝试将无限小数与实数联系起来，但将小数视为实数的表示会更准确。不幸的是，使用“表示”一词意味着实数存在，而无限小数是我们赋予它们的名称或标签。定义 2 假设实数已经存在。这就是整个问题——对于认为所有数字都是分数的学生来说，实数并不存在。这里的整个任务是引入实数——使它们成为现实（双关语是练习的重点）。学生们还没有将实数建立为一个概念系统，因此这种无理性的定义通常被误解。事实上，除非仔细打好基础，否则不能也不应该通过这个定义来理解无理数。

The second definition addresses the problem of existence and actually tells you what an irrational number is, namely a certain kind of infinite decimal. However, it does not make sense unless you know what an infinite decimal is. You can try to identify infinite decimals with real numbers but it would be more accurate to think of decimals as representations of real numbers. Unfortunately using the word “representation” implies that the real numbers exist and infinite decimals are names or labels that we attach to them. Definition 2 assumes that the real numbers already exist. And that is the whole problem—the real numbers do not exist for students for whom all numbers are fractions. The whole task here is to introduce the real numbers—to make them real, (the pun is the whole point of the exercise). The students have not yet established the real numbers as a conceptual system and as a consequence this definition of irrationality is generally misunderstood. Indeed irrational numbers cannot and should not be understood by way of this definition unless the ground is carefully prepared.

当我们向学生介绍一个复杂的想法时，我们表现得好像我们已经为这个想法画了一幅客观的图画，并相信聪明的学生能够明白我们的意思，而愚钝的学生会失败。我们忘记了我们画的图画（即使它是一个正式的定义）不是概念。我们以一种过于简单的方式介绍复杂的东西，忽略了它的微妙之处。结果，我们最终可能会让更优秀的学生感到困惑，因为他们会发现我们的介绍毫无意义，所以他们不会理解。他们会感觉到我们在向他们隐瞒什么，或者老师并没有真正理解他或她所介绍的内容。在这种情况下，隐藏的是实数的性质及其与无限小数的关系。

When we introduce a complex idea to students we behave as though we have drawn an objective picture of the idea and believe that the bright ones will be able to see what we are getting at and the dull ones will fail. We forget that the picture we have drawn (even if it is a formal definition) is not the concept. We introduce something complex in a simplistic manner that ignores its subtleties. As a consequence we may end up confusing the more talented students who will not get it because they are the ones who will see that our presentation just does not make sense. They will sense that we are hiding something from them or that the teacher does not really understand what he or she is presenting. In this situation what is hidden is the nature of real numbers and their relationship to infinite decimals.

8.2.2循环论证

8.2.2Circular Reasoning

学生通常会陷入以下困境。他们被告知：(1) 实数由两种数字组成——有理数和无理数；(2) 无理数是某种实数。如果你知道有理数和无理数是什么，那么第一种情况会告诉你什么是实数。如果你已经知道什么是实数，那么第二种情况会告诉你什么是无理数。这种情况循环往复。难怪学生最终会感到困惑。

The student is typically in the following kind of dilemma. They have been told that (1) the real numbers are made up of two kinds of numbers—the rationals and the irrationals, and (2) that an irrational number is a certain kind of real number. The first tells you what a real number is if you know what rationals and irrationals are. The second tells you what an irrational is if you already know what a real number is. The situation is circular. No wonder students end up confused.

为了摆脱这种困境，实数通常通过实数线作为准几何对象引入。学生被告知每个数字在该线上都有一个位置。问题在于“实数线”不是实数；它是一个几何隐喻。这个过程也是循环的，因为实数是线上的一个点，但线只不过是所有实数的集合（的表示）。

To escape from this dilemma the real numbers are often introduced as quasi-geometric objects via the real number line. Students are informed that every number has a location on that line. The problem with this is that the “real number line” is not real; it is a geometric metaphor. This process is also circular because a real number is a point on the line but the line is nothing but (a representation of) the set of all real numbers.

在尝试引入无理数时，陷入这种循环并非偶然。实际上，这些逻辑循环为我们提供了有关正在发生的事情的重要提示。请记住，我们感兴趣的是概念发展，而不是逻辑发展。有几种非常好的（即“逻辑”）方法可以从有理数发展到实数，稍后我将提到其中一些。但是，它们都非常复杂，在学生发展的这个阶段用处不大。概念发展有其自己的“逻辑”，这种“发展逻辑”有循环甚至矛盾的空间，正如我们在创造力一章中看到的那样。如果我们将概念发展视为一种创造性活动，我们就不会因遇到的逻辑问题而退缩。如果接受不一致是不可避免的，那么整个学习过程就会以不同的眼光看待，其中关键问题变成了如何使用有问题的元素，而不是如何避免它们。

It is not an accident that one gets into these kinds of circularities when attempting to introduce irrational numbers. Actually these logical loops give us an important hint about what is going on. Remember that we are interested in conceptual development not logical development. There are several perfectly good (i.e. “logical”) ways of developing the real numbers from the rational numbers and I will mention some of them a little later on. However they are all quite complicated and of little use at this stage of the student’s development. Conceptual development has its own “logic” and this “developmental logic” has room for circularities and even contradictions as we saw in the chapter on creativity. If we see concept development as a creative activity we will not be put off by the logical problems we encounter. If the inconsistencies are accepted as inevitable, then the entire learning process is seen in a different light in which the key question becomes how to use the problematic elements instead of how to avoid them.

我们的问题是，我们有多种表示事物的方式，这些事物将发展成为实数和无理数的概念——直线上的点、长度、无限小数等等。在第四章​​中，我讨论了数学中建设性模糊性的本质，我们看到了数字的模糊表示在数字系统的每一次扩展中都发挥着作用。定义的所有问题实数和无理数的歧义归结为存在未解决的歧义。这种歧义并非例外，而是每个重要学习情况的特征。请记住，概念变化之所以困难，正是因为对于学生来说，CS 2尚不存在，而对于老师来说，学生只停留在 CS 1中，而他们头脑中的想法则被视为不正确。对于学生来说，歧义尚未解决，但对于老师来说，歧义已经解决。这是学生和老师之间的巨大鸿沟。如果有一种从 CS 1到 CS 2 的逻辑或系统方法，那么这种鸿沟就不会存在或可以避免。不幸的是，事实并非如此。

Our problem was that we had multiple ways of representing things that will develop into the concepts of real and irrational number—a point on a line, a length, an infinite decimal, and so on. In chapter four I discussed the nature of constructive ambiguity in mathematics and we saw how the ambiguous representation of numbers played a role in every extension of the number system. All of the problems with the definition of real and irrational numbers come down to having an unresolved ambiguity. This ambiguity is not exceptional but characterizes every significant learning situation. Remember that conceptual change is hard precisely because for the student CS2 does not yet exist while for the teacher what is going on in the mind of the student who resides exclusively in CS1 is rejected as incorrect. For the student the ambiguity is unresolved but for the teacher it is. This is the vast gulf between student and teacher. If there were a logical or systematic way of going from CS1 to CS2 then this gulf would not be there or could be avoided. That, unfortunately, is just not the way things are.

8.2.3对于学生来说CS 1是什么？

8.2.3What is CS1 for the Student?

让我们思考一下学生在这个过程开始时所处的概念系统。CS 1至少有两种可能性：分数和有限小数。五十年前，CS 1肯定是分数，但今天它更有可能是有限小数，因为这些是您在计算机或计算器屏幕上看到的数字。当然，它们不是同一个系统。分数在数学上更漂亮，因为您可以在该系统内进行所有算术运算。有限小数在乘法和除法下表现不佳。例如，1/3 = .333...，是无穷小数，因此不属于有限小数系统。然而，许多学生，甚至在大学里，都认为数字就是他们在计算器屏幕上看到的数字。他们可能认为π= 3.14159 ，因为这是他们按下π 按钮时看到的数字。

Let’s think about the conceptual system that the students are living in at the beginning of this process. There are (at least) two possibilities for CS1: the fractions and the finite decimals. Fifty years ago CS1 would certainly have been the fractions but today it is more likely that it is the finite decimals because these are the numbers that you see on your computer or calculator screen. These are not the same system, of course. The fractions are nicer mathematically because you can do all of the arithmetical operations within the system. The finite decimals don’t behave so well under multiplication and division. For example, 1/3 = .333…, an infinite decimal, and so is outside of the system of finite decimals. Nevertheless many students, even in university, think that a number is what they see on their calculator screen. They may think that π= 3.14159 because that is what they see when they push the π button.

8.2.4“无限”小数

8.2.4“Infinite” Decimals

从 CS 1的任何一个版本转到实数和无理数都意味着要考虑无限小数。这并非易事。以下轶事说明了这个问题。多年来，我教授高年级的分析课程，这门课程只有数学专业的学生才能选修。有一年，我在黑板上写下表达式.9999… = 1 ，并问学生它是真还是假。大多数人都说这是假的。对他们来说.999……“非常接近1 ”，但不等于 1。“有多接近？”我问道。“无限接近，”他们中的一些人回答道。这让我觉得非常有趣，因为对于一个数学家来说.999……和1只是同一事物的两个名称、同一数学对象的两种表示形式。

To move from either version of CS1 to the real and irrational numbers means thinking about infinite decimals. This is no easy task. The problem is illustrated by the following anecdote. For years I taught the senior year analysis course which was only taken by students who specialized in mathematics. One year I wrote the expression .9999… = 1 on the blackboard and asked the students whether it was true or false. Most of them said that it was false. For them .999… was “very close to 1” but not equal to it. “How close?” I asked. “Infinitely close,” some of them answered. This struck me as very interesting since for a mathematician .999… and 1 are just two names for the same thing, two representations for the same mathematical object.

“好吧，”我说，“我会向你证明这个等式是正确的。”我写下了通常的顺序：设x = .999…，则10x = 9.999…且9x = 10x − x = 9.999… - .999… = 9。如果9x =9然后x = 1。“你相信这个论证吗？”我问道。他们想了想，几乎所有人都相信这个论证是有效的。“那么，现在你相信这个等式是正确的吗？”令人震惊的答案（对数学家来说）是“不”。他们相信证明是正确的，但他们仍然不相信结果。发生了什么事？对于学生来说.999……是一个在时间中发生且没有尽头的过程。这样的过程不可能与封闭表达式 1 相同，也没有证据或其他论据可以说服他们。他们从未掌握无限小数的概念系统，并且在缺乏适当的概念发展的情况下，逻辑论证毫无效力。

“Okay,” I said, “I’ll prove to you that the equation is true.” And I wrote down the usual sequence: let x = .999…, then 10x = 9.999… and 9x = 10x − x = 9.999… - .999… = 9. If 9x =9 then x = 1. “Do you believe the argument?” I asked. They thought about it and almost all were convinced that the argument was valid. “So, now do you believe that the equation is true?” The shocking answer (to a mathematician) was, “no.” They believed the proof was correct but they still did not believe the result. What was going on? For the students .999… was a process that happened in time and had no end. There was no way that such a process could be identical to the closed expression 1 and no proof or other argument could convince them otherwise. They had never grasped the conceptual system of infinite decimals and in the absence of the appropriate conceptual development logical arguments have no force.

最简单的无限小数是那些重复的小数。例如，.121212…，它是无限和1/10 +2/100+1/1000+2/10000+ …。在这种情况下，和是12/99现在，它有两种表示形式——分数和小数。有理数的这种模糊表示是学生在掌握实数的道路上要克服的第一个障碍。在处理无限小数的一般形式之前，学生需要熟悉分数的十进制表示。这意味着他们应该能够通过长除法将分数转换为小数，知道分数总是产生循环小数（为什么？），并知道如何将循环小数转换为分数。大多数情况下，他们不具备这些技能。

The simplest infinite decimals are the ones that repeat. For example, .121212…, which is infinite sum 1/10 +2/100+1/1000+2/10000+ …. . In this case the sum is 12/99 and which is now seen to have two representations—as a fraction and as a decimal. This ambiguous representation of rational numbers is the first obstacle for students to overcome on the way to mastering the real numbers. Preliminary to dealing with general versions of infinite decimals students need familiarity with the decimal representations of fractions. This means that they should be able to convert a fraction to a decimal by long division, know that a fraction always produces a repeating decimal (why?), and know how to convert a repeating decimal to a fraction. For the most part they do not have these skills.

如果所讨论的无限小数不重复怎么办？例如，像.10100100010000…它有规律，但没有重复的模式。我们怎么知道和是一个数字呢？你可以把无限小数看作是有理近似值的序列。这里它们是1/10、10/100、101/1000、1010/10000等等。这些分数越来越接近，但先验地，没有这就是为什么它们必须近似某个特定数字的原因。你可能越来越接近某个不存在的东西——接近数字系统中的黑洞——然后无限小数就不再代表任何数字了。事实上，如果你生活在有理数的世界里，就会发生这种情况。换句话说，你必须知道这个数字存在，然后才能近似它，这就是整个问题——学生不知道它存在。

What if the infinite decimal in question does not repeat? For example, something like .10100100010000… which has a pattern but not a repeating pattern. How do we know that the sum is a number? You can think of an infinite decimal as a sequence of rational approximations. Here they are 1/10, 10/100, 101/1000, 1010/10000, and so on. These fractions get closer and closer to each other but, a priori, there is no reason why they must approximate some particular number. You might be getting closer and closer to something that did not exist—approaching a black hole in the number system—and then the infinite decimal would not stand for any number. In fact this is precisely what happens if you live in the world of rational numbers. In other words you really have to know that the number is there before you can approximate it and that is the whole problem—the student does not know that it exists.

因此，第二个定义，即通过十进制表示描述无理数的定义，隐藏了许多不明显的问题。除了无理数是否存在的问题之外，这种方法还隐藏了其他问题。最大的问题是它基于无穷大的概念。数字由无限的数字序列或无限的分数和给出，无论哪种情况，都需要将这个无限的数据集合视为一个完整的对象。这是一个巨大的问题。

So the second definition, the one that describes an irrational number via its decimal representation, hides a great deal that is not at all obvious. Beyond the question of whether irrational numbers exist this approach hides other problems. The greatest problem is that it is based on the notion of infinity. The number is given by an infinite sequence of digits or by an infinite sum of fractions and, in either case, this infinite collection of data needs to be treated as one completed object. This is a huge problem.

第二个问题是区分“不重复”的概念和“模式”的概念。如果你没有无限序列的概念，那么重复意味着什么？一个把数字看作有限小数的学生如何确定.1235555…是重复的、非重复的还是有规律的？数字序列可能继续 (1) 无限的5字符串或 (2) 数字1235555一遍又一遍，甚至（3）π的数字。前两种情况有重复，但第三种情况没有。有趣的是，通常学生不会识别重复，除非它们很短——一位或两位数——你可能不得不在十进制展开中取出一百万位数字才能看到重复，这种想法对他们来说毫无意义。

The second problem is differentiating the idea of “non-repeating” from the idea of “pattern”. What does repeating mean if you don’t have the concept of an infinite sequence? How is a student who thinks of a number as a finite decimal to determine whether .1235555… is repeating, non-repeating, or has a pattern? The sequence of digits might continue with (1) an infinite string of 5’s or (2) the digits 1235555 over and over again or even (3) the digits of π. In the first two cases there is a repetition but not in the third. It is interesting that normally students do not recognize repetitions unless they are quite short—one or two digits—the idea that you might have to go out a million digits in the decimal expansion to see the repetition would not be meaningful to them.

8.3从有理数构造实数

8.3Constructing the Real Numbers from the Rational Numbers

可以从有理数开始，然后从中构造实数。这种构造是从一个到另一个的逻辑桥梁。这种情况并不例外——总是可以从旧系统开发新系统，并将两者整合到一个演绎结构中。这是一个很好的机会来指出认知发展和逻辑发展之间的区别。请记住，在第四章中，罗森伯格将创造行为分解为四个阶段，其中只有第四个阶段与逻辑严谨性有关。本节，即实数的逻辑构造，是关于第四步的。但要记住，学习与所有四个步骤有关。仅仅因为逻辑发展是可能的并不意味着学习以这种方式发生。相反，概念发展还必须考虑非逻辑步骤，这些步骤不可避免地将成为概念学习每个重要实例的一部分。

It is possible to start with the rational numbers and construct the real numbers from them. This construction is a logical bridge that gets you from one to the other. The situation is not exceptional—it is always possible to develop the new system from the old and integrate the two in a single deductive structure. This is a good opportunity to point out the difference between cognitive development and logical development. Remember that in chapter four, Rothenberg broke down the creative act into four stages where only the fourth was concerned with logical rigor. This section, the logical construction of the real numbers, is about this fourth step. But it is well to remember that learning concerns itself with all four steps. Just because logical development is possible does not mean that learning happens in this way. On the contrary conceptual development must also take into account the non-logical steps that inevitably will be a part of every significant instance of conceptual learning.

尽管有这些评论，但实数可以用分数构造出来这一点很有趣也很有启发性。事实上，有两种主要方法可以做到这一点：戴德金分割和柯西序列。下面是对第一种方法的简要描述。“分割”是一种将所有有理数分成两个不相交集合的方法，我们将其写为A < B，其中 (1) 每个有理数要么是A的元素，要么是B的元素， (2) 没有一个数是两者的元素，(3) A的每个元素都小于B的每个元素。例如，A可以是所有小于或等于1 的分数和B将是所有大于1 的分数。这是一个“有理分割”的例子（在数字1处），因为数字 1 划分了两个集合。在另一个例子中

Notwithstanding these comments it is interesting and informative that the real numbers can be constructed from the fractions. There are, in fact, two principal ways of doing so: Dedekind cuts and Cauchy sequences. Here is a very brief description of the first. A “cut” is a way of partitioning all the rational numbers into two disjoint sets which we will write as A < B, where (1) every rational number is either an element of A or of B, (2) no number is an element of both, and (3) every element of A is less than every element of B. For example, A could be all fractions less or equal to 1 and B would be all fractions greater than 1. This is an example of a “rational cut” (at the number 1) because the number 1 divides the two sets. In another example

A = { x = m/n : x 2 <2 }和B = { x = m/n : x 2 >2 }。

A = {x = m/n:x2 <2}and B = {x = m/n : x2 >2}.

这是一个无理割集的例子，因为没有有理数可以划分这两个集合。每个实数都将与这些割集之一对应。可以用割集“做算术”，例如对它们进行加法和乘法；你可以对割集进行排序，使“大”和“小”有意义；并证明“割集”具有你期望实数具有的所有属性。每个“割集”都是（与）一个实数对应。

This is an example of an irrational cut because there is no rational number that divides the two sets. Every real number will be identified with one of these cuts. It is possible to “do arithmetic” with cuts, to add and multiply them, for example; you can order the cuts so that “bigger” and “smaller” make sense; and demonstrate that the set of “cuts” has all of the properties that you would expect the real numbers to have. Every “cut” is (identified with) a real number.

这里的问题是，这种构造太抽象了，很难直观地感受到以这种方式定义的“割线”。在实践中，你“先验地”知道实数是什么，然后展示你可以用这种方式从分数（重新）构造它们。它给你一个有趣而重要的但对于我们的目的——教授和学习实数——来说价值不大。

The problem here is that the construction is so abstract that it is difficult to get any intuitive feel for the “cuts” that are defined in this way. What happens in practice is that you “know” a priori what the real numbers are and then show you can (re-) construct them from the fractions in this way. It gives you an interesting and important mathematical result but is of little value for our purposes—teaching and learning the real numbers.

另一种方法以某些特殊的柯西有理数序列为主要对象。柯西序列是1、1/2、1/3 等序列……序列越往外，其元素之间的距离就越近。这些序列中的每一个都用一个实数来标识 — 上面的序列将用0来标识。如上所述，您必须证明以这种方式定义的数字可以相加或相乘，并且具有表征实数的其他属性。

The other method takes certain special, Cauchy, sequences of rational numbers as the primary objects. Cauchy sequences are sequences, like 1, 1/2, 1/3, … whose elements get closer and closer together the further out you get in the sequence. Each of these sequences is identified with a real number—the above sequence would be identified with 0. As above you have to show that numbers defined in this way can be added or multiplied, say, and have the other properties that characterize the real numbers.

现在，每个无限小数实际上都是有理数的柯西序列，因此我们的第二个定义（将实数定义为无限小数）是这种方法的变体。不幸的是，使用无限小数定义忽略了许多复杂性。

Now every infinite decimal is actually a Cauchy sequence of rational numbers so our second definition, which defined a real number to be an infinite decimal, is a variation on this approach. Unfortunately using the infinite decimal definition ignores many complexities.

例如，考虑将两个无限小数相加（或相乘，或更糟的是相除）的问题。你该怎么做呢？从一个简单的例子开始：.2222… + . 8888…。您不能使用通常的加法算法，因为它从右侧开始，而这里没有右侧起点。如果您以有限的部分进行操作，.2 + .8 = 1.0，.22 + .88 = 1.1，.222 + .888 = 1.11，等等，你会发现答案应该是1.1111……然后你就可以提出论据来证明你的猜测是正确的。即使在这个简单的例子中，你也会发现无限小数比有限小数更复杂，你必须将它们视为无限的近似序列。

Consider, for example, the problem of adding (or multiplying or, worse, dividing) two infinite decimals. How do you do it? Start with an easy example: .2222… + .8888… . You can’t use the usual algorithm for addition because it starts at the right and here there is no right-hand starting point. If you do it in finite pieces .2 + .8 = 1.0, .22 + .88 = 1.1, .222 + .888 = 1.11, and so on, you will see that the answer should be 1.1111… and then you will be able to make an argument to show that your guess is correct. Even in this simple example you will see that infinite decimals are more complex than finite ones and that you have to consider them as an infinite sequence of approximations.

如果两个数列不重复，我们该怎么办？在这种情况下，你会如何将它们相加或相乘？对于大多数人来说，这远非显而易见。即使你坚信无限小数“是”实数，处理它们也很困难。

What are we to do if the two sequences do not repeat? How would you add or multiply them in that case? For most people this is far from obvious. Even if you accept on faith that infinite decimals “are” real numbers, working with them is difficult.

如果从无限小数开始，区分有理数和其余小数也并非易事。我们说有理数是那些重复的小数，但我们的表示法是以十为基数的——它将小数写成a/10 + b/100 + ... 的形式。如果我们以2为基数（仅使用0和1）将这些数字写成a/2 + b/4 + c/8 + ...会怎样？分数也是以2为基数的重复小数吗？如果一个数字在一个基数中重复，而在另一个基数中不重复，那将是多么灾难！

Distinguishing the rational numbers from the rest of the decimals is also not straightforward if you begin with infinite decimals. We said that the rational numbers were those decimals that repeated but our notation is to base ten—it writes decimals in the form a/10 + b/100 + … . What if we wrote these numbers in base 2 (only using 0’s and 1’s), as a/2 + b/4 + c/8 + …? Would a fraction also be a repeating base 2 decimal? What a disaster it would be if a number were repeating in one base and not in another!

另一方面，如果一个数在一种进制中是非有限非循环数（即无理数），那么它在所有其他进制中也是无理数吗？我们当然希望如此！这就是为什么数学家通常希望在采用某种特定表示法之前知道实数存在的原因——您希望数字的属性（比如有理数或无理数）取决于数字本身，而不是取决于您选择表示它的方式。

On the other hand, if a number is a non-finite and non-repeating (that is, irrational) number in one base is it also irrational in every other base? We would certainly hope so! This is why mathematicians would normally like to know that the real numbers exist before taking up some particular representation—you would like the properties of the numbers (like being rational or irrational) to depend on the number itself and not on the manner in which you choose to represent it.

本节的结论是，尽管有可能从有理数构造实数，但这并不是正确的教学方法。这是一种使概念学习连续的方法，并掩盖了该过程不连续的事实。

The conclusion of this section is that even though it is possible to construct the real numbers from the rational numbers, this is not the correct pedagogical way to proceed. It is a way to make conceptual learning continuous and disguises the fact that the process is discontinuous.

8.4如何了解无理数？

8.4How Do You Learn about Irrational Numbers?

前面的评论表明了实数和无理数的概念有多么复杂。因此，我没有写下我自己的向学生介绍这些数字的“完美程序”。我尝试过许多方法，似乎它们都存在某种缺陷。结论是，没有一种简单的方法——从分数、几何隐喻或无穷级数构造——可以解决问题。

The previous comments indicate how complex the notions of real and irrational number are. As a result I did not write down my own “perfect procedure” for introducing these numbers to students. I have gone through a number of approaches and it would seem that they all are deficient in some way. The conclusion is that there is no simple approach—construction from the fractions, geometric metaphor, or infinite series—that will do the trick.

还剩下什么？我们最好从对这项任务的现实评估开始。请记住，在关于创造力的章节中，许多人谈到同时在头脑中持有两个相互矛盾的想法。看起来，这样的事情将是发展无理数概念的关键一步。学生需要建立一个“概念形象”，这将包括对这些数字的许多不同方法、许多不同类型的计算、解决许多不同类型的问题、大量的亲自动手和处理具体情况。例如，如果你想谈论无限小数，那么你必须准备好讨论无限，这需要老师和学生进行大量的思考和准备。相信一个人可以神奇地绕过与无限对象相关的障碍，充其量是天真的。

What is left? We might well begin with a realistic appreciation of the task. Remember that many people in the chapter on creativity spoke about holding two contradictory ideas in the mind at the same time. It looks like something like this will be a crucial step in developing the concept of an irrational number. The student needs to build up a “concept image” and that will include many different approaches to these numbers, many different kinds of calculations, solving many different kinds of problems, a great deal of getting your hand dirty and working with concrete situations. For example, if you want to talk about infinite decimals then you have to be prepared to discuss infinity and this requires a great deal of thought and preparation on the part of the teacher and the student. To believe that one can magically bypass the obstacles associated with working with infinite objects is at best naive.

我们可以把这个讨论看作是引入实数的多种表示形式。有时人们会认为问题在于找到“正确”的表示形式并将其作为所有其他表示形式的基础。但事实并非如此，必然会有多种表示形式，这些表示形式必然会相互冲突。这只是另一种说法，当实数或无理数首次被引入时，以及此后很长一段时间内，它们都不可避免地具有歧义性。学习就是通过这种冲突、通过歧义来进行的。那么，学习是什么呢？在某个时候，学生会发现这些多种表示形式都与一个单一的概念有关。无论是数轴上的一个点、线段的长度还是无穷小数，它都是同一种数字。然后，你会看到实数可以用多种方式表示，而不是相互冲突的表示形式，并且你可以根据需要灵活地从一种表示形式移动到另一种表示形式。这就是理解实数或无理数的意义所在。

We can think of this discussion as introducing multiple representations of real numbers. Sometimes people proceed as though the problem was to find the “right” representation and use it as the basis for all the others. But, no, there will inevitably be multiple representations around and these representations will inevitably clash with one another. This is just another way of saying that, when it is first introduced and for a long time thereafter, the real numbers or the irrational numbers are inevitably ambiguous. Learning proceeds by way of this clash, by way of ambiguity. What then is learning? At some point the student sees that these multiple representations are all concerned with one unitary concept. It’s the same kind of number whether it is a point on the number line, the length of a line segment, or an infinite decimal. Then instead of clashing representations you see that a real number can be represented in multiple ways and you gain the flexibility of moving from one representation to another as is appropriate. This is what it means to understand real or irrational numbers.

8.5实数作为障碍

8.5The Real Numbers as an Obstacle

尽管实数是学生在高中和大学后期学习的大多数数学概念体系的基础，但大多数学生从未理解过实数。问题的一部分可能在于“实”这个词。随便问一个受过教育的人实数是什么。很多时候，他们的回答会涉及到他们目前正在使用的概念数字系统的一部分的数字。它可能是我们讨论过的任何数字系统，而且对于令人惊讶的数量的人来说，“实”数只不过是一个计数数字。对于其他人来说，它可能是整数或分数。对于大学理工科学生来说，它通常是有限小数加上一些无限小数，比如.333……，一些平方根和立方根，以及数字π和e。另一些则将根加上π并将e 转换为分数，因此基本上是希腊人的位置，但没有几何表示。很少有人真正在实数的概念系统中工作，其中包括每天使用数学的商业和政府专业人士。

Even though the real numbers are the conceptual system that underlies most of the mathematics that a student learns in the later high school and university years most students never understand the real numbers. Part of the problem may lie with the word “real.” Ask a random educated person what a real number is. Much of the time their answer will involve the numbers that form part of the conceptual number system that they are currently employing. It may be any of the number systems that we have discussed and, for a surprising number of people a “real” number is nothing more than a counting number. For others it may be the integers, or the fractions. For university science students it is often the finite decimals to which are added a few infinite decimals like .333…, a few square and cube roots, and the numbers π and e. Others add the roots plus π and e to the fractions and so are basically in the position of the Greeks but without the geometric representation. Very few, and this includes professionals in business and government who use mathematics daily, truly work within the conceptual system of the real numbers.

许多学生将函数、微积分和线性代数等名义上基于实数的学科理解为基于较基本的概念系统之一。每个数学课堂都是该学科不同概念方法的场所——基于实数的数学理论和基于学生当前使用的概念数字系统的“学习”理论。学生将老师的每一句话和教科书中的每一句话（实际上都是基于实数）解释为关于对他们而言“真实”的数字的陈述——他们的操作概念系统。

Many students understand subjects like functions, calculus, and linear algebra that are nominally based on the real numbers, as though they were based on one of the more elementary conceptual systems. Every mathematics classroom is the site of different conceptual approaches to the subject—the mathematical theory based on the real numbers and the “learned” theory that is based on the conceptual number system that the student is currently using. The students interpret every statement of the teacher and every statement in the textbook, which are in fact based on the real numbers, as a statement about the numbers that are “real” to them—their operative conceptual system.

当概念发展与理论发展不匹配时，即当出现这样或那样的障碍，阻止大多数学生将理论数学转化为概念系统时，课堂上必须采取一些措施来弥补这种障碍。就像一条被倒下的树挡住的小溪，学生会开辟一条避开障碍的新路。最终，在老师的默许下，学生学到的是一个简化的、人为的学科版本，一个基于早期概念系统的学科版本。

When conceptual development does not match the theoretical, that is, when obstacles of one kind or another arise that prevent a majority of students from making the theoretical mathematics into a conceptual system then something must happen in the classroom to compensate for that blockage. Like a stream that is blocked by a fallen tree, the student creates a new path that avoids the blockage. In the end what the student learns, with the implicit acquiescence of the teacher, is a simplified and artificial version of the subject, one that is based on an earlier conceptual system.

8.6功能

8.6Functions

这是如何运作的？让我们先关注一下函数。在学生建立了数字的概念系统后，注意力可以转移到数字之间的关系上。诸如f ( x ) = 2x或g ( x ) = x 2之类的函数是一种规则，它将“输入”数字x转换为“输出”数字，这里是2x或x 2 。第一个函数可以称为“加倍”函数，第二个函数可以称为“平方”函数。输入x的可能值有哪些？在我们的例子中，x可以是任何实数，但许多学生只会考虑他们熟悉的数字作为x 的可能值，即使这会将x限制为计数数字。学生认为作为x候选的数字范围甚至可以限制为小正整数，{0,1, 2, 3}或{0, ±1, ±2, ±3}。老师经常参与其中，因为他们在课堂示例中使用的数字通常仅限于这几个整数，因为其他整数可能会导致大量繁琐的计算。

How does this work? Let’s focus on functions for a moment. After the student has built up a conceptual system of numbers, attention can move to the relationship between numbers. A function such as f(x) = 2x or g(x) = x2 is a rule that takes an “input” number x and transforms it to an “output” number, here 2x or x2. The first function could be called the “doubling” function and the second the “squaring” function. What are the possible values of the input x? In our examples x could be any real number but many students will only consider numbers with which they are comfortable as possible values for x even if this restricts x to the counting numbers. The range of numbers that a student considers as candidates for x may even be restricted to the small positive integers, {0,1, 2, 3} or {0, ±1, ±2, ±3}. The teacher is often complicit in this because the numbers that they use in classroom examples are often restricted to those few integers simply because the others may lead to a lot of tedious computation.i

因此，学生通常会继续或多或少地舒适地生活在一个与教师所假设的教学世界截然不同的概念世界中。每一句话、每一个想法，都会立即被翻译成更熟悉、更舒适的世界，这种简化在一段时间内是有效的。当然，这些概念上的遗漏迟早会回来困扰学生。她会不时地遇到一些数学陈述，从她更原始的概念系统的角度来看，这些陈述是不可理解的，甚至是完全错误的。例如，经常引入一个函数并将其与它的图形联系起来。对于函数f ( x ) = 2x来说，它是通过原点的直线，斜率为2。但对学生来说，这个函数可能仅仅是一个有限列表：

As a result of this the student often continues to live more or less comfortably within a conceptual world that is very different than the one the teacher assumes that she is teaching. Every statement, every idea, is immediately translated into the more familiar and comfortable world and this reduction works—for a while. Of course, sooner or later these conceptual omissions will come back to haunt the student. She will, from time to time, encounter mathematical statements that are incomprehensible or just plain wrong when viewed from the perspective of her more primitive conceptual system. For example, a function is often introduced and identified with its graph. In the case of the function f(x) = 2x it is the straight line through the origin with slope 2. But, to the student, the function may merely be the finite list:

十 = -3 -2 -1 0 1 2 3
2x = -6 -4 -2 0 2 4 6

像直线或抛物线这样的连续几何对象需要实数背景才能有意义。作为基于实数的几何对象，您有（中间值）定理：如果函数的值在某个x处为正在另一个位置为负数，则介于两者之间的某个位置必定为零。这对于分数或其他更简单的数字系统来说并不成立。

A continuous geometric object like a line or a parabola requires a context of the real numbers to make any sense. As a geometric object based on the real numbers you have the (intermediate value) theorem: if the value of the function is positive at some x and negative at another then somewhere in between it must be zero. This is just not true for fractions or other, simpler number systems.

8.7功能作为概念系统

8.7Functions as a Conceptual System

当我们从概念的角度看待数字时，一个引人注目的发现是数字系统是分层的——较高级别的系统包含嵌入其中的较低级别的系统的同构图像。这种分层嵌入的思想在整个数学中都很重要，人们在科学史中也能找到它，例如，相对论“包含”经典牛顿理论——牛顿定律并没有被相对论抹杀，而是继续作为一种近似值发挥作用。我们不仅发现理论科学中存在这样的层次结构，而且在自然界（原子、分子、细胞）中也存在这样的层次结构。而“还原论”则是试图将自然还原为其最简单的元素，我们在这里反其道而行，考虑从简单的元素构建更复杂的结构。这也是概念系统发展和成长的方向。

When we looked at numbers in conceptual terms one of the striking observations was that number systems are hierarchical—the higher level system contains an isomorphic image of the lower level system embedded within it. This idea of hierarchical embedding is important throughout mathematics and one finds it as well in the history of science, where, for example, the theory of relativity “contains” classical Newtonian theory—the laws of Newton are not obliterated by relativity but continue to function as an approximation. We find such hierarchies not only in theoretical science but also in nature (atoms, molecules, cells). Whereas “reductionism” is the attempt to reduce nature to its simplest elements, here we are going in the opposite direction and considering building up more complex structures from simpler ones. This is also the direction of development and the growth of conceptual systems.

函数（实变量的实值函数）可看作是一个概念系统，它本身内嵌了实数的副本。（实数作为常数函数嵌入，例如函数f ( x ) = 1，对于任何输入，它的值都为1。）一旦有了特定的数字系统作为基础，就可以开发一个具有来自该数字系统的输入的函数系统。在函数系统中，数字本身不是基本对象，但基本元素是数字之间的各种关系 - 加倍、平方等等。函数系统的元素由数字的变化方式组成 - 它们是变化的模式。

Functions (real-valued functions of a real variable) can be looked at as a conceptual system that carries an embedded copy of the real numbers within itself. (The real numbers are embedded as the constant functions, for example, the function f(x) = 1, which takes the value of 1 for any input whatsoever.) Once you have a specific number system as a basis then you can develop a system of functions that has inputs from that system of numbers. In the system of functions the numbers themselves are not the fundamental objects but the basic elements are those various relationships—doubling, squaring, and so on—that numbers have with each other. The elements of the function system consist of the ways in which numbers change—they are patterns of change.

通常，我们将数字视为对象，因此它们是静态的——三就是三。但在应用中，我们可能希望数字表示随时间变化的系统状态。例如，粒子在时间“ t”的位置由F ( t ) = 2t+3给出因此在时间0它位于位置3，时间-1，位置1，时间3/2在位置6处，在时间π处在位置2π+ 3 处。函数是我们将变化引入数学及其应用的方式。

Normally we think of numbers as objects and, as such, they are static—three is just three. But in applications we might want a number to represent the state of a system that is changing with time. For example the position of the particle at time ‘t’ is given by F(t) = 2t+3 so that at time 0 it is at position 3, at time -1 position 1, at time 3/2 at position 6, and at time π at position 2π+ 3. Functions are the way that we introduce change into mathematics and its applications.

由于自然界中的一切都会随时间而变化，“函数”是现代数学最重要和最基本的概念之一。当你思考一个函数时，你不能停留在单个数字的层面上；你必须把整个函数看作一个单一的对象或过程。你可以通过简单地写下规则f ( x )来做到这一点= 2x，就像我之前做的那样，或者将函数视为一个图形、一个列表或计算器上的一个按钮——一个黑匣子，只要你输入x，它就会输出“ 2x ” ，或者以其他各种方式。无论你使用哪种表示来思考函数，它都包含了它所构建的数字系统。不仅因为原始系统嵌入在新系统中，还因为每个函数都包含原始数字系统的所有数字。由于大多数数字系统都是无限的，我们再次遇到了无限性的认识论障碍——函数在很大程度上包含无限集的概念，而这个概念在历史上和现在都很难理解。对无限集感到不舒服的学生还有另一个理由相信函数只有一组有限的可能输入。

Since everything in the natural world changes over time “function” is one of the most important and basic concepts of modern mathematics. When you think about a function you cannot stay at the level of the individual numbers; you have to think about the function as a whole as a singular object or process. You can do this by simply writing down the rule, f(x) = 2x, as I did earlier, or by thinking of the function as a graph, or a list, or as a button on a calculator—a black box that spews out ‘2x’ whenever you input x, or in various other ways. Whichever representation you use to think about functions subsumes the number system on which it is built. Not only because the original system is embedded in the new but also because every function implicates all of the numbers of the original number system. Since most number systems are infinite we again run into epistemological barrier of infinity—functions, for the most part, subsume the concept of an infinite set, which was historically and is today hard to grasp. The student who is uncomfortable with infinite sets has another reason to believe that a function has only a finite set of possible inputs.

函数是模糊的生物——它们有多种表示形式。这类似于我们在数字中看到的情况，其中一个关键的发展步骤是看到-3既是过程又是数字。对于函数，我在上一段中列出了多种表示形式。这些表示形式分为两类：将函数视为静态对象（图形或列表）的表示形式，以及将其视为过程的表示形式（计算器按钮、输入输出机器）。现在，学生可能会被教导其中一种表示形式比其他表示形式更基本。过去，教科书总是将函数称为有序对的集合：对于加倍函数，它将是对：（x，2x）其中x可以是任何实数。从历史上看，函数的概念源于规则或公式的概念，因此人们的函数目录仅限于具有名称或其他符号表示的函数：sin（x），log（x），等等。这两种表示可以相互协调，但它们在概念上并不相同。同样，当老师使用函数这个词时，她的意思是一种，而学生理解的是另一种。只有当学生掌握了所有各种表示都指的是同一件事时，她才能理解函数的概念。

Functions are ambiguous creatures—they come with multiple representations. This is similar to the situation that we witnessed with numbers, where a crucial developmental step was to see -3 as both process and a number. For functions, I have listed multiple representations in the previous paragraph. These representations break down into two categories: those that see the function as a static object—a graph or list—versus those that see it as a process—the calculator button, the input-output machine. Now the student may be taught that one of these representations is more basic than the others. It used to be that textbooks invariably referred to functions as sets of ordered pairs: for the doubling function it would be the pairs: (x,2x) where x can be any real number. Historically the notion of function arose from the concept of a rule or formula so people’s catalog of functions was restricted to functions that had names or other symbolic representations: sin(x), log(x), etc. These two representations can be reconciled with one another but they are not conceptually identical. Again the teacher means one thing when she uses the word function and the student understands another. The student only understands the concept of function when she grasps that all of the various representations are referring to the same thing.

请注意，我们建立在实数上的函数的模糊表示，而实数本身也有模糊表示。实数又建立在有理数系统上，有理数也有多种表示。它以这种方式一直延续到我们与生俱来的核心概念系统中数字的模糊表示。我们通过一次在一个层次上工作来管理这种令人难以置信的复杂性，通常是在最高层次上。对于函数，这意味着假设学生知道什么是数字，并从那里开始。如果学生在准备微积分时学习实数变量的函数，并且不理解实数，那么大厦总是有点摇摇欲坠。然而，事情必须这样——很少有人会建议工程和商业专业的学生需要与数学学生一样对实数有相同的概念理解。然而，教育者需要更加意识到，不同的学生群体有不同的概念包袱。尽管我们教授的某一门学科有一个共同的名称——微积分或函数——但现实是，我们教授给工程师的学科与我们教授给商科学生或经济学学生的学科不同——开发一个不同的概念系统。

Notice that we have ambiguous representations of function built on real numbers, which themselves have ambiguous representations. The real numbers in turn are built on the system of rational numbers, which also have multiple representations. And it goes on in this fashion down to the ambiguous representation of number in the core conceptual systems that we are born with. We manage this incredible complexity by working at one level at a time, usually at the highest level. For functions this means assuming that a student knows what a number is and building up from there. If the student is being taught about functions of a real number variable in preparation for the calculus and does not understand the real numbers then the edifice is always a little shaky. Yet it has to be this way—few would suggest that engineering and commerce students need the same conceptual understanding of the real numbers as mathematics students. However educators need to be more aware that different groups of students come in with different conceptual baggage. Even though a particular subject we are teaching has a common name— calculus or functions—the reality is that we are teaching engineers a different subject—developing a different conceptual system—than the one we are teaching to commerce students or economics students.

这些评论在很大程度上解释了为什么教和学数学如此困难。当我们从最高层次看问题时，早期的层次可能看不见，但当我们希望更仔细地检查我们正在使用的思想或程序时，它们仍然可能出现。数学课程是分层次的，但每门新课程都以学生处于概念发展水平为前提，而这一水平是通过对前一门课程的最佳理解而暗示的。不幸的是，许多数学思想非常微妙且逻辑复杂，学生可能需要很多年才能形成足够的概念理解。因此，在实践中，有很多“假装”行为，而不仅仅是学生的行为。即使学生获得了好成绩，他们也常常会坦率地承认他们不理解这门学科；老师知道学生不理解材料，但感觉被困在一个必须让学生通过的系统中，并假装考试成功意味着理解水平令人满意。在设定现实的教育目标之前，必须对正在发生的事情有一些简单的诚实。

These comments go a long way towards explaining why teaching and learning mathematics is so hard. The earlier levels may not be visible when we look at things at the highest level yet may still emerge any time that we wish examine the ideas or procedures that we are using more closely. Mathematics courses are hierarchical but every new course begins with the assumption that the student is at the level of conceptual development that would be implied by an optimal understanding of the previous course. Unfortunately many mathematical ideas are so subtle and logically complex that it may take students many years to develop an adequate conceptual understanding. As a result, in practice there is a lot of “faking it” going on and not merely on the part of the students. The student will often freely admit that they don’t understand the subject even if they have gotten a good grade; teachers knows that the students do not understand the material but feel trapped within a system where they have to pass the student and pretend that being successful on examinations implies a satisfactory level of understanding. Some simple honesty about what is going on is necessary before realistic goals for education can be set.

8.8微积分与分析

8.8Calculus and Analysis
