微积分、微分和积分最好被认为是一个单一的概念系统，它建立在对数字和函数的理解之上。这本身就是对情况的现代解读，反映了现代课程的传统顺序。这是你在演绎系统中会发现的顺序，在这个系统中，概念系统 A 被引入并（希望）被理解，然后再开发概念系统 B（使用 A 的概念）。有趣的是，这是这与该学科的历史发展方式不同。我们今天认为对实数和函数的理解不够充分和不完整，但最初这足以为牛顿和莱布尼茨发展微积分奠定基础。他们不需要抽象和一般的函数定义，也不需要从有理数构造实数的方法，就能找到曲线下面积，比如y = x从x = 0 到x = 1 的面积，或者计算一个粒子在时间 x 的位置由p ( x ) = x 3 + 2x = 1给出的瞬时速度。

The calculus, differential and integral, is best thought of as a single conceptual system that builds on an understanding of both numbers and functions. This is in itself a modern reading of the situation and reflects the conventional order of the modern curriculum. It is the order you would find in a deductive system in which conceptual system A is introduced and (hopefully) understood before developing conceptual system B (which uses the concepts of A). Interestingly enough this was not the way the subject developed historically. An understanding of real numbers and functions that we would today consider inadequate and incomplete was originally enough of a foundation for Newton and Leibniz to develop the calculus. They did not need an abstract and general definition of function nor a method of constructing the real numbers from the rational numbers in order to be able to find the area under a curve like y = x from x = 0 to x = 1 or to calculate the instantaneous velocity of a particle whose position at time x is given by p(x) = x3 + 2x = 1.

正如数学教学中常见的情况一样，历史序列的元素在课堂上不断重复。实际上，这意味着微积分不是一个而是两个截然不同的概念系统。微积分分为微分和积分，这反映在课程中，并根据不同类型的问题和不同的几何情况在不同的历史上发展。但对我的目的而言，更重要的是，我们可以将微积分分为非正式微积分与理论微积分，或者简单地说微积分与分析。一般来说，数学家对后一种划分并不满意。他们倾向于认为，呈现材料的唯一正确方式是逻辑上完整和全面的方式——从公理到定理的演绎方式。因此，他们对于教授非正式微积分感到有些抱歉，并在可能的情况下将这种教学交给助教和初级教师。对于数学家来说，只有一个微积分，或者用我们的术语来说，只有一个概念系统——你要么明白，要么不明白。这使得该学科的教学存在问题，因为每个人都清楚，向商科学生、工程师、经济学家以及无数其他需要在工作中使用微积分的人教授严格的分析是不合适的。顺便说一句，微积分教学中存在的这个问题并不是独一无二的。统计学教学也存在同样的问题。由于许多学科都需要统计学，但“数理统计学”对这些学科的大多数学生来说太难或不适合，因此心理学和经济学等系往往试图教授自己的统计学课程，就像物理系可能希望教授自己的微积分课程一样。

As is normal in the teaching of mathematics, elements of the historical sequence find themselves repeated in the classroom. Practically speaking this means that calculus is not one but two, substantially different, conceptual systems. There is the division of calculus into differential and integral calculus, which is reflected in the curriculum, and in separate historical development based on different kinds of problems and different geometric situations. But more importantly for my purposes there is what we could call informal calculus versus theoretical calculus or simply calculus versus analysis. Mathematicians, as a rule, are not happy with the latter division. They tend to hold to the view that the only correct way to present material is in a manner that is logically complete and comprehensive—the deductive way of proceeding from axioms to theorems. Therefore they feel somewhat apologetic for teaching informal calculus and, when they can, pass this teaching off to teaching assistants and junior faculty. For the mathematician there is only one calculus or, in our terms, one conceptual system—you either get it or you don’t. This makes the teaching of the subject problematic since it is clear to everyone that it is not appropriate to teach rigorous analysis to commerce students, engineers, economists, and the myriad others who will need to use calculus in their professions. By the way, this problem in the teaching of calculus is not unique. The same problem arises with the teaching of statistics. Because statistics is needed in a vast array of disciplines but “mathematical statistics” is too hard or otherwise inappropriate for most students in these disciplines, departments like psychology and economics tend to try to teach their own statistics courses just as a physics department might wish to teach its own calculus classes.

是否存在与微积分相对应的独特概念系统？更一般地说，在何种意义上，任何概念系统（如计数数字或分数）与与之相关的形式系统相同？这是一个重要的问题，答案是，虽然谈论概念系统是有意义的，但事实上，不存在对每个人在任何时候都相同的单一和不变的概念系统版本。当我们认为只有一种理解实数的方法时，我们混淆了概念系统“实数”和形式数学系统“实数”。概念“实数”是一个认知系统，因此，它因人而异，事实上，它在历史上也发生了变化。在单个个体中，它也会发生变化，这种变化就是我们所说的“发展”或“学习”。

Is there indeed a unique conceptual system that corresponds to calculus? More generally, in what sense is any conceptual system, like the counting numbers or the fractions, identical to the formal system that is associated with it? This is an important question and the answer is that though it makes sense to speak of a conceptual system, there is in fact no singular and invariant version of the conceptual system that is the same for everyone at every time. When we think that there is a single way to understand the real numbers we are confusing the conceptual system “real numbers” with the formal mathematical system “real numbers.” The conceptual “real numbers” is a cognitive system and, as such, it varies from individual to individual as, indeed, it has varied historically. Within a single individual it also varies and this variation is what we call “development” or “learning.”

然而，它是可变的，并不意味着它是任意的。显然，当我和你谈论计数数字时，我们有足够的共同点可以进行对话。然而，有些非凡的人可能以不同于大多数或所有同龄人的方式理解某些概念或概念系统。例如，伟大的自学成才的印度数学家斯里尼瓦瑟·拉马努金就是一个著名的例子，他以非凡而独特的方式构思了数论中的深奥问题。天才的标志往往是发展出一种独特的思考方式来思考给定的科学情况——他或她自己对目前接受的概念系统的版本。后来，这些人必须面对将他们的发现传达给他人的问题，这很可能需要将他们的个人概念系统转化为科学界接受的传统系统的术语。ii

However the fact that it is variable does not mean that it is arbitrary. It is evident that when I talk to you about the counting numbers, there is enough in common for us to have a conversation. Nevertheless there are extraordinary individuals who may understand some concept or conceptual system in a way that differs from most or all of their peers. For example, there is the famous case of the great, self-taught Indian mathematician, Srinivasa Ramanujan, and the remarkable and unique way in which he conceived of deep problems in Number Theory. Often the hallmark of genius is the development of a unique way of thinking about a given scientific situation—his or her own version of the currently accepted conceptual system. Later on these people have to face the problem of communicating their discoveries to others, which may well entail translating their personal conceptual system into the terms of the conventional system that is accepted by the scientific community.ii

微积分的入门课程通常基于受限的数字系统以及受限的函数族。在这些限制内，它可以（非正式地）讨论有趣的想法，例如我们所说的“一个量相对于另一个量的变化率”或指数增长或衰减的性质。它可以解决重大问题，例如确定受牛顿定律支配的粒子的速度，并且通常提供一种处理和解决可以用某些类型的微分方程表示的问题的方法。它对于找到某些最大值和最小值很有用过程。非正式微积分效果很好。事实上，微积分之所以在课程中占据现代地位，正是因为这种非正式版本的微积分可以教给工程和商科学生。在这个概念系统中可以做的事情有限制吗？当然有，但任何概念系统都有一些方面存在问题。教师需要意识到他们所教内容的局限性。他们对这门学科的理解必须超越学生的理解，否则他们的教学就没有深度。他们必须能够为聪明的学生指明正确的方向。

First courses in calculus are typically based on a restricted version of the number system as well as a restricted family of functions. Within these limitations it can discuss interesting ideas (informally) like what we mean by the “rate of change of one quantity with respect to another” or the nature of exponential growth or decay. It can solve significant problems like determining the velocity of a particle that is governed by Newton’s laws and, in general, supply a way of tackling and solving problems that can be represented by certain kinds of differential equations. It is useful for finding maxima and minima of certain processes. Informal calculus works well. In fact calculus assumed its modern role in the curriculum precisely because this informal version of calculus could be taught to engineering and commerce students. Are there limitations to what can be done within this conceptual system? Sure there are but there are aspects of any conceptual system that are problematic. The teacher needs to be aware of the limitations of what they are teaching. Their understanding of the subject must go beyond that of the student or their teaching will have no depth. They must be able to point the bright student in the right direction.

分析或严格微积分是另一门学科和另一个概念系统。它充分利用了实数的丰富性。它使用与非形式微积分不同的函数类——连续函数、可微函数和可积函数——所有这些都是非常大的函数集合，远远超出了学生最初熟悉的函数类。连续性、可微性和可积性的概念是抽象引入的，很难掌握。这些都是非常微妙的概念，只有通过难以描述和难以验证的函数的例子才能生动地展现出来：在任何地方都不可微的连续函数、可以微分一次而不是两次、两次而不是三次的函数等等。

Analysis, or rigorous calculus, is another subject and another conceptual system. It uses the full richness of the real numbers. It uses a different class of functions than informal calculus—the continuous functions, differentiable functions, and integrable functions—all of which are very large collections of functions that go way beyond the class of functions with which the student is initially familiar. The concepts of continuity, differentiability, and integrability are introduced abstractly and are very difficult to grasp. These are very subtle concepts and only come alive through examples of functions whose properties are hard to describe and hard to verify: continuous functions that are nowhere differentiable, functions that can be differentiated once and not twice, twice and not three times, and so on.

将这些抽象的难懂概念精确化的动机是因为存在一系列异常，这些异常是由于以更非正式的方式使用这些概念而产生的。微积分在被引入后的一个世纪里并没有建立在我们今天认为的牢固而严谨的基础之上。换句话说，数学界花了一个世纪才完成罗森伯格的创造过程的第 4 阶段——在统一的理论框架内进行整合的阶段。当我们要求我们的学生在三到六个月的时间内实现同样的飞跃时，我们必须记住这花了多长时间，这一成就有多么困难。当然他们做不到——很少有人能够如此迅速地实现概念上的进步。即使是伟大的数学家保罗·哈尔莫斯在他的自传中也说，他最初并不理解 ε-δ 证明（现代方法的关键步骤）。我记得直到我在我还是研究生的时候就被要求教授这些数学知识，而且随着我学习新的数学知识，我的理解也不断加深。

The motivation for making these difficult abstract concepts precise was because of the existence of a series of anomalies that arose as a result of using these concepts in a more informal manner. Calculus was not put on what we would today consider a firm and rigorous foundation for a century after it was introduced. In other words it took a century for the mathematical community to accomplish Rothenberg’s Stage 4 of the creative process—the stage of integration within a unified theoretical framework. We must remember how long it took and how difficult this accomplishment was when we demand that our students make the same jump in three or six months time. Of course they cannot do it—very, very few people would be capable of such rapid conceptual growth. Even the great mathematician Paul Halmos stated in his autobiography that he initially did not understand ε-δ proofs (the key step in the modern approach). I remember that I did not really understand these ideas until I was called upon to teach them as a graduate student and even then my understanding grew as I learned new mathematics.

微积分和分析教学的主要教学困难在于我们经常混淆两个不同的概念系统。非正式微积分课程通常仍会从极限、连续性和可微性的抽象定义开始。这些抽象定义几乎从未使用过，学生完全不知道引入它们的原因。即使是分析课的学生也会在没有动机的情况下得到这些抽象定义和一系列例子来说明这种抽象的必要性。换句话说，这两个概念系统几乎是不同的主题——不同的数字、不同的函数、不同的问题。

The main pedagogical difficulty with the teaching of calculus and analysis is that we often confuse two different conceptual systems. Often a course in informal calculus will still start with an abstract definition of limits, continuity, and differentiability. The abstract definitions are almost never used and the student is completely in the dark about the reason for introducing them. Even the students in analysis are given these abstract definitions without motivation and a family of examples that brings out the need for such abstraction. In other words these two conceptual systems are almost different subjects—different numbers, different functions, different problems.

数学之所以在科学、金融和政府的日常世界中发挥着如此重要的作用，是因为它可以通过不同的概念系统来理解。微积分可以作为一系列技术来教授，这些技术或多或少可以通过死记硬背来学习。它可以变成一系列解决标准问题的算法。统计学也是如此。如果没有这个不太复杂的层次，那么这些学科就不会对科学、商业和技术领域产生影响。因此，CS 1是研究这些学科的有效而重要的方法。但 CS 2的存在不仅仅是为了数学家的娱乐。CS 1的问题在于使用它的人不一定了解他们在做什么。有多少专业人士在使用统计学时不了解它的假设和局限性？正是在需要明确这些假设时，才有必要回到概念图板并开发 CS 2 ，而 CS 2 的产生源于对 CS 1真正含义的深思熟虑。

The reason that mathematics works so well in the everyday world of science, finance, and government is connected to the fact that it can be approached via different conceptual systems. Calculus can be taught as a series of techniques that can be learned more or less by rote. It can be turned into a series of algorithms for solving standard problems. The same is true of statistics. If this less complex level were not available then these subjects would not have the influence on the worlds of science, business, and technology that they have. So CS1 is a valid and important way to look at these subjects. But CS2 does not exist merely for the amusement of mathematicians. The problem with CS1 is that the people who use it do not necessarily understand what they are doing. How many professionals use statistics without understanding its assumptions and its limitations? It is precisely when these assumptions need to be made explicit that it becomes necessary to go back to the conceptual drawing board and develop CS2, which arises out of thinking very hard about what CS1 really means.

我必须结束这一节，除了我提到的两种方式，你还可以用更多的方式来理解微积分。特别是微积分的发明者牛顿和莱布尼茨，他们对这个主题有自己的思考方式，与我所描述的方式完全不同。他们的概念系统都涉及无穷小的量、流数和无穷小量。他们的方法有效，但长期以来数学家们难以证明它们。今天我们知道他们的概念系统是一种有效的微积分和分析方法——这种方法在某些方面比传统的数学分析方法更优越，但在其他方面更困难。本质上，你所做的事情是创建一个大于实数的数字系统，其中包括无穷小数，对于每个正整数 n，无穷小数大于 0 但小于 1/n。在实数中不存在这种数字。无穷小技术自希腊人以来就存在——它们有效，也就是说，它们是一个有效的数学和概念系统。问题是“第 4 阶段”，即将它们与数学的其他部分合并成一个单一的演绎系统。今天我们知道这是可以做到的，因此，有一种有效的数学分析方法，它从这个系统开始。有争议的是这个系统在概念上是否对学生有用。当然，通常的分析概念系统对很多人来说并不是很容易理解，所以我们可能看到的只是对概念系统改变的通常抵制。

I cannot leave this section without adding the comment that you can understand calculus in more ways than the two that I have mentioned. In particular Newton and Leibniz, the inventors of calculus, had their own ways of thinking about the subject that were completely different than either of the ways that I have described. Both of their conceptual systems involved quantities that were infinitely small, fluxions and infinitesimals. Their methods worked but for a long time mathematicians had trouble justifying them. Today we know that their conceptual system is a valid way of approaching calculus and analysis—a method that is in some ways superior and in others more difficult than the way of conventional mathematical analysis. Essentially what happens is that you create a number system that is larger than the real numbers and includes infinitesimal numbers, which are numbers greater than 0 but less than 1/n for every positive integer n. In the real numbers these kinds of numbers do not exist. Infinitesimal techniques have existed since the Greeks—they work, that is, they are a valid mathematical and conceptual system. The problem was “Stage 4,” that is, incorporating them into a single deductive system with the rest of mathematics. Today we know that this can be done and, as a result, there is a valid approach to mathematical analysis, which starts with this system. What is in dispute is whether this system is conceptually accessible to students. Of course the usual conceptual system for analysis is not very accessible to many so what we may be seeing is merely the usual resistance to a change in conceptual systems.

8.9线性代数

8.9Linear Algebra

线性代数是本科课程的另一个基础。就我的目的而言，只需指出它包含两个不同的概念系统，这两个概念系统通常作为两个独立的科目来教授：矩阵理论和线性代数本身。这两个科目的关键元素都是矩阵，即一个矩形数字阵列。矩阵由某个数字系统的元素构成，通常是实数或复数，但理论上，这些数字可以取自任何数字系统。这个数字系统的使用方式并不复杂，但它处于背景中，因此，如果学生的概念数字系统是有理数，那么他们就处于劣势。然而，正如我之前提到的，线性代数中的许多工作都是在只涉及小整数的情况下进行的。

Linear Algebra is another foundation of the undergraduate curriculum. For my purposes it is enough to note that it comprises two distinct conceptual systems that are often taught as two separate subjects: matrix theory and linear algebra proper. The key element of both subjects is the matrix, a rectangular array of numbers. A matrix is built out of the elements of some number system, usually the real or the complex numbers but, in theory, the numbers could be taken from any number system at all. This number system is not used in a very intricate way but it sits in the background so that if a student’s conceptual number system is the rational numbers then they are at a disadvantage. Nevertheless, as I mentioned earlier much of the work in linear algebra proceeds as though the only numbers around were the small integers.

矩阵既可以看作是数字的集合，也可以看作是更高维度的函数，称为线性变换。在矩阵理论的概念系统 CS 1中，矩阵的功能方面并没有得到强调，而是着重于矩阵的性质和问题我们所遇到的问题大部分是数值和计算的。在 CS 2中，矩阵既是数值对象，又是函数变换。有人可能会认为 CS 2是线性代数，而不是矩阵理论，但这并不是我们从一个概念系统转移到另一个概念系统的方式。我们已经看到了高级系统如何包含低级系统的一个版本。在这种情况下，每个线性变换都可以用矩阵表示，与 CS 1相关的概念适用于矩阵。从教学的角度来看，线性代数之所以如此迷人，是因为学生遇到的学习困难显然与获得成功驾驭多种表示情况所需的思维灵活性有关。这是我们之前在从 CS 1到 CS 2 的其他过渡中发现的关键困难。在这里，CS 1是具体的和计算的，而 CS 2是抽象的和理论的。学生发现自己不断地在这两个视角之间来回转换。她哀怨地问：“看待这个问题的正确方法是什么？”答案是，有很多种观点，但你不能先验地说哪种观点是正确的，哪种观点是错误的；只是在某种情况下，以一种特定的方式思考问题会很有用。

A matrix can either be considered as a collection of numbers or as a higher dimensional function, called a linear transformation. In the conceptual system of matrix theory, CS1, the functional aspects of the matrix are not emphasized and the properties and problems that are encountered are for the most part numerical and computational. In CS2 a matrix is both a numerical object and a functional transformation. One might think that CS2 would be linear algebra as opposed to matrix theory but that is not how we move from one conceptual system to another. We have seen how the higher-level system contains a version of the lower-level one. In this case, every linear transformation can be represented by a matrix, for which the concepts associated with CS1 apply. What makes linear algebra such a fascinating subject from a pedagogical point of view is that the learning difficulties that students encounter are clearly associated with acquiring the mental flexibility that is required to successfully navigate situations of multiple representations. This is the key difficulty that we have earlier found in other transitions from CS1 to CS2. Here CS1 is concrete and computational whereas CS2 is abstract and theoretical. The student finds herself continually shifting back and forth between these two perspectives. She asks plaintively, “What is the right way to look at this problem?” The answer is that many viewpoints are possible but you cannot say a priori which one is right and which is wrong; only that in one situation it is useful to think of things one particular way.

8.10结论

8.10Conclusion

教授数学并不涉及写下一组公理并推导出它们的逻辑后果。它涉及向学生介绍一个新的概念系统。这些概念通常非常微妙和深奥。你无法想象大多数人会在一两个学期的课程中学会驾驭这些深度。我们实际上是通过连续近似的方法进行工作的，通过这种方法，我们会在越来越高的水平上一次又一次地回到相同的概念。

Teaching mathematics does not involve writing down a set of axioms and deducing their logical consequences. It involves introducing students to a new system of concepts. These concepts are often extremely subtle and deep. You cannot imagine that most people will learn to navigate these depths in a one or two semester course. We are effectively working by the method of successive approximations whereby we spiral back to the same concepts again and again at higher and higher levels.

数学中许多最重要的概念都有内涵和外延意义，混淆两者是错误的。什么是数字？它的内涵意义非常广泛，但你只能通过将自己置于某个概念数字系统中来写下定义。什么是连续性？每个定义都会将你置于不同的概念领域——单变量实值函数、高维函数、度量空间和拓扑空间。尽管这些领域可以正式嵌入到分层方案中，但作为概念系统，它们仍然存在显著差异。

Many of the most important concepts in mathematics have both connoted and denoted meanings and it is a mistake to confuse the two. What is a number? Its connoted meaning is vast but you can only write down a definition by placing yourself within a certain conceptual number system. What is continuity? Each definition puts you in a different conceptual domain—real valued functions of one variable, higher dimensional functions, metric space, and topological spaces. Even though these domains can be formally embedded in a hierarchical scheme it is still true that as conceptual systems they differ in significant ways.

教学问题就是引入概念和概念系统的问题。在这个关键任务中，形式数学论证程序的价值不大。我们在形式数学中推理的方式本身就是一种概念系统——演绎逻辑——但将其与数学等同起来是一个巨大的错误。演绎系统中的概念在哪里？在正常的教学中，学生只能自己从形式定义中梳理出概念理解，但即使这样做，也是本末倒置。数学存在于其概念和概念系统中，这需要在数学教学中明确解决。

The problem of teaching is the problem of introducing concepts and conceptual systems. In this crucial task the procedures of formal mathematical argument are of little value. The way we reason in formal mathematics is itself a conceptual system—deductive logic—but it is a huge mistake to identify this with mathematics. Where are the concepts in a deductive system? In normal teaching the student is left on her own to tease out conceptual understanding from the formal definitions but even if this can be done it is putting the cart before the horse. Mathematics lives in its concepts and conceptual systems, which need to be explicitly addressed in the teaching of mathematics.

考虑计算x =113/84时x 3 + 3 x 2 − 7x + 4的值或者甚至在我的公式中你也可以看到我选择了“简单”的数字1、3 、-7、4。

i Think about calculating the value of x3 + 3x2 − 7x + 4 when x =113/84 or Even in my formula you can see that I picked the “easy” numbers 1, 3, -7, 4.

ii比尔·瑟斯顿举了一个有趣且富有启发性的例子。天才的标志很可能是能够开发出一种独特的方法来概念化给定的科学情况。想想爱因斯坦和相对论。

ii Bill Thurston gives an amusing and instructive example of this. The hallmark of genius may well be the ability to develop a unique way of conceptualizing a given scientific situation. Think of Einstein and relativity.

第九章

Chapter 9

心智能教会我们什么数学知识

What the Mind Can Teach Us About Mathematics

不存在独立于心理学的逻辑和认识论。

There is no logic and epistemology independent of psychology.

-H.庞加莱

-H. Poincaréi

9.1介绍

9.1Introduction

从本书开始，我就一直通过用来创造和理解数学的认知结构的视角来看待数学。通常，人们认为数学的概念领域与内容完全脱节。内容被认为是主要的，与主题相同，而概念是次要的。内容和概念之间的这种区别虽然有时很有用，但却是人为的。最终，它扭曲了我们对这门学科的理解，因此不仅给个人学习者带来了各种各样的问题，也给那些将数学应用于工作乃至整个社会的人带来了各种各样的问题。

From the beginning of the book I have been viewing mathematics through the lens of the cognitive structures that are used to create and understand it. Normally one thinks of the conceptual domains of mathematics as totally disjoint from the content. The content is thought of as primary and identical to the subject whereas the conceptual is secondary. This distinction between the content and the conceptual, though useful at times, is artificial. Ultimately it distorts our understanding of the subject and therefore produces all kinds of problems not only for individual learners but also for people who apply mathematics to their work and so to society in general.

思考数学的最佳方式是不仅要考虑算法、程序、定理和证明的内容维度，还要考虑学习、理解和创造数学的认知维度。伟大的法国数学家亨利·庞加莱在早期对形式主义的批评中写道：“似乎只有逻辑观点才令人感兴趣 [希尔伯特] ii。给定一系列命题，他发现所有命题都符合逻辑。有了这个第一个命题的基础，有它的心理起源，他并不关心我感兴趣的是庞加莱的“心理起源”，即产生和理解数学的心灵。数学的真正基础不在于公理、定义和逻辑推理，这些是形式数学的基本要素。数学的真正基础在于数学家在与世界互动并试图理解世界时的心灵——他们的想法、直觉和审美感性。

The best way to think about mathematics is to include not only the content dimension of algorithms, procedures, theorems, and proofs but also the cognitive dimensions of learning, understanding, and creating mathematics. In an early critique of Formalism the great French mathematician Henri Poincaré wrote, “The logical point of view alone seems to interest [Hilbert]ii. Being given a sequence of propositions, he finds that all follow logically from the first. With the foundation of this first proposition, with its psychological origin, he does not concern himself.” I am interested in Poincaré’s “psychological origin,” that is, in the mind that produces and understands mathematics. The true foundations of mathematics do not lie in axioms, definitions, and logical inference, which are the foundational elements of formal mathematics. The true foundations of mathematics lie in the minds of mathematicians as they interact with and try to make sense of their world—in their ideas, their intuitions, and their aesthetic sensibility.

事实上，形式数学系统是基本认知结构（概念系统）的抽象。形式系统是这些概念系统的社会、共识维度，其中剥离了认知元素。但它没有任何意义，无论是数学意义还是其他意义，除非通过学习、认识和理解重新赋予它生命。因此，抽象结构本身不是数学。学习和研究是将生命重新引入学科的过程。你让它回到真正的数学中，就像你让研究论文重新焕发生机一样——不是被动地阅读，而是找出它的核心思想。如果这个过程成功了，就会让人惊叹：“啊！现在我明白发生了什么。”真正的数学是活的，是思想赋予了它生命！

In fact a formal mathematical system is an abstraction of a basic cognitive structure—a conceptual system. The formal system is the social, consensual dimension of these conceptual systems with the cognitive elements stripped away. But it has no meaning, either mathematical or otherwise, unless it is brought back to life by learning, knowing, and understanding. Thus an abstract structure is not in itself mathematics. Learning and research are the processes whereby life is reintroduced to the subject. You make it back into real mathematics in the same way that you put life back into a research paper—not by reading it passively but by ferreting out its core ideas. If this process is successful it results in the exclamation, “Ah! Now I see what is going on.” Real mathematics is alive and it is the mind that gives it life!

我一直把以二元论的眼光看待数学的情况称为建设性模糊性。数学是一门学科，可以从两个角度来看待它——内容的理论角度或概念和概念系统的认知角度。这两个角度是相互丰富的。形式定理和证明加深了我们对所涉及概念的理解。相反，更深的概念理解会带来新的、更好的定理。

Viewing mathematics in such a dualistic way is the kind of situation that I have been calling a constructive ambiguity. You have one subject, mathematics, which can be looked at from two perspectives—the theoretical perspective of its content or the cognitive perspective of concepts and conceptual systems. These two perspectives are mutually enriching. The formal theorems and proofs deepen our understanding of the concepts involved. Conversely a deeper conceptual understanding leads to new and better theorems.

数学的理论维度和认知维度显然不是相互独立的。前面的章节利用它们之间的对应关系，从数学的概念发展的角度对数学的教学和学习提出了观察和建议。在本章中，我打算反过来看看这种对应关系能告诉我们关于数学本质的什么信息。

The theoretical and cognitive dimensions of mathematics are obviously not independent of one another. Earlier chapters utilized the correspondence between them to make observations and suggestions about teaching and learning mathematics that come from the conceptual development of the subject. In this chapter I intend to turn matters around and see what this correspondence can tell us about the nature of mathematics.

内容和认知之间的深层关系尚未被普遍认识到，因为主流数学哲学柏拉图主义和形式主义都压制了主体的认知维度。它们充当概念系统；在实践中，数学与通过这些哲学之窗所看到的完全相同。柏拉图主义假定存在某种理想领域，不受人类干预，数学的永恒真理就存在于其中。形式主义明确将理论维度——演绎系统——与主体的整体联系起来。我对柏拉图主义和形式主义之间的争论不感兴趣，原因很简单，这些观点假设“数学”是指数学的客观内容、计算方法、定理和证明。现在是时候提出另一种观点——一种新的概念系统——它更符合当代数学的现实。

The deep relationship between content and cognition are not generally recognized because the dominant philosophies of mathematics, Platonism and Formalism, both suppress the cognitive dimension of the subject. They function as a conceptual system; in practice mathematics is identical to what is seen through the window of these philosophies. Platonism postulates some ideal domain that exists independent of human intervention in which the timeless truths of mathematics reside. Formalism explicitly identifies the theoretical dimension—the deductive system—with the entirety of the subject. I am not interested in the argument between Platonism and Formalism for the simple reason that these points of view assume that “mathematics” means the objective content of mathematics, its computational methods, theorems, and proofs. The time is ripe for another point of view—a new conceptual system—that is more consistent with the reality of contemporary mathematics.

数学发展始于极早期，正如我们所见，它似乎是从婴儿出生时就具有的核心概念结构中建立起来的。数学认知是人类与世界互动的最基本方式之一。我们是数学生物。出于毫无疑问的进化原因，大自然优先发展了数字、秩序和数量等数学概念。因此，当我们考虑一般的认识论问题时，数学是一个很好的研究对象。换句话说，正确理解数学将使我们深入了解人性、自然世界的结构以及它们之间的关系。相反，从更一般的角度来看待数学将带来一种理解和欣赏数学的新方式。

Mathematical development begins at an extremely early age and, as we saw, it appears to be built up from core conceptual structures that infants are born with. Mathematical cognition is one of the most basic ways in which human beings interact with the world. We are mathematical beings. For what are no doubt good evolutionary reasons, nature has privileged the development of mathematical notions like number, order, and quantity. It follows that mathematics is a good place to look when we consider general epistemological questions. In other words understanding mathematics properly will give us great insight into human nature, the structure of the natural world, and the relationship between them. Conversely looking at mathematics from a more general perspective will lead to a new way to understand and appreciate mathematics.

9.2真正的数学是概念数学

9.2Real Mathematics is Conceptual Mathematics

数学有两种类型。第一种是形式理论——欧几里得几何就是一个很好的例子——有公理、定义和证明。第二种涉及人类对主题的内部表征——认知维度。大多数人最接近描述这种二分法的是他们讨论非正式数学与正式数学时。“非正式”可能指的是人们将数学视为考虑理解和直觉等因素，因此形式要求（例如证明）被放宽了。近年来，我们看到越来越多的数学形式要求有所放宽，例如实验数学，它与计算机的复杂使用有关。即使在这里，也有人争论这种工作是否是“真正的”数学，其中“真正的”是指数学严谨的古典理想。然而，关于什么是真正的数学的共识观点在过去已经发生了多次变化，今天也在发生变化。

Mathematics comes in two flavors. The first is the formal theory— Euclidean geometry is a good example—with its axioms, definitions, and proofs. The second involves human beings’ internal representations of the subject—the cognitive dimension. The closest most people come to describing this dichotomy is when they discuss informal versus formal mathematics. “Informal” might refer to mathematics where one takes into consideration things like understanding and intuition and so the formal requirements—for proof, for example—are loosened. In recent years we have seen more of mathematics in which the formal requirements have been relaxed somewhat—experimental mathematics,iii for example, which is associated with the sophisticated use of computers. Even here there is a debate about whether this kind of work is “real” mathematics where “real” refers to the classical ideal of mathematical rigor. However the consensus view about what constitutes real mathematics is something that has changed many times in the past and is changing today.

今天，我们正处于一个时代的终结，这个时代以试图将严谨性和形式主义作为数学的决定性特征而闻名。这一尝试源于非欧几里得几何的出现所带来的危机以及与微积分和实数系统相关的问题和悖论。这是一次使数学完全客观和普遍的尝试，这在实践中意味着将数学的内容与数学过程分开——将数学作为知识与数学作为一种认识方式分开。

We stand today at the end of an era which is notable for an attempt to make rigor and formalism into the defining characteristics of mathematics. This attempt arose out of the crisis associated with the advent of non-Euclidean geometries and the problems and paradoxes associated with calculus and the real number system. It was an attempt to make mathematics completely objective and universal, which in practice meant separating the content of mathematics from the process of doing mathematics—mathematics as knowledge from mathematics as a way of knowing.

这种倾向的开端可以追溯到欧几里得几何，当时欧几里得试图为他的体系中的所有事物提供精确的定义。不幸的是，你无法定义一切，所以他的一些定义（例如点和线的定义）在现代数学家看来是做作和循环的iv。欧几里得的论证看起来似乎合乎逻辑，但它们通常是以几何图表为基础的。从一个角度来看，这是他的体系的弱点，因为论证往往微妙地依赖于图表。然而，你也可以从相反的角度来思考这种“缺陷”，即欧几里得几何的优点。是的，我们确实将我们的几何直觉带入了欧几里得几何。这并不贬低这一创建演绎和严谨体系的杰出尝试。相反，它告诉我们一些关于严谨在数学中的正确作用和价值的宝贵信息。欧几里得几何是一门奇妙的学科，并不是因为它摒弃了人的因素，而是因为它成功地将逻辑和直觉结合在一起，同时建立了一种演绎演绎系统的作用是消除认知因素，同时吸引和培养实践者的创造力。认为演绎系统的作用是消除认知因素，这是由于形式主义的过度而产生的错误。欧几里得几何告诉我们，逻辑严谨性可以与最深刻的直觉共存。欧几里得几何中几乎每一个演绎和命题的解决都需要创造力的火花——通常是几何构造。一代又一代的数学家、科学家，甚至人文学科的人们都发现欧几里得几何不仅是逻辑论证的训练场，也是创造力和深度思考的训练场。

You can see the beginnings of this tendency as far back as Euclidean geometry when Euclid tried to supply a precise definition for everything that formed a part of his system. Unfortunately it turns out that you just cannot define everything and so some of his definitions—of points and lines, for example—look contrived and circular to the modern mathematicianiv. Euclid’s arguments look as though they are logically solid but they are usually made with a geometric diagram in mind. From one point of view this is a weakness of his system because the arguments often depend subtly on a diagram. However you can also think of this “deficiency” in the opposite way, as a strength of Euclidean geometry. Yes, it is true that we bring our geometric intuitions to Euclidean geometry. This does not demean this brilliant attempt at creating a system that is deductive and rigorous. On the contrary it tells us something valuable about the proper role and value of rigor in mathematics. Euclidean geometry is a wonderful subject, not because it does away with the human element, but because it so successfully marries logic and intuition, simultaneously building up a deductive system while it engages and trains the creative resources of the practitioner. The notion that the role of a deductive system is to do away with the cognitive element is a mistake that arose with the excesses of formalism. Euclidean geometry tells us that logical rigor can coexist with the deepest intuition. The resolution of almost every deduction and proposition in Euclidean geometry requires a spark of creativity—often a geometric construction. Generations of mathematicians, scientists, and even people in the humanities have found Euclidean geometry to be a training ground, not only for logical argumentation, but also for creativity and deep thinking.

在将知识与认知分离的方向上，最终的成功将是计算机生成的数学。正如我在其他地方所指出的那样，这种尝试很有趣，但最终注定会失败。试图产生这样一门“客观”学科最终是一种梦想，它被一种超越人类状况的徒劳尝试所驱动。即使我们不是永生的，我们也希望能够创造出一些永恒的东西，一些永远不会消亡的东西。不幸的是，在数学和科学中产生“永久”理论不是一个现实或富有成效的目标。任何被创造的东西都注定会改变，很可能最终会变得无关紧要。如果在任何地方都能找到超越，那就是在变化中，而不是用一个永远不会改变的理论框架来取代变化。在数学、科学和生活中，进化最终将拥有最终决定权。

The ultimate success in the direction of separating knowledge from cognition would be the production of computer-generated mathematics. As I have argued elsewhere, such attempts are interesting but ultimately doomed to failure. The attempt to produce such an “objective” discipline is ultimately a dream driven by a futile attempt to transcend the human condition. Even if we are not immortal we hope that we can produce something permanent, something that will never die. Unfortunately the production of “permanent” theories in mathematics and science is not a realistic or productive goal. Whatever is created is doomed to change and quite possibly to eventually descend into irrelevance. If transcendence is to be found anywhere it is within change and not by replacing change with a theoretical framework that will never change. In mathematics as in science and in life, evolution will ultimately have the final word.

让我们最终公开承认，如果“真正的”数学指的是客观的、永远不会改变的学科，那么它就不存在。让我们放弃柏拉图式的梦想和形式主义的梦想的简单版本。真正的数学是概念数学。真正的数学是一种创造性和发展的艺术形式。作为其基本要素的概念和思想并不存在于教科书、研究论文或任何形式数学中——这些东西仅仅是数学的表现形式，它们的主要目的是唤起活生生的思想和概念。思想和概念并不存在于印刷品中；它们存在于数学家的头脑中。这可能就是伟大的法国数学家勒内·托姆曾说过，如果该领域最优秀的五位数学家都认为某条定理是正确的，那么该定理就是正确的。概念存在于个人的头脑中，但也存在于社会背景中——在课堂上和数学家社区中。

Let us finally admit openly that there is no “real” mathematics if by that we mean a subject that is objective and will never change. Let us give up on the simplistic version of both the Platonic dream and also the dream of Formalism. Real mathematics is conceptual mathematics. Real mathematics is a creative and developmental art form. The concepts and ideas that are its essential elements do not live in the textbook or research paper or in formal mathematics of any sort—these things are merely representations of mathematics and their principal purpose consists in evoking living ideas and concepts. Ideas and concepts do not exist in print; they exist in the minds of mathematicians. This is probably what the great French mathematician René Thom had in mind when he said that a theorem is true if the five best mathematicians in the field affirm that it is. Concepts live within the mind of the individual but they also live in a social context—in the classroom and in the community of mathematicians.

9.3以新视角看待数学的后果

9.3Consequences of Looking at Mathematics in a New Way

接受“真正的数学是概念数学”这一观点的后果是什么？首先，我们必须以不同的方式看待数学和学习中存在问题的方面。这门学科的发展发生在个人和整个数学界的头脑中。它起源于出现问题和故障的地方。说“这没有意义”或“这是一个矛盾”，然后就此打住，这不会给你带来任何好处。为什么它没有意义？我怎样才能改变这种情况，使它现在有意义？这些都是更好的问题。所有系统都有其局限性、有效性区域，有趣的事情发生在边界上。一个有趣的悖论是无价之宝——你可以肯定其中隐藏着许多优秀的数学知识。想想康托集这个绝佳的例子，它很小，因为它的长度为零，但它很大，因为它的基数与实数相同。这个例子中产生了巨大的数学财富：不仅加深了对实数的理解，而且还介绍了奇异吸引子和分形等深奥的数学思想。

What are the consequences of accepting the idea that real mathematics is conceptual mathematics? For one thing we would have to look at the problematic aspects of mathematics and of learning in a different way. The growth of the subject takes place in the minds of individuals and the mathematical community as a whole. It has its origins in the places where problems and breakdowns occur. To say, “This does not make sense,” or “this is a contradiction,” and leave it at that will not get you anywhere. Why does it not make sense? How can I change the situation so that it now makes sense? These are better kinds of questions. All systems have their limitations, their regions of validity, and interesting things happen at the boundary. An interesting paradox is worth its weight in gold—you can be sure that there is a lot of good mathematics that is hiding inside of it. Think of the wonderful example of the Cantor set, which is tiny because it has length zero but is huge because it has the same cardinality as the real numbers. Enormous mathematical riches came out of this example: not only a deeper appreciation of the real numbers but also an introduction to deep mathematical ideas like strange attractors and fractals.

数学的进步以及一个人对数学理解的进步都源于问题的解决。如果像躲避瘟疫一样避免非逻辑元素，这种情况就不会发生。如果没有非正式、直观的方法，这种情况也不会发生。一个想法与从一组公理中形式化和逻辑推导这个想法之间存在着重大差异。数学最终是关于想法的，而想法具有认知维度。

Advances in mathematics, and advances in a person’s understanding of mathematics, come out of the resolution of problems. This does not happen if non-logical elements are avoided like the plague. It equally does not happen if there is no place for informal, intuitive approaches. There is a major difference between an idea and the formalization and logical derivation of that idea from a set of axioms. Mathematics is ultimately about ideas and ideas have a cognitive dimension.

9.4数学是非正式的

9.4Mathematics is Informal

改变我们对数学本质的看法将改变形式数学和非形式数学之间的关系。我们在第五章中看到，严谨性和形式主义只出现在创造过程的最后阶段，而其他阶段则是非正式的。我们习惯于用形式化版本来定义整个主题，这就是我们在研究专著和教科书中经常看到的内容。从形式的角度来看，非正式并不重要——结果才是最重要的；如何实现结果并不那么重要。认知方法将改变形式和非正式之间的关系——如何实现结果——你的理解——与最终结果同样重要。没有非正式的形式是无用的。

Shifting our perspective on the nature of mathematics would change the relationship between formal and informal mathematics. We saw in chapter five that rigor and formalism only come in at the final stage of the creative process whereas the other stages are informal. We are used to identifying the entire subject with its formalized version, which is what we see in research monographs and often in textbooks. From a formal perspective the informal is not significant—the result is all that matters; how you get there is not as important. A cognitive approach would change the relationship between the formal and the informal— how you get there—your understanding—is every bit as important as the final result. The formal without the informal is sterile.

非形式化数学缺乏严格的演绎系统所具有的严谨性和精确性。儿童数学是非形式化的，但将非形式化视为我们应该努力摆脱的幼稚观点将是一个严重的错误。一个更好的观点是，所有数学，尤其是做数学和学习数学的过程，都是非形式化的。形式化最好被视为与其他元素相互作用的非形式化元素。例如，你正在学习数学的某个部分，通过处理示例、几何图等，你对正在发生的事情有所了解。这是非形式化的工作。然后，你尝试将其写下来（形式化），并意识到最初的想法有问题。由此产生了另一个想法（非形式化），你试图将其纳入证明（形式化）等等。

Informal mathematics lacks the complete rigor and precision that come from being embedded into a strict deductive system. Children’s mathematics is informal but it would be a grave mistake to regard the informal as a childish perspective that we should attempt to grow out of. A better perspective is that all of mathematics, especially the process of doing and learning mathematics, is informal. The formal is best viewed as an element of the informal that interacts with other elements. For example, you are studying some part of mathematics and you get an idea of what is going on by working with examples, with geometric diagrams, and so forth. This is informal work. Then you try to write it up (formalize) and realize that there is something wrong with the initial idea. Out of this comes another idea (informal) that you try to incorporate into the proof (formal) and so on.

从历史上看，如果以现代标准来判断，许多数学都是不拘泥于形式的。欧拉在无穷级数方面的工作并不完全严格。牛顿和莱布尼茨对微积分的发展需要近一个世纪的努力才能以现代数学家认为可以接受的方式发展。甚至欧几里得的几何学也不是严格的。然而，欧拉、牛顿和莱布尼茨——更不用说欧几里得了——是有史以来最伟大的数学家。显然，这些人都在做数学，显然逻辑论证是他们工作的一部分，但不是全部。然而，逻辑的使用比大多数人要微妙得多人们今天仍然认为这是理所当然的。用于微积分和无穷级数的非正式方法一直被人们接受，直到它们开始产生异常和悖论。然后，人们必须更深入地研究该学科的基础，以便弄清楚到底发生了什么。这个过程同样是由问题驱动的。逻辑阐述是对问题的回应，但它也产生了额外的问题和见解。换句话说，以这种方式看待事物将严谨的过程融入了更大、更基本的做数学和学数学的过程之中。

Historically, a great deal of mathematics was informal if judged by modern standards. The work of Euler on infinite series was not completely rigorous. The development of the calculus by Newton and Leibniz needed nearly a century of work on its foundations before it could be developed in a manner that the modern mathematician would consider acceptable. Even the geometry of Euclid was not rigorous. Yet Euler, Newton, and Leibniz —not to speak of Euclid—were some of the greatest mathematicians of all time. Obviously these people were doing mathematics and clearly logical argumentation was part but not all of their work. However the use of logic is much more subtle than most people today give it credit for. The informal methods that were in use for calculus and infinite series were accepted until they began to produce anomalies and paradoxes. Then it became necessary to delve more deeply into the foundations of the subject in order to sort out what was really going on. Again the process is driven by the problematic. The logical exposition arises in response to the problematic but it also generates additional problems and insights. In other words looking at things in this way integrates the process of rigor within the larger and more fundamental process of doing and learning mathematics.

伟大的印度数学家拉马努金的例子很好地说明了整个情况，他只对证明的性质有基本的了解，就提出了最非凡的数学。他的导师，剑桥大学的 G. H. 哈代，费了好大劲才向他解释相对较新的欧洲严谨标准，并说服拉马努金相信其必要性。人们可能会说，拉马努金的数学大部分（如果不是全部的话）都是非正式的，但没有人会否认这是最高水平的数学。拉马努金——他本人和他的作品——完美地说明了数学的神秘深度和数学中出现的创造性过程。它对我们了解数学活动的本质有很大的帮助，正是因为一个看似不可或缺的元素——它的形式结构——只存在于最基本的术语中。

The whole situation is beautifully illustrated by the case of the great Indian mathematician Ramanujanv who came up with the most extraordinary mathematics with only a rudimentary knowledge of the nature of proof. His mentor, G. H. Hardy at Cambridge, had a great deal of trouble trying to explain to him the relatively new European standards for rigor and convince Ramanujan of its necessity. One might say that most, if not all, of Ramanujan’s mathematics was informal but no one would deny that it was mathematics at the very highest level. Ramanujan—the man and the work—beautifully illustrates the mysterious depths of mathematics and the creative process as it arises in mathematics. It has a great deal to teach us about the nature of mathematical activity precisely because one of the seemingly indispensible elements—its formal structure—is present in only rudimentary terms.

Reuben Hersh vi最近的一篇论文阐述了形式数学和非形式数学、纯数学和应用数学之间微妙的关系。他讨论了现代数学处理无穷级数的矛盾方式。无穷级数的基本问题是它们是收敛（加起来等于某个确定的数）还是发散（不收敛）。理论上，级数是收敛还是发散只取决于级数的“无穷尾”——初始项a 1、a 2、…、a N（其中 N 可能非常大）可以更改或省略，而不会影响级数的收敛性。另一方面，假设给你一个实际的级数，有人问你认为它是收敛还是发散。你会怎么做？练习？应用数学家会怎么做？赫什指出，他们做的和每个学生都会做的一样 — — 开始加法，也许借助计算机。如果他们发现得到的和越来越接近 — — 比如说，在把前五项相加后，所有后续和都精确到小数点后两位，在把 20 项相加后，所有和都精确到小数点后 5 位，在把 50 项相加后，精确到小数点后 15 位 — — 那么大多数人会得出结论，该级数收敛。请注意，所有这些信息都是通过使用有限数量的项获得的，理论认为这些项是无关紧要的。这个过程没有任何正式价值，但具有很大的启发性或非正式价值。只有在你有非常好的非正式证据证明该级数收敛后，你才会试图证明它。

A recent paper by Reuben Hershvi illustrates the uneasy relationship between formal and informal mathematics, and pure and applied mathematics. He discusses the paradoxical manner in which infinite series are dealt with in modern mathematics. The essential question about infinite series is whether they converge (add up to some definite number) or diverge (do not converge). According to theory whether a series converges or diverges only depends on the “infinite tail” of the series—the initial terms, a1,a2,…,aN, (where N can be very large), can be changed or omitted without affecting the convergence of the series. On the other hand suppose you are given some actual series and someone asks you whether you think it converges or diverges. What do you do in practice? What would an applied mathematician do? Hersh points out that they do what every student would do—they start adding, perhaps with the aid of a computer. If they discover that the resulting sums are getting closer and closer together—say after adding the first five terms all subsequent sums agree to two decimals places, after 20 terms they all agree to 5 decimals places, after 50 terms to 15 decimals places—then most people will conclude that the series converges. Notice that all of this information is obtained by using a finite number of terms, which the theory says are irrelevant. This process is of no formal value whatsoever but it is of great heuristic or informal value. Only after you have very good informal evidence that the series converges would you try to prove it.

非形式数学通常以这种方式进行——通过归纳和模式识别。当然，有些人更敏感，他们能看到别人看不到的模式。拉马努金就是一个著名的例子，他发现了别人做梦也想不到的规律。有人评论他的配分函数公式说，居然有人凭直觉知道这样的公式可能存在，更不用说知道公式的具体形式了，这真是太不可思议了。我们倾向于认为，尽管拉马努金缺乏正规训练，但他仍然很有创造力，但也许正是缺乏训练（以及他特殊的宗教信仰）才让他如此有独创性。

Informal mathematics often works in this way—by induction and through the recognition of patterns. Of course some people are more sensitive and see patterns where others see nothing. Ramanujan is a famous example of someone who discerned regularities that no one else even dreamed of. Someone commented about his formula for the partition function that it was extraordinary that anyone intuited that such a formula might exist much less the particular form that the formula would take. We tend to think that Ramanujan was so creative despite his lack of formal training but maybe it was precisely that lack of training (and also the particular form of his religious beliefs) that made him such an original mind.

正如我在整本书中指出的那样，为了进行创造性工作，大脑必须经历交替的专注和放松阶段，右半球过程的主导地位必须与左半球过程的主导地位交替。严谨与左半球有关：与专注的思想、分析和以某种方式封闭有关。非正式与右半球有关：与直觉、综合、数学游戏、实验和开放有关。数学涉及两者之间的相互作用。大多数人认为分析和正式才是最终决定权，但我更喜欢把它交给好玩和创造性，也就是非正式。

As I have pointed out throughout the book, in order to do creative work the mind must go through alternating periods of focusing and relaxation, the dominance of right hemispheric processes must alternate with those of the left. Rigor is connected with the left hemisphere: with the focused mind, analysis, and with closing down in a certain way. The informal is connected to the right hemisphere: to intuition, synthesis, mathematical play, experimentation, and opening up. Mathematics involves an interaction between the two. Most people give the last word to the analytic and formal but I prefer to give it to the playful and the creative, that is, the informal.

9.5概念和定义

9.5Concept and Definition

质疑数学逻辑结构的作用时产生的另一个问题是我在第八章中提到的概念和定义之间的关系。在形式数学中，概念等同于其定义。（形式）数学世界中的每个元素都有一个定义，反之，如果它没有严格的定义，它就不是数学的一部分。从这个角度来看，数学是关于精确定义的实体、它们的属性和关系。从定义开始，然后开发已定义对象的属性及其与其他明确定义的对象的关系。

Another thing that comes out of questioning the role of the logical structure of mathematics concerns the relationship between concept and definition that I referred to in chapter eight. In formal mathematics a concept is identical to its definition. Every element in the (formal) mathematical universe has a definition and conversely if it does not have a strict definition it is not a part of mathematics. In this vision mathematics is about precisely defined entities, their properties and relationships. One begins with the definition and then develops the properties of the defined object and its relationships with other well-defined objects.

非正式数学是否使用概念？如果是，这些概念是什么？当发展心理学家谈论“核心概念”或婴儿的“数字概念”时，他们使用“概念”一词的方式是否与数学家讨论连续性时的方式相同？要回答这些问题，就必须讨论概念的性质。

Does informal mathematics use concepts and, if so, what kind of concepts would these be? When a developmental psychologist talks about “core concepts” or a baby’s “concept of number,” are they using the word “concept” in the same way as a mathematician does when she discusses continuity? To answer such questions necessitates a discussion of the nature of concepts.

什么是“概念”？这个问题有着悠久的历史，我没有足够的篇幅来深入探讨它。许多杰出的思想家都对这个问题发表了看法，毫不奇怪，他们的观点并不一致。我将在接下来的几段中尝试找出一些突出的问题。然而，首先让我承认，我一直在非正式地使用“概念”这个词，我的用法并不完全一致。

What is a “concept?” This is a question with a long and distinguished history that I don’t have the space to go into in the depth that it deserves. Many eminent thinkers have weighed in on this question and, not surprisingly, they do not agree with one another. I shall try to isolate some of the salient questions in the next couple of paragraphs. However first let me own up to the fact that I have been using the word “concept” in an informal manner that my usage has not been completely consistent.

数学家工作中使用的“概念”与发展心理学家使用的“概念”有何不同？一方面，数学家的概念基于文字和符号，而婴儿不会说话。关于概念是否依赖于文字确实存在争议，双方都有非常聪明的人。例如，语言学家诺姆·乔姆斯基主张概念依赖于文字，而让·皮亚杰等心理学家则持相反观点。大多数数学家和科学家可能会说，概念不仅依赖于文字，还依赖于逻辑和符号表示。

What is the difference between the use of “concept” in the work of mathematicians and the “concept” used by developmental psychologists? For one thing the mathematician’s concepts are based on words and symbols whereas the baby is non-verbal. There is indeed a debate about whether concepts depend on words and there are very smart people on both sides of this debate. The linguist Noam Chomsky, for example, argued for the verbal dependence of concepts whereas psychologists such as Jean Piaget claimed the opposite. Most mathematicians and scientists would probably say that concepts depend not only on words but also on logic and symbolic representations.

第二个问题是，用伟大的哲学家伊曼纽尔·康德的话来说，概念是先验的还是后验的。也就是说，它们是内在的还是来自经验？核心概念的概念似乎倾向于先验方向。另一方面，有一种观点认为，概念是从大量具体经验中抽象出来的。让我们重新考虑“数字”的概念。它从未在数学中定义过，尽管它一直在使用，可以被认为是所有数学中最基本的元素。定义的是我所说的各种数字系统——计数数字、有理数、实数和复数等等。现在你可以把“数字”看作是这些各种特定数字的抽象。这种方法的问题在于，这意味着与发展和历史的方向背道而驰。在我们知道一、二和三以外的任何数字之前，我们“知道”了一些数字概念。事实上，我们有（至少）两个专门用于“数字”的核心系统。

A second question is whether concepts are, in the words of the great philosopher Emmanuel Kant, a priori or a posteriori. That is, are they built-in or do they come from experience? The notion of core concepts seems to lean in the a priori direction. On the other hand there is the view that a concept is abstracted from a multitude of specific experiences. Let’s reconsider the concept of “number.” It is never defined in mathematics even though it is used all the time and could be considered the most basic element in all of mathematics. What is defined are the various number systems that I have spoken of—counting numbers, rational numbers, real and complex numbers, and so on. Now you could consider “number” as an abstraction of these various specific kinds of numbers. The problem with that approach is that this would mean going in the opposite direction from the developmental and the historical. We “know” something of the concept of number before we know any numbers beyond one, two, and three. In fact we have (at least) two core systems devoted to “number.”

有些人牢记我对正式概念和非正式概念的区分，用“数量”一词代替了“数字”。数量是指“趋向于数字”。出于同样的原因，我在《盲点》一书中使用了“原始概念”一词，即区分非正式趋势和正式定义的实体。

Some people, bearing in mind the distinction I made between formal concepts and their more informal variety, have substituted the word “numerosity,” for the word “number.” Numerosity refers to the “tendency towards number.” I used the term “proto-concept” in my book The Blind Spot, for the same reason, namely to distinguish between an informal tendency and the formally defined entity.

我们似乎生来就倾向于用“数字”和相关的“数量”概念来安排世界。这些早期的核心系统为我们提供了进一步发展的方向。正如我前面提到的，这些核心系统以及这种倾向在我们的一生中一直活跃。这种倾向之所以活跃，是因为“什么是数字？”或“什么是数量？”或者更简单地说，“多少？”和“多少？”这个根本问题从未得到完全解决。通过我们在家里和学校对数字的体验，我们以特定数字系统的形式对这些问题形成了越来越复杂的答案：计数数字、整数、分数等等。经验和天生的倾向结合起来，产生了一种发展的数字概念——不断变化和成长——它包含了我所提到的所有六个类别的元素。一直在讨论：正式的、非正式的、口头的、非口头的、先验的、后验的。

It would seem that we are born with a tendency towards ordering the world by means of “number” and the related concept of “quantity.” These early core systems give us a direction for further development. As I mentioned earlier these core systems, and therefore this tendency, remain active throughout our lives. The tendency remains active because the fundamental problem, “What is number?” or “What is quantity?” or more simply, “How much?” and “How many?” is never fully resolved. Through our experience of number at home and at school we develop more and more sophisticated answers to these questions in the form of specific number systems: the counting number, the integers, the fractions, and so on. Experience and innate tendencies combine to produce a concept of number that is developmental—that changes and grows—and contains elements of all of the six categories that I have been discussing: formal, informal, verbal, non-verbal, a priori, a posteriori.

康德还使用分析和综合的范畴来指代概念，我在本书的其他地方讨论过这种区别。这给出了与“概念”这一想法相关的八个相互关联的属性。概念很可能是所有这些属性的复杂混合体。它具有言语和非言语方面。它源于某种内置事物，但也可能从许多具体经验中抽象出来。它既有分析维度，也有综合维度。所有这些范畴不应被视为互相排斥，而应视为说明“概念”的不同维度。如果我们问“数字（的概念）是什么”这个问题，我们不应该期待一个“正确”和明确的答案，而应该期待一个随着时间而增长和变化的过程。概念不是一个固定的实体。

Kant also used the categories of analytic and synthetic to refer to concepts and I have discussed this distinction elsewhere in the book. This gives eight inter-related properties associated to the idea of “concept.” It may well be that a concept is a complex mélange of all of these properties. It has verbal and non-verbal aspects. It arises from something that is built-in but may also be abstracted from many specific experiences. It has both an analytic and a synthetic dimension. All of these categories should not be approached as mutually exclusive but rather as illustrating different dimensions of “concept.” If we ask the question, “What is (the concept of) number,” we should not be expecting a “correct” and definitive answer but a process that grows and changes in time. A concept is not a fixed entity.

概念有“外延意义”和“内涵意义”。内涵类似于“非正式”意义。回想一下 Tall 和 Vinner 的“概念意象”，即思考或使用概念的所有可能方式的总和。内涵意象不是“明确定义的”——你无法在字典中查找它。它具有可塑性，可以随时扩展以覆盖新领域；它总是可以用新的方式来看待。每当诗人写下一个隐喻——形式为 A是B的东西——她就给了我们A的新内涵。即使是时间、空间和数字等科学概念也具有隐喻维度。实际上，它们是隐喻，而不是对象，但这并不意味着它们不真实或模糊。David Tall 在他最近的著作《人类如何学会数学思考》中使用了令人回味的术语“结晶概念”，强调了概念的丰富性和多维性。

Concepts have a “denoted meaning” and a “connoted meaning.” The connotation is something like the “informal” meaning. Recall Tall and Vinner’s “concept image,” the totality of all possible ways of thinking of, or working with, the concept. The connoted image is not “well-defined”—you cannot look it up in the dictionary. It is malleable and can always expand to cover new territory; it can always be viewed in a new way. Every time a poet writes down a metaphor—something of the form A is B—she is giving us a new connotation for A. Even scientific ideas like time, space, and number have a metaphoric dimension. Actually they are metaphors as opposed to being objects but this does not make them unreal or vague. The richness of and multi-dimensional nature of concepts is highlighted by David Tall’s use of the evocative term “crystalline concept” in his recent book How Humans Learn to Think Mathematically.

然而，概念不仅仅是不同隐喻内涵的集合，因为概念是单一的。我们可能很难确切说明“数字”的含义，但我们感觉“数字”确实指代某个特定事物。概念图像的元素是集中的或综合的。这告诉我们，概念的内涵意义是人工智能的问题，你会记得人工智能通过创建统一体或格式塔来发挥作用——一支笔，一张桌子，一个关于“数字”或“空间”或“时间”的想法。一个可以从多个角度看待的统一体

However a concept is not merely a collection of disparate metaphoric connotations because a concept is singular. It may be hard to specify exactly what we mean by “number” but we have the feeling that there is indeed some particular thing to which “number” refers. The elements of the concept image are focused or synthesized. This tells us that the connoted meaning of a concept is a matter of the synthetic intelligence which you will recall functions by creating unities or gestalts—one pen, one desk, one idea for “number” or “space” or “time.” One unity that can be looked at from multiple points of view

另一方面，外延意义显然是分析性的。在科学中，人们通常认为我们处理的是具有精确定义的“外延概念”。但即使在科学中，情况也并非如此。考虑时间、空间、数字、随机性等概念。我们“知道”它们的含义；即使我们无法给出定义，我们也对它们有直觉。这告诉我们，我们正在处理“内涵意义”。然后，我们可以尝试使含义精确。例如，我们可以假设空间是一个三维连续体，由所有可能的有序三元组 (x,y,z) 组成，其中 x、y 和 z 是实数。这将捕捉到我们在以更非正式、内涵意义使用“空间”时的部分含义，但不是全部含义。没有什么可以阻止内涵概念产生多个外延意义。例如，我们有平坦的牛顿三维空间（欧几里得空间），而爱因斯坦有四维弯曲时空。不同的表示含义甚至可以产生不相交的理论，就像随机性的概念一样，它可以发展成概率和统计的正态理论，或者柯尔莫哥洛夫和柴廷的算法随机性。

The denoted meaning, on the other hand, is clearly analytic. In science it is generally assumed that we are dealing with “denoted concepts” with precise definitions. But even in science this is not true. Consider concepts like time, space, number, randomness, and so on. We “know” what they mean; we have an intuitive feeling for them, even if we are not able to produce a definition. This tells us that we are dealing with the “connoted meaning.” We may then try to make the meaning precise. We may postulate, for example, that space is a three-dimensional continuum consisting of all possible ordered triples, (x,y,z), where x, y, and z are real numbers. This will capture some but not all of what we mean when we use “space” in a more informal, connotative sense. Nothing precludes a connoted concept from generating multiple denoted meanings. For example, we have the flat Newtonian three-dimensional space (Euclidean space) versus the four-dimensional curved space-time of Einstein. Different denoted meanings can even generate theories that are disjoint as we find with the concept of randomness, which can be developed into the normal theories of probability and statistics or into the algorithmic randomness of Kolmogorov and Chaitin.

试图使概念的含义精确化，就是试图确定合成的、隐含的含义，这种尝试总是暂时的，而且必然是不完整的，因为你无法“捕捉”合成的、非正式的想法，就像左脑无法捕捉右脑的活动一样。捕捉它意味着将其转化为适合分析智能使用的对象。这意味着将概念从一个认知领域转移到另一个认知领域。分析和合成各有优缺点。科学和数学正确地涉及了两者之间的关系，而不是试图将一个简化为另一个。

Attempts to make the meaning of a concept precise are attempts to pin down the synthetic, connoted meaning and are always tentative and necessarily incomplete because you can’t “capture” a synthetic and informal idea in the same way that the left hemisphere cannot capture the activities of the right. Capturing it would mean transforming it into an object that is suitable for use by the analytic intelligence. It means transforming the concept from one cognitive domain to another. The analytic and the synthetic each have their own strengths and weaknesses. Science and mathematics properly involve the relationship between the two, not the attempt to reduce one to the other.

这是科学和数学永远要面对的一个限制。困境在于我们必须努力使事物精确，但我们使用的术语本身却不能（完全）精确。这可以从积极或消极的角度来思考。积极的含义在数学中比在科学中更容易接受。它们是数学和科学都是永无止境的过程，就像音乐和艺术也永无止境。科学和数学将继续为基本思想提供源源不断的新含义，并为物理、生物和数学世界的本质提供新的创造性见解。

This is a constraint that science and mathematics will always have to work with. The dilemma is that we must try to make things precise but that the very terms that we use cannot be made (completely) precise. This can be thought of in either a positive or negative way. The positive implications are more acceptable in mathematics than in science. They are that mathematics and science are processes without end in the same way that music and art have no end. Science and mathematics will continue to produce an endless stream of new meanings for basic ideas, and new creative insights into the nature of the physical, biological, and mathematical worlds.

9.6抽象与具体

9.6The Abstract and the Concrete

抽象确实是概念形成的一个基本要素，数学是研究抽象过程最深入的学科。我在第三章介绍了数学处理抽象的方式，但这里可能更适合全面地谈谈抽象和具体作为数学认知的范畴，而不是像通常那样将它们视为数学内容的范畴。从认知的角度来看，抽象最有意义。

Abstraction is indeed an essential element of concept formation and mathematics is the discipline that has investigated the process of abstraction in greater depth than anywhere else. I have introduced the way mathematics handles abstraction in chapter three but this may be the appropriate place to say something more comprehensive about the abstract and the concrete as categories of mathematical cognition as opposed to the usual way of looking at them as categories of mathematical content. Abstraction makes most sense when it is looked at from a cognitive point of view.

数学是一门最抽象和最具体的学科。我们以最具体和最亲密的方式了解数学，因为它与我们许多核心概念系统有关。对大多数人来说，计数数字几乎是触手可及的，在这个层面上，我们感觉不到自己在向一个预先存在的世界添加数字，而是通过数字的过滤器来看待世界。婴儿在学会说话之前就能辨别数量，所以你可以说“数字”比“单词”更基本。数字构成了自然世界和我们自己的内在认知世界，因此它是两者之间最基本的桥梁。如果说有什么是具体的，那就是我在第一章中讨论的数字的核心思想。

Mathematics is simultaneously the most abstract and the most concrete of disciplines. We know it in a concrete and most intimate way because it is implicated in a number of our core conceptual systems. The counting numbers are almost tangible to most people and, at this level, it does not feel as though we add number to a pre-existing world so much as we see the world though the filter of number. Babies can discern quantity before they learn to speak and so you could claim that “number” is more elementary than “word.” Number structures the natural world and our own inner cognitive world and so it is the most basic bridge between the two. If anything at all is concrete it is the core ideas for number that I discussed in chapter one.

另一方面，数学结构是人类智慧最复杂、最抽象的创造物之一。人类竟然能够创造出像实数和复数、分形或费马大定理证明这样微妙而抽象的系统，这真是太了不起了。它们是人类创造物，最接近人类大脑或 DNA 结构的难以置信的复杂性。自然界最深层的趋势之一似乎是趋向于结构化和层次化的复杂性，这种趋势是反映在人类创造性的文化世界中——托尔斯泰的伟大小说、莎士比亚的戏剧、贝多芬和马勒的交响曲、相对论和量子力学的物理学以及纯数学的广阔结构中。

On the other hand mathematical structures are among the most complex and abstract creations of human intelligence. It is extraordinary that human beings have managed to create systems as subtle and abstract as the real and complex numbers, fractals, or the proof of Fermat’s Last Theorem. They are the human creations that best approximate the incredible complexity of the human brain or the structure of DNA. One of the deepest tendencies of the natural world seems to be the tendency towards structured and hierarchical complexity and this tendency is mirrored in the cultural world of human creativity—in the great novels of Tolstoy, the plays of Shakespeare, the symphonies of Beethoven and Mahler, in the physics of Relativity and Quantum Mechanics, and in the sweeping structures of pure mathematics.

具体与抽象、经验与理论之间存在着一种奇妙的关系。具体是否必然以抽象为前提，或者反之亦然，我们需要抽象的范畴来感知具体？我们需要数字的概念来构想计数数字，还是“数字”是我们处理小正整数的经验的抽象？一般来说，我们感知到的世界是一般规律的具体体现吗？这是我们经常思考科学的方式：万有引力定律决定了从树上掉下来的苹果的轨迹。人们曾经认为——现在很多人仍然这样认为——宇宙带有一套蓝图——抽象定律——这些蓝图决定了宇宙后来的大部分历史。这种态度是那句老话的背后原因：“上帝是数学家。”

There is a curious relationship between the concrete and the abstract, the empirical and the theoretical. Does the concrete necessarily presuppose the abstract or, vice versa, do we need abstract categories to perceive the concrete? Do we need the concept of number in order to conceive of the counting numbers or is “number” an abstraction of our experience of working with the small positive integers? In general, is the world that we sense a concrete manifestation of general laws? This is the way we often think about science: there is the law of gravity that determines the trajectory of the apple that falls from the tree. People once thought—and many people still do—that the universe comes with a set of blueprints—abstract laws—which determine a great deal of the subsequent history of the cosmos. This attitude is behind the old expression, “God is a mathematician.”

另一方面，人们普遍认为抽象源于具体。你有大量的数据。你通过忽略某些变量并测量其他变量来抽象数据，但也通过用某些概念描述数据来抽象数据——下落的苹果有质量、位置、速度等等。然后，如果你观察到模式或规律，你可以给它们命名，并称它们为“定律”，就像万有引力定律一样。抽象源于具体，离直接经验的现实只有一步之遥，这几乎是显而易见的。然而，抽象原则往往比经验更真实。如果我们没有概念工具来描述经验，我们会意识到经验吗？这些问题的答案并不明显，仍然存在争议。在本节中，我感兴趣的是数学中抽象与具体的关系，以及这告诉我们具体与抽象之间的一般关系。

On the other hand there is a common belief that the abstract arises out of the concrete. You have a mass of data. You abstract the data by ignoring certain variables and measuring others but also by describing the data in terms of certain concepts—the falling apple has mass, position, velocity, and so on. Then if you observe patterns or regularities you may give these names and call them “laws” like the law of gravity. It seems almost obvious that the abstract arises from the concrete and is a step away from the reality of immediate experience. Yet the abstract principles often seem more real than the experience. Would we even be aware of the experience if we had no conceptual apparatus with which to describe it? The answers to such questions are not at all obvious and remain controversial. In this section I am interested in the relationship of the abstract to the concrete in mathematics and what this tells us about the general relationship between the concrete and the abstract.

20 世纪 60 年代，数学教育中出现了一场运动，称为“新数学”。它试图根据某些抽象原则教授数学。例如，对于每对数字a 和b，a + b = b + a 和ab = ba。这些关系被称为“交换律”，因此学生们被教导要重复3 + 11 = 11 + 3， 因为交换律。人们认为这些定律解释了某些观察到的算术规律背后的原因。但是“定律”能解释为什么某事是真的，为什么某事会发生吗？苹果从树上掉下来“是因为”万有引力定律吗？

In the 1960’s there was a movement in mathematics education called “the new mathematics.” It attempted to teach mathematics on the basis of certain abstract principles. For example for every pair of numbers, a and b, a + b = b + a and ab = ba. These relationships are called the “commutative laws” and so students were taught to repeat that 3 + 11 = 11 + 3 because of the commutative law. It was felt that these laws explained the reason behind certain observed regularities of arithmetic. But does a “law” explain why something is true, why something happens? Does an apple fall from the tree “because” of the law of gravity?

“新数学”试图将当时在研究领域占主导地位的数学哲学引入学校数学。现代数学的大部分内容都涉及对抽象定义的结构的研究，这些结构是用有限的属性列表来定义的。想想加法运算下的整数。其最明显的属性包括 (1) 两个整数相加会得到另一个整数，(2) 加法的顺序无关紧要，(3) 将零加到任何数字上，数字保持不变，(4) 每个整数a都有一个负数-a，使得a + ( -a ) = 0，以及 (5) 对于任意三个元素a、b 和 c，a + ( b + c ) = ( a + b ) + c。如果首先假设一组数学对象具有整数的这些属性（且只有这些属性），则会得到所谓的“阿贝尔群或交换群”。数学家已经发展出一种由“代数学家”或“群论家”研究的关于此类群的复杂理论。这就是抽象的过程，是一种非常强大的思维方式。

The “new mathematics” was an attempt to put into school mathematics a philosophy of mathematics that was dominant at that time in the world of research. Much of modern mathematics involves the study of structures that are defined abstractly, in terms of a finite list of properties. Think of the integers under the operation of addition. Its most obvious properties include (1) when you add two integers you get another, (2) the order of addition does not matter, (3) when you add zero to any number the number is unchanged, (4) every integer, a, has a negative, -a, such that a + (-a) = 0, and (5) for any three elements, a,b, and c, a + (b + c) = (a + b) + c. If you begin by postulating that a set of mathematical objects have these properties of the integers (and only these properties) you get what is called an “Abelian or commutative group.” Mathematicians have developed an elaborate theory of such groups studied by “algebraists” or “group theorists.” This is the process of abstraction and it is a very powerful way of thinking.

然而，发展和学习的方向恰恰相反。交换律对儿童来说并不是先验的。它是通过大量处理正整数的经验来学习的，最明显的是，当孩子发现3 + 12 的最有效方法是从12 开始再数3 ，而不是从3 开始再数12 时。因此，学习通常从具体开始，然后逐渐过渡到抽象。

However development and learning work in the opposite direction. The commutative law is not true for children a priori. It is learned as a result of a great deal of experience working with positive integers, most notably when the child sees that the most efficient way of adding 3 + 12 is to start with the 12 and count 3 more instead of starting with the 3 and counting 12 more. Thus learning usually begins with the concrete and proceeds to the abstract.

我之前提到过，实数系统非常复杂和难以理解。但是，我们可以通过抽象出它的某些更明显的属性来更有效地研究它，比如它的元素在加法下形成一个阿贝尔群，它的非零元素在乘法下也形成一个这样的群。其他从实数中抽象出来的属性，变成了数学主题，可以单独研究，包括实数有一个自然顺序，在加法和乘以正数时保持不变。此外，还有一个自然距离（或两个数字之间的度量（metric）也可以被抽象出来并作为抽象结构来研究。这些从实数中产生的抽象结构都是一盏手电筒，照亮了这个数字系统的不同重要方面。这个过程突出了抽象的价值，即它在将注意力集中在现象的特定方面而忽略其他方面方面的作用。

I mentioned earlier that the system of real numbers is very complex and difficult. However we can study it more efficiently by abstracting out certain of its more obvious properties like the fact that its elements form an Abelian group under addition and that its non-zero elements also form such a group under multiplication. Other properties that have been abstracted from the real numbers and turned into mathematical subjects to be studied in their own right include the fact that there is a natural order for the real numbers which is preserved under addition and multiplication by positive numbers. Also there is a natural distance (or metric) between two numbers and this also can be abstracted and studied as an abstract structure in its own right. Each of these abstract structures that arise out of the real numbers is a flashlight that illuminates different, important aspects of this number system. This process highlights the value of abstraction, namely, its role in focusing the attention on particular aspects of phenomena and ignoring others.

由于抽象将注意力集中在某些特定的特征上，因此它使用闪光灯意识和分析智能。抽象突出了环境中令人担忧的方面，而忽略了其他一切。这样，抽象和具体之间的关系就植根于我们大脑和意识的结构中。抽象是分析智能的自然运用，就像具体和直接与使用思维的综合方式有亲和力一样。我们自然会在两者之间来回切换。

Since abstraction focuses attention on some particular set of features, it follows that it uses flashlight consciousness and the analytic intelligence. Abstraction highlights aspects of the environment that are of concern and ignores everything else. In this way the relationship between the abstract and the concrete has its roots in the structure of our brains and our consciousness. Abstraction is a natural use of the analytic intelligence just as the concrete and the immediate have an affinity to the synthetic way of using the mind. We naturally go back and forth between the two.

9.7数学合乎逻辑吗？

9.7Is Mathematics Logical?

将认知维度视为数学学科的内在组成部分所产生的最重要的后果之一与逻辑的作用有关。对于数学家和非数学家来说，数学和逻辑是不可分割的。数学是逻辑的，反过来说，形式逻辑是数学的，也就是说，数理逻辑如今已成为数学的一个成熟领域。数学和逻辑是如此紧密地交织在一起，以至于许多人会对我断言数学中存在非逻辑的方面感到惊讶。然而，我相信，努力确立逻辑论证在数学中的适当作用不仅对数学很重要，而且对科学和所有其他经常使用数学的学科也很重要。它将向所有在人类活动领域使用逻辑论证作为真理的最终裁决者的人发出一个信息。

One of the most important consequences of thinking of the cognitive dimension as an intrinsic part of the discipline of mathematics concerns the role of logic. For mathematicians and non-mathematicians alike, mathematics and logic are inseparable. Mathematics is logical and, conversely, formal logic is mathematical, that is, mathematical logic is today a well-established field of mathematics. Mathematics and logic are so enmeshed with one another that many people would find my assertion that there are aspects of mathematics that are non-logical to be surprising. Nevertheless I believe that an effort to establish the appropriate role of logical argumentation in mathematics is important not just for mathematics but for the sciences and all other disciplines that use mathematics on a regular basis. It will send a message to all those in whatever field of human endeavor who use logical argumentation as the ultimate arbiter of truth.

逻辑是一种运用思维的方式；它是思考和推理过程的形式化。整本书都试图证明，还有另一种运用思维的方式，即深度思考，而这种思考方式存在于数学。让我回顾一下我在第四章和第五章中讨论的与这些问题相关的几个要素。我区分了使用普通逻辑的分析思维和不使用普通逻辑的综合思维。我认为两者都在数学中发挥着重要作用。我还坚持认为，当你从一个概念系统转移到另一个概念系统时所涉及的深度思考并不是严格合乎逻辑的，或者，如果你愿意的话，它涉及另一种逻辑，我称之为发展逻辑或创造性逻辑。在罗森伯格关于科学创造力的讨论中，我们看到形式逻辑在罗森伯格指定的创造力的第四阶段中占有适当的位置。早期阶段不仅不合逻辑，而且还涉及矛盾的系统使用。在我早期的著作中，我还指出了模糊性和悖论在数学历史发展中的建设性用途。因此，要从发展的角度讨论数学，我们必须重新评估逻辑推理的作用。vii

Logic is a way of using the mind; it is a formalization of the process of thinking and reasoning. This whole book was an attempt to establish the claim that there is another way of using the mind namely, deep thinking, and that this other way of thinking is to be found in mathematics. Let me recall a few elements of my discussion in chapters four and five that bears on these questions. I distinguished analytic thinking, which uses ordinary logic from synthetic thinking, which does not. I argued that both had an important role in mathematics. Also I maintained that deep thinking, the thinking that is involved when you move from one conceptual system to another, is not strictly logical, or, if you will, that another kind of logic is involved that I called developmental or creative logic. In Rothenberg’s discussion of creativity in science we saw that formal logic had its proper place in what Rothenberg designated as the fourth stage of creativity. The earlier stages were not only non-logical but they involved the systematic use of contradiction. In my earlier writing I also pointed to constructive uses of ambiguity and paradox in the historical development of mathematics. It follows that to discuss mathematics from a developmental point of view then we must reassess the role of logical inference.vii

关于逻辑作用的讨论必然是微妙的，因为我们大多数人对分析比对综合更熟悉、更适应。在我们作为世界观察者的立场上，也就是我们在讨论科学时所采取的立场上，我们已经走在了分析的道路上。我们观察世界，把它分解成碎片，然后根据科学定律和逻辑规则重新组装这些碎片。这意味着观察综合很难，更不用说讨论它了。一本书、一篇研究论文或一个理论不得不优先考虑分析，因为它的最终形式来自于使用这种特定的思维方式。

The discussion about the role of logic is necessarily subtle because most of us are much more familiar and comfortable with the analytic than the synthetic. In our stance as observers of the world, which is the stance we take when we discuss science, we are well on the way to the analytic. We observe the world, break it into pieces and reassemble those pieces according to the laws of science and the rules of logic. This means that it is difficult to observe the synthetic much less to discuss it. A book, a research paper, or a theory cannot help but privilege the analytic since its final form comes from using that particular way of thinking.

出于类似的原因，很难掌握创造性思维中的非逻辑元素。科学创造力的最后阶段涉及“写下来”，这意味着将结果转化为逻辑格式。这不仅适用于数学，也适用于所有科学——所有科学期刊对论述风格和用于证明结果“真实性”的标准都有非常严格的要求。这等于说，科学发现过程中涉及的非逻辑元素不可避免地被隐藏起来。几乎每一篇数学或科学期刊文章都不能只是阅读，而必须解读。作者删除了活生生的非正式主题，并用正式而严谨的论证取而代之。希望从论文中学到一些东西的读者必须接受正式的陈述，并在自己的脑海中重新创造被压抑的生命本质。这就是为什么数学研究论文很难读，除非你深入研究这个领域。从非正式到逻辑再回到非正式的过程告诉我们一些关于科学和数学本质的重要信息。

For similar reasons it is difficult to get one’s hands on the non-logical elements in creative thinking. The last stage in scientific creativity involves “writing things up” and this means translating the result into a logical format. This is true of all of science and not just of mathematics—all scientific journals have very strict requirements about the style of discourse and the criteria that are used to justify the “truth” of the result. This amounts to saying that the non-logical elements that are involved in the process of scientific discovery are inevitably hidden from view. Almost every journal article in mathematics or science cannot just be read but must be deciphered. The author has removed the living informal subject and replaced it with a formal and rigorous argument. The reader who hopes to learn something from the paper must take the formal presentation and recreate in his or her own mind that living essence that has been suppressed. That is why research papers in mathematics are hard to read unless you are deeply involved in the field. This process of moving from the informal to the logical and back again tells us something important about the nature of science and mathematics.

逻辑——经典谓词演算——和数学是我们寻求建立客观真理的地方，不仅是科学，也是社会科学、哲学，并最终为政府和商业决策提供依据。当我质疑逻辑是先验的假设时，它超越了人类文化，因此是通往真理的客观指南，它是唯一正确和富有成效的思维方式，所有其他使用思维的方式至少有可能归结为形式逻辑，那么我就是在质疑西方文化中相当一部分的公理之一。受过教育的人如此依赖使用逻辑推理来定位和构建他们的生活，以至于质疑逻辑作为终极价值就像质疑理性本身，因此可能会产生心理影响，带来一种眩晕感，一种失去立足点的感觉，一种陷入混乱的感觉。如果出现这种感觉，我们应该注意，因为创造力正是从这种发酵中产生的。这正是我们在鼓励学生学习新知识时暗中敦促学生进入的状态。

Logic—classical predicate calculus—and mathematics are where we look to establish the objective truth not only of science but also of the social sciences, of philosophy, and ultimately to justify decision making in government and business. When I question the assumption that logic is a priori, that it stands outside of human culture and so is an objective guide to the truth, that it is the only correct and productive way of thinking, and that all other ways of using the mind are, at least potentially, reducible to formal logic, then I am taking issue with one of the axioms of a good part of Western culture. Educated people are so dependent on using logical inference to orient and structure their lives that questioning logic as an ultimate value can seem like questioning rationality itself and therefore may have the psychological effect of bringing on a kind of vertigo, a feeling that one has lost one’s footing, a kind of descent into a form of chaos. We should take note of this feeling if it arises because this is the kind of ferment out of which creativity arises. It is exactly the state that we implicitly urge students to enter when we encourage them to learn something new.

9.7.1谓词演算

9.7.1Predicate Calculus

让我们花点时间思考一下数学中逻辑论证的含义。数学家不使用逻辑真值表来构建他们的论证，但他们经常使用一些非正式的逻辑规则，我现在列出这些规则。

Let’s take a moment and consider what we mean by logical argument in mathematics. Mathematicians do not use logical truth tables to structure their arguments but they constantly use a few informal logical rules, which I now list.

（1）其中最重要的是蕴涵规则：如果P和Q是两个命题，并且P蕴涵Q，那么如果P为真， Q也必定为真。由于每个数学命题都是由P（假设）和Q（结论）组成的蕴涵，因此这种逻辑规则允许人们建立“真理”的线性字符串：P意味着Q意味着R，等等。以下是两个例子：（a）如果m 2是奇数，则m也是奇数。（b）如果T 是平面上的三角形，并且欧几里得几何公理为真（尤其是平行公设），则内角和等于两个直角。

(1) The most important of these would be the rule of implication: if P and Q are two propositions, and P implies Q, then if P is true Q must also be true. Since every mathematical proposition is an implication consisting of a P (the hypothesis) and a Q (the conclusion) this logical rule allows one to build up linear strings of “truths”: P implies Q implies R, and so on. Here are two examples: (a) If m2 is an odd integer then m is also odd. (b) If T is a triangle in the plane and the axioms of Euclidean geometry are true (especially the parallel postulate) then the sum of the interior angles is equal to two right angles.

(2) 可以将蕴涵“ P蕴涵Q ”转换为（逻辑上）等价蕴涵“非 P蕴涵非 Q ”的逻辑规则，称为逆否命题。例如，上面的 (a) 将是“如果m 为偶数，则m 2 为偶数”。例如 (b)，如果T 的内角和不等于两个直角，那么欧几里得公理之一必定无效。

(2)The logical rule that enables you to turn an implication “P implies Q” into the (logically) equivalent implication “not P implies not Q,” called the contrapositive. For example (a) above this would be “if m is even then m2 is even.” For example (b), if the sum of the interior angles of T do not add up to two right angles then one of the axioms of Euclid must be invalid.

从逻辑上讲，一个陈述和它的反面陈述具有相同的真值状态。后者有时比前者更容易（直接）证明（如示例 a 所示），因此它们作为数学陈述（而不是纯逻辑陈述）的状态并不相同。

Logically a statement and its contrapositive formulation have the same truth status. The latter is sometimes easier to prove (directly) than the former (as in example a) so that their status as mathematical statements (as opposed to purely logical statements) is not identical.

(3) “反证法”：人们不假设P为真，而直接试图证明Q为真，而是假设P为真，但Q为假，并推断出其他一些众所周知的真实数学陈述（如1 ≠ 0）是矛盾的。希腊人喜欢这种证明方法，并用它来证明二的平方根是无理数，并且素数有无数个。

(3) “Proof by contradiction”: Instead of assuming P is true and directly trying to prove that Q is true, one assumes P is true but that Q is false and deduces that some other well-known, true mathematical statement, like 1≠0, is contradicted. The Greeks liked this method of proof and used it to show that the square root of two was irrational and that there are an infinite number of primes.

（1）、（2）和（3）是数学家的主要逻辑规则，但还有另外两个逻辑规则在数学中也很重要，但并不总是明确的：

(1), (2), and (3) are the main logical rules of the working mathematician but there are two other logical rules that are important in mathematics but are not always made explicit:

(4) “同一律”确保数学概念保持不变。（用 Gertrude Stein 的话来说，“玫瑰就是玫瑰就是玫瑰。”）因此，π总是指同一个常数，等边三角形总是有相同的定义。另一种说法是，（正式的）数学概念由其正式定义决定。“素数”始终是除了自身和 1 之外没有其他因数的整数。函数连续的含义完全由其定义所捕获——这是一个复杂的逻辑陈述，我在这里就不多说了。这种恒定性适用于理论数学和科学的元素，但不适用于它们的概念元素。正如我之前所讨论的，概念并不等同于其正式定义。概念会随着对它们的探索和理解而改变。在一段时间内（即当你在概念的定义可能与公认的范式或概念系统一样，看起来似乎已经固定下来，但在科学和数学中，一个众所周知的概念经常会被提出新的定义。这个新定义是以新的方式看待旧情况的结果。因此，概念发生了变化，或者更准确地说，我们与概念的关系发生了变化。

(4) The “law of identity” that ensures that mathematical concepts remain constant. (In Gertrude Stein’s phrase, “A rose is a rose is a rose.”) Thus π always refers to the same constant and an equilateral triangle always has the same definition. Anther way of saying this is that (formal) mathematical concepts are pinned down by their formal definitions. A “prime number” is always an integer with no divisors except itself and 1. What it means for a function to be continuous is totally captured by its definition—a complex logical statement that I will not bother with here. This constancy is true for the elements of theoretical mathematics and science but not for their conceptual elements. A concept is not identical to its formal definition as I discussed earlier. Concepts change as they are explored and understood. For a time (i.e. when you are working within an accepted paradigm or conceptual system) it may appear that they have been pinned down but very regularly in science and mathematics there will be a new definition that is proposed for a well-known concept. This new definition is the result of looking at the old situation in a new way. As a result the concept has changed or it might be more accurate to say that our relationship with the concept has changed.

(5) “不矛盾定律”规定，P 和非 P 不可能同时为真。例如，一个整数不可能既是偶数又是奇数，因为偶数意味着非奇数，反之亦然。请注意，这并不意味着P或非P必须为真，也不意味着两者之一必须可证明的更强有力的陈述。

(5) The “law of non-contradiction” which states that it is impossible for P and not P to be simultaneously true. For example, an integer cannot be both even and odd since even means non-odd and vice versa. Note that this does not mean that either P or not P must be true nor does it mean the stronger statement that one of the two must be provable.

规则 4 和规则 5 都不像看上去那么明显。如果现实是由过程而不是对象组成的，那么同一律就不是真的，而只是一种我们必须假设的假象，以便开始对世界进行任何智力或科学分析。另一方面，我们看到罗森伯格声称，创造过程中的一个关键步骤是否认规则 5 的有效性。同样真实的是，从发展和/或学习的角度来看，这些逻辑规则中的一些或全部都可能被打破。

Neither rule 4 nor rule 5 are as obvious as they seem. If reality is made up of processes and not objects then the law of identity is not true but merely an artifice that we must assume in order to get started with any intellectual or scientific analysis of the world. On the other hand we saw that Rothenberg claims that a crucial step in the creative process is denying the validity of rule 5.
