It is equally true that from the point of view of development and/or learning some or all of these logical rules may well be broken.

9.7.2基于深度思考的数学概念体系

9.7.2A Conceptual System for Mathematics Based on Deep Thinking

然而，逻辑在数学中的作用远远超出了数学家在教学和研究过程中所采用的逻辑规则。数学被视为一个庞大的概念系统，它已经将自己与逻辑、演绎结构联系起来。因此，数学家会告诉你她“只证明定理”，而事实上，她做的远不止这些。例如，她也是原创概念、结构和思想的创造者。因此，形式逻辑在数学中扮演着双重角色。在所谓的局部层面上，它是数学证明和理论中的一种语言和组织工具。从整体上看，它提供了许多人认为的整个学科的定义特征。因此，不可避免地我认为数学中存在重要的非逻辑元素，这一观点可能会引起一些人的争议。

However the role of logic in mathematics goes way beyond the logical rules that the working mathematician employs in the course of her teaching and research. Mathematics, when viewed as a vast conceptual system, has come to identify itself with its logical, deductive structure. Thus a mathematician will tell you that she “only proves theorems” when, in fact, she does a great deal more than that. For example, she also is the creator of original concepts, structures, and ideas. Thus formal logic has a double role in mathematics. At what one might call the local level it is a language and an organizational tool in the proofs and theories of mathematics. Globally it provides what many think of as the defining characteristic of the entire subject. Thus it is inevitable that my contention that there are important non-logical elements in mathematics will be controversial to some.

普通逻辑有其价值和局限性。它的作用是将理论或论证的要素结合在一起，形成一个线性、连贯的整体。当你在固定的范式或概念系统中操作时，这非常有用。事实上，使某事物成为范式或概念系统的主要因素恰恰是它形成了一个连贯的整体。正是这种连贯性赋予了稳定性，并使系统如此难以改变。它是如此有意义，以至于人们不愿意放弃它，甚至不愿意对其进行实质性的修改。由于数学以我上面提到的两种方式使用逻辑，因此它特别难以改变，这就是为什么事实上的概念系统在许多人看来是客观“真实的”的原因。

Ordinary logic has its value and its limitations. Its role is to tie together the elements of a theory or argument into one linear, coherent whole. This is wonderful when you are operating within a fixed paradigm or conceptual system. In fact the main factor that makes something into a paradigm or conceptual system is precisely that it forms a coherent whole. It is this coherence that imparts stability and makes the system so resistant to change. It makes so much sense that one resists giving it up or even modifying it in a substantial way. Because mathematics uses logic in the two ways that I mentioned above, it is especially resistant to change and is the reason why what is in fact a conceptual system appears to many to be objectively “true.”

这在一定程度上解释了数学在现代文化的许多方面所具有的影响力。因此，人们普遍倾向于错误地将数学模型与现实等同起来（至少在最近的金融危机中，这种大厦轰然倒塌之前是这样）。请记住，一个系统与其说是描述现实，不如说是创造现实，因此，对许多人来说，放弃这样一个系统，甚至承认它的局限性，都意味着迈向未知的可怕一步。例如，众所周知，有心理障碍的人往往不愿意放弃他们不正常的想法或行为，即使这些想法或行为显然会对他们造成伤害。听起来很矛盾，这些人不愿意放弃他们的问题，因为这对他们来说似乎是最真实的——他们认同的东西——没有它，他们就不知道自己是谁。他们的“问题”以与概念系统相同的方式发挥作用；有了它，事情可能会令人不快，但它们“有意义”。普通逻辑是将概念系统结合在一起的粘合剂，在数学中，这一点在极端程度上是正确的。

This explains to some degree the power that mathematics has assumed in many aspects of modern culture. Therefore there is a general tendency to mistakenly identify mathematical models with reality (at least until the edifice comes crashing down such as in the recent financial collapse). Remember that a system doesn’t describe reality so much as it creates reality so that giving up such a system or even admitting its limitations entails, for many people, a frightening step into the unknown. It is well known, for example, that people with psychological difficulties are often reluctant to give up their dysfunctional ideas or behavior even when these clearly do them harm. As paradoxical as it sounds such people are reluctant to let go of their problem because this is what seems most real to them—what they identify themselves with—and without it they would not know who they are. Their “problem” functions in the same way as a conceptual system; with it things may be unpleasant but they “make sense.” Ordinary logic is the glue that holds conceptual systems together in general and in mathematics this is true to an extreme degree.

对许多人来说，数学就是逻辑，逻辑就是真理。因此，数学和量化在我们的文化中扮演着特殊的角色。但其负面作用在于，数学与形式逻辑的结合所带来的连贯性和引人注目的本质，使得形式主义的数学概念体系特别僵化，难以改变。这反过来又使数学变得僵化。现代文化中那些以数学为模型的元素。本书试图通过强调非逻辑元素来打破这种僵化，这些非逻辑元素在数学大厦中很容易找到，但当前的概念体系或多或少使它们变得不可见。

For many people mathematics is logic and logic is truth. It follows that the role of mathematics and quantification in our culture is a privileged one. The negative side to this is that the very coherence and compelling nature of mathematics that comes from its identification with formal logic makes the formalist conceptual system for mathematics especially rigid and resistant to change. This in turn imparts rigidity to those elements of modern culture that use mathematics as a model. This book is an attempt to break down this rigidity by highlighting the non-logical elements, which can be easily found within the edifice of mathematics, but which the current conceptual system render more or less invisible.

对于每个概念系统来说，都会有这样一个时刻：系统被大量不符合旧范式的新现象和问题元素所淹没。近年来，数学的经典观点受到了技术和结果的挑战，这些技术和结果大多来自计算机的使用。旧数学观的连贯性崩溃的时刻即将到来，或者可能已经到来。即便如此，许多人仍会坚持旧观点的安全性，但不可避免地会有人愿意承认旧系统行不通，并开始寻找新的东西。本书试图预测数学新概念系统的元素。至少，一种看待数学的新方式将打破将数学与形式主义和逻辑等同起来的观念。

For every conceptual system there comes a time when the system is overwhelmed by a critical mass of new phenomena and problematic elements that do not fit within the old paradigm. In recent years the classical view of what mathematics is has been challenged by techniques and results that mostly arise from the use of the computer. The moment will come, or perhaps has come already, when the coherence of the old view of mathematics will break down. Even then many will hold on to the security of the old but inevitably there will be people who are prepared to admit that the old system does not work and who cast about for something new. This book is an attempt to anticipate elements of a new conceptual system for mathematics. At the very least a new way of looking at mathematics will entail breaking the identification of mathematics with formalism and logic.

任何创造性突破总是发生在人们有勇气打破他们用来建立现实的体系时，但在数学（以及程度较小的科学）的情况下，这种突破将比其他情况更加困难。这是因为逻辑论证对我们整个文化起着稳定作用，并且通过大量引入计算机及其带来的变化而具体化。

Any creative breakthrough always comes about when someone has the courage to break free from the system through which they establish what is real but in the case of mathematics (and science to a lesser extent) such a break will be even more difficult than it is in other situations. This is because logical argumentation plays a stabilizing role for our entire culture and has been reified through the massive introduction of computer and the changes that it brings in its wake.

数学新观的飞跃将不可避免地取决于对逻辑和非逻辑元素作用的重新评估。我们可能首先要简单地认识到非逻辑元素是存在的。它们是数学的一部分，而且一直是数学的一部分。例如，数学概念总是允许多种表示，因此通常是模棱两可的。这种模棱两可性是数学力量和灵活性的驱动力。在多种表示情况下出现的建设性模糊性存在于许多数学中。例如，每个同义反复定理，即每个形式为P当且仅当Q 的定理，都是模棱两可的，因为它表明一个数学元素可以用两个表示不同的方式，P和Q viii。因此，模糊性是数学理论结构中必不可少的元素。当然，它也存在于学习或创造数学的过程中，正如我多次指出的那样，它往往是正在发生的事情的本质。

The leap to a new view of mathematics will inevitably depend on reassessing the roles of logical and non-logical elements. We might begin with the simple realization that non-logical elements exist. They are, and have always been, a part of mathematics. For example, mathematical concepts always admit multiple representations and so are generally ambiguous. This kind of ambiguity is the motor behind the power and flexibility of mathematics. The constructive ambiguity present in situations of multiple representations is present in much of mathematics. For example, every tautological theorem, that is, every theorem of the form P if and only if Q, is ambiguous in the sense that it states that one element of mathematics can be represented in two different ways, P and Qviii. Thus ambiguity is an essential element in the theoretical structure of mathematics. Of course it is also present in the process of learning or creating mathematics where, as I have pointed out on numerous occasions, it is often the essence of what is going on.

接受这种非逻辑元素在数学局部结构中的普遍性应该会导致对数学整体性的重新评估。形式逻辑和非逻辑因素（如深度思考）的相对作用将被颠倒过来。深度思考是你思考或理解数学思想的方式；逻辑思考是你验证你的想法是否一致和连贯的方式。这样，深度思考将成为主要的，逻辑验证将被视为次要的。数学作为一个整体将被视为一种创造性的努力，这无疑是它，而不仅仅是一种纯逻辑的练习。正如形式主义将逻辑作为数学的决定性特征一样，深度思考可能会被视为一种新的和扩展的数学概念系统的决定性特征。

Accepting the ubiquity of such non-logical elements in the local structure of mathematics should lead to a reassessment of the global nature of mathematics. The relative roles of formal logic and non-logical factors like deep thinking would then be reversed. Deep thinking is how you think up or understand the ideas of mathematics; logical thinking is how you verify that your ideas are consistent and coherent. In this way deep thinking would be primary and logical verification would be seen as secondary. Mathematics as a whole would then come to be seen as the creative endeavor that it undoubtedly is and not just as an exercise in pure logic. Just as Formalism makes logic into the defining characteristic of mathematics, deep thinking might come to be seen as the defining characteristic of a new and expanded conceptual system for mathematics.

新事物是通过在一种尚无法连贯、更无法用逻辑形式捕捉的情境中使用思维的方式产生的。今天，尚无法以任何明确的方式设想“新”数学将会是什么。从形式主义或我们数学家用来向自己解释我们到底在做什么的正常概念系统的角度来看，我试图做的事情似乎是不可能的。如果放宽逻辑要求，对这些人来说，数学就不再是数学了。

The new is produced by a way of using the mind in a situation that cannot (yet) be made coherent much less captured in a logical form. Today what the “new” mathematics will be cannot yet be conceived in any definitive way. From the point of view of formalism or the normal conceptual system through which we mathematicians explain to ourselves just what it is that we do, what I am trying to do may seem to be impossible. Mathematics for these people would not be mathematics if the logical requirements were to be loosened.

另一方面，整本书都在描述产生深度思考的各种情况，而这正是我们今天在数学中遇到的情况。深度思考是数学的本质。它是一个明确的过程，是学习和创造的特征，但它的规则不是我们在学校学到的逻辑规则。然而，如果我们不至少暂时摆脱普通逻辑的束缚，我们就无法开始思考深度思考及其“过程逻辑”。同样，如果我们不摆脱将形式主义、形式逻辑和演绎系统视为数学定义特征的束缚，我们就无法想象当今数学的发展。

On the other hand this entire book has been describing the kinds of situations that produce deep thinking and this is the situation in which we find ourselves today in mathematics. Deep thinking is the essence of mathematics. It is a definite process that is characteristic of learning and creation but its rules are not the logical rules that we learned at school. However we cannot even get started with a consideration of deep thinking and its “process logic” without letting go, at least for a time, of the straightjacket of ordinary logic. In just the same way we cannot conceive of what mathematics has become today without getting out of the straightjacket of considering formalism, formal logic, and the deductive system as the defining characteristics of mathematics.

只有承认逻辑推理的局限性，人们才能接受更基本的创造性和发展过程。深度思考源于问题，涉及接受与“不知道”的黑暗相遇。它产生于不连续的时刻，而不是通过创建一个“逻辑”的情境模型，该模型将使人们能够用算法过程的清晰度取代创造性过程的紧张和不透明性。

Only by acknowledging the limitations of logical inference can one be receptive to more basic creative and developmental processes. Deep thinking arises out of the problematic and involves accepting the encounter with the darkness of “not knowing.” It comes into being in a moment of discontinuity and not by creating a “logical” model of the situation that will enable one to replace the tension and opaqueness of the creative process by the clarity of a process that is algorithmic.

正如哲学家汉娜·阿伦特ix所指出的，新思想的诞生并非源于操纵逻辑推理。当一个人“同时在头脑中持有相互矛盾的想法”时，他就会陷入一种两难境地——“事情就是这样，但不可能是这样。”面对这种困境，以这种方式与不可能的事情搏斗，会导致大脑变得活跃和兴奋，无法确定它所熟悉的任何可能性。另一方面，根据某些规则进行正式推理的大脑只会有最低限度的活跃。无论逻辑操纵多么复杂或微妙，它都不会像面对彻底改变信仰体系的需要那样挑战一个人。

As the philosopher Hannah Arendtix pointed out, the birth of a new idea does not come out of manipulating logical inferences. When one is “holding contradictory ideas simultaneously in the mind,” one is in a kind of double bind—“this is the way it is but it cannot be like this.” Facing this kind of dilemma, grappling with the impossible in this way, results in a mind that is active and aroused, a mind that is unable to settle on any of the possibilities that it is familiar with. On the other hand the mind that is spinning out formal inferences according to some set of rules is only minimally active. Logical manipulations no matter how complicated or subtle never challenge a person in the same way as confronting the need for a complete overhaul of one’s system of beliefs.

逻辑是当前数学概念系统的关键要素，但数学包含的内容远比当前概念系统允许我们看到和理解的要多得多。正如当今逻辑既以局部又以全局的方式发挥作用一样，新的数学概念系统将以两种方式使用深度思考。第一种方式是局部使用，作为学习和创造数学的关键要素。从全局来看，深度、创造性思维可能会被视为该学科的决定性特征，就像今天的逻辑一样。在进行这种根本性转变时，深度思考将以第三种方式使用，因为它是思维从一个概念系统转移到其后续系统的方式。旧系统形式主义将数学等同于形式逻辑。它的后续系统将基于一种以思想、创造过程和深度思考为中心的数学新思维方式。

Logic is the key element in the current conceptual system for mathematics but mathematics contains much more than the current conceptual system allows us to see and comprehend. Just as logic functions today in a way that is both local and global, a new conceptual system for mathematics would use deep thinking in two ways. The first way would be the local usage, as the key element in the learning and creating of mathematics. Globally, deep, creative thinking might come to be seen as a defining characteristic of the subject in the way that logic is today. In making this kind of fundamental transition deep thinking would be used in yet a third way since it is the way the mind is used in moving from one conceptual system to its successor. The old system, formalism, identifies mathematics with formal logic. Its successor will be based on a new way of thinking about mathematics centered on ideas, the creative process, and deep thinking.

9.8结论

9.8Conclusion

如果确实如庞加莱所说，没有一种数学不是认知的，而且这对我来说似乎是不言而喻的，那么就会产生许多重要的启示。所有这些都涉及到看穿传统上对数学的绝对客观性、确定性和精确性的迷雾。这些特征与其说是数学的内在部分，不如说是数学的当前概念系统。它们是数学在我们文化中扮演的角色的体现。科学研究​​论文通过统计测试来验证，政治通过民意调查来实施，商业和工业决策是通过创建和应用数学模型来做出的。当我们试图确定真理时，我们往往会求助于数学。

If it is indeed true that there is no mathematics that is not cognitive, as Poincaré stated, and which seems pretty self-evident to me, then there are plenty of important implications that follow. All of these involve seeing through the smoke screen of absolute objectivity, certainty, and precision through which mathematics is traditionally viewed. These characteristics are not so much an intrinsic part of mathematics as they are of the current conceptual system for mathematics. They are a manifestation of the role that mathematics has come to play in our culture. Research papers in science are validated by statistical tests, politics is conducted via public opinion polls, and decisions in business and industry are arrived at via the creation and the application of mathematical models. When we look to establish the truth we tend to reach for mathematics.

但变化和进化是存在的规则，数学也不例外。数学是一种创造性的努力，它植根于心理和社会现实。这似乎限制了数学，事实上也打破了数学与真理的统一。然而，从另一个角度看，数学揭示了一个更深层次、更重要的真理。数学展示了心灵与自然世界的统一——一个引人注目的事实是，数学心灵能够如此深入地洞察自然世界的结构，而自然世界通过数学世界也能够揭示心灵的属性（我将在下一章也是最后一章中讨论）。

But change and evolution are the rules of existence and mathematics is no exception to that rule. Mathematics is a creative endeavor that is grounded in psychological and social realities. This may seem to put limitations on mathematics and indeed it does break the identification of mathematics with truth. However mathematics, looked at in another way, reveals an even deeper and more vital truth. Mathematics demonstrates the unity of mind and the natural world—the remarkable fact that the mathematical mind is able to see so deeply into the structure of the natural world but also that the natural world through the world of mathematics is able to reveal the properties of the mind (as I shall discuss in the next and final chapter).

i Poincaré (1909) 被 Miller (1984) 引用。

i Poincaré (1909) quoted in Miller (1984).

ii著名数学家和形式主义的创始人大卫·希尔伯特。

ii The eminent mathematician and founder of Formalism, David Hilbert.

iii考虑一下 Borwein (2008) 等人对实验数学的倡导。

iii Consider the advocacy of experimental mathematics by people like Borwein (2008).

iv根据欧几里得的说法，“直线是一条在其自身上均匀分布点的线。”但要理解这个定义，人们必须知道什么是线。

iv According to Euclid, “A straight line is a line which lies evenly with the points on itself.” But one would have to know what a line is to understand this definition.

诉Kanigel (1991)。

v Kanigel (1991).

vi Hersh,（2014 年）。

vi Hersh, (2014).

vii另请参阅 Grosholz (2007)。

vii See also Grosholz (2007).

viii例如“一个数是有理数当且仅当它可以用有限小数或循环小数表示”这一定理将有理数放在两个语境中，即分数和实数。

viii e.g. The theorem “a number is rational if and only if it can be represented by a finite or repeating decimal” places the rational number in two contexts, namely, the fractions and the real numbers.

ix Arrendt (1966)。

ix Arrendt (1966).

第十章

Chapter 10

数学能教会我们什么关于心智的知识

What Mathematics Can Teach Us About the Mind

10.1简介：原始心灵

10.1Introduction: The Primordial Mind

让我们回到我在第五章中讨论过的阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦的短语“显露于世界的心灵” 。对爱因斯坦来说，这句话简洁地描述了他从一生对自然世界的冥想中学到的东西。世界不是随机事件的混乱集合。它是一个连贯的整体。它是有意义的。因为它以如此错综复杂和出乎意料的方式组合在一起，所以你不禁感觉到其中有智慧在起作用。这种智慧、这种连贯性就是我所说的“心灵”。对爱因斯坦来说，非凡之处在于这种智慧可以为人类所获取——对他来说。显露于世界的心灵与使任何概念系统变得生动的心灵即人类心灵同构。

Let us return to Albert Einstein’s phrase, “the mind that is revealed in the world” that I discussed in chapter five. For Einstein this phrase was a succinct description of what he had learned from his lifelong meditation on the natural world. The world is not a chaotic collection of random events. It is a coherent unity. It makes sense. Because it fits together in such an intricate and unexpected fashion you can’t help but feel that there is intelligence at work. This intelligence, this coherence, is what I mean by “mind.” And the extraordinary thing for Einstein was that this intelligence was accessible to humanity—to him. The mind that is revealed in the world is isomorphic to the mind that makes any conceptual system come alive, that is, the human mind.

谈论心灵是谈论深度思考的另一种方式。爱因斯坦在自然世界的运作中发现了心灵，但这一发现是他成功克服了当时的正常观点的结果。爱因斯坦的智慧在于他能够以一种全新的方式看待世界——创造一个全新的概念体系。这本书也是关于向新概念体系的过渡。每一个新的概念体系都与之前的概念不相容，这种不相容性往往通过一个简单的问题来揭示，例如，2 和 3 之间有多少个数字？在这种情况下，问题是“心灵是什么？”旧的答案是心灵来自复杂的神经元排列或可能是计算机电路。但还有另一个可能的答案，那就是心灵是原始的——它不必从其他任何东西中产生。从我们的传统观点来看，这种说法完全没有意义。如果它有意义，世界将会发生巨大的变化。发展思维、学习思维和创造思维都是同一基本过程——深度思考的变体。

Speaking about mind is another way of speaking about deep thinking. Mind was revealed to Einstein in the functioning of the natural world but that revelation arose as a result of his success in overcoming the normal point of view of his time. Einstein’s intelligence lay in his ability to look at the world in a radically new way—to create a radically new conceptual system. This book is also about making a transition to a new conceptual system. Every new conceptual system is incompatible with what went before and this incompatibility is often revealed by a simple question, for example, how many numbers are there between 2 and 3? In this case the question is, “What is Mind?” The old answer is that mind comes out of a complex arrangement of neurons or possibly of computer circuits. But there is another answer that is possible and it is that mind is primordial—it does not have to come out of anything else. This statement makes absolutely no sense from our conventional point of view. If and when it comes to make sense the world will have changed in a dramatic way. The mind of development, the mind of learning, and the mind of creating are all variants on the same basic process—deep thinking.

我所描述的过程的核心可以用符号 CS 1 → CS 2来表示，即从基础概念系统、发展阶段、范式、思想或思想体系到后续系统的转变。在本章中，我将首先回顾我在第一章末尾列出的一些深度思考的特征，然后继续从我所描述的方式看待事物中得出一些推论。这些结论构成了“数学可以告诉我们关于思维的知识”。

The core of the process that I have been describing was represented symbolically as CS1 → CS2, the movement from a base conceptual system, developmental stage, paradigm, idea, or system of ideas to a successor system. In this chapter I shall begin by revisiting some of characteristics of deep thinking that I first listed at the end of the first chapter and then proceed to make some inferences that can be drawn from looking at things in the manner that I have described. These conclusions make up “what mathematics can tell us about the mind.”

10.2心智是自然的

10.2Mind is Natural

“心智是自然的”，意味着深度思考的能力始终存在，尽管它常常无法实现。深度思考的潜力始终存在。因此，心智与自然世界密不可分。它既体现在物理和生物世界的进化中，也体现在学习、发展和创造行为中。

“Mind is natural,” means that the capacity for deep thinking is always present even though it may often be inaccessible. The potential for deep thinking always exists. Thus mind is not separate from the natural world. It manifests itself both in the evolution of the physical and biological world as well as in learning, development, and acts of creativity.

心灵的原始本质意味着，没有任何知识可以独立于概念系统。心灵并非在某一时刻诞生，因此它永远不是一片空白；发展和进化总是从某个地方开始。

The primordial nature of the mind means, in particular, that there is no knowledge that is independent of a conceptual system. Mind does not come into existence at a certain moment so it is never a blank slate; development and evolution always start somewhere.

CS 1 → CS 2的运动是自由的。回想起来，CS 2似乎是不可避免的，但从 CS 1的角度来看，CS 2 的出现是一种先验无法预测的启示。这就是为什么创造力往往包含偶然的元素，它似乎“不知从何而来”，当然，在旧系统中无处不在。它令人震惊，并重新定义了情况，但事后它可能看起来完全自然，也就是说，简单甚至显而易见。

The movement CS1 → CS2 is free. In retrospect CS2 may seem inevitable but from the point of view of CS1, CS2 arrives on the scene as a revelation that was unpredictable a priori. That is why creativity often contains elements of serendipity, which seems to come out of “nowhere,” that is, of course, nowhere within the old system. It is shocking and reframes the situation, And yet after the fact it may appear completely natural, that is, simple and even obvious.

10.3思维是离散的

10.3Mind is Discrete

心智是离散的，也就是说，CS 1 → CS 2 的运动是不连续的。这意味着变化或洞察力是突然发生的。心智以可以比喻为“光的火花”的形式显露出来。这是创造过程的一部分，无论是在发展、范式变化，还是在进化变化中。它并不适用于通常包含在“学习”标题下的所有事物，但它是某种学习的重要组成部分——我倾向于称之为“真实学习”，尤其是概念学习。如果没有发生这种不连续性，那么任何创造性的发生都是值得怀疑的。教育，真正的教育，就是在学生身上引发这种不连续的变化。因此，学习和发展分为“阶段”，每个阶段都是平衡状态，因此（相对）稳定。科学范式和进化变化也是如此。

Mind is discrete, that is, the movement CS1 → CS2 is discontinuous. This means that the change or insight happens suddenly. Mind is revealed in what could metaphorically be called “sparks of light.” This is a part of the creative process whether in development, paradigm change, and even in evolutionary change. It is not true for everything that is usually included under the rubric of “learning,” but is an essential part of a certain kind of learning—what I am tempted to call “authentic learning” and, in particular, of conceptual learning. If this discontinuity does not happen then it is doubtful that anything creative has occurred. Education, real education, is about inducing such discontinuous changes in the student. It follows that learning and development come in “stages” each of which is an equilibrium state and thus (relatively) stable. This is also true for scientific paradigms and for evolutionary changes.

10.4进入自然心灵是困难的

10.4Accessing the Natural Mind is Difficult

CS 1 → CS 2的运动之所以困难，是因为它取决于能否摆脱习惯性思维模式的惯性。人们倾向于坚持过去或多或少行之有效的方法。

The movement CS1 → CS2 is difficult because it depends on being able to break free of the inertia of one’s habitual thought patterns. There is a tendency to cling to the security of what has worked, more or less well, in the past.

说它困难，是因为它需要跳转到一个新的视角。这种困难是所有讨论过的变化的内在组成部分。发展和进化变化也正是如此“困难”。前者显而易见，例如，当你看到一个婴儿挣扎着站起来或迈出第一步时。后者源于进化必然涉及适应不断变化的条件的斗争这一观点。在这种情况下，停滞不前不是一种选择——一个人必须适应或灭亡。我认为，所有生命都涉及这样的斗争，而停滞的概念，即斗争结束、我​​们可以休息的时间，只是一种假象。另一种说法是“生命是动态的，宇宙本身也是动态的。”或者可以说“生活是艰难的”。唯一的选择是接受甚至享受这种困难，还是抵制它，让事情变得更加困难。

It is difficult because it involves a leap to a new point of view. This difficulty is an intrinsic part of all the varieties of change that have been discussed. Development and evolutionary change are also “hard” in this way. The former is evident, for example, when you see a baby struggle to stand or take her first steps. The latter follows from the idea that evolution necessarily involves a struggle to adapt to changing conditions. In such situations stasis is not an option—one must adapt or perish. It occurs to me that all of life involves such a struggle and that the notion of stasis, a time when the struggle is over and we can rest, is merely an illusion. Another way of putting this is that “life is dynamic, the universe itself is dynamic.” Or else one could say that “life is difficult.” The only choice is whether to accept and perhaps even enjoy this difficulty or to resist it and make things even more difficult.

10.4.1深度思考怎么会既自然又困难呢？

10.4.1How Can Deep Thinking be Natural and Difficult at the Same Time?

回想一下，创造力（在第五章中）通常涉及同时在头脑中持有两种相互矛盾的想法。这本书也是由两种相互矛盾的想法产生的。这些想法是：（1）深度思考是自然的，（2）深度思考是困难的。我在这本书中指出的新视角直接来自于面对和解决这个僵局。某件事怎么可能同时是自然的和困难的呢？从正常的角度来看，自然与我所描述的那种困难是不相容的。然而，还有另一种视角，我们看到同一种情况既自然又困难。我们可以说，从灯笼意识、综合思维和右半球的角度来看，深度思考是自然的。从手电筒意识、分析思维和左半球的角度来看，深度思考非常困难，甚至是不可能的。

Recall that creativity (in chapter five) often involved holding two contradictory ides in the mind at the same time. This book as well is generated by two contradictory ideas. These ideas are: (1) deep thinking is natural and (2) deep thinking is difficult. The new perspective that I am pointing to in this book comes directly from confronting and resolving this impasse. How can something be natural and difficult at the same time? From the normal perspective being natural is incompatible with the kind of difficulty I have been describing. Yet there is another perspective where we come to see that the very same situation can be both natural and difficult. We could say that deep thinking is natural from the perspective of lantern consciousness, synthetic thought, and the right hemisphere. It is very difficult and even impossible from the perspective of flashlight consciousness, analytic thought, and the left hemisphere.

个人的思想往往无法自由发挥创造力，因为它被熟悉的习惯模式和对未知的恐惧所阻碍和遮蔽。自然的思想是自由的，但自由可能令人恐惧，因为它意味着失去安全感。正如伦纳德·科恩在歌曲《Closing Time》中所说， “它看起来像自由，但感觉像死亡。”如果可以选择，许多人会选择安全而不是自由。自由是可取的，但并不容易。有人说，自由的代价在于永远保持警惕。所需的警惕包括抵制回到旧思维习惯的倾向，即那些已经失去用处的概念系统。

The mind of the individual is often not freely creative because it is blocked and obscured by clinging to familiar habit patterns and fear of the unknown. The natural mind is free but freedom can be frightening because it entails the loss of security. As Leonard Cohen says in the song Closing Time, “it looks like freedom but it feels like death.” Given the choice many people would choose security over freedom. Freedom is desirable but it is not easy. The cost of freedom, it has been said, lies in eternal vigilance. The vigilance that is required involves resisting the tendency to fall back into old habits of thought, that is, conceptual systems that have outlived their usefulness.

如果说深层思考的坏消息在于其难度，那么好消息则是每个人都有可能进行深层思考。它存在于思维的深层。但如果我们希望将这些深层思考带入意识，就必须非常努力并克服大量阻力。这是一项艰苦的工作，但它是一种不同寻常的工作，因为它涉及消除我们在头脑中建立的障碍，这些障碍阻碍我们活在当下，并意识到什么是真实的和即时的。逻辑无法打破这些障碍；非逻辑手段是必要的。

If the bad news lies in its difficulty, the good news is that deep thinking is potentially accessible to everyone. It resides in the deeper layers of the mind. But we must work very hard and overcome a good deal of resistance if we desire to bring these deeper layers up to consciousness. This is hard work but it is an unusual kind of work for it involves undoing barriers that we have erected in our minds that prevent us from living in the present and being aware of what is real and immediate. Logic will not break down these barriers; non-logical means are necessary.

10.5分析思维是心智的模拟

10.5Analytic Thought is a Simulation of Mind

分析思维不是一种原始现象。它不是心智，而是心智的模拟。持续的变化涉及在操作概念系统内进行计算，从而探索一个人的概念系统或范式。持续的劳动构成了科学和学习中的绝大部分工作。这种工作不可避免地会产生问题因素，最终使旧局面无法维持。但这种工作并不包含深度思考所特有的那种困难。

Analytic thought is not a primary phenomena. It is not mind but a simulation of mind. Continuous change involves making computations within the operative conceptual system and thereby exploring one’s conceptual system or paradigm. It is continuous labor that makes up the vast majority of work in science and in learning. Inevitably this work gives rise to the problematic elements which ultimately make the old situation untenable. But such work does not contain the kind of difficulty that is characteristic of deep thinking.

10.6所有系统都有极限

10.6All Systems Have Limits

思维无法包含在任何一个概念系统中，也没有内在的限制。所有系统都有限制。概念系统即使本质上是无限的，也不可避免地有限制和不完整。我们通过操作概念系统看到的现实必然是不完整的。还有一个更基本的现实，如果你愿意的话可以称为“潜在概念化”，它最终会显现出来。它是如何显现的？在概念现实中总是出现的矛盾和不一致性、模糊性和悖论中。这是我们可以从哥德尔的不完备性结果中得出的推论，也可以从现代数学和科学的一系列结果中得出的推论。这就是我在上一本书中所说的“盲点” 。

Mind cannot be contained in any one conceptual system and has no intrinsic limits. All systems have limits. Conceptual systems even if they are essentially infinite are inevitably limited and incomplete. The reality, which we identify with what we see through our operative conceptual system, is inevitably incomplete. There is a more basic reality, the “potentially conceptualized,” if you will, that shows up eventually. How does it show up? In the contradictions and inconsistencies, the ambiguities and paradoxes that always arise within the conceptual reality. This is the kind of inference that we can draw from the incompleteness results of Gödel, for example, but also from a whole series of results in modern mathematics and science. It is what I called the “Blind Spot” in a previous booki.

10.7推理和逻辑推理的局限性

10.7Reasoning and the Limits To Logical Inference

有些人认为，我们可以通过构建某种超越所有系统的超级系统（逻辑推理或算法思维、万物理论或超级计算机）来摆脱这些限制。这是一个白日梦。逻辑并不存在于概念系统之外；它本身就是一个概念系统。

Some people believe that we can escape from these limitations through the construction of some kind of super system—logical inference or algorithmic thinking, a theory of everything, or a super computer—that transcends all systems. This is a pipe dream. Logic does not stand outside of conceptual systems; it is itself a conceptual system.

逻辑往往使思维僵化。一个人被自己建立的结构的坚固性所迷惑。结果可能是一种倾向合理化不一致或问题，甚至否认它们的存在。我在关于半球分化的章节中用逻辑推理讨论了这个问题——左半球看不到不符合其运作组织方案的元素。逻辑是左半球组织世界的方式。如果我们想学习或发挥创造力，我们必须给右半球一些空间，这涉及打破我们为自己创造的完美而美丽的逻辑陷阱。

Logic tends to cause the mind to freeze up. One is mesmerized by the solidity of the structure that one has erected. The result can be a tendency to rationalize inconsistencies or problems or even to deny their existence at all. I discussed this problem with logical inference in the chapter about hemispheric differentiation—the left hemisphere does not see elements that do not fit in with its operative organizational scheme. Logic is the left hemisphere’s way of organizing the world. If we want to learn or to be creative we must give the right hemisphere some space and this involves breaking down the perfect and beautiful logical trap that we have created for ourselves.

区分形式逻辑和更一般的推理过程很有用。推理似乎非常基础，不仅限于左脑或成人。婴儿积极地尝试理解，即推理他们的世界。推理可以定义为一种使用思维获取有关世界的客观信息的方式。形式逻辑或命题演算仅仅是更基本推理的某些属性的抽象；它并没有“捕捉”所有可能的推理方式。事实上，我在书中的各个地方都提到过，我所说的“创造性或发展性逻辑”是一种有效的推理方式，它涉及表面上非逻辑元素的有效使用。这种推理还涉及确定什么是客观有效的。然而，它不是算法，因此与那些将思维简化为可编程的尝试背道而驰。发现和发展是客观现象，但它们不是算法。

It is useful to distinguish between formal logic and the more general process of reasoning. Reasoning seems to be very basic and not just restricted to the left hemisphere nor to adults. Babies actively try to make sense, that is, reason, about their world. Reason might be defined as a way of using the mind to get objective information about the world. Formal logic, or the propositional calculus, is merely the abstraction of certain properties of more basic reasoning; it does not “capture” all possible ways of reasoning. In fact I have suggested at various places in the book that what I called “creative or developmental logic,” which involves the productive use of ostensibly non-logical elements, is a valid way of reasoning. This kind of reasoning also concerns itself with establishing what is objectively valid. It is however not algorithmic and thus flies in the face of those attempts to reduce thinking to what is programmable. Discovery and development are objective phenomena but they are not algorithmic.

10.8当系统崩溃时

10.8When Systems Break Down

特别关注既有系统崩溃的情况是明智的。由于现行系统倾向于完全定义给定情况的感知现实，因此必须打破对现状的执着，才能出现新的事物。这并不是说最初的系统是错误的，也不是说当它被另一个系统取代时会被否定或消失。即使在人们转向后继系统之后，原有的体制仍然存在，并在适当的情况下继续运作。变化的是，原有体制的束缚被打破了。人们不再将其与整体局势等同起来。

It would be wise to pay special attention to those situations in which established systems break down. Because of the tendency for the operative system to completely define the perceived reality of the given situation, the obsessive attachment to the status quo must be broken down before something new can appear. It is not that the initial system is wrong or that it will be negated or disappear when it is replaced by another system. Even after one has moved on to the successor system, the original system will still be around and will continue to operate in appropriate circumstances. The change is that the hold of the original system is broken. One no longer identifies it with the total situation.

我们打破 CS 1霸权的方法是接受并忍受其存在的问题。五比三的比例虽然不能算作一个数字，但如果你以某种方式思考它并进行某种计算，它似乎会以数字的方式运行。处理这种矛盾的情况；克制自己不去立即拒绝它，最终就会迎来一个创造性的时刻，一种新的数字就会出现。

The way we break down the hegemony of CS1 is by accepting and living with its problematic elements. The ratio of five to three cannot be a number yet if you think of it in a certain way and perform certain kinds of calculations it appears to behave in ways that numbers behave. Working with this contradictory situation; refraining from rejecting it out of hand, one eventually arrives at a creative moment in which a new kind of number sees the light.

10.9引导

10.9Bootstrapping

开发和范式转变中的引导法是为了解释深度思考的神秘性，几乎是奇迹般的本质。我们如何学习是一个与“生命是如何开始的？”同样深刻的问题。我们如何获得新事物，也就是说，新层次的组织是如何从更基本的事物中出现的？它总是具有不可预测性。那些声称可以根据某种理论预测它的人不可避免地会事与愿违。假设你现在知道了 B，你能编造一些故事来“解释”从 A 到 B 的移动吗？这就像事后预测股市崩盘一样——你想出了一些“解释”，但下一次崩盘发生的原因却完全不同。

Bootstrapping in development and paradigm change is an attempt to account for the mysterious, almost miraculous, nature of deep thinking. How we learn is a question that is every bit as profound as the question, “How did life begin?” How do we get something new, that is, how does a new level of organization appear out of something more elementary? It always has an element of unpredictability. Those who claim that they can predict it on the basis of some theory are inevitably working backswords. Given that you now know B can you make up some story that “explains” the movement from A to B. It is like predicting a stock market crash after the fact—you come up with some “explanation” but next time the crash happens for entirely different reasons.

引导式发展理论作为发展解释的优势在于它同时包含了连续和非连续元素——旧系统内的计算以及新系统的突然出现。然而，解释这一运动有其局限性，有时“引导式发展”在我看来就像是试图超越这些限制，解释发展而不为不连续性留下空间——事实上，旧系统完全被新系统超越。

The strength of bootstrapping as an explanation for development is that it incorporates both continuous and discontinuous elements—the computations within the old system as well as the sudden emergence of the new system. However explaining this movement has its limits and sometimes “bootstrapping” feels to me like an attempt to go beyond these limits and explain development without leaving room for the discontinuity—the fact that the old system is completely transcended by the new.

10.10学习与发展的“弊端”

10.10The “Disadvantages”· of Learning and Development

发展与学习之间存在着一种隐含的权衡。例如，谁对科学及其所引发的技术发展没有过这种感觉？从某种意义上说，它令人兴奋、美妙；从另一种意义上说，它有各种有害的副作用，从过度拥挤和污染到个人意义感和幸福感的消退。我认为，这种权衡隐含在主要的发展范式 CS 1 → CS 2中。

There is a trade off that is implicit in development and learning. Who has not had this feeling, for example, about science and the technological developments that have arisen in its wake? In one sense it is exciting and wonderful; in another there are all kind of noxious side effects from overcrowding and pollution to the erosion of the individual’s sense of personal meaning and happiness. My suggestion is that this trade-off is implicit in the primary developmental paradigm CS1 → CS2.

我再次借助数学来提供一些相对简单的例子。再考虑从计数数字向上移动到我讨论过的更复杂、更抽象的数字系统。我们看到，每个数字系统都是对“什么是数字？”这个问题的回答。矛盾的是，尽管每个级别似乎都是前一个级别引入的数字的抽象和概括，但从另一个角度来看，每个级别都会逐步缩小焦点。沿途的第一步是最引人注目的，因为它将数字变成了或多或少可以通过分析、集中意识明确定义和管理的东西。在此之前，它更加神秘和短暂——你知道它是重要的东西，但你不能确切地说它是什么。在这个阶段，数字更像是一种感觉或直觉，而不是一个具体的对象。每一个向明确方向发展的举动都倾向于隐藏隐含的意义；外在的意义隐藏了内涵的意义，抽象隐藏了具体的意义。潜在的范围总是比实际的要大。

Again I look to mathematics to provide some relatively simple examples. Consider again moving from the counting numbers up the hierarchy to the more complex and abstract numbers systems that I have discussed. We saw that each number system is an answer to the question, “What is (a) number?” Paradoxically, even though each level appears to be an abstraction and generalization of the kind of number introduced at the previous level, in another way each level successively narrows the focus. The first step along the way is the most dramatic for it makes number into something that is more or less well defined and manageable by analytic, focused consciousness. Before this it is much more mysterious and fleeting—you know it is something significant but you can’t quite say what it is. At this stage number is more of a sense or intuition than it is a concrete object. Every movement towards what is explicit tends to hide the implicit; the denoted meaning hides the connoted meaning, the abstract hides the concrete. The potential is always larger in scope than the actual.

以从有理数到实数的转变为例。这里的得失是惊人的。有理数更具体，更直接。实数的发明是一项令人难以置信的成就，但实数非常抽象、复杂，而且最终远离我们的直接经验。所以我们得到了一些东西，但也失去了一些东西。

Take the move from the rational numbers to the real numbers. Here the gain and loss are striking. The rational numbers are more concrete, more immediate. The invention of the real numbers is an incredible accomplishment but real numbers are very abstract, complex, and ultimately remote from our immediate experience. So we gain something but we lose something as well.

正如我们在戈普尼克和麦吉尔克里斯特的著作中所看到的，这种权衡在儿童发展中显而易见。我们失去了灯笼意识和右半球的即时性。哀悼童年的纯真、创造力和活力的丧失几乎是陈词滥调。这既是个人发展的问题，也是社会发展。在某种程度上，教育的最终任务是找到让学生保持创造力的方法，这是每个人与生俱来的权利。创造性过程减轻了我所说的权衡。某种教育会扼杀创造力，扼杀学生的学习体验。创造性教育是一个不断重生的过程，是一个让学习变得丰富和令人兴奋的过程。

This trade-off is evident in child development as we saw in the writings of Gopnik and McGilchrist. We lose touch with lantern awareness and the immediacy of the right hemisphere. It is almost a cliché to mourn the loss of the innocence, creativity, and vitality of childhood. This is at once a matter of individual development and of social development. In a way the ultimate task of education is to find ways to keep students in touch with the creativity that is every one’s birthright. The creative process mitigates the trade-off that I spoke of. A certain kind of education kills creativity and deadens students’ learning experience. Creative education is a continual process of rebirth, of coming alive to the richness and excitement of learning.

10.11智力

10.11Intelligence

智力是心智的本质。它是深思熟虑的过程，遵循我上面概述的原则。智力将涉及创造力，反过来说，所有创造性活动都是智力的运用。请注意，智力将是一个过程——你所做的事情，而不是你是谁或你拥有的东西。当然，这意味着智力并不是在人类发展出一定脑容量或复杂性时才进入宇宙的。事实上，现在许多人认为智力和意识是人类与动物，甚至与植物等没有大脑的生物共享的东西。[Chamovitz，第 167 页和第 170 页]。这更意味着大脑的进化本身就是智力的结果。从这个观点来看，智力是第一位的。

Intelligence is the essence of mind. It is the process of deep thinking and follows the principles that I have outlined above. Intelligence would then involve creativity and conversely all creative activity would be an exercise of intelligence. Notice that intelligence would then be a process—something that you do not something that you are or something that you have. Of course this would imply that intelligence didn’t come into the universe at the moment that human beings developed a certain brain size or complexity. And, indeed, many people now see intelligence and awareness as something that human beings share with animals and, perhaps, even with things like plants, which, of course, do not have brains. [Chamovitz, pages 167 and 170]. It would rather mean that the evolution of the brain was itself the result of intelligence. Intelligence, in this view, comes first.

这导致了一种哲学，即创造力和智慧是宇宙的固有属性，就像学习潜能是儿童的固有属性一样。创造性智慧并非是特殊个体的专利，而是创造性天才具有非凡的能力，他们能够向自然和自身中的创造力敞开心扉。想象我们生活在这样一个“创造性的宇宙”中，真是令人兴奋。在社会似乎被其面临的巨大挑战压垮的时候，创造性智慧是我们寻找迫切需要的解决方案的地方，也是唯一的场所。在我看来，我们所需要的就在我们身边。我们需要做的是接受现代社会和文化中存在的深刻矛盾，但不要向绝望屈服。通过这样做这样我们就能向我们周围的建设性和创造性力量敞开心扉。

This leads to a certain kind of philosophy, namely, that creativity and intelligence are built into the universe in the same way that the potential for learning is built into children. Creative intelligence is not something that is reserved for exceptional individuals but rather creative geniuses are exceptional in their ability to open themselves up to the creative forces in nature and within themselves. It is very exciting to imagine that we live in such a “creative universe.” At a time when society seems to be overwhelmed by the enormity of the challenges it faces creative intelligence is the place, the only place, that we can look for the solutions we so desperately require. In my view what we need is there all around us. What we need to do is to accept the deep contradictions that exist within modern societies and cultures but not give in to despair. By doing this we open ourselves up to the constructive and creative forces that surround us.

10.12进化

10.12Evolution

我在一开始就提到，想到其他自然过程也遵循我在本书中阐明的模式——创造性学习和发展的过程，真是令人兴奋。在进化论中，我们也看到冲突、斗争和不连续的变化。我们还看到暂时的平衡被打破，然后在另一个层面上重新建立。从最基本的意义上讲，进化就是学会适应和在特定的外部环境中茁壮成长。它是一种普遍的学习形式，因此它遵循与一般的发展和学习相同的原则是很自然的。这意味着进化过程本身就是一种创造性的发展形式。

I mentioned at the outset that it is very exciting to think that other natural processes follow the pattern that I have elucidated in this book—the process of creative learning and development. In the theory of evolution we also see conflict, struggle, and discontinuous change. We also see temporary equilibriums that break down and are reestablished at another level. In a very basic sense evolution is learning to adapt to and thrive in a given external environment. It is a generalized form of learning and so it is natural that it obeys the same principles as development and learning in general. The implication is that the evolutionary process is itself a form of creative development.

10.13为什么？

10.13Why?

如果我所假设的过程确实发生了，那么自然而然的问题是“为什么会发生？”这是更基本的原因吗？我们研究的概念系统是为了应对不和谐而发展起来的。然而，除了解决问题的需要之外，可能还有另一个因素。有人说，创造力本身就是回报。学习和发展本身就带有内在的满足感。当婴儿迈出第一步时，她对自己有多么满意！因此，我们被克服不和谐的需要所推动，但我们被对某种可以用统一、和谐和连贯性来描述的东西的需求所推动。我们可以在我描述的所有情况下辨别出一种建立复杂统一的运动。婴儿统一其世界元素以及科学家或数学家创造统一人类思想和经验的广阔领域的理论结构的背后，都有一种普遍的学习和理解需求。

If the process that I am positing does occur then the natural question to ask is, “Why does it happen?” Is it the result of something more basic? The conceptual systems we have studied developed as a response to the dissonant. However there may be another factor in addition to the need to resolve the problematic. Creativity is its own reward, it has been said. Learning and development carry with them their own intrinsic satisfaction. When a baby takes it first steps how pleased she is with herself! So we are pushed from behind by the need to overcome dissonance but we are pulled forward by our need for something that could be described by the words unity, harmony, and coherence. We can discern in all of the situations that I have described a movement towards the establishment of complex unities. A generalized need to learn and to understand stands behind both the baby’s unification of the elements of their world and the scientists’ or mathematicians’ creation of theoretical structures that unify vast areas of human thought and experience.

10.14正确的教育方法

10.14The Correct Approach to Education

我一直在阐述这样一种世界观：创造性学习是核心和基础。无论怎样强调其重要性都不为过。我们作为一个社会和文化的存在，取决于能否培养出能够在不断变化的环境中茁壮成长的公民。这是当今技术环境的挑战。我们绝不能忘记，未来的公民是在今天的学校中培养出来的。他们接受的是什么样的教育？我担心，这种教育往往是针对昨天的问题的。他们是否具备应对明天的问题、在缺乏重要平衡期的情况下生活的问题的能力？

I have been presenting a view of the world in which creative learning is central and basic. It is impossible to overstate its importance. Our very existence as a society and culture depends on the production of citizens who can thrive in an environment of continual change. This is the challenge of the present technological environment. We must never forget that the citizens of tomorrow are being produced in the schools of today. What kind of education are they receiving? Often, I’m afraid, it is an education for the problems of yesterday. Are they being equipped to face the problems of tomorrow, the problems of living in the absence of significant periods of equilibrium?

最好的教育是引导人们过上富有成效和创造性的生活。你学习什么科目并不重要；你学到的重要东西超越了特定的科目。然而，我认为数学是一门特别适合从创造性的角度来教授的学科。这很讽刺，因为数学往往是由那些本身就教得不好的老师教得不好的。大多数人甚至无法想象从创造性的角度学习数学意味着什么，因此只能满足于更少的东西。数学在很多方面都是课程中最困难和最成问题的领域，因此，关于教育本质的斗争最有意义的地方就在这里。

At its best education is an introduction to the practice of living a productive and creative life. It doesn’t matter what subject you study; the important things that you learn transcend the particular subject. However I would maintain that mathematics is a subject particularly well suited to being taught from a creative perspective. This is ironic because mathematics is often badly taught by teachers who themselves were badly taught. Most people cannot even imagine what it would mean to study mathematics from a creative perspective and so settle for much less. Mathematics is in many ways the most difficult and problematic area of the curriculum and so it is there that the battle for the nature of education could most usefully be fought.

从概念发展和创造性学习的角度来看待教育似乎不切实际。以这种方式改变我们的态度确实需要彻底的改变，但风险也同样巨大。我们是否想培养出这样的公民：他们是一台非人性化机器上的齿轮，被无休止的电子产品和娱乐所吸引？还是我们应该把自己视为建设性和创造性智慧的表现，从而将我们的生活视为有意义、连贯、充满活力和目标的生活？

It may seem that the idea of approaching education from the point of view of conceptual development and creative learning is pie in the sky. Changing our attitudes in this way would indeed involve radical change but the stakes are commensurably enormous. Do we want to produce citizens who are cogs in a depersonalized machine and endlessly diverted by an endless stream of gadgets and entertainment? Or shall we experience ourselves as the expression of a constructive and creative intelligence and therefore see our lives as meaningful and coherent, filled with energy and purpose?

i Byers（2011）。

i Byers (2011).
